webTitle: At the point of no return

fields.headline: At the point of no return
fields.standfirst: David Lacey  says Arsenal and Leeds are England's weakest links
fields.trailText: David Lacey welcomes the return of the competition, but points to Arsenal and Leeds as England's weakest links.
fields.body:
Time may heal wounds but it can also dissipate dreams. Ten weeks ago it was possible to believe that this season's European Cup final might be contested by two English teams. Now England would be grateful to get two into the Champions League quarter-finals.

Leeds United were the heroes of the games played before the tournament went into hibernation. Against all odds David O'Leary's side bearded and beat Lazio's Roman lions in their own arena, thereby hastening the arrival of Sven-Goran Eriksson as England's coach.

On the same night Arsenal surrendered a two-goal lead to Bayern Munich to be held 2-2 at Highbury, and the following evening Manchester United savoured their plum of a second-round draw with an easy 2-0 win away at Sturm Graz.

So after two matches in the second phase Manchester United have taken an early command of Group A, Leeds, with Anderlecht, are tucked in behind Real Madrid in Group D, and Arsenal are last in Group C.

From an English point of view the next 72 hours are unlikely to bring a dramatic improvement, quite the reverse in fact.

Take tomorrow evening. Arsenal, whose away form this season has been patchy at best, face Lyon in the Gerland stadium needing a win but knowing they will be hard pressed to scrape a draw.

The French side have lost once in 16 matches and, despite qualifying from the first round with three defeats, they have the knack of winning essential games, witness the 3-0 win over Spartak Moscow after losing 1-0 away at Bayern.

Lyon will be looking to the goalscoring potential of Steve Marlet and Sonny Anderson in their pursuit of a quarter-final place. Arsenal, having already conceded six goals in the second phase, must reacquire their better defensive habits if Group C is not to become a triangular tournament between Lyon, Bayern and Spartak.

Since Leeds beat Lazio the season at Elland Road has spawned five wins and four defeats in the Premiership and an early departure from the FA Cup. With scant chance of finishing in the top three, O'Leary knows that his sole chance of appearing in next season's Champions League lies in winning it this time, an even more remote hope.

Still, Leeds have so far confounded logic in their more difficult European encounters, and Anderlecht lost 5-1 at Old Trafford in the first phase and 4-1 to Real in the second. But, like Leeds, they have defeated Lazio 1-0 and will come to Elland Road backed by a run of nine successive victories in Belgium.

Leeds are still producing fluent football, but only spasmodically. The youthful sheen is wearing off O'Leary's side and having two of your most important players standing trial for assault is not the ideal way to resume operations in the Champions League.

If Leeds can win tonight they will make a strong case for a place in the last eight, but with their next two matches away to Anderlecht and Real they cannot afford to drop more points at home.

Compared with Arsenal and Leeds the prospects for Manchester United appear serene. With maximum points so far from the second phase, they have surely allayed the doubts that arose from taking only one point from three away matches in the first round.

Tomorrow's match in Valencia will test the truth of this supposition. With Jaap Stam back in the heart of defence, Sir Alex Ferguson will have fewer fears of suffering a repeat of Brussels, where Anderlecht raced to a 2-0 lead in a half the United manager described as "an absolute nightmare".

Yet Valencia, though well beaten by Real in last year's all-Spanish European Cup final, remain daunting opponents on their own ground and this season are proving miserly, conceding only 16 goals in 22 league games, four in the Champions League first round and none so far in the second.

A draw in the Mestalla stadium would not disappoint Ferguson. Even a defeat would be offset by the fact that United have home matches against Valencia and Sturm Graz to come.

At this stage United, Bayern and Real look the best bets for the quarter-finals, with Valencia, Spartak, Galatasaray, Milan and Anderlecht most likely to join them. If there is to be another English representative it will surely be Leeds.

Arguably the most intriguing European encounter involving English interests this week is in the Uefa Cup, where Liverpool meet Roma in their fourth-round away leg. Who knows, this could be a preview of next season's Champions League. Certainly the present participants must be grateful the Italian league leaders, Gabriel Batistuta, Cafu et al, are for the moment confined to the plate competition.

 Valencia's midfielder Miguel Angel Angulo denied yesterday that comments he made last week implied that his side had agreed to draw last season's Champions League match with Manchester United. "A part of what I said last Friday has been taken completely out of context," he said.

webTitle: Referee Graham Barber to be called to account

fields.headline: Barber put on the spot over Varga challenge
fields.trailText: Referee Graham Barber is to be called to account by the FA for his failure to send off Sunderland's Stanislav Varga against Liverpool on Saturday.
fields.body:
The referee Graham Barber is to be called to account by the FA for his apparent failure to apply a mandatory instruction in Saturday's 1-1 draw between Sunderland and Liverpool.

Sunderland's Stanislav Varga escaped an automatic red card for preventing a scoring opportunity in the incident that led to Liverpool's equaliser from a controversial penalty.

Varga was not even booked for checking Gary McAllister's run on goal and in the mayhem that erupted over the penalty decision, given for a challenge shown to be outside the box, Barber appeared to forget to take the appropriate action of sending the defender off.

The FA's referees committee will write to Barber for an explanation. The committee has the power to suspend officials in such circumstances, as once happened to Dermot Gallagher, though a severe reprimand is more likely.

Barber's Premier League colleague Paul Durkin was rebuked after a similar incident last season when he failed to send off Chelsea's goalkeeper Ed de Goey.

Graham Rix, the former Chelsea coach, will be interviewed for the vacant coaching position at Portsmouth this week - and hopes to beat his old Stamford Bridge colleague Ray Wilkins to the job at Fratton Park.

Rix will meet Portsmouth's chairman Milan Mandaric and player-manager Steve Claridge in the hope of returning to football. The 43-year-old Rix has been out of a job since he and Wilkins were sacked by the Chelsea coach Claudio Ranieri after the Italian was appointed as Gianluca Vialli's replacement.

Birmingham have signed Peter Atherton on a three-month loan from Bradford City.

The 30-year-old defender is expected to make his debut in Saturday's home derby with West Bromwich. But he is not eligible for the League Cup final against Liverpool in Cardiff because he is cup-tied.

webTitle: FA Cup: Bolton buzzing again

fields.headline: Bolton buzzing again as Allardyce builds for future
fields.trailText: Daniel Taylor reports as revitalised Bolton prepare for a neighbourly spat at home to Blackburn and a possible place in the quarter-finals.
fields.body:
When Sam Allardyce was lured back to Bolton Wanderers 16 months ago he was intrigued to find the club's history charmingly encapsulated in a museum behind the Nat Lofthouse stand.

Through one of the 1950s Ellison red-iron turnstiles, it is the nostalgic story of "over 100 years of dreams - some fulfilled, some not", from tributes to Harry Goslin and the Wartime Wanderers to the stockings worn by Ted Vizard in a 6-0 trouncing of Blackburn in 1925 and the dinner menu after the 1958 FA Cup final.

For the footballing sentimentalist - and there are many in Bolton - it is a misty-eyed trip down memory lane. But for Allardyce the priorities have shifted. Rather than living in the past, the emphasis is on building for the future.

Tonight they visit Portsmouth, but many minds will already be turning towards the weekend and beyond. A neighbourly spat at home to Blackburn on Saturday will decide which of them reaches the FA Cup quarter-finals. The same all-Lancashire skirmish the following Friday could conceivably settle which side finishes behind Fulham in the First Division. "This is what it's all about," Allardyce sighed yesterday.

The old-timers at Bolton will fondly remember him as the old-fashioned, broken-nose epitome of the 70s centre-half. "He was what I called a ball-playing defender," says Dave Bassett, a long-time friend. "If he wasn't playing with the ball he was playing with your balls."

Yet beneath the thick-set, gravel-voiced exterior and the fondness for a pint of Boddingtons, this moustachioed 46-year-old is becoming recognised as one of the most enterprising managers in the game: an alumnus of football's old school in many respects yet also a student of the appliance of science.

"I got into sports science when I was playing for Tampa Bay and I've used it ever since," he says. "In those days people in England used to treat cramp with salt tablets whereas in America they would have laughed at things like that. Over there it was all about potassium, electrolytes and replacement fluids.

"I brought that back with me and now I have a fitness coach who was educated in America and goes back there every year to update himself on the latest scientific techniques."

The new regime means his players are not allowed even a half-time cup of tea because, according to the boffins, it can reduce fluid levels and increase muscle fatigue. Yet the dietetics would be irrelevant if Allardyce had not assembled a talented and willing squad on a budget not wholly dissimilar to his early days at Limerick when his duties regularly included organising a club collection.

Financial restraints have compelled him to grub around at the fag-end of the transfer market but the 34-year-old free transfer Ian Marshall has been a revelation, Colin Hendry has shored up the defence while on loan from Coventry and Nicky Summerbee has swiftly acclimatised since joining from Sunderland.

Then there is Michael Ricketts, a 22-year-old Brummie with 17 goals since signing from Walsall for £250,000. "He's got all the same qualities as Emile Heskey and he's actually a better natural finisher; £7m would be peanuts for him now," eulogises Allardyce. "If he gives it more time he should be looking to play for England."

There is a case that Bolton's abysmal semi-final against Aston Villa last season, and specifically the sight of Dean Holdsworth wafting the ball over an open Wembley goal, detracted from the club having reached such a lofty perch.

Losing one semi-final is unfortunate; losing three can be construed as careless. Yet Bolton also came off second best to Tranmere in the Wor thington Cup and, most excruciatingly, Ipswich in the play-offs.

Allardyce promptly took off on a two-week cruise minus his mobile phone. "I wanted to get away," he says, but now he and Bolton are very much back in the groove. A renaissance is taking shape and the policeman's son from Dudley has a new 10-year contract.

"By signing a long-term deal I've got the right amount of time now to do the job properly. The infrastructure is not totally in place yet but when we do get into the Premiership I want us in a position where we can sustain our position rather than being this yo-yo club of the last 40 years.

"The facilities at this club are second to none and you can't help feel there is a real buzz about the place."

webTitle: Wednesday call time on Jewell

fields.headline: Wednesday call time on Jewell
fields.trailText: Sheffield Wednesday, bottom of the First Division, yesterday tried a last desperate throw of the dice when they sacked their manager Paul Jewell. The resignation of their chairman Howard Culley followed.
fields.body:
Sheffield Wednesday, bottom of the First Division, yesterday tried a last desperate throw of the dice when they sacked their manager Paul Jewell. The resignation of their chairman Howard Culley followed.

Jewell has been replaced by his highly experienced assistant Peter Shreeves, who will be in charge in a caretaker capacity for tonight's game with their fellow strugglers Tranmere at Hillsborough.

Although Shreeves would undoubtedly welcome the chance to return to permanent front-line management, Wednesday will probably seek to install someone with a reputation for turning around seemingly lost causes.

Two former managers of their bitter rivals Sheffield United - Dave Bassett and Howard Kendall - may feature on the directors' wish-list. Bassett, football's most celebrated firefighter, is unemployed after recently resigning his post at Barnsley, and Kendall has been out of management for more than two years.

Jewell departed pointing an accusing finger at those who guard the Wednesday purse-strings.

"I'm disappointed because, in all honesty, I didn't see this coming," he said. "I was preparing for the home game with Tranmere and working on bringing in a loan player from Southampton, Trond Egil Soltvedt." The Norwegian became Peter Shreeves' first signing yesterday on a month's loan.

"Look at the players I was forced to sell last summer," Jewell went on. "In contrast I have barely been given a penny to spend; I have had to rely on kids.

"But I do not regret coming here because I have learned much over the past seven months or so. Obviously it is not nice getting sacked. But I don't think I have been given enough time."

Culley's decision to stand down in the face of mounting public discontent about his handling of club affairs was not totally unexpected and he hands what must be regarded as a poisoned chalice to one of his directors, Geoff Hulley.

"Given the present position, and in view of the board's decision to terminate the contract of Paul Jewell, I have decided to step aside as chairman," he said.

"I did also offer to resign as a director but at the request of the other directors I have agreed to continue temporarily."

Relegated from the Premiership only last May, Wednesday lie at the foot of the First Division table, two points adrift of safety and having played more games than other clubs in trouble.

The final straw for Jewell and Culley came on Saturday when the team were humbled 4-1 away by Wimbledon.

Yesterday's developments came 72 hours after Culley had indicated his determination to extend a tenure which began less than 12 months ago after his predecessor Dave Richards took up the post of chairman of the Premier League.

Another director, the nightclub and casino owner Dave Allen, has agreed to buy a 36% stake in the club from the venture capital arm of the leading investment bank Charterhouse. Allen is believed to have paid about £4m in a deal which values the club - who have estimated debts of £16m - at £11m .

Newcastle are poised to complete a £1m deal for the Sheffield United full-back Wayne Quinn after a month's loan at St James' Park. The move is expected to be rubberstamped in the next 24 hours.

Leicester have announced a £2.5m two-year sponsorship deal which could be worth up to £7m with on-field incentives. The deal with the information technology electronics manufacturer LG Electronics will commence in June and the Foxes will kick off next season in shirts bearing the LG logo.

 Gérard Houllier is resigned to facing Roma without Steven Gerrard and knows he may have to give up on several other Liverpool casualties for Thursday night's Uefa Cup tie. Gerrard, 20, is struggling with the groin injury sustained at Sunderland on Saturday, and his fellow midfielder Igor Biscan will be unavailable too. "Steven is definitely out, and Igor Biscan is cup-tied after playing for Dinamo Zagreb in Europe," said Houllier.

webTitle: Sugar admits to £20m profit

fields.headline: Sugar admits to £20m profit
fields.trailText: Sir Alan Sugar yesterday agreed that he had made a profit of nearly £20m during his chairmanship of Tottenham as he gave evidence in his trial over the Daily Mail's description of his reign as "miserly".
fields.body:
Sir Alan Sugar will walk away from Tottenham with almost £20m after his near 10-year chairmanship of the club.

The High Court yesterday heard Sugar, who is selling two-thirds of his majority shareholding, agree that he had made a profit of nearly £20m during his stewardship.

Sugar, 53, also agreed that it would be no exaggeration to say he had a "massive" personal fortune - with that £20m representing less than 10% of his net worth.

He was continuing his evidence in his libel case over an article in the Daily Mail in December 1999 calling him "miserly" in his reign.

He became heated as he sparred with Nicholas Stadlen QC, defending, who suggested that Sugar could personally afford the money to spend on players for Spurs if he chose.

But Sugar retorted that Viscount Rothermere, owner of Associated Newspapers, was also capable of buying the Daily Mail a new printing press but it was unlikely that the newspaper would ask him to "bung us a few quid".

"It's absolutely ludicrous to suggest something like that.

"Do they say to Richard Branson, lend us a few quid to buy us a new plane?"

Sugar said that about £100m had been spent on players and White Hart Lane in his time and he agreed that the bank would "most probably" have loaned him £7.5m to buy Dennis Bergkamp, but Tottenham's then manager Gerry Francis had vetoed the idea.

Sugar agreed he could have doubled the £12m budget that George Graham, his current manager, was initially given.

"The board wanted to restrict the activities within what it could afford to do," he said. "What is the point of putting the company into debt?"

Sugar, who invested £8.5m in the club in 1991, is selling shares for £22m and keeping a stake worth £6.5m. He said he and his family were "passionate" Spurs supporters and that he had not bought the club to make money for himself.

webTitle: Bergkamp's fear of Eurostarring

fields.headline: Bergkamp's fear of Eurostarring
fields.trailText: An apparent phobia for high-speed trains and not just a fear of flying means Dennis Bergkamp will be staying in London for the tie.
fields.body:
Dennis Bergkamp's absence from Arsenal's European trips does not usually raise an eyebrow but questions were being asked last night. It appears the man famed for his fear of flying may have developed a phobia for high-speed trains as well.

Given his desperation to play in tonight's vital Champions League fixture, logic suggested Bergkamp would have proposed letting the train take the strain for a journey of just over five hours. Apparently not. "The train flies," Arsène Wenger said with a smile. "He prefers to travel by car."

Having seen Wenger turn down his plan to come here by road, Bergkamp will be twiddling his thumbs at home while his team-mates set about trying to rectify their poor start to this second group stage.

"It's not the best way to prepare, to have 10 hours on the road," Wenger said, doubtless with one eye on Sunday's FA Cup tie at home to Chelsea.

Not that Bergkamp's arrangements have been occupying all Wenger's thoughts. His willingness to extend his contract beyond next season will hinge on reforms to the transfer system. "If it comes out that players can move with three months' notice of course I will just leave club football," he said.

Lyon, and particularly their striker Sonny Anderson, provide a more immediate problem. Defeat this evening would all but end Arsenal's hopes of reaching the quarter-finals.

With Igor Stepanovs ineligible and Martin Keown injured, Gilles Grimandi is expected to play at centre-half. "It unfortunate," said Wenger. "Although I am for rotation up front, I try to keep stability at the back."

Arsenal (4-4-2, possible): Seaman; Dixon, Adams, Grimandi, Cole; Lauren, Parlour, Vieira, Pires; Henry, Kanu.

webTitle: Reds' Martyn move miffs Leeds

fields.headline: Reds' Martyn move miffs Leeds
fields.trailText: David O'Leary's preparations for two pivotal games against the Belgian champions have been disrupted by the news that Liverpool are hoping to tempt Nigel Martyn to Anfield.
fields.body:
David O'Leary's attempts to focus on Leeds United's return to Champions League activity against Anderlecht tonight have been disrupted by the news that Liverpool are hoping to tempt Nigel Martyn to Anfield.

As Leeds prepare for two pivotal games against the Belgian champions in the space of eight days, O'Leary and his chairman Peter Ridsdale have been dismayed to learn of Gérard Houllier's intentions.

It is well known that the Liverpool manager is looking for a new goalkeeper after a number of dubious displays by Sander Westerveld this season and although Martyn signed a four-year contract last summer, the emergence of Paul Robinson means he can no longer be guaranteed a first-team place at Leeds.

Ideally, O'Leary would like to keep both the 33-year-old England international and his 21-year-old understudy but there is also a feeling in the Leeds camp that Martyn should not be perceived as indispensable.

Leeds understand that Martyn heads a Liverpool shortlist that also includes Coventry's Chris Kirkland.

It is a subplot Leeds could do without as they size up an Anderlecht side whose success in reaching this stage has been unexpected as their own.

After the first three games of the opening phase the Belgians were bottom of their group but squeaked into the second stage after beating Manchester United 2-1 in Brussels.

So far in Group D they have been soundly beaten 4-1 by Real Madrid but a 1-0 win at home to Sven-Goran Eriksson's Lazio put them level with Leeds on three .

O'Leary will have to fare without Robbie Keane who is cup-tied, having played for Internazionale.

webTitle: Lyon 0 - 1 Arsenal

fields.headline: Lyon 0 - 1 Arsenal
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Lyon: 1-Gregory Coupet; 2-Eric Deflandre, 20-Patrick Muller, 3-Edmilson, 26-Jeremie Brechet; 8-Pierre Laigle, 17-Marc-Vivien Foe, 6-Philippe Violeau, 10-Vikash Dhorasoo; 7-Steve Marlet, 9-Sonny Anderson. Subs: Hugues, Loko, Govou, Delmotte, Malbranque, Chanelet, Linares.

Arsenal: 1-David Seaman; 2-Lee Dixon, 18-Gilles Grimandi, 6-Tony Adams, 29-Ashley Cole; 15-Ray Parlour, 12-Lauren, 4-Patrick Vieira, 7-Robert Pires; 14-Thierry Henry, 25-Nwankwo Kanu. Subs: Manninger, Ljungberg, Wiltord, Malz, Luzhny, Vivas, Pennant.

Referee: Urs Meier (Switzerland)

1 Arsenal kick-off this sell-out in the Stade Gerland. According to one French paper tickets have been harder to come by than Greek passports. Not bad. Anderson wins the first free-kick of the game; comes in from the right but Arsenal clear.
2 Parlour and Pires knock it around just outside the Lyon area, but in no time the home side break and are again pressuring the Gunners' goal as Anderson charges in on Seaman.
4 Anderson already a handful for the Arsenal back line - Adams lucky when Anderson tumbles over him just outside the area and the ref waves play on.
6 Lyon unlucky not to get the opener; Marlet, in space from Grimandi on the edge of the Arsenal area, tries to lob Seaman but the Arsenal keeper flaps a hand at the ball to send it wide.
7 Henry creates the first real opening for Arsenal with a useful run into the Lyon penalty area.
9 Pires catches Deflandre out of position and gets away on the left; Edmilson stops him dead.
11 Cole very lucky to survive a penalty appeal as Lyon flood forward again. Two corners in succession for the home side have Arsenal on the rack; the first is hooked clear from under the crossbar by Adams, the second is held by Seaman under pressure from his ponytail.
13 Good movement by Violeau and Brechet almost releases Marlet through the middle but Arsenal hold firm.
14 Pires releases Cole on the left but the cross is poor.
16 Free-kick for Arsenal 30 yards out on the left. Pires takes towards Adams and Vieira at the far post but Lyon keeper Coupet punches clear.
17 Pires gets caught on the ball deep on his own half; Marlet picks it up and shoots from 25 yards.
18 Arsenal come desperately close to scoring when Kanu runs through from 30 ayards, beats three men with the ball stuck to his feet and chips the ball across goal with the outside of his right foot... wide.
20 Henry played in by Vieira just outside the Lyon area. He is forced to come back on himself to shoot but still manages to force Coupet down to his right.
22 Arsenal living dangerously, allowing far too much space in midfield. Only Seaman's fine form and some fearless defending by Grimandi keep Dhorasoo and Marlet from scoring as Lyon heap pressure on the Arsenal goal.
24 Arsenal corner, Pires takes, Lyon clear. End to end stuff now as both teams run riot in the cavernous expanses now dominating the middle of the park.
27 Dhorasoo and Anderson play a one-two just outside the Arsenal area before the ball goes to Deflandre out on the right. He shoots and forces another save from Seaman.
28 Adams getting the measure of Marlet as he robs him in midfield; passes to Vieira who slides the ball through to the on-running Henry... too long.
31 Booking Cole; went in too hard.
32 And so it came to pass that in the 32nd minute things calmed down slightly.
33 For a moment at least... Violeau almost rattles the crossbar with a blistering shot from 25 yards.
35 Booking Adams for upending Anderson just outside the area. Lucky. Free-kick taken by Edmilson and it's vicious, wide of the left upright. Resulting corner comes to nothing.
37 Booking Mulller for shirt-pulling.
45 Beautiful move by Arsenal; Kanu, on the edge of the area, knocks the ball over his head for Henry to see his shot skim off the far post. Half-time. An open half verging on the reckless, but Arsenal appear to have weathered the storm and look good for a lucky away goal in the second half.

46 Lyon get the second half underway. With Arsenal clearly not ready to settle for a draw, it should make for a lively finale.
47 First chance of the half falls to Kanu. He gets away from Edmilson deep on the right and decides to go it alone with a dead-end shot to the the near post when a pass to Henry or Pires would have been more useful.
51 Henry runs at Edmilson on the edge of the Lyon area; he is beaten back but still squeezes in a shot before going down.
55 Dhorasoo wins a corner for Lyon. Dhorasoo takes, Grimandi heads clear and Violeau goes down claiming for a penalty on the edge of the Arsenal area. Ref not having it.
56 Lyon with the best chance of the half so far. Marlet finds Anderson running into the area and Seaman is at full stretch to fingertip Anderson's shot wide of the far post.
58 GOAL: Lyon 0 - 1 Arsenal A goal made by Cole when he crosses high from the left side of the area for Henry to head Arsenal into the lead.
61 Marlet in space 20 yards out and borderline offside tries unsuccessfully to chip Seaman.
64 Henry impatient as he tries to get on the end of Lauren's pass and is caught offside in what would have been a great position.
68 Seaman in just the right spot at the just the right time to save from Anderson on the six-yard line.
69 Substitution Ljungberg on for Pires.
72 Lyon getting the better of the ref's decisions as Edmilson gets away with a chop into the back of Kanu's legs.
74 Henry given bags of time and space to tee up a shot from 25 yards and force a save.
75 Substitution Malbranque and Govou on for Violeau and Dhorasoo.
76 Corner to Lyon, comes to nothing.
80 Vieira, a towering presence in midfield tonight, now playing deep as Arsenal batten down the hatches and try to hold on for victory. Neveretheless, Lauren and Ljungberg still trying to gain ground down the flanks. Lauren wins a corner on the right; vcomes to nothing.
82 Marlet comes close to ruining Arsenal's night when he puts over the bar under pressure from Vieira.
87 Arsenal finishing the game as a team of defenders as Henry manages to charge the ball downfield and waste a few moments in the Lyons half.
88 A wall of red and white greets Anderson as he as tries desperately to break through in search of an equaliser.
90 Substitution Vivas on for Kanu. Desperate stuff for Lyon as Arsenal hang on. Full-time. Lyons 0 - 1 Arsenal A season-turning result for Arsenal that sees them go second in the group after Bayern Munich beat Spartak Moscow 1-0.

webTitle: Camera shy

fields.headline: Camera shy
fields.standfirst: Henri Cartier-Bresson is outraged by a collection of 'snapshots' of himself.
fields.trailText: Henri Cartier-Bresson is outraged by a collection of 'snapshots' of himself.
fields.body:
There is something poignant about the reluctance of the great 92-year-old photo- grapher Henri Cartier-Bresson to have his picture circulated. Cartier-Bresson has objected to a book of photographs of him by the American David Douglas Duncan, entitled Faceless. They are mediocre, "snapshots" rather than true portraits, he protests. But it can't be just the quality of the pictures that has upset him. Duncan too is a famous photographer, whose images of the Korean war are classics. He was able to photograph Cartier-Bresson casually, over drinks at the Musee Picasso in Paris, because Cartier-Bres son was on assignment to photograph him. The fact is, the world's most revered photographer hates having his picture taken.

He's not alone. Who doesn't have a fear of the camera's power to tell us what we are? From posing for our first school photo, we learn the oppressiveness of the camera, its power to define us. Think of poor Marilyn Monroe, going through the contact sheets of her photo sessions, crossing out shots she didn't like. Artists, who understand the authority of visual experience, are not less but more mystical about the power of the image.

Cartier-Bresson at least allows some images of himself to circulate. Stanley Kubrick, who began as a photojournalist, be came such a stranger to snappers that an impersonator was able to pass himself off as the director despite looking nothing like him. And who can say what part was played in the disintegration of Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman's marriage by their decision to play a married couple to Kubrick's searching camera in Eyes Wide Shut? The camera seemed to capture a lack of physical passion in their scenes together, and a falseness in the marriage that has now collapsed.

Yet Kubrick did allow one person to portray him - his wife. Christiane Kubrick, an artist, painted Kubrick and showed his portrait in exhibitions in St Albans. Kubrick clearly only trusted images that were made with love. The same is true of Cartier-Bresson. He is happy with the photographs taken of him by his wife, Martine Franck. Similarly, it's hard to imagine the American painter Georgia O'Keeffe posing semi-nude in a series of portraits had the photographer, Alfred Stieglitz, not also been her lover.

Other artists have had a more troubled relationship with the one-eyed intruder. Jackson Pollock's fame was established by Arnold Newman and Hans Namuth's photos of him brooding in front of his canvases or throwing paint. But when Namuth persuaded him also to be filmed at work, Pollock felt exposed. He ended the session by falling spectacularly off the wagon (he'd been dry for a few highly productive years), turning over the dinner table and shouting: "I'm not the phony, you're the phony."

Artists seem to divide, just like the rest of us, into clumsy introverts, terrified of the camera, and people who love - and are loved by - the lens. I doubt whether Salvador Dali ever objected to having his picture taken. He even let Helmut Newton photograph him with a tube in his nose in his last days, a miserable figure of futile wealth and sterile fame. Picasso was a happy subject and adept media performer: Cartier-Bresson caught him in a fearful moment in wartime, Duncan shot the artist in the bath. But other kinds of portrayal caused Picasso pain he was horrified when Francoise Gilot published an account of their relationship. Images didn't bother him words did.

Duncan points out in his defence of Cartier-Bresson that he is celebrated for snatching "the decisive moment", photographing people unawares. But I don't think that's adequate. Cartier-Bresson is not a pitiless snapper. If he has a personal fear of the lens, he has tried to soften its assault on others. His pictures of artists in particular - Matisse, Bonnard, Picasso - are richly artful celebrations "portraits", he would say, rather than "snapshots".

His portrait of Matisse, taken in 1944, catches the artist sketching in a room full of pet birds, one of which he holds Matisse has been photographed spontaneously, yet the image Cartier-Bresson has selected from the many he took that day is an allegory of Matisse as creator, his imagination soaring. None of the birds is in a cage.

Cartier-Bresson complains that, rather than choose one significant portrait, Duncan has published an entire reel of film. He sees an opposition between the use of the camera to make a sensitive work of art and the routine photography that dominates our lives: arbitrary, crude in its definition of who we are and - in his eyes - violent.

· Faceless by David Duncan is published by Assouline.

Duncan points out in his defence of Cartier-Bresson that he is celebrated for snatching "the decisive moment", photographing people unawares. But I don't think that's adequate. Cartier-Bresson is not a pitiless snapper. If he has a personal fear of the lens, he has tried to soften its assault on others. His pictures of artists in particular - Matisse, Bonnard, Picasso - are richly artful celebrations "portraits", he would say, rather than "snapshots". His portrait of Matisse, taken in 1944, catches the artist sketching in a room full of pet birds, one of which he holds Matisse has been photographed spontaneously, yet the image Cartier-Bresson has selected from the many he took that day is an allegory of Matisse as creator, his imagination soaring. None of the birds is in a cage. Cartier-Bresson complains that, rather than choose one significant portrait, Duncan has published an entire reel of film. He sees an opposition between the use of the camera to make a sensitive work of art and the routine photography that dominates our lives: arbitrary, crude in its definition of who we are and - in his eyes - violent. · Faceless by David Duncan is published by Assouline.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Alison
fields.trailText: After having enjoyed reading your NZ experiences I am all of a sudden looking forward to going there myself. I am currently in Sydney with a flight on hold and having problems with my visa...
fields.body:
Hi Sam,

After having enjoyed reading your NZ experiences I am all of a sudden looking forward to going there myself. I am currently in Sydney with a flight on hold and having problems with my visa...

That is all boring though.

The reason I am writing to you is because after NZ myself and my friend are traveling to Perth to catch a flight to Johannesburg. This is all a bit nerve-racking as everyone we speak to talks of how dangerous it is in Africa and that we are mad to go there. We have had some hair raising experiences en route so far....so are not particuarly worried.

I was intrigued when I read your comments to people who had recommended safaris to you. You know where this is going..

I would be hugely grateful if you could pass on any travelling tips that you receive or find out for yourself regarding Africa - places/accomodation/safaris/etc. The only contact I have there is a friend of a friend who does jungle treks in Zimbabwe.

I don't know where you are now but I hope you are enjoying Oz. I am sick of it now but had some fun times although most of my time here has been a drunken blur.

Need any tips for Sydney? Just ask me - I've been here eight months...

Hope to hear from you soon anyway.

Alison.

webTitle: Week 11: Sydney to Wyong

fields.headline: Held captive down under
fields.standfirst: Newly arrived in Sydney, Sam meets up with several old friends, and enjoys the novelty of a pizza and a video at home
fields.trailText: Newly arrived in Sydney, Sam meets up with several old friends, and enjoys the novelty of a pizza and a video at home
fields.body:
G'day! Yes, I've arrived in Australia.

I'm always a bit disorientated when I land at a new airport. Sydney was no exception - I got lost trying to find the information desk.

Normally I get out of an airport straight away, but this time I hadn't sorted out any accommodation beforehand. Major airports usually have a display with the numbers of certain hostels and a free telephone you can use to call them, and after lugging my rucksack round most of the terminal, I eventually found Sydney's.

I tried number after number but they were all full. This was a bit worrying, as it was beginning to get late. In my slightly muddled state I ended up buying a guidebook in order to find more numbers.

Now armed with numerous hostel numbers I quickly found a place in the leafy University suburb of Glebe. It was called Wattle House and was very nice with small dorms and comfortable beds. It also had a book exchange with at least five different guidebooks on the shelf. I kicked myself for buying a brand new guide at the airport.

The next morning I set out to have a look round. I had thought after the US I had gone off cities, but I really liked Sydney. It was easy to get around and there were lots of interesting areas to explore.

There was a exciting buzz among the skyscrapers in the centre. Suited office workers were packing the bars and restaurants. The feeling of wealth and people enjoying spending it was almost tangible.

At the heart of the city are the beautiful botanical gardens. A colony of fruit bats has established itself among the trees there (look at Sam's photos) and at night the bats move out across the city. You can see them silently flying over the buildings. It's like Gotham City.

Along the harbour there are lots of beaches and little empty bays surrounded by forest. I caught the ferry to Manly beach. This cost just a few dollars - much cheaper than taking a formal harbour cruise - and was a great way to see the city from the water. At Manly it's great fun to watch the surfers trying to drown themselves in the huge waves.

On Friday I met up with fellow Netjetter, Milly. The last time I had seen her was on a cold October day outside the Guardian's offices in London. Here in Sydney the sun was out so we went for a ferry ride to Darling Harbour.

We had been emailing each other but it was good to catch up on news and we had a lot to talk about after almost three months travelling. Despite going to completely different parts of the world many of our experiences and our reactions to them have been quite similar. I decided I was extremely jealous of her having her own room in a settled flat.

Milly's camera has been out of action for a while so I took a photo of us both before we said our goodbyes (look at Sam's photos).

That evening, I splashed out and booked myself a ticket to the opera to see Mozart's Cosi Fan Tutte.

The Opera House is in an incredible setting (as you all know), and as I walked up the steps, the QEII was just slipping out of the harbour on the next leg of a round the world cruise (look at Sam's photos). Waving crowds lined her decks and the harbour quay as two tugs gently ushered away the huge liner, like chaperones escorting a debutante.

Inside, the Opera House was suitably plush and the opera was very good, but it was the romantic view outside with the moon rising over the harbour and the lights of the skyscrapers reflecting on the water that really stole the show.

Leaving Sydney, I moved on up to the small town of Wyong to visit my friends, Ben and Amber, who I met in Fiji.

Wyong isn't exactly on the regular backpacker circuit but it was a nice small town. Ben and Amber lived next to the river and only a short drive from the beach.

We went out to see the surf and had a few beers and a game of pool at the local pub. There I discovered 'Pokies'. These are electronic gambling games - like fruit machines but more complicated. They are really popular and many Australian pubs (or hotels as they're called) have whole rooms put aside for addicts. We put a couple of dollars in the slot and started to play. We whooped as our winnings rose to a fortune of six dollars and then groaned as they evaporated and we lost our original stake. I was hooked and would have kept playing all night, but the other two pulled me away.

Back at the house we had pizza and a video (Gladiator - Amber likes Russell Crowe). I loved this. Doing anything as normal as this is a real treat when you're travelling as it's impossible most of the time.

The next day we went for a drive out in the bush and I saw my first kangeroos hopping along in the grass. We also saw a deadly red-bellied black snake dozing on a tree stump (look at Sam's photos). This was a black snake with a red underbelly and is an excellent example of the complicated way Australians come up with names for things. There are plenty of other examples in Sydney. These include the bridge over the harbour ('The Harbour Bridge') and the city's circular quay ('Circular Quay').

Next week I'm off to the hippie haven of Byron Bay and then a four-wheel drive adventure on the sand dunes of Frazer Island.

webTitle: MP among 350 held at nuclear submarine base protest

fields.headline: MP among 350 held at nuclear submarine base protest
fields.trailText: Labour MP George Galloway was among 350 protesters arrested yesterday during an anti-nuclear demonstration at the Faslane Trident submarine base on the Clyde.
fields.body:
Labour MP George Galloway was among 350 protesters arrested yesterday during an anti-nuclear demonstration at the Faslane Trident submarine base on the Clyde.

Socialist MSP Tommy Sheridan and Green MEP Caroline Lucas were also detained as around 700 people tried to blockade the base, home to Britain's nuclear submarine fleet. The demonstration, one of the biggest in recent years, was backed by church leaders, politicians and celebrities, including actors Emma Thompson and Sir Sean Connery, who sent messages of support.

The protest started at 7am when coachloads of demonstrators arrived from across Britain and Europe, forming a human chain at the main entrance to the base.

They unfurled banners, banged on drums and chanted slogans, and police had to cut through tubing which some protesters had used to tie themselves together.

Mr Galloway said: "We are worried about how to pay for care of the elderly and reducing class sizes in schools. However, we are spending millions on weapons of mass destruction that will never be used."

Mr Sheridan recently spent five days in jail for non-payment of a fine imposed after a similar protest last February.

The blockade was organised by anti-nuclear groups Trident Ploughshares and Scottish CND, who claim nuclear weapons breach international law because they cannot distinguish between civilian and military targets. Three high court judges are considering the issue following a sheriff's ruling that three women who vandalised a Trident installation at Loch Goil were not acting illegally.

Ploughshares spokesman David Mackenzie said they were delighted at the turnout and a powerful message had been sent to the government.

webTitle: Labour ends Lords talks

fields.headline: Labour ends Lords talks as rift with Lib Dems grows
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lords reform
fields.trailText: Labour-Liberal Democrat co-operation came to an abrupt end ahead of the general election last night when Labour pulled the plug on joint discussions between the two parties over the future of the House of Lords.
fields.body:
Labour-Liberal Democrat co-operation came to an abrupt end ahead of the general election last night when Labour pulled the plug on joint discussions between the two parties over the future of the House of Lords.

The move effectively ends all policy cooperation between the two parties, and also raises the prospect of a wider deterioration in relations. Many senior Liberal Democrats believe Tony Blair is now confident of another large overall Commons majority and will abandon his troublesome co-operation with the Lib Dems.

At the weekend the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, again warned that any Labour decision to drop its manifesto commitment to a referendum on electoral reform for the Commons would spell the end of the relationship between the two parties. He was backed yesterday by a leading Liberal Democrat advocate of cooperation, Lord McNally, who said dropping the referendum pledge would mark the end of the drive to rid British politics of party tribalism.

The latest deterioration in relations came when Labour cancelled a joint committee due to meet tomorrow on the future of Lords reform. Labour said no common agenda could be agreed. Labour sources said the row meant there was no prospect of further meetings ahead of the election.

The proposed joint policy had been intended to be presented to the electorate as a sign of the benefits of cooperation between the two parties. It would have also made it easier to speed second stage Lords reform through parliament after the election. The Liberal Democrats effectively hold the balance of power in the Lords, so the failure to agree a joint policy may set back the likelihood of early reform to the Lords which still contains over 90 hereditary peers.

The decision to pull the plug on joint cooperation was taken by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, the leader of the Commons, Margaret Beckett, and the leader of the Lords, Lady Jay. They had been struggling for months to finalise a joint agenda for the talks with their Liberal Democrat counterparts Robert Maclennan and the Lib Dem leader of the Lords, Lord Rodgers.

The Liberal Democrats had been insisting that the joint committee - a sub-committee of the joint consultative committee set up by Sir Paddy Ashdown and Tony Blair - should discuss the future composition of a reformed second chamber, as well as its powers. Labour insisted that the composition of the Lords, including the proportion of elected members, has already been decided by the royal commission chaired by Lord Wakeham.

The two parties, Labour maintained, could only discuss the powers and procedures of a reformed second chamber. The Liberal Democrats want a largely elected second chamber, but Tony Blair wants only about 80-90 elected peers. He fears a larger element would lead to a conflict of roles between the upper and lower chambers.

Labour said last night any changes to government proposals could only come legitimately in debate when it produced a bill in the next parliament.

webTitle: Wobbly start for Orange flotation

fields.headline: Wobbly start for Orange flotation
fields.trailText: Mobile phone operator Orange has made a nervous stock market debut, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Mobile phone operator Orange has made a nervous stock market debut, as investors hold back from the debt-laden telecoms sector.

After one hour of trading, the shares were at 618p in Paris, below the 632p issue price for institutions but above the 601p offered to retail buyers.

Although analysts cautioned against reading too much into the early stages of the flotation, the fact that Orange was launched at the bottom end of an already lowered price range will cause concern among its competitors.

UK telecoms giant BT, German rival Deutsche Telekom and KPN of Holland are all planning to float their mobile phone operations and will balk at the reception given to Europe's second largest wireless company.

BT is struggling to reduce a £30bn debt burden and the planned flotation of its wireless division is beset with problems. These include the future of its stakes in French rival Cegetel and Spanish mobile phone company Airtel.

"It will be hard to get BT and KPN onto the market," said Mark James, telecoms analyst at Nomura.

"I am not even sure what is in BT's wireless subsdiary at the moment and I don't even know if their stakes in Airtel or Cegetel will be in there. BT Wireless gets smaller every time we look at it."

Telecoms companies are rushing their subsidiaries to market in a bid to pay back the massive loans they have taken out to pay for European third generation mobile phone licences.

More than £50bn was spent on licences in the UK and Germany alone last year.

webTitle: Oxford to get most 'Laura Spence' money

fields.headline: Oxford to get most 'Laura Spence' money
fields.standfirst: Oxbridge and elitism
fields.trailText: The University of Oxford is likely to get the biggest allocation from the so called 'Laura Spence' money - government grants for elite academic institutions to recruit more state school pupils. The prime minister, Tony Blair, announced the list of winners of the money last week.
fields.body:
The University of Oxford is likely to get the biggest allocation from the so called 'Laura Spence' money - government grants for elite academic institutions to recruit more state school pupils. The prime minister, Tony Blair, announced the list of winners of the money last week.

If Oxford was to meet the government''s target of attracting 80% of state school pupils in its student intake it would receive about £2.8m over three years. The university would have to recruit another 900 state school entrants if it was to reach this target. State schools currently make up 50% of new students at the university.

The allocation of £18m of government funds over three years for 27 universities provides about £3,000 for every extra state pupil. Other universities receive much smaller amounts of money per student recruited from poor backgrounds.

These indicative allocations come from the 1998-99 performance indicators published by the higher education funding councils last year. The 27 institutions qualified for the funds because they currently enrol less than 80% of state school pupils.

Our calculation assumes that this is the target to be achieved for the institutions. Overall 5,838 students would need to be recruited if every university reached the 80% threshold. If the £18m is distributed equally among the students they will each receive £3,000 over the three years.

webTitle: Lib Dems vow to scrap tuition fees

fields.headline: Lib Dems vow to scrap tuition fees
fields.standfirst: Education site
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats yesterday pledged to abolish tuition fees for higher education as part of a package which they claimed would provide free education for all and open up universities to students from poor backgrounds.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats yesterday pledged to abolish tuition fees for higher education as part of a package which they claimed would provide free education for all and open up universities to students from poor backgrounds.

Central to the package are proposals to ensure quality and fair play by injecting an additional £700m into the sector above existing government spending plans. The party wants to encourage universities to use the extra cash to improve pay and conditions and end the "disgraceful gap" between the pay of female and male academics.

The party plans to end top-up fees and introduce a means-tested support grant along the lines of the system in Scotland, increase the threshold at which student loans are repaid and give greater financial incentives to recruit and retain students from under-represented groups.

While the government has claimed that the introduction of tuition fees has not deterred students from applying to British universities, the Liberal Democrats claim their research shows this is not the case.

Their leader, Charles Kennedy, said: "Liberal Democrats are committed to scrapping tuition fees."

The party's higher education spokesman, Evan Harris, added: "Our carefully costed commitments will allow us to restore the principle of higher education free at the point of access, open up our universities to students from poorer backgrounds, remove some of the burden of student debt, abolish the disgraceful pay gap which exists for female academics and tackle the recruitment and retention crisis affecting lecturers and researchers."

Last week the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, issued an unexpected Commons statement ruling out the introduction of American-style top up fees which allow some universities to charge students as much as £7,000 a year.
fields.bodyText: The Liberal Democrats yesterday pledged to abolish tuition fees for higher education as part of a package which they claimed would provide free education for all and open up universities to students from poor backgrounds. Central to the package are proposals to ensure quality and fair play by injecting an additional £700m into the sector above existing government spending plans. The party wants to encourage universities to use the extra cash to improve pay and conditions and end the "disgraceful gap" between the pay of female and male academics. The party plans to end top-up fees and introduce a means-tested support grant along the lines of the system in Scotland, increase the threshold at which student loans are repaid and give greater financial incentives to recruit and retain students from under-represented groups. While the government has claimed that the introduction of tuition fees has not deterred students from applying to British universities, the Liberal Democrats claim their research shows this is not the case. Their leader, Charles Kennedy, said: "Liberal Democrats are committed to scrapping tuition fees." The party's higher education spokesman, Evan Harris, added: "Our carefully costed commitments will allow us to restore the principle of higher education free at the point of access, open up our universities to students from poorer backgrounds, remove some of the burden of student debt, abolish the disgraceful pay gap which exists for female academics and tackle the recruitment and retention crisis affecting lecturers and researchers." Last week the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, issued an unexpected Commons statement ruling out the introduction of American-style top up fees which allow some universities to charge students as much as £7,000 a year.

webTitle: The incentives facing those who want to train as teachers

fields.headline: Teach us all a lesson
fields.standfirst: Satisfaction is not the only incentive if you train as a teacher, says  Ralph Tabberer
fields.trailText: Satisfaction is not the only incentive if you train as a teacher, says Ralph Tabberer
fields.body:
Teaching is like no other profession. You can quickly assume responsibilities that in other careers would not come your way for years. It is intellectually stimulating, creative and endlessly varied, and gives you the opportunity to influence young minds, to shape lives for the better.

There has never been a better time to enter teaching. New training salaries worth £6,000 a year and other financial incentives pay you to train, and salaries and rewards for extra skills and responsibilities have been greatly improved. The pay scale goes well beyond £30,000 for a leading classroom teacher and to £80,000 or more for a headteacher.

Training is no longer restricted to years of study at university or college. Around 10% of would-be teachers train through programmes tailored to their individual needs and circum stances and taking account of previous experience. This route can involve part-time study fitted around a full-time job, or short intensive study. All routes include classroom experience.

New teachers are in demand. For your first job, your options are wide open, with over 20,000 maintained schools and nearly half a million teaching posts in England and Wales.

For graduates, the most popular route to gaining Qualified Teacher Status is by taking a Postgraduate Certificate of Education (PGCE). These are usually full-time and last a year, but some part-time and distance learning courses, normally over two years, are available. The courses combine subject and professional studies with teaching experience, and are offered by higher education institutions in partnership with local schools. Some schools, or groups of schools, are also accredited to offer training.

Ideally, your degree - or equivalent - should reflect the subject you're planning to specialise in. If it doesn't quite fit, your course provider may feel your degree contains enough subject-based knowledge and take you on. If not, you will be advised how to get the knowledge you need.

There are also employment-based routes. The Graduate Teacher Programme (GTP) offers people of 24 and over the security of working in a school as a teacher, on a salary of up to £13,000, while training. Top priority, in England, goes to high-quality trainees in good schools teaching specified subjects or to those from under-represented groups.

Eligible postgraduate trainee teachers in England, who are resident in the UK, receive a £6,000 training salary - the equivalent of £150 a week - while they are training. Anyone following flexible training can claim £3,000 during their training and another £3,000 on achieving QTS.

An additional £4,000 - popularly known as a golden hello - is available for eligible postgraduates teaching mathematics, science, modern foreign languages, design and technology or ICT in England. You can claim this when you have successfully completed your induction and embark on your second year of teaching in a maintained school, provided this is within five years of the start of the first academic year after you achieve QTS. This money is not a loan and there are no fees to pay back.

People training to teach certain subjects in secondary schools - maths, science, modern foreign languages, design and technology, ICT, religious education, music or geography - may be eligible for awards based on financial need.

Some arrangements are different in Wales. An incentive payment of £6,000 is available to postgraduates beginning primary or secondary initial teacher training from September 2001. Trainees who go on to teach in maths, science, technology, modern foreign languages or Welsh will also be entitled to a £4,000 incentive payment after completing their first year of teaching successfully.

Ralph Tabberer is head of the Teacher Training Agency

The Teacher Information Line (0845 6000 991 or, for Welsh speakers, 0845 6000 992) is a free information service. The Teacher Training Agency website is at www.canteach.gov.uk. Applications to most postgraduate courses are through the Graduate Teacher Training Registry (GTTR 01242 223 707) or its website (www.gttr.ac.uk)

webTitle: Higher browsing

fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.trailText: higher
fields.body:
The third degree

What's in a name? Loadsamoney perhaps. A judge in New York State has said a woman can sue her former professor for sexual harassment for calling her "Monica Lewinsky" .

Inbal Hayut sued the State University of New York at New Paltz and Alex Young, a professor of political science, who, she claims, created a "sexually hostile environment" by constantly referring to her as "Monica". Judge David N Hurd ruled that the professor's words could be considered sexual harassment and is allowing the case to proceed. Professor Young had observed that she wore the same coloured lipstick as Clinton's intern and made remarks such as "How was your weekend with Bill?" and "Shut up, Monica. I'll give you a cigar later" in front of the entire class. She argues she was forced to drop out because her morale and her grades were affected. The professor admits the remarks but thought they were fun. "He feels bad that it may have been tasteless or politically incorrect, but he certainly had no intention of making it a sexual thing," said Kenneth Kelly, his lawyer. "It was joking and teasing."

The race is on to succeed Sir William Stubbs as head of the London Institute. No longer, after this summer, will his Calvinist susceptibilities be assaulted by raunchy student fashion shows . Among the runners is his funding wizard, Roger McClure, who followed him from the Further Education Funding Council after missing the top job there.

Stories? Gossip? Contact us: donald.macleod@theguardian.com lee.elliotmajor@theguardian.com

News: Annihilation day

A cosmic impact will one day wipe out most of the human race, MPs heard last week as they discussed the first House of Commons select committee report on space science and technology in more than a decade. The report has called for more government support for space exploration, and highlights the country's strong academic presence in space research.

According to Lembit Öpik, Lib Dem MP for Montgomeryshire, one urgent need for more support is the threat of cosmic disaster.

"It will happen, we just do not know when," he said. "It could be before I finish speaking - in which case I apologise for the fact that my words will be the last thing that honorable Members hear - or it could be in 50m years. My guess is that it will be somewhere between those two."

Evidence suggests, he said, that the last fatalities from cosmic impact in the UK took place in 1783 - when16 people were killed by an unusual object from space. Dinosaurs, meanwhile, were wiped out 65m years ago.

"We know that species will be wiped out again in the near future - unless we take action to prevent it."

Research news

Forward march

A commission on the future of social sciences has been established by the recently formed Academy of Learned Societies for the Social Sciences.

Spacy, man

Women are less likely than men to be eligible to apply for research grants provided by the Wellcome Trust and all government research councils -except for the Economic and Social Research Council - according to a long-awaited report. But it said when women did apply for grants they were as successful as male colleagues.

Universe

Africa cashes in

The Association of African Universities, which has more than 170 member institutions from 43 countries, has signalled support for charging tuition fees. The four-yearly meeting in Nairobi heard that institutions like Uganda's Makerere University had been able to raise staff salaries and revamp programmes after introducing fees. Universities on the continent face dire financial problems, aggravated by the spread of Aids, and many believe that free higher education cannot be sustained.

webTitle: Why depression is common among graduates

fields.headline: Reality blues
fields.standfirst: You've got your degree - so what next? For many the loss of structure is a passport to depression, says  Lyndsey Winship
fields.trailText: You've got your degree - so what next? For many the loss of structure is a passport to depression, says Lyndsey Winship
fields.body:
Depression among students is very well documented. From fresher stress to the pressure of finals, money worries, exhaustion, loneliness and coursework, the road is riddled with pitfalls. But leaving education doesn't mean leaving problems behind. Every year graduate depression strikes, and seems completely unexpected.

"It didn't occur to me that this was going to happen to me," says Melanie, who graduated with a first-class degree in psychology two years ago. "I think I went a bit crazy for a while . . . I didn't handle it very well. I felt adrift, with no direction after being so focused."

While one in four students suffers depression during their university years, there are no official figures for the post-graduation period. Mike Burton, of the Sussex University Counselling service, admits that this group "slips through the system". They become indivisible from any other adult facing major life transitions - even counsellors who work with students seem to be unaware of the problem. It is also quite possible that some graduates don't realise they are affected, as symptoms are not always as obvious as feeling miserable all the time. Feeling tired, restless or agitated, losing interest in life and becoming unable to enjoy anything, finding it hard to make decisions, having difficulty sleeping, avoiding people and losing self-confidence are some of depression's guises.

Saying goodbye to the familiar haven of education and the flexible but purposeful structure of university life can be a real shock to those who don't have a definite career plan. Nicola, 23, went straight to university from sixth-form college, then finished her English degree not knowing what she wanted to do with her life. She went to her parents' house for the summer, then picked up part-time work but wasn't happy. She became apathetic, couldn't get out of bed, lost her appetite and all her confidence: "The minute I was on my own I'd burst into tears. It didn't hit me until March that I was horrendously depressed," Nicola says.

It isn't just those graduates taking their first steps into the adult world who lose their footing. Melanie was 30 when she began her degree, after raising two children. She excelled at university and enjoyed her new identity. When she came out with a first she felt invincible. "I thought, 'I'm going to conquer the world' - that this was the start of something fantastic."

Her PhD proposal was accepted but she couldn't get funding, so, taking time off to look after her kids, she began to feel that she was back where she started. Lots of her friends, other mature students, also went back to doing the same thing they were doing before their degree, "not because they wanted to, but that was just the easiest thing to do". She had succumbed to the luxury of learning, and she and her friends all wanted to go back to it, to the active mind-set of constant discussion and discovery.

"When you're at university, you do a piece of work, hand it in, get a response," she says. "There's no other environment where you get that, that kind of validation all the time, those rewards." When she left she realised she didn't feel equipped to actually do anything. Nicola agrees: "It's all 'transferable skills', but you don't have any idea where to transfer them to!"

"I think those people who got themselves work before they left [university] were much better off," says Melanie. "You can go straight into work, you don't have that loss."

According to a 1998/99 census, 68.5% of students were employed six months after finishing their first degree. But the figures, collated by the Higher Education Statistics Agency, include part-time and voluntary work and make no distinction between career choices and stopgap jobs. Research from the Institute for Employment Studies shows that many graduates take two or more years to settle into "stable" employment, with one in three entering temporary or fixed-term contracts.

Even for those who walk into their dream jobs, the transition is not necessarily an easy one. Hannah, 22, was head-hunted to work for a record company in London and expected it to be hard work, but was less prepared for how it would radically change her life.

"You think life's hard when you're a student, then you get into the real world and discover what being skint really means," she says.

On top of the exhaustion of flat-hunting in London, the 12-hour days and the distance from her friends, Hannah found her idealism deflated. "University is for yourself, for your personal development. In the corporate world, no one cares about you."

After being encouraged to think independently at university, to compare ideologies, to criticise her own and other people's judgement, she found herself put into place as a cog of capitalism, working to make money for someone else and never being asked to engage her brain.

Mike Burton, a psychiatrist, sees this post-university period as just one of many major life events that can bring about unease and anxiety. "We're just not very well designed for large changes," Burton says. As post-university may be a time when many transitions happen at once, while also losing a support system of friends and tutors, it is unsurprising that this is a prime period for self-doubt.

"Vulnerable students are likely to be those who have unrealistic goals with little or no back-up," he says. Burton points to another contributing factor: the transition from the structured rituals of academic life to the relatively formless ordinary world of earning a living.

Surely this need not be an inevitable stumbling block? With so many students facing difficulties, is there anything being done to make the transition more seamless? Careers services do provide advice, resources and seminars to help students with their decision making, and new research projects are under way, aiming to help students recognise the skills they have learned and apply them in the workplace.

Although Nicola wishes her university could have prepared its students earlier for what lies ahead, she recognises that careers offices can only take so much responsibility. "It's getting out there and doing it that teaches you what you want to do," she now realises. Burton suggests arranging an exit interview with careers or counselling staff to talk through fears and hopes, but in most cases it is not until students have left that they realise theirvulnerability.

Higher education should equip adults for fruitful futures, but actually it only postpones responsibility and reality.

"Expectations are so high these days," says Patricia White of Depression Alliance. "With increasing competition, and spiralling debts, the pressure is endless, and for some this can turn into a depressive episode. If you think you might be suffering from depression, go to your GP. Choose some close friends or family to confide in and, most importantly, remember that it is not your fault. It is a medical condition and a very treatable one. When diagnosed early, recovery can be relatively quick and your quality of life doesn't have to deteriorate."

For further information, contact Depression Alliance on 020-7633 0557. The organisation's website address is: www.depressionalliance.org

webTitle: How government policy affects refugee academics

fields.headline: But what now?
fields.standfirst: Abdul Lalzad is an Afghan professor who, like many academic refugees, has found safety in Britain. Under Jack Straw's new strategy, says  Donald MacLeod, he might not have got this far
fields.trailText: Abdul Lalzad is an Afghan professor who, like many academic refugees, has found safety in Britain. Under Jack Straw's new strategy, says Donald MacLeod, he might not have got this far
fields.body:
Like most academics, Abdul Lalzad talks eagerly about his research. He is working on a way of using solar power to desalinate water cheaply - potentially a vast boon to his native Afghanistan and a swathe of countries across Asia, the Middle East and Africa which suffer from water shortages but no lack of sunshine.

But as he talks at his bench at South Bank University in London his eyes betray deep anxiety and sadness. There is sadness for the wreck of his country under a regime which has driven him out and destroyed the university he was proud of. But uppermost in his mind is whether his wife and their five children will be allowed to join him after more than two years apart. They were being interviewed in Pakistan that day by the British High Commission about a visa. "My mind is not here," he apologises.

The professor of engineering from Kabul is one of 27 people now being helped by the Council for Assisting Refugee Academics (Cara), a body which started in 1933 to help Jews and other victims of the Nazi purge of universities. The formation of what was then called the Academic Assistance Council was kick-started by a tumultuous meeting at the Albert Hall addressed by Albert Einstein. Today the centres of persecution have shifted via South Africa and Latin America to Iraq, Sudan, Ethiopia, Rwanda and Somalia, but the job of helping university teachers and researchers to pick themselves up after persecution and establish themselves in this country remains the same.

The climate of hatred and distrust of asylum seekers is perhaps even worse than in the 1930s, although over the years Britain's reward for sheltering scholars has been out of all proportion to the tiny investment - 18 Nobel prizewinners, 71 fellows of the Royal Society, 50 fellows of the British Academy.

The council campaigns on refugee issues and criticises what it sees as the worst excesses of government policy, such as the demeaning vouchers system. Its president, Sir Raymond Hoffenberg, who himself was a political exile from South Africa, has attacked the "wholly unacceptable" Immigration and Asylum Act and the current wave of bigotry at a time of unprecedented prosperity: "It is difficult to imagine the implications for the UK and the world had Karl Popper or Max Perutz - two of the scholars we supported - been dealt with in the demeaning way envisaged by the current legislation: in isolation from other scholars, dumped far from cen tres of learning and forced to live on benefits provided by vouchers."

But most of the council's work is practical: advice about the labyrinthine asylum and social security regulations, making contact with university departments where they might be welcome, small grants for fees and travel. Cara limits its scope to helping genuine academics but even for this small section of the overall refugee population it could do a lot more if it had more funds.

Professor Lalzad's case is typical. A specialist in thermal engineering with a Russian masters degree, he taught in the department of mechanical engineering at Kabul University. He had five textbooks and more than 30 published articles to his credit and had held senior university positions. When the victorious Taliban closed the university, he worked for the Red Cross, in charge of distributing thousands of tonnes of food to 40,000 widows and disabled people.

He was arrested, beaten with Kalashnikovs and thrown in prison on suspicion of giving information to anti-Taliban forces. The influence of the Red Cross got him released, but his life was in danger and he fled to Pakistan, where his wife and children were eventually able to follow.

He arrived at Heathrow in December 1998, to be grilled for hours by immigration officials who believed he was Pakistani because his English was so good. (It was the medium of instruction in his department.) Lalzad concedes that Pakistanis do try to enter the UK by claiming to be Afghan refugees, and is sure he would have been deported had he not produced his Red Cross identity card.

Then came a frustrating wait while his application for asylum was considered (it took 18 months) and he tried to get work. "I felt ashamed sitting at home. It is a morally bad way of living for someone with education and knowledge not to work." Letters to universities produced no result, though he was encouraged by a short course at the University of North London, where he made contacts. He was at last given a break at South Bank by the director of engineering research, Professor Tassos Karayiannis.

A grant from Cara is paying bench fees and for the purchase of a computer as Lalzad pursues a part-time PhD on his desalination research. At the moment he is doing mathematical modelling with the aim of building an experimental model of a solar-powered desalination plant.

Desalination technology is well advanced in the oil-rich Middle East states, but across a wide zone of northern Asia, the Middle East and North Africa there is a pressing need for small, cheap plants. The goal is a gadget consisting of a small box and a condenser.
