webTitle: The legacy of David Blunkett's Greenwich lecture of a year ago

fields.headline: Date with Destiny
fields.standfirst: A year ago, at Greenwich University, the education secretary announced a bright new global vision for higher learning. Stephen Court asks what the real legacy of that speech will be, and David Blunkett himself reflects
fields.trailText: A year ago, at Greenwich University, the education secretary announced a bright new global vision for higher learning. Stephen Court asks what the real legacy of that speech will be, and David Blunkett himself reflects
fields.body:
David Blunkett intended his speech 12 months ago at the University of Greenwich to be a landmark in the development of higher education in the UK. I think it will be, but not necessarily in the ways the secretary of state for education planned.

Foremost in Blunkett's mind appeared to be his concern that universities in the UK should not be left in an educational backwater by the tide of globalisation. Allied to this was the utilitarian theme of higher education at the productive heart of the knowledge economy. You had to wait quite a while before you heard specifics about other core Labour policies of social inclusion, access and diversity - or the importance of research and intellectual development.

Blunkett cast his introduction of undergraduate tuition fees and final abolition of the maintenance grant as a more progressive system of student support. But Scotland's return to a grant-and-loan system, and its scrapping of the up-front tuition fee in favour of a graduate endowment, suggests history will not view Blunkett's policies in such a positive light.

While the Robbins report in the 1960s set out four aims (not in any rank order) of higher education - instruction in skills necessary for employment; promotion of the powers of the mind; the advancement of learning; and transmission of "a common culture and common standards of citizenship" - Blunkett's vision at Greenwich seemed to be much narrower: universities are chiefly there to drive the economy.

He placed his speech in the context of landmarks such as the Robbins report and Tony Crosland's speech in 1965 on the development of the polytechnics - a "defining moment for higher education". Blunkett was caustic about the Conservatives' treatment of higher education in the eighties and the nineties. Yet it was under Kenneth Baker that the sector began huge expansion in student numbers, and the transformation from an elite to a mass system of higher education.

Blunkett's speech launched two initiatives: the e-university and two-year foundation degrees. These reflect concerns about globalisation and the knowledge economy, in line with the maxim "think globally, act locally".

The plan is that the e-university will support UK universities and other partners in the development and delivery of online programmes, and provide a gateway to learning materials and services for learners, such as tutorial support and student advice. Government support for a UK-wide online university would give the higher education sector the strength to compete internationally with the likes of the University of Phoenix, corporate universities and leading American US institutions such as MIT.

The aim is for the e-university to be online by 2002. Meanwhile, the English higher education funding council is shortlisting private sector partners, selecting members of the crucial academic quality committee and chewing over responses from institutions to its business model.

Some institutions, including those with their own plans for international online collaborations, have been critical. But others have thrown themselves into the venture. Academic leaders from universities such as York, Southampton, London, Kent, Cardiff, Manchester Metropolitan and Edinburgh have contributed to the project's steering group. But the presence of international big-hitters such as Oxford, Cambridge, University College London and Imperial College in the group would have strengthened the venture.

The foundation degrees are to help plug the UK's intermediate skills gap - and help meet the government's target of 50% of 18-30-year-olds participating in higher education by 2010, widening access at the same time. The consortium-based approach involving further and higher education and employers could be a very positive development.

The extent to which bids for the prototype courses for next year were oversubscribed shows the enthusiasm of the sector. But doubts remain about the real demand from employers for sub-degree qualifications, the academic rigour of the courses, and whether two years will be enough to develop knowledge and skills.

What will Blunkett's legacy be? If the Greenwich speech is a defining moment in the history of higher education, for me it will be in terms of crystallising how the state views universities: as engines of the economy.

I think the e-university initiative is an exciting venture: an example of the government being entrepreneurial on behalf of higher education. And if foundation degrees can combine vocational focus with academic rigour then they could meet an important need in the parts of the economy. But I doubt if either project will have the significance of the post-Robbins university expansion, or the development of Crosland's polytechnics - or the development of mass higher education under Baker, John MacGregor (remember him?) and Ken Clarke.

Stephen Court, senior research officer at the Association of University Teachers, is writing in a personal capacity.

David Blunkett: substantial strides

Much has happened since my Greenwich lecture. Globalisation continues to reshape our universities. Alliances have grown: Oxford, Princeton, Stanford and Yale have recently formed a virtual college for lifelong learning; Leeds, Sheffield, Southampton and York universities have announced a partnership with California, Pennsylvania, Washington and Wisconsin-Madison universities.The prime minister's ambition that we increase recruitment of international students is also being met.

We have pressed ahead with new, vocationally-orientated foundation degrees. These degrees are being designed with employers, providing students with the mix of specialist knowledge, wider skills and academic underpinning that the labour market demands. They will form a central thrust of the expansion of higher education. Last November, the Higher Education Funding Council announced the 21 consortia of universities and colleges that will be offering the prototype degrees for the coming academic year in areas such as e-commerce, internet computing, chemical technology, property and construction.

Online learning is central to the future of higher education. To ensure that UK universities can compete effectively in the global online learning market, I announced at Greenwich the creation of an e-universities venture - a partnership between higher education and the private sector to provide global online opportunities. The Higher Education Funding Council for England has made substantial progress and it is due to be launched next year.

Sir Martin Harris has led a fundamental review of higher education careers advice and guidance, which will lead to the improvements I called for at Greenwich. Likewise, we will bring forward proposals for expanding work experience opportunities, just as we have done for student volunteering.

My speech also covered the vital issue of widening access to higher education. I have since announced a new £150m access programme, the Excellence Challenge. This will create a coherent structure of support for bright young people from disadvantaged backgrounds who have the potential to enter higher education. It will provide summer schools, master classes, mentoring by undergraduates, financial incentives and better information and advice for young people from 13 onwards. Universities will also receive £12m a year for recruitment officers, admissions training and so on, in addition to existing funds for widening participation.

These new resources are part of nearly £1bn extra for higher education by 2003-4. Funding per student will increase for the first time in well over a decade the first time next year, and expansion will be fully funded thereafter. Funding for research, business and community outreach, and capital facilities will also rise significantly. New resources for pay - rising to £170m in 2003-04 - have also been announced, so that high-quality staff can be recruited and retained. In total, funding from the Higher Education Funding Council for England will have increased by £1.7 billion or 18% in real terms over the six years to 2003/4.

Taken together, we have made substantial strides towards meeting the challenges I identified at Greenwich. In the coming years, this coherent programme will deliver the real improvements needed, in stark contrast to the uncosted and unfunded schemes of our political opponents.

David Blunkett is education and employment secretary

webTitle: Labour's attempt to bury the fees issue alarms vice-chancellors

fields.headline: Fees: the last word?
fields.standfirst: Labour's attempt to bury the fees issue alarms vice-chancellors, warns  Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Labour's attempt to bury the fees issue alarms vice-chancellors, warns Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
University leaders have vowed to keep the prospect of top-up fees alive, despite a decision by the Labour government to rule them out if re-elected for a second term.

In a move designed to reassure voters in the run-up to the next General Election that Labour opposes extra university fees, education secretary David Blunkett last week told MPs that "there will be no levying of top-up fees if we win the next election."

The surprise statement came after Blunkett had spoken directly to the prime minister, Tony Blair, to agree the new policy, following concerns that continuing speculation over fees could damage Labour during a re-election campaign. The party's electoral drive continues this week with two policy papers on education and the knowledge economy.

The introduction of the current capped tuition fees - a maximum of £1,050 a year for students - is still seen by many advisers as one of the bravest decisions made by the Labour government during its first term.

But the ruling out of any extra private contributions from students puts the government on a collision course with universities, which are reviewing fees and other funding options for the sector.

Ironically it was Blunkett's invitation a year ago to have a frank and full discussion on university funding in the next parliament that led to the review in the first place. And his comment that top-up fees would not be allowed while he was education secretary prompted the widely held belief that fees were inevitable when he moved to a different government post after an election.

Only this month Nottingham University's vice-chancellor, Sir Colin Campbell, argued that the only op tion open to the government was to allow institutions to charge richer students extra fees. Aston University recently decided to include proposals for top-up fees in its five-year plan.

University heads now say they will go on with the funding review, which includes proposals for fees, irrespective of the education secretary's comments. An initial report is due next month, and a conference is being organised for early April.

The government wants universities to expand student numbers and house world-class research groups, but it is unwilling to channel more public funds into the sector. If universities cannot generate extra money by charging richer students more fees, the question is where else will they find new funds?

"It's clear the sector needs much more support to be able to bring in the extra students the government wants to see in our universities," said Diana Warwick, chief executive of Universities UK. "If higher contributions from students or graduates are ruled out, more public funding will be necessary in the future."

Labour officials point to the recent injection of public funds into the academic sector, which next year will see the funding per student rise in real terms for the first time in 15 years. Yet even the most conservative estimates by vice-chancellors show that an extra £1bn every year over the next decade is needed on top of existing budgets.

Universities, meanwhile, also expressed disappointment over last week's announcement by Tony Blair that 27 "elite" English universities, including Oxford and Cambridge, are to receive £18m over three years to attract more state-school pupils. The winners were unveiled as part of a pre-election promise to build a "meritocratic society in which social barriers are dismantled". Yet the scheme has only caused divisiveness in the academic world.

The universities, which will receive about £3,000 a year for every new state-school student, were chosen because they enrol less than 80% of state pupils.

But as MPs on the Commons education committee recently pointed out, the money in effect rewards failure in widening access rather than success. Many of the new universities, who have strong records in attracting students from poor backgrounds, complain about not getting enough government support for their efforts.

Geoffrey Copland, vice-chancellor of the University of Westminster and convenor of the Coalition of Modern Universities, said students who did not get into the 27 selected institutions would think themselves failures.

"It's clear the sector needs much more support to be able to bring in the extra students the government wants to see in our universities," said Diana Warwick, chief executive of Universities UK. "If higher contributions from students or graduates are ruled out, more public funding will be necessary in the future." Labour officials point to the recent injection of public funds into the academic sector, which next year will see the funding per student rise in real terms for the first time in 15 years. Yet even the most conservative estimates by vice-chancellors show that an extra £1bn every year over the next decade is needed on top of existing budgets. Universities, meanwhile, also expressed disappointment over last week's announcement by Tony Blair that 27 "elite" English universities, including Oxford and Cambridge, are to receive £18m over three years to attract more state-school pupils. The winners were unveiled as part of a pre-election promise to build a "meritocratic society in which social barriers are dismantled". Yet the scheme has only caused divisiveness in the academic world. The universities, which will receive about £3,000 a year for every new state-school student, were chosen because they enrol less than 80% of state pupils. But as MPs on the Commons education committee recently pointed out, the money in effect rewards failure in widening access rather than success. Many of the new universities, who have strong records in attracting students from poor backgrounds, complain about not getting enough government support for their efforts. Geoffrey Copland, vice-chancellor of the University of Westminster and convenor of the Coalition of Modern Universities, said students who did not get into the 27 selected institutions would think themselves failures.

webTitle: Gladiator and Crouching Tiger lead race for Oscars

fields.headline: Gladiator and Crouching Tiger lead race for Oscars
fields.trailText: The nominations for this year's Academy Awards put Gladiator, Traffic, Erin Brockovich and Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon at the front of the race for Oscar glory
fields.body:
The nominations for the 73rd annual Academy Awards were announced at 5.38am Pacific time (1.38pm GMT) by Academy president Robert Rehme and actress Kathy Bates (an Oscar winner herself for 1990's Misery). In keeping with the Oscar tradition the announcement took the form of a swift and sober Beverly Hills press call - a spartan contrast, one assumes, to the lavish ceremony that will follow on March 25.

There were few major surprises in the list of nominees. As expected, Gladiator leads the hunt with 12 nominations, closely followed by Ang Lee's dark-horse Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (10 nominations). The award for Best Film will be fought out between Chocolat, Erin Brockovich, Crouching Tiger, Gladiator and Traffic.

The one unexpected guest in the Best Actor category was Spanish star Javier Bardem (nominated for Before Night Falls). The other contenders are Russell Crowe (for Gladiator), Tom Hanks (for Cast Away), Ed Harris (Pollock) and Geoffrey Rush (Quills).

The nominees for Best Actress are Joan Allen (The Contender), Juliette Binoche (Chocolat), Ellen Burstyn (Requiem for a Dream), Laura Linney (You Can Count on Me) and heavy favourite Julia Roberts (Erin Brockovich).

The award for Best Director will go to either Ridley Scott (Gladiator), Ang Lee (for Crouching Tiger), Britain's Stephen Daldry (for Billy Elliot) or Steven Soderbergh who has been nominated for both Traffic and Erin Brockovich.

The great wild cards of this year's awards are thus confirmed as Soderbergh, who may yet wind up splitting the votes in both the Best Film and Best Director categories and so come away with nothing, and Crouching Tiger. Ang Lee's epic is nominated for both Best Film and Best Foreign Language Film. If Ang Lee's Mandarin film fails to snare the coveted Best Film Oscar, insiders predict it will take the other as a consolation prize.

webTitle: Anger over two-tier school plan

fields.headline: Anger over two-tier school plan
fields.standfirst: Education site
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday heralded a "post-comprehensive" era of secondary education that will require each school to develop a distinct ethos and deliver learning tailor-made for each pupil. "The day of the bog-standard comprehensive is over," his official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday heralded a "post-comprehensive" era of secondary education that will require each school to develop a distinct ethos and deliver learning tailor-made for each pupil. "The day of the bog-standard comprehensive is over," his official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said.

Launching a five-year plan for the sector, the prime minister tried to write off 40 years of the comprehensive system which, he said, had too often held back individual students.

Mr Blair set out Labour's key proposals for what he insisted would still be his priority in a second term. With polls showing continued high approval ratings for his record on education, he will be keen to fight the election on that ground.

In switching his focus from primary to secondary schools, Mr Blair attempted to steer a middle course between Labour ideals of old and what he characterised as the "free for all" of the Tories' proposals.

But the government's proposals, contained in a green paper, received a lukewarm response from unions and heavy criticism from the Liberal Democrats, who said David Blunkett could go down in history for being the education secretary who introduced the most selective schools.

Up to one in 10 pupils can be selected in the government's proposed specialist schools, which will increase from 600 to 1,500 by 2006 - 46% of all secondary schools in England. Headteachers said the plans could lead to a two-tier system, dividing specialist schools from the rest. "Diversity must become the norm, not the exception," Mr Blair told an audience of headteachers at Downing Street.

The previous grammar/secondary modern split had been "rigid and unfair". But in comprehensives, the need to tailor provision to individuals often took second place, Mr Blair said.

"Inclusion, a good principle, became an end in itself, rather than the means to identify and provide better for the talents of each individual pupil."

Fewer than half of 16-year-olds achieved five or more good GCSEs and there were "unacceptably high" numbers of pupils leaving with no qualifications, Mr Blair said. Only six out of 10 pupils at age 14 achieved the standards expected of them in English, maths and science.

"Our best schools have moved decisively to a post-comprehensive argument. They take inclusion and equality of opportunity for granted, but are highly flexible in the ways they meet them. They are not afraid to be different or distinct."

Phil Willis, the Liberal Democrat education spokesman, said: "Blunkett's green paper signals the end of the comprehensive system. It will mean selection and division for our children with no increase in standards."

For the Tories, Theresa May said Labour had adopted the rhetoric of the Conservative free schools plan.

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "I am very disappointed... there remains a substantial risk that this programme will create a two-tier system of comprehensive schools."

But Peter Smith, general secretary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, said: "David Blunkett is right to argue that we need to work hard at identifying children's natural talents and aptitudes earlier, rather than leave it to chance. That's not the same as reinforcing selection and those who argue that are Jurassic scaremongers."

The government is to make it easier for religious schools to join the state sector by reducing the amount they have to contribute to capital spending projects.

Reinforcing the themes of raising standards, promoting diversity and achieving results, Mr Blunkett announced measures designed to challenge bright children and tackle low achievement.

Worried about those pupiIs who "mark time" in the early years of secondary school, the government will pilot plans for pupils to take their key stage three tests after two years, at 13.

Clever children will be encouraged to take key stage tests and GCSEs early if they are ready. The government will open a "national centre for gifted and talented youth" to provide summer schools for bright secondary pupils, modelled on a centre in Baltimore in the US. This could mean lectures over the internet from PhD students, or from professors in US universities.

The green paper promised to enhance the "earned autonomy" of successful schools, giving them greater freedom over their curriculum, budgets, and pay and conditions for staff. The prime minister said no school could succeed without a good headteacher.

At the other end of the scale, Mr Blunkett sounded the death knell for his beleaguered "fresh start" policy for turning round failing schools. Instead of relying on intervention by Whitehall and local authorities, the preferred option would be private or voluntary organisations (which could include other state or private schools) being brought in to improve them.

In primary schools, Mr Blunkett announced consultation on higher targets for 11-year-olds - 85% to reach at least level four and 35% to reach level five in English and maths.

"Over time", every child would have the opportunity to learn a musical instrument.

webTitle: Ministers pledge to raise schools' standards

fields.headline: Ministers pledge to raise standards
fields.standfirst:
Higher achievement for all, but stress also on identifying talent and developing choice and diversity

Education site
fields.trailText: The government yesterday pledged to "empower" individual pupils and schools in a radical shake-up of secondary schools, which ministers hope will dramatically raise standards in the 21st century.
fields.body:
The government yesterday pledged to "empower" individual pupils and schools in a radical shake-up of secondary schools, which ministers hope will dramatically raise standards in the 21st century.

Accepting that the educational standards of 11- to 14-year-olds are not high enough and that teaching is poor, Labour has set out a wide range of measures in its green paper, Schools: Building on Success. They are designed to raise educational expectation and achievement by building on significant achievements made in the primary sector.

The paper focuses on the secondary sector, but also covers early years and primary schools, building up to the transition to secondary schools and on to higher education or the jobs market. Ministers want education where "every pupil is good at all the basics, and striving for excellence in the areas of their greatest strength; every school is good at all the basics and excellent at much more, and every school has a distinct mission, ethos and character". The paper goes out for a four-month consultation. Among the key measures are:

Targets for primary pupils

Labour is on course to hit key targets for English and maths for 11-year-olds - 80% will achieve the standard set for their age (level 4 or above) in English, and 75% in mathematics, in the national curriculum (or so-called SATs) tests by 2002. But yesterday the government said that, amid clear evidence its literacy hour and daily maths lesson were working, it was time to raise the targets further. It wants 85% of 11-year-olds to achieve the standard for their age in English and in maths, and 35% to achieve the advanced level 5 in each subject. The latter appears to be recognition of many headteachers' complaints that top marks such as level 5 or 6 are not officially recognised, and that there was no incentive to aim for the highest marks.

Ballet and music lessons

One challenge is to ensure that a pupil's individual talents are fostered and weaknesses addressed through a broader curriculum and better support. The national curriculum will remain a basic entitlement, but ministers want all children to have greater access to extra-curricular activities and after-school clubs, regardless of social background or family income. At present 97% of primaries provide some extra-curricular support and seven out of 10 increased their provision between 1998 and 2000. Ministers wish that in time every primary child has the opportunity to learn a musical instrument, take up ballet, or try out one of a range of sports.

Secondary school standards

The government has introduced measures to improve the transition between primary and secondary, where there is evidence of a dip in ability. Summer schools have helped to ensure continuity of learning. Now proposals have been drawn up for a strategy to inject pace and drive up standards in the first years of secondary school. It centres on new targets, catch-up lessons for 12-year-olds who have fallen behind, and better teaching for 11- to 14-year-olds, backed up with £82m in 2001/02. The government states, quite bluntly, that "standards for pupils aged 11-14 are not high enough", with teaching generally of a lesser quality. There is evidence of falling motivation and rising disaffection - largely responsible for creating the discipline problems highlighted in Ofsted's annual report last week.

Ministers are to consult on reducing the time to reach assessment and tests at 14 (so-called key stage three) from three to two years from 2004. This would stop pupils "marking time" in the early years of secondary while adjusting to the new environment. It would also identify pupils ready to take GCSE examinations a year early, with some pupils also given the chance to do key stage three tests early.

National academy for talented youth

An academy for the brightest youngsters in England is to be created. The national centre for gifted and talented youth will be modelled on the US centre for talented youth at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, Maryland, which helps more than 10,000 children each year across the United States. It offers individualised programmes taught by top professionals in three-week summer programmes on campuses each year, typically subjects not offered in the classroom - paleobiology, geopolitics, astronomy and logic.

Although the UK centre would have a headquarters, its task will be to promote provision for gifted children in schools and establish intensive summer schools. Its first job will be to pilot university-based summer schools for young people with exceptional talent in one or more subjects. These will typically be among the 5% to 10% identified by their schools as "gifted and talented".

External sponsors

Ministers want to change the law to allow private sector and other external sponsors to take over schools that fail. The fresh start scheme, whereby schools reopen under a new name with new staff and with the help of government cash, has been fraught with difficulties. The government hopes instead to entice external sponsors such as businesses and voluntary groups to take over failing or under-performing schools - and even successful schools. Ministers hope other schools or educational partners, including the churches and even private schools, might want to get involved in running of schools, on a contract of say five to seven years with renewal subject to performance.

The successful model for this is Kings school near Guildford in Surrey - the former failing Kings Manor school - taken over by a private sector partnership, '3Es', headed by Kingshurst city technology college in Solihull in the West Midlands. But the original takeover was the subject of a local row, with parents uniting against what they saw as the first full privatisation of a state school in the UK.

Specialist and beacon schools

The government wants nearly half all secondary schools specialising by 2006. Part involves creating specialisms in engineering, science, and business and enterprise, alongside the existing categories of technology, arts, languages, and sports. There are 536 specialist schools: 313 technology colleges, 99 language colleges, 67 sports colleges, and 57 arts colleges.

The government has already signalled plans to allow further colleges to specialise from next September, bringing the total to 650. Previous plans anticipated 1,000 by September 2004, and the new announcement expands this to 1,500 by 2006. A new status is to be given to some high-performing specialist schools - advanced specialist schools - with emphasis on teacher and leadership training. Specialist schools qualify for extra funding and are allowed to select up to 10% of pupils according to aptitude.

Ministers deny the expansion will lead to a two-tier comprehensive system. Instead they say some of the money given to specialist schools is dependent on sharing "good practice" with neighbouring schools. There are also plans to expand "beacon" schools which have demonstrated particularly good practice. By September 2001 there will be 2,000 beacon schools, including some 250 at secondary level. The government wants to nearly double the latter in the longer term.

Religious and single faith schools

Labour has helped create more schools supported by the churches and other major faiths. Some 560 secondaries are provided by the Anglican or the Catholic churches. For the first time, Muslim, Sikh and Greek Orthodox schools have been brought inside the state system, and given voluntary-aided status and government funding. Ministers wish to welcome more such schools, and those provided by other voluntary and community groups, where there is local demand.

There are numerous applications from other minority faith schools in the pipeline, including the first Islamic secondary in Birmingham due to be considered this week. But the government is to change capital funding to encourage more to apply: the contribution required from the church or faith has been reduced from 15% to 10%.

Teacher recruitment and retention

As expected, the paper sets out proposals to recruit and retain entrants to the profession. In the shortage subjects of maths, science, languages, technology and English, the next three years' intake will have their student loan repaid over a period of 10 years, provided they remain teaching in the state sector - worth £10,000 to a typical graduate.

Undergraduates on traditional academic degrees will be able to take education modules and so gain part of a teaching qualification while an undergraduate. In addition, all undergraduates would have the opportunity of a placement as a teaching assistant. Other measures include on the job training in high-cost areas and incentives for those with teaching qualifications to return.

Changing face of the next generation

 Every primary school child to be entitled to learn a musical instrument and take up ballet

 Higher targets for tests at age 11

 Key stage three tests to be taken at age 13 rather than at 14

 Bright students to take GCSEs early

 Vocational GCSEs to be available for those who want them

 Companies and voluntary organisations to support failing schools

 More specialist schools (1,500 by 2006) with new subject specialisms in engineering, science and business

 More beacon schools to spread best practice, and more city academies in areas of underachievement

 Extra support for religious schools, with government contributions for capital spending increasing from 85% to 90%

 New teachers in shortage subjects to have their loans written off

 New education modules in degree courses to give undergraduates a taste of teaching

The national curriculum will remain a basic entitlement, but ministers want all children to have greater access to extra-curricular activities and after-school clubs, regardless of social background or family income. At present 97% of primaries provide some extra-curricular support and seven out of 10 increased their provision between 1998 and 2000. Ministers wish that in time every primary child has the opportunity to learn a musical instrument, take up ballet, or try out one of a range of sports. Secondary school standards The government has introduced measures to improve the transition between primary and secondary, where there is evidence of a dip in ability. Summer schools have helped to ensure continuity of learning. Now proposals have been drawn up for a strategy to inject pace and drive up standards in the first years of secondary school. It centres on new targets, catch-up lessons for 12-year-olds who have fallen behind, and better teaching for 11- to 14-year-olds, backed up with £82m in 2001/02. The government states, quite bluntly, that "standards for pupils aged 11-14 are not high enough", with teaching generally of a lesser quality. There is evidence of falling motivation and rising disaffection - largely responsible for creating the discipline problems highlighted in Ofsted's annual report last week. Ministers are to consult on reducing the time to reach assessment and tests at 14 (so-called key stage three) from three to two years from 2004. This would stop pupils "marking time" in the early years of secondary while adjusting to the new environment. It would also identify pupils ready to take GCSE examinations a year early, with some pupils also given the chance to do key stage three tests early. National academy for talented youth An academy for the brightest youngsters in England is to be created. The national centre for gifted and talented youth will be modelled on the US centre for talented youth at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, Maryland, which helps more than 10,000 children each year across the United States. It offers individualised programmes taught by top professionals in three-week summer programmes on campuses each year, typically subjects not offered in the classroom - paleobiology, geopolitics, astronomy and logic. Although the UK centre would have a headquarters, its task will be to promote provision for gifted children in schools and establish intensive summer schools. Its first job will be to pilot university-based summer schools for young people with exceptional talent in one or more subjects. These will typically be among the 5% to 10% identified by their schools as "gifted and talented". External sponsors Ministers want to change the law to allow private sector and other external sponsors to take over schools that fail. The fresh start scheme, whereby schools reopen under a new name with new staff and with the help of government cash, has been fraught with difficulties. The government hopes instead to entice external sponsors such as businesses and voluntary groups to take over failing or under-performing schools - and even successful schools. Ministers hope other schools or educational partners, including the churches and even private schools, might want to get involved in running of schools, on a contract of say five to seven years with renewal subject to performance. The successful model for this is Kings school near Guildford in Surrey - the former failing Kings Manor school - taken over by a private sector partnership, '3Es', headed by Kingshurst city technology college in Solihull in the West Midlands. But the original takeover was the subject of a local row, with parents uniting against what they saw as the first full privatisation of a state school in the UK. Specialist and beacon schools The government wants nearly half all secondary schools specialising by 2006. Part involves creating specialisms in engineering, science, and business and enterprise, alongside the existing categories of technology, arts, languages, and sports. There are 536 specialist schools: 313 technology colleges, 99 language colleges, 67 sports colleges, and 57 arts colleges. The government has already signalled plans to allow further colleges to specialise from next September, bringing the total to 650. Previous plans anticipated 1,000 by September 2004, and the new announcement expands this to 1,500 by 2006. A new status is to be given to some high-performing specialist schools - advanced specialist schools - with emphasis on teacher and leadership training. Specialist schools qualify for extra funding and are allowed to select up to 10% of pupils according to aptitude. Ministers deny the expansion will lead to a two-tier comprehensive system. Instead they say some of the money given to specialist schools is dependent on sharing "good practice" with neighbouring schools. There are also plans to expand "beacon" schools which have demonstrated particularly good practice. By September 2001 there will be 2,000 beacon schools, including some 250 at secondary level. The government wants to nearly double the latter in the longer term. Religious and single faith schools Labour has helped create more schools supported by the churches and other major faiths. Some 560 secondaries are provided by the Anglican or the Catholic churches. For the first time, Muslim, Sikh and Greek Orthodox schools have been brought inside the state system, and given voluntary-aided status and government funding. Ministers wish to welcome more such schools, and those provided by other voluntary and community groups, where there is local demand. There are numerous applications from other minority faith schools in the pipeline, including the first Islamic secondary in Birmingham due to be considered this week. But the government is to change capital funding to encourage more to apply: the contribution required from the church or faith has been reduced from 15% to 10%. Teacher recruitment and retention As expected, the paper sets out proposals to recruit and retain entrants to the profession. In the shortage subjects of maths, science, languages, technology and English, the next three years' intake will have their student loan repaid over a period of 10 years, provided they remain teaching in the state sector - worth £10,000 to a typical graduate. Undergraduates on traditional academic degrees will be able to take education modules and so gain part of a teaching qualification while an undergraduate. In addition, all undergraduates would have the opportunity of a placement as a teaching assistant. Other measures include on the job training in high-cost areas and incentives for those with teaching qualifications to return. Changing face of the next generation  Every primary school child to be entitled to learn a musical instrument and take up ballet  Higher targets for tests at age 11  Key stage three tests to be taken at age 13 rather than at 14  Bright students to take GCSEs early  Vocational GCSEs to be available for those who want them  Companies and voluntary organisations to support failing schools  More specialist schools (1,500 by 2006) with new subject specialisms in engineering, science and business  More beacon schools to spread best practice, and more city academies in areas of underachievement  Extra support for religious schools, with government contributions for capital spending increasing from 85% to 90%  New teachers in shortage subjects to have their loans written off  New education modules in degree courses to give undergraduates a taste of teaching Useful links The green paper in full (pdf file) DfEE Building on Success site

fields.headline: CD-rom reviews
fields.trailText: The Era of the Second World War | Thomas the Clown
fields.body:
The Era of the Second World War
(AVP, £69 + VAT)
Age 11+ yrs

This title supports KS3 history with a package that offers children the opportunity to learn about the second world war and to research through period materials. Different media are well integrated, with excellent pictures and supporting spoken text. Children find it an easy program to navigate, thanks to an excellent screen interface and clear icons. One popular feature is the guided tour through modules, such as The Home Front - an audio tour through the chronology of the period. This interactive encyclopaedia offers excellent content and also encourages research skills.

Thomas the Clown
(Logotron, £23 + vat. Tel: 01223 425558, www.logo.com)
Age: KS1

This package offers five activities to support early mathematical problem-solving: colour and shape recognition, matching, sequencing and basic programming. The software supports the user with a spoken introduction to each activity, with reiteration possible by clicking on the screen. Young children find it easy and rewarding. They need to listen carefully - an excellent skill in itself - as there are no written instructions. Children can work independently, the only ICT skills required being click and point. With progressive levels of difficulty, there is plenty here to stretch all children.

You can read full evaluations of these programs at www.teem.org.uk

webTitle: If you ask me...

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: For about two years I have missed a lot of school because of depression. Since I don't think I'm ready, I have decided not to do my GCSEs this year. I've found out that if I want to sit exams later I need to register with an exam centre, but I don't know how to get in touch with one. Can you advise me?
fields.trailText: Leading experts advise on your problems
fields.body:
I do hope your school is giving you lots of support, because that's what you need right now. And I think you've made a very sensible decision not to take your GCSEs at the moment, because if you go into them feeling under pressure, you're very likely to feel the pressure all the more.

One thing you might think about, though, is that you don't have to take all your GCSEs in one go. Maybe there are some subjects you are particularly good at or find less stressful than others - if so, you could consider taking two or three instead of the seven or eight you were maybe intending to take. Passing these exams would be a real confidence boost, and would give you a real "can do" attitude for continuing with your GCSEs, if that's what you want to do, the following year.

If you decide you want to do your GCSEs once you've left school I don't think you'll find any problems - in most areas you will find colleges and schools tend to do the same boards, so you should find a college that follows the same board as your school.

If you want to do your GCSEs right after leaving school, your school might let you use them just as an examination centre - you can ask them. Otherwise, most higher education colleges are centres for GCSEs, so don't worry about needing to register with an examination centre as your college or school will do this for you.

Remember that you shouldn't have a problem picking up GCSEs in later life. The government is very keen on lifelong learning, and you'll have every possibility of carrying on if you want to.

George Turnbull
The Assessment and Qualifications Alliance, exam board for GCSEs and A-levels

Course work at your stage of life is stressful, and it's well known that the pressures do get to a lot of teenagers. I think it's important to set yourself some goals: maybe it's going to be an NVQ, or maybe a smaller number of GCSEs than you'd envisaged.

Most teenagers have times of feeling low - one of the things that can help is to keep in touch with one or two friends. If you're not feeling up to going out, talk to them on the phone, or invite them over to see you. If you can, try to talk a bit about how you feel to one or other of your parents, or perhaps to a brother or sister.

It's definitely going to help you to concentrate on what you're good at. Staying at school but reducing your academic aims will have the big advantage of keeping you in touch with your friends - if you're thinking of studying at home, you should bear in mind that although there would be pros and cons, it could be quite lonely.

Don't forget to build "fun" activities into your life too: make sure you have time to go out shopping with your friends, to go to the cinema, to have coffee and to go swimming or do some other exercise.

You might find it helpful to talk to a professional, for example a counsellor or a clinical psychologist. If you think this would help, ask your GP for a referral. Above all, be optimistic that you will get through this difficult time in your life and that things will all turn out OK.

Dr Hugh Koch
Chartered clinical psychologist

You've had a lot to deal with over the last few months, and you've taken a very mature approach. You're clearly a sensible and conscientious young person, and that's a very positive start.

I'd say if you have a reasonable expectation of doing well academically, it's probably going to be advisable to concentrate on a small number of core subjects - English, maths, science - or perhaps a couple of subjects you really enjoy.

If you have a really strong career path in mind, then it might be worth looking at an NVQ course in that area. But you do need to take care in terms of what level of NVQ you're embarking on - the higher the level, the more academic they become and it might defeat the object if you find yourself very pressurised by this course.

What you really need is to talk things through with someone you know and trust.

My gut instinct is that you'd protect your future better if you opted for the smaller number of GCSEs initially, so that later you could either pick up on your academic studies or move on to an NVQ.

David Scott
Head of Calder High School in Mytholmroyd, West Yorks

Coming next

My daughter has been offered a place at an excellent secondary school. As we are Muslim I have asked if she would be allowed to wear a headscarf. The reply was no. Can they discriminate against my daughter in this way?

Do you have a problem with your child's education? Is something bothering you about his or her school? Each week we ask leading experts to advise on a specific issue. webTitle: Letters

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Education letters
fields.body:
Home benefits

I think that the writer of the "Wrong side of the tracks" letter (Feb 6) misses the point of Melissa Benn's realisation that she was privileged. Her education at a comprehensive school made her realise that her home background gave her advantages. The pleasure gained from success in the 11+ examination is a very different experience.

Incidentally, was this the only letter sent in? Surely there must have been messages of support for Melissa's and her parents' views on comprehensive schools. I certainly have happy memories of the days when schemes for reorganising schools into a comprehensive system had the guiding principle of "parity of esteem". I think the person in charge at the time was called Shirley Williams.

S. Lupton
Prestwich, Manchester

Let me be a teacher

Julie Taylor (Letters, Feb 6) may have unwittingly stumbled on an excellent idea for teacher recruitment. To work three days, be able to pay for childcare and still have £300 per month seems quite attractive to me. I, and many of my friends, count ourselves lucky to just cover childcare and keep ourselves in the job market. Where's my application form?

S. Walker
Oxfordshire

Comp confusion

The Campaign for State Education is to be congratulated on its comprehensive school role model campaign (Class Notes, Education, Feb 6).

It must, however, get its facts right. There are nowhere near 90% of our pupils in comprehensive schools. In its other campaign on grammar school ballots, CASE itself argues that the remaining grammar schools and their secondary moderns comprise some 20% of schools. That takes us down to 80% in "comprehensives". But that fails to consider private schools, which educate another 8% of our most able children and also create secondary moderns. When you add to these the rash of other selective schools that have been created by this and the previous government, genuine comprehensives may not reach the 50% mark. DfEE figures claim 81% of our schools are comprehensive, 9% private, 4% grammar and, nonsensically, 2.5% secondary moderns!

However, it can still be said that in spite of the success of the selective lobby in recovering ground from around 1980 onwards, the comprehensive revolution has had a tremendous impact on raising standards and changing attitudes.

What we desperately need is some honesty in this matter, including a clear definition of the terms "comprehensive" and "secondary modern" and their strict application, to clarify our thinking and ensure that parents are not misled.

Tony P. Mitchell
Bedfordshire

Research rules

The Education Guardian of Jan 30 contained two apparently unconnected items: "Big Boys' Rules", discussing discontent among many Cambridge University staff, and "Shambles? Shame on you", about an inadequately prepared exam paper. In fact, both articles reflect the equivocal attitude of government and many academics to the role of the higher education system: it is not clear whether its purpose is to research or to teach.

At my own university we are expected to teach, to research and to undertake some administration, but promotion is more easily achievable by those who concentrate solely on research.

The overall message is that whilst you are supposed to work in three areas, in reality you need work well in only one. So it is not surprising that many university staff feel undervalued and that examination papers may be poorly presented.

Name and address supplied

Affirmative action

I was horrified by Alderman's opinion (Higher, Feb 6) but I suppose exposing an extreme viewpoint (more common in the US than here) will at least revive this argument, and maybe enlighten a few people. His opinion is smug, self-satisfied and paternalistic, and fails on many points.

First, if so-called ethnic minorities are underrepresented in UK academic posts, that in itself proves that selection methods are unfair. Or is he arguing that these minorities are less academically able? That is a dangerous road to go down! If selection methods are unfair, they need to be changed. And that will mean a lessening in numbers of white academics. And that is why there is so much opposition to positive discrimination - or affirmative action, as it is called in the US.

If people with skins other than white are encouraged to gain academic posts, that will increase the standards of academic teaching, not lower them.

Susan Gibb
Dulverton, Somerset

Guilt over recruitment

I was pleased to see in your report ("Don't count on us", Higher, Feb 6) that Dr Marshall of the ESRC intends to take action on the desperate problems we have in recruiting numerate people to work in the social sciences. However, when I read this, I also felt a sense of guilt, as a numerate medical sociologist who does not do any undergradute or junior postgraduate teaching.

I wonder how far my own experience of trying and failing to get a teaching post in a British university might apply to other people in my position, and help explain our present plight? In the late 1980s and early 1990s I applied to many universities for a teaching post, but no one seemed to want a person to teach students how to analyse data on health and illness.

The result of these failures is that, in common with many other colleagues, I have no established university post and keep myself employed by writing research proposals for short-term contracts. This leaves no time for teaching other than PhD supervision.

Mel Bartley
Dept of Epidemiology and Public Health, University College London

We've got to pay up

I write to support Alan Street's letter "A High Price to Pay" (Feb 6).

Perhaps we, as a nation, cannot have it both ways - we cannot have fully staffed schools and healthcare on the cheap. We either pay upfront for training our students or we pay later in terms of higher salaries for those whom we expect to invest so heavily in their own futures.

Gail Sudall
Bingley, West Yorks

Letters on education are welcome and should be sent to Guardian Education, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, faxed to 0171-239 9933, or e-mailed to: education.letters@theguardian.com.

webTitle: Who benefits from extra funding for "gifted and talented" pupils?

fields.headline: Make mine a G&T
fields.standfirst: Schools have been given £29m to help "gifted and talented" pupils.  Dea Birkett asks why the middle class benefits most
fields.trailText: Schools have been given £29m to help "gifted and talented" pupils. Dea Birkett asks why the middle class benefits most
fields.body:
Joseph is learning Latin. He's a member of Mensa. Six months ago, he gained grade A in his ICT GCSE. "He thinks he'll take a year off before he does his A-level," says his mother, Danielle Sanderson. Joseph is nine and a half.

Despite his immense academic ability, Joseph attends the local primary school just a few hundred yards away from his Hertfordshire home. The government wants to ensure more children like Joseph flourish within the state system.

In 1999, a programme for "gifted and talented" children was introduced as part of the Excellence in Cities (EiC) initiative. Over 1,000 inner-city schools were targeted to identity 5% to 10% of their pupils as "gifted and talented". A staggering £29m was allocated to fund learning programmes for these children, "gifted and talented co-ordinators" at each school, and after-school masterclasses and summer schools for the exceptionally able.

Last month, the education department announced EiC would be expanded to a third of all state secondary schools by 2004.

To its supporters, EiC is exactly what the state system has long needed. "There's been a feeling in the past that this type of youngster would get by - they'd make it. There is a group of gifted who will make it anyway. But there are quite a lot who don't engage with school as well as you might expect. You need a coherent strategy," says Deborah Eyre, head of the Research Centre for Able Pupils at Westminster Institute of Education.

But to its critics, it is a costly, cynical attempt to keep middle-class children like Joseph, whose father is a finance director and whose mother gained an exhibition to read physics at Oxford, from fleeing the state system.

For a start, what counts as "gifted and talented"? Parents often feel it is obvious. Joseph's talents are apparent and, according to his mother, always have been. "When he was 14 months old I was driving past a Tesco's van and he said 'Tesco'. He could read it. By 15 months he was speaking in 10-word sentences."

But even those who support the "gifted and talented" category struggle to define it. "There are 1%-2% of children who are exceptionally bright," says Ken Bore, director of the National Association for Gifted Children. "But on the broadest definition, up to 40% of the school population could be gifted in some way. We could be talking about half a million children."

Rigorous tests aren't always the answer. "IQ testing can be an indicator, but not a hard and fast diagnostic tool," says Bore. World-class tests are being developed and tested on nine- to 13-year-olds, to identify the top 10% academic achievers worldwide. Even Eyre has reservations about the current criteria. "For schools it's a problem what counts as gifted," she says. "If you're in an inner-city school with low-achieving children and pick out a child who to you seems outstanding, then took that child and put them somewhere else, they might be very ordinary. You can be considered gifted in one school and not another."

Inevitably, perhaps, given the subjective nature of the "gifted and talented" label, those who benefit from EiC tend to be self-selecting. "The chances of middle-class families pushing for their kids to be on EiC schemes is much higher than working-class parents," says Helen Lucey, a researcher at King's College London's School of Education.

From Lucey's sample of 45 high-IQ children, with the vast majority from working-class homes, only three were on gifted and talented schemes. All three were from professional middle-class families.

She is an ardent advocate of EiC, but admits that the take-up for the summer schools she runs has been slow. "If I'm honest, it hasn't been easy to find the children because we're looking for those who come from a background where there is no higher education. They don't have the confidence to do it," she says.

Newton Prep in Battersea, south London, a private primary school established to cater specifically for the intellectually gifted, aims to have 10% of its intake on means-tested scholarships. However, the trustees admit that very few poorer families have applied. Nearly all their pupils come from highly privileged backgrounds - scholarships or no scholarships.

Julian Johnson, a university lecturer whose eight-year-old son Ben has exceptional academic ability, says, "He's not a little Mozart. He's just very quick off the mark and has an enquiring mind. The EiC "gifted" tag, critics say, can exacerbate this misunderstanding. "They call them 'the G&Ts'", says Lucey. "Some of the kids don't want to know them. One boy said they get special treatment and go on special trips, just because they're quicker."

This is Lucey's main concern: that by labelling clever children as "gifted and talented", the less able are also being stigmatised. "It's all about exclusion, not inclusion at all. To pick up 10% of kids, you've got to exclude 90%. The kids who aren't chosen talk really emotionally about not being good enough. Some kids feels sorry for the G&T children because they're nerds - but it's contempt hiding envy."

But even once the few have been chosen, what is to be done with them? In the bad old school days, before EiC, the answer was often nothing. Ben spent literacy hour at his local state primary school in East Sussex sitting on the carpet and staring out of the window, while at home he devoured astronomy books and Harry Potter. "He was getting bored, frustrated and isolated," says his father. "Being clever seemed not to count for very much. It felt like he wasn't valued."

Johnson wanted his son to skip a year. "He was streets ahead, and was the oldest in his class. The head felt it would set a precedent, and refused. Yet the same school happily keeps other children back a year. I always said we'd never send our children to private school. But in the end we had no choice."

Ben is now at a £2,200-per-term school, 13 miles from home, where they agreed to accelerate him a year. "He's much livelier and more confident - everything an eight-year-old should be. We've got our child back," says Johnson.

If you do things earlier than anybody else, what is the eventual outcome? You would have to go to university earlier, but by the time you're 30, who cares? What's the gain?"

Even in the EiC scheme, precisely how gifted children can be helped is unclear. Most schools simply add on extras or remove children from regular classes.

webTitle: The Guardian / BBC Proms Young Composers' Competition

fields.headline: Next stop, the Albert Hall
fields.standfirst: If you love writing music, read on, urges  Peter Kingston - you can't lose; and Leonard Slatkin hails the forgotten heroes of music
fields.trailText: The Guardian / BBC Proms Young Composers' Competition If you love writing music, read on, urges Peter Kingston - you can't lose; and Leonard Slatkin hails the forgotten heroes of music
fields.body:
Do you enjoy writing music? Are you aged between 12 and 16? If the answer to both these questions is yes, then we've got the perfect competition for you. For the third time, The Guardian has joined forces with BBC Proms, the world's greatest music festival, to offer a unique opportunity for all young composers.

To enter, all you have to do is write a five-minute composition. The music can be in any style - string quartets, heavy metal, or the kind of song that would knock the socks off the Popstars judges. Just write the piece out (using either standard or graphic notation) and record it on audio cassette, CD, DAT or Minidisc and send it to us to arrive no later than June 1. (For full details of how to enter, see "Competition details", below.)

Our distinguished panel of judges will select three overall winners. Each winner will get prizes any composer would dream of. Not only will they have their composition broadcast in full on prime-time BBC Radio 3, but Yamaha has once again generously donated six keyboards, one for each of the three winners, and one for each of their schools.

And this year, for the first time, there are no losers. Everybody who enters will get a prize. All contestants will be invited with a parent or teacher to a special Young Composers' Day at the Proms on Sunday July 29.

This will include a presentation by the composer Sally Beamish about how she created her latest work. There will also be an advice session from professional composers and songwriters about composing as a career, a peek-in on rehearsals for that evening's Prom and two tickets for that concert, which will feature the world premiere performance of a BBC-commissioned piece.

Four days earlier, on July 25, the winners and 20 runners-up will be invited to London to attend a rehearsal by Leonard Slatkin, the chief conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. They will be able to discuss their work at a session with Slatkin and the composers Mark-Anthony Turnage and Fraser Trainer.

For any young person who enjoys writing music, our competition is a must, says one of last year's winners. "I was so chuffed," recalls Ollie Haydon-Mulligan, 14, who won with Merlin, a piece of jazz funk. "It's given me great encouragement and a lot of motivation to keep going. I'd encourage anybody who likes composing to have a go."

As for the judges, we had such an enthusiastic response last year, and were so impressed with the entries that we are delighted to do it all over again. Andrew Kurowski, BBC executive producer responsible for new music, says: "I had no idea the entries would be quite as characterful and impressive."

Another judge, the composer Gary Carpenter said: "We had entrants, and not just the prize-winners, whose work would be taken seriously by any of the major conservatories."

So, whether it's your ambition one day to hear your symphony played at the BBC Proms, or to write a number one hit, or you simply get a kick out of creating music, enter the only national competition for composers of your age.

Peter Kingston

You are the future of music

Who are the most important people in music: performers, composers, or the folk who listen - and pay?

As a conductor, I've been lucky to work with many fine instrumentalists and singers, some of them among the best in the world. They are unquestionably very important artists.

And together we've performed for some wonderful audiences. This summer I'm very much looking forward to coming back to the BBC Proms as chief conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. Prom audiences are special and there is always a great atmosphere in the Royal Albert Hall. I'm particularly looking forward to becoming the first American to conduct the famous Last Night of the Proms.

At the risk of ruffling a few feathers, though, I would say that no musical group can be more important than composers. And none is more vital than the next generation of young composers. That's you. You are literally the future of music.

Without you, the rest of us shall have nothing to play. That's not quite true, of course. There is all the music that has already been written. So long as there are orchestras around, they will always be playing Beethoven and Mozart, and all the other great composers.

But music needs a constant supply of fresh material if it is going to thrive as a living, vibrant art rather than just survive as some antique curiosity. And that is what we are hoping for from you. In fact, we are depending on it.

Composing is generally a solitary activity. I know. I've composed a bit myself. I also know that if you've got people to guide you, that can be an invaluable help. It is also great to have friends who can perform your stuff. If not, composing can be a very lonely business, especially if you don't know any other young people who do it. Sometimes you are the only person you know who is writing music seriously.

Like all artists, composers depend on audiences, whatever the style of their music. They need feedback. They need to hear the cheers. And it is useful, but not so thrilling, to get the muted applause, if not the occasional raspberry.

That is why The Guardian/BBC Proms competition is so important. For one thing, you'll find out that your hobby isn't so strange after all. There are other young people all over the country doing it.

How will you find this out? Because you will all be invited to London. The day will include a special event for young composers and two tickets to hear the evening Prom, which includes the world premiere performance of a BBC commission.

Also, your work will be judged by some real live professional composers. And finally, three of you will have your pieces broadcast on Radio 3 in a programme devoted to the competition.

Some composers have to wait a lifetime for that. What more could you ask for?

Leonard Slatkin

Competition details

The judges

Leonard Slatkin, chief conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra; Mark-Anthony Turnage, the composer; Peter Kingston, of The Guardian; Andrew Kurowski, in charge of BBC Radio 3's contemporary music output; Fraser Trainer, a composer and creative director, London Sinfonietta.

The prizes

What our three young composers win: This year Yamaha has again generously donated six keyboards - one for each winner, and one for each of their schools. Yamaha's new PSR-280 model, which retails at £199, offers over 250 sounds and a digital signal processor with effects, to simulate different environments such as concert hall and studios. It has as six-track song recording system.

The overall winners will also hear their music broadcast on BBC Radio 3, which will devote a programme to the competition. The winning entries will be played in full. The programme may also feature other entries the judges feel are of very high quality. Finally, on July 25, winners and selected runners-up will be invited to attend a rehearsal by Leonard Slatkin, and will be able to meet Mark-Anthony Turnage and Fraser Trainer.

What every entrant wins: Every young entrant will be invited, with a parent or teacher, to a special Young Composers' Day at the Proms on Sunday, July 29. The day will include presentations from Sally Beamish, a foremost British composer, and other composers and songwriters. It will end with a ticket to that evening's Prom, which will feature the world premiere performance of a special BBC-commissioned piece.

How to enter

 The competition is open to young people who will be aged between 12 and 16 (inclusive) on September 1 this year, and who are attending a school in the UK during this academic year.

 Entries (classical, jazz or rock/pop, for any combination of voices/instruments) must be no longer than five minutes, submitted on audio cassette, CD, DAT or Minidisc (two copies of whichever method) plus two written-out versions, either using standard or graphic notation. They can involve texts which, if not original, must be out of copyright.

 Only one entry per person.

 The Radio 3 programme will use submitted recordings (whole or excerpts) if they are of broadcast quality.

 Entries to be sent to: Young Composer Competition, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. They must include the name, address and telephone number of the school, the entrant's date of birth, and must be signed by the entrant and a music teacher.

 Winners will be judged from all entries received by June 1. They will be notified via their schools by June 29.

 The names of the winners will be published in The Guardian and on the BBC Proms website on July 3.

 Entrants supplying tapes/scores agree to grant the BBC an exclusive licence to use such entries in all media for all the purposes of the competition including without limitation transmission on radio and streaming on the internet and making copies or new recordings, if required. In connection with BBC's planned usage of the entries, entrants must ensure that a) works submitted are original b) any other musicians performing have agreed to it being used for all purposes of the competition - but please note professional musicians' performances on entries broadcast/streamed on the internet will be dealt with in accordance with the BBC's agreements with the Musicians' Union or under such other arrangements as normally apply.

webTitle: England's only Buddhist school searches for a new head

fields.headline: Principal with principles
fields.standfirst: The new head of England's only Buddhist school will need to bring karma to Dharma, says  Simon Midgley
fields.trailText: The new head of England's only Buddhist school will need to bring karma to Dharma, says Simon Midgley
fields.body:
Cross-legged or kneeling, the children meditate, their eyes closed, before a shrine in the Sun room. There is a bowl of water on the purple-robed altar, a lit candle, some incense and a statue of the Buddha.

A minute's silence ensues before the peace is broken by the tinkling of a Tibetan bell. Kevin Fossey, headteacher of the Dharma School in Brighton, England's only Buddhist school, relates an ancient Tibetan story about the worried man and the big-headed man. The moral of the tale - about telling tall stories - acknowledges the difficulty of trying to ascertain the truth, but emphasises the importance of trying.

The 70 boys and girls and sprinkling of mothers are then exhorted to send waves of heartfelt loving kindness to their families, friends and even people they have difficulty getting on with. Finally, Fossey says we must also be generous with ourselves and give ourselves a smile as well.

Fossey, 49, has been to Dharamsala in northern India on several occasions to help the Tibetan government in exile refine its teacher training programmes. He is about to give up the headship and the school is looking for his successor. Only practising Buddhists need apply.

"The school is strong. It's established and is not seen as that wacky little school on the hill," he says. "Visitors say, 'Oh, it's quite normal, really', as if we all went round in robes bowing to each other all the time."

I have arrived at the school in the middle of a puja, a devotion or spell of living in the moment. The assembly is taking place in the White House, a 1930s detached house in its own grounds, in the lee of the South Downs. A Tibetan chant follows - Om Mani Padme Hung, literally the jewel in the flower of the lotus.

After a prayer, the assembled throng bows three times: once to thank the Buddha for being; once to thank him for his teachings - dharma - and once for the community of people sharing this moment.

The private school - fees £3,000 a year - was founded in September 1994 to cater for Brighton's flourishing Buddhist community. It started off with four children aged four to six in the living room of a parent's house, but moved in 1995.

Today, half its pupils come from families that practise Buddhism, while the others come from various religious and secular backgrounds. Several of the school's teachers, including the head, are practising Buddhists, and monks from Tibet and other Buddhist traditions regularly visit. Brighton's Buddhist community includes groups representing Tibetan, Zen, Gaia House, Friends of the Western Buddhist Order and Theravadan traditions. The school itself is open to all traditions.

Buddhist doctrines are not taught in a didactic way, rather the school is infused by Buddhist principles exemplified in teachers' behaviour. Key principles include developing honesty, respect for all sentient beings, co-operation, concentration, self-discipline and resourcefulness.

Daily meditation gives children periods of stillness and inner quiet. Opportunities are taken to demonstrate the relationship of all living things with their environment. Children are encouraged to consider the consequences of their actions and to be aware of the moment. They are also taught - bearing in mind that the Buddha taught that everything is impermanent - to cope with uncertainty and loss.

All pupils and staff undertake to maintain the five Buddhist precepts: take care of all living things; respect property and not take things that are not ours; accept responsibility in relationships; understand the dangers of substance abuse; and, finally, speak honestly and kindly.

Alison Mayo, who has taught at the school since it started and set up the nursery, is a practising Buddhist. She says that the school allows space for things to happen.

"Rather than filling every moment, there is time to reflect on what you are doing. The children get a lot of individual attention," she added. "Because the classes are small, the teaching is not about controlling large groups. There is a strong sense of community.

"Buddhism is a way of life rather than a set of beliefs. It is not a matter of saying people should believe in a particular thing. It's easy for non-Buddhists to feel at home here."

Dawn Sackett and her partner, Adrian Weston, who run a marketing and PR agency in Brighton, have a 10-year-old son, Crusoe, at the school. They moved him from a primary school where he was floundering in a 100-strong year group.

"We are not Buddhists, but it's a small school and I like Buddhism's five basic principles," Sackett says. "Crusoe has changed from being an unhappy, disruptive child to a happy, settled child. The school is very good at working on social relationships between the children."

Thomas Chandler, 11, who has Asperger's syndrome, which makes him prone to fits of temper, said: "I like this school. You do not have to be part of the crowd. In other schools I have been to, you had to like a fashion or be excluded."

The pupils once had an audience with the Dalai Lama. One child asked what was the best thing they could hope to achieve. He replied: "To develop a good heart." And that is just what the Dharma School tries to help them to do.

webTitle: On the board: The diary of a parent governor

fields.headline: On the board
fields.standfirst: The diary of a parent governor
fields.trailText: The diary of a parent governor
fields.body:
"Thank you to Jane for preparing these curriculum maps," says Mr Richardson. Or rather, Edward, since we find ourselves in a curriculum development meeting, ahead of next week's first meeting of the full governing body, and therefore permitted the relative informality of first names.

Judging by her work on these curriculum maps, Jane (Miss Roberts) certainly demonstrates a mastery of spreadsheet software. The curriculum map consists of a sheaf of charts, one for each year, showing in broad-brush form what will be taught in each subject during the school year. Every primary school will have one and, since the national curriculum has assured nothing if not conformity, one school's curriculum map will look much like another's.

In fact, when it comes to English and maths, the curriculum is so tightly dictated by the education department that the spreadsheets simply contain a note referring us to the "national strategy frameworks" - literacy and numeracy hours and the like.

Nevertheless, the curriculum map is the best available "at-a-glance" guide to what your child will be learning at any particular time.

"Any questions?" asks Edward, expressionlessly.

Much shuffling of sheets. I smile inwardly when I realise that our Lucy's recent inquiry about the whereabouts of the nearest fire station, which had seemed à propos of nothing at the time, must have been (ahem) sparked by the content of her history lessons this term, while year 3 have been learning (in an apparent reversal of geopolitical fact) that the Romans have given way to the Egyptians. I think, day-dreamily, that it looks sort of fun; I wouldn't mind going back to school. By the time I wake from this momentary reverie, the discussion has somehow veered towards the subject of SATs - upcoming for year 6.

"There are national targets, but the local authority sets their own targets," explains Elizabeth 'Liz' Mills, the deputy head, to the partnership governor sitting on my right. "We have to achieve 75 in English, 75 in maths, and 80 in science."

"Sorry - 75 and 80 of what?" I ask.

"That's the percentage attaining level 4 or above. Level 4 is what the average 11-year-old is supposed to be capable of," she answers, with friendly briskness.

"So how do you fit in revision and exam preparation for the year 6s?" I ask. "There doesn't seem time for anything extra at all."

I confess (to you, not in the meeting) that I'm thinking of my nephew who will be starting at secondary school next September - at a private school, although he has been at a state primary in his area.

"Ah, well," responds Jane (Miss Roberts). "That's true: there's not a spare hour. But what happens with year 6 is that we are going through past years' papers - we did the 1997 paper before Christmas; we'll have done the 1998 paper by half-term; and then we'll do last year's paper before Easter."

"So what happens to their curriculum map? When are they going to learn about . . . " I pause to study the chart, "electrical circuits, say?"

"Well, it all gets pushed into the summer term - after they've done the SATs basically."

"And," adds Liz (Mrs Mills) soothingly, "we more than met last year's target. I think we did something like 80 in English, 77 in maths and 82 in science. We have a couple more SENs [children with special educational needs] in this year's year 6, but they're still a very capable clientele."

Clientele. I can't quite work out whether she is using the term in inverted commas. Perhaps, with all the management-speak of performance indicators and attainment, that is what the children are now: a clientele.
