webTitle: Book reviews

fields.headline: Book reviews
fields.trailText: The Amazing Pop-up House of Inventions, by Robert Crowther, and The Total Volunteering Book, by Sandra Cain and Michelle Maxwell
fields.body:
Amazing Pop-up House of Inventions by Robert Crowther
(Walker Books, £12.99) Age: 4-7 yrs

Pop-up books are usually inadvisable for classroom use but this is more durable than most. Each spread offers a 3-D illustration of a room, plastered with sturdy flaps, underneath which lie hundreds of fascinating facts. Bizarre details range from the inventor of the box-shaped kite to information about a chocolate gramophone record, but there is also a lot of day-to-day information, each little chunk appealingly brief and to the point. An attempt at conventionality - a spread entitled Some Inventions that Changed the Way we Live - is useful, but let's face it, it's the flaps that will appeal.

The Total Volunteering Book by Sandra Cain and Michelle Maxwell
(A&C Black, £6.99)
Age: 11-18 yrs

One of the strains of adolescence is a desire to take responsibility in a world that doesn't consider you particularly responsible. Volunteering is an excellent way of channelling energies into something constructive. This paperback includes a selection of personal accounts offering a wide variety of volunteering experiences - sports coaching, taking people with disabilities on holiday, reading to older people, sponsored events, and so on. There is also an alphabetical listing of organisations to contact, each relevant to young people in the UK, and guidance on how to choose the organisation that best suits you.

webTitle: The government's plan for specialist schools

fields.headline: Special effects
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair has unveiled his latest big idea for education: by 2006, half of Britain's secondary schools will be specialist colleges. But what are they, and what will this mean for children?  Phil Revell answers parents' questions
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has unveiled his latest big idea for education: by 2006, half of Britain's secondary schools will be specialist colleges. But what are they, and what will this mean for children? Phil Revell answers parents' questions
fields.body:
I hear Tony Blair has another new plan for education, education, education?

You're right. As the election draws closer, Blair is rolling out his 10-year plan. Central to this is a huge expansion of the flagship specialist schools programme, which allows schools to concentrate on one subject area.

Currently there are over 500 schools specialising in technology, sport, the arts or languages. In return for a promise to raise standards across the curriculum, schools receive a capital grant of £100,000 plus an extra £123 per year per pupil (up to 1,000 pupils), worth over £100,000 a year for a typical secondary school.

The government aims to have 1,500 schools in place by 2006, which would mean that every other secondary school would have a specialism. And there will be new specialisms, with engineering, science and business and enterprise colleges likely to open in September 2002.

And remind me - where did this idea come from?

Specialist schools were a Conservative initiative brought in to cover the cracks of a failing City Technology Colleges programme. Margaret Thatcher saw CTCs as an opportunity for business to invest in education. Companies were invited to fund new schools, which would effectively be independent, able to set their own curriculum and experiment with new teaching methods. But only 15 were created and big-name donors were hard to come by.

Specialist schools were seen as a more acceptable way to involve business and Labour, far from abandoning the initiative, has expanded it.

Arts, languages, science - these are things I'd expect all schools to cover. Why should some get more money to teach the same subjects?

Any state secondary can apply for specialist status, but a school would have to be confident of success before beginning the process. Schools have to submit a three-year plan outlining how they propose to raise standards. They also have to find £50,000 of seed corn money. Few "failing" schools would want to take that kind of challenge on board.

Schools are expected to make efforts to raise as much as they can locally, but a safety net exists for schools in poorer areas. The Technology Colleges Trust (TCT) acts as a mediator between donors keen to support the programme and schools in need of assistance.

Schools are always moaning about extra initiatives - why are they so keen to sign up to this one?

For the additional funding - worth about half a million pounds over three years. A recent report by the London School of Economics concluded that the popularity of the programme among heads was largely related to the extra money.

More than half the heads questioned by LSE admitted that their supposed specialism was not in fact the school's strongest teaching area, and the same number said that extra funding had been their primary motive for becoming a specialist school.

At the Centre for the Study of Comprehensive Schools (CSCS), director Mark Hewlett admitted that that had been the case when he applied for specialist status at Rawlings comprehensive in Leicestershire. "We went for specialist status because we could not afford to disadvantage our kids by depriving them of that money," said Hewlett, who has since left the school.

Cash for Sats, then? Or is there some other way of deciding which schools specialise and which children benefit? I don't fancy complicating my housing arrangements by being forced to choose whether to live in an arty, business-like or Francophile catchment area.

Bids are assessed by the DfEE but there doesn't appear to be any national plan to distribute schools evenly across the country. There are now 536 specialist schools in operation: 313 in technology, 99 in language, 67 in sports and 57 in arts.

The dominance of technology is partly explained by the fact that the arts, sports and languages categories were added in 1997. But the ability to spend thousands on computers has also made technology more attractive.

So is my child expected to decide at the age of 11 whether he's a budding Richard Branson or a would-be Sam Mendes? How can the school tell?

In theory, specialist schools are able to select up to 10% of their pupils. Applicants might be asked to bring in artwork or perform on a musical instrument, although languages assessment is more difficult, because few primary schools teach languages.

But in practice few schools select. The education department estimates that only 7% of existing specialist schools do so - a figure confirmed by the TCT. But schools admit that they may be forced to select where they are massively oversubscribed.

Let's get this straight: better schools will get more cash and be allowed to pick pupils; meanwhile, the school that has been refused specialist status will be left with less money and the kids who didn't manage to fight their way into the specialist school. Sounds suspiciously like a two-tier selective system to me.

Well spotted. Most of the critics of the specialist school programme make that point and some believe that a two-tier system is precisely what the government intends.

"It would be more honest to come right out and say that they want to replace the comprehensive system with a new model," says Nigel de Gruchy general secretary of the Nasuwt. "Let's be clear, this will be a fundamental change to the structure of secondary education - and where's the debate?"

Harry Tomlinson is professor of education at Leeds Metropolitan University. He argues that perceived equality is something the government should not abandon. "We're losing parity of esteem," he says. "Slowly the differentiation being built into the system is eroding the principal of equality."

And what of English, maths etc? Won't they suffer if dance and engineering are squeezed onto the curriculum?

Specialist schools follow the national curriculum, so the day-to-day diet isn't that different. But differences would be obvious to anyone visiting the school.

"Six years ago we had 50 computers," says Chris Gerry, head of the Hugh Christie technology college. "Today we have 400. That's alongside video conferencing facilities, distance learning and a website which allows children to continue learning at home." Technology is a compulsory subject at GCSE, but Gerry offers a thriving sport and arts programme, too.

We hear nothing but tales of teacher shortages, particularly in subjects such as modern languages. Won't the extra cash drain the best teachers away from non-specialist schools?

The simple answer is Yes. Heads privately acknowledge that it is easier to recruit to schools with good facilities, but salaries are the same and the specialist schools in inner cities suffer the same recruitment problems as their neighbours.

I'm convinced that my 10-year-old is a science genius and that a spe cialist school is exactly what she needs. When will a science specialist school open in my area?

Pass. Even in 2006, when the government plans to have 1,500 specialist schools, there will be no guarantee that every area will offer the full range.

"The logistics of this haven't been thought out ," says Hewlett. He argues that it is not realistic to expect parents to transport their children for miles to these schools. "If civil servants think this will work they have no understanding of the practicalities governing pupils' and parents' choice of schools."

And does it work? Will my child succeed in a specialist school?

The record of specialist schools in raising standards is impressive. A national study of non-selective specialist schools last year found that they averaged 52% A-C grades at GCSE, more than 10 percentage points higher than their comprehensive non-specialist competitors.

The research, by David Jesson, showed specialist schools improving their results at nearly double the rate of other comprehensives. "The average ability of pupils entering these schools was similar to that for all other comprehensives," said Jesson, who specialises in "value added" data in education. He explains the better performance of specialist schools in terms the government would approve of: it's down to good leadership and programmes that target literacy.

So if they're so successful, why not make all schools specialist?

Labour came into office with two slogans for schools: "Education, education, education" and "Standards not Structures". The problem is that raising standards has proved expensive. Many would argue that the specialist schools system is simply a form of rationing, doling out additional monies only to those schools that can be guaranteed to ratchet up the results.

"There is no doubt that resources have gone to those schools who least need them," says Hewlett. "That issue should be solved by funding all schools fairly, from the beginning of the next parliament."

Additional reporting by Rebecca Smithers and Claire Phipps.

He argues that perceived equality is something the government should not abandon. "We're losing parity of esteem," he says. "Slowly the differentiation being built into the system is eroding the principal of equality." And what of English, maths etc? Won't they suffer if dance and engineering are squeezed onto the curriculum? Specialist schools follow the national curriculum, so the day-to-day diet isn't that different. But differences would be obvious to anyone visiting the school. "Six years ago we had 50 computers," says Chris Gerry, head of the Hugh Christie technology college. "Today we have 400. That's alongside video conferencing facilities, distance learning and a website which allows children to continue learning at home." Technology is a compulsory subject at GCSE, but Gerry offers a thriving sport and arts programme, too. We hear nothing but tales of teacher shortages, particularly in subjects such as modern languages. Won't the extra cash drain the best teachers away from non-specialist schools? The simple answer is Yes. Heads privately acknowledge that it is easier to recruit to schools with good facilities, but salaries are the same and the specialist schools in inner cities suffer the same recruitment problems as their neighbours. I'm convinced that my 10-year-old is a science genius and that a spe cialist school is exactly what she needs. When will a science specialist school open in my area? Pass. Even in 2006, when the government plans to have 1,500 specialist schools, there will be no guarantee that every area will offer the full range. "The logistics of this haven't been thought out ," says Hewlett. He argues that it is not realistic to expect parents to transport their children for miles to these schools. "If civil servants think this will work they have no understanding of the practicalities governing pupils' and parents' choice of schools." And does it work? Will my child succeed in a specialist school? The record of specialist schools in raising standards is impressive. A national study of non-selective specialist schools last year found that they averaged 52% A-C grades at GCSE, more than 10 percentage points higher than their comprehensive non-specialist competitors. The research, by David Jesson, showed specialist schools improving their results at nearly double the rate of other comprehensives. "The average ability of pupils entering these schools was similar to that for all other comprehensives," said Jesson, who specialises in "value added" data in education. He explains the better performance of specialist schools in terms the government would approve of: it's down to good leadership and programmes that target literacy. So if they're so successful, why not make all schools specialist? Labour came into office with two slogans for schools: "Education, education, education" and "Standards not Structures". The problem is that raising standards has proved expensive. Many would argue that the specialist schools system is simply a form of rationing, doling out additional monies only to those schools that can be guaranteed to ratchet up the results. "There is no doubt that resources have gone to those schools who least need them," says Hewlett. "That issue should be solved by funding all schools fairly, from the beginning of the next parliament." Additional reporting by Rebecca Smithers and Claire Phipps.

webTitle: On the Web: Global fashion industry | Maps

fields.headline: On the Web
fields.trailText: Global fashion industry | Maps
fields.byline: Compiled by Amanda Grimwood and Jim Merrett
fields.body:
How to teach globalisation

www.tidec.org/Globalisation/globmain.html

Suitable for: teachers

This site, from Birmingham's Development Education Centre, includes the Globalisation Rose, a framework for looking at issues from global to local. The site includes three alternative viewpoints, a useful introduction to the debate. A model is provided in the form of a study on Nike clothing and the 1998 World Cup. An excellent starting point.

How to teach globalisation (2)

www.dea.org.uk

Suitable for: teachers

The Development Education Association provides a range of resources for teaching and learning about globalisation. There are many useful links to organisations involved with the DEA.

An introduction

www.cafod.org.uk

Suitable for: KS3/4 and teachers

The Rough Guide to Globalisation covers what it is, what's driving it and why some people are against it. It includes the testament of Gani, a garment worker in Indonesia who makes Gap and Docker clothes.

The background to fashion

www.cafod.org.uk/garment_industry.htm

Suitable for: KS3/4 and teachers

A more in-depth report from Cafod on the real "fashion victims". Although very text heavy, this could be a useful classroom resource for a project.

Workers' stories (1)

www.oxfam.org.uk/campaign/clothes/clocodh.htm

Suitable for: KS3/4 and teachers

Includes the experiences of workers in the Dominican Republic and Bangladesh.

Workers' stories (2)

www.maquilasolidarity.org

Suitable for KS3/4 and teachers

Included in this Canadian website are workers' stories from El Salvador, China and Canada itself. The latter is an interesting contrast as it looks at the plight of homeworkers in one of the world's more economically developed countries.

Labour behind the labels

www.cleanclothes.org/companies.htm

Suitable for KS3/4 and teachers

This Dutch site is very text heavy, but provides detailed reports on the reality of the working conditions of those providing garments for some of the world's major clothing and fashion companies, from Adidas to Reebok.

Maps

Atlapedia Online

www.atlapedia.com

Suitable for: KS2 pupils, teachers

This comprehensive American site includes full colour physical and political maps of the world. "Resources" has school and homework material, although some of it is restricted to licence purchasers.

Ordnance Survey

www.ordnancesurvey.gov.uk

Suitable for: KS1/2 pupils, teachers

Includes lesson information for teachers and a quiz for children, although they would need help. There are also lesson notes for years 3 to 6 involving local studies.

Millennium Map

www2.getmapping.com

Suitable for: KS1/2 pupils, teachers

Enter your postcode to see an aerial photograph of the location. It's a hugely interesting for children and an ideal introduction to the art of mapping.

Multimap

uk2.multimap.com

Suitable for: KS1/2 pupils, teachers

Click on any part of the world map to zoom in on a country and again for a detailed map of the region.

Choropleth Map

www.teachingideas.co.uk/geography/chlormap.htm

Suitable for: KS2 pupils, teachers

A choropleth map shows areas which have the same characteristics. A worksheet is provided along with full instructions. Use the same URL (website address), substituting the word map for chlormap, to find lesson ideas.

Click Teaching

www.clickteaching.com/geography/ks1_mapwork.shtml

Suitable for: KS1 teachers

Here's another source of lesson ideas involving a plan view of the classroom with suggestions for differentiation.

Primary Resources

www.primaryresources.co.uk/geography/geography.htm

Suitable for: KS2 teachers, pupils

Ideally you would have the Lake District OS map and the Oxford First Atlas to use alongside this site but the material could be adapted. Enables the children to use grid references.

Maps.com

www.maps.com/learn

Suitable for: KS2 teachers, pupils

Quizzes on various continents and a geography crossword. A marvellous educational activity for wet playtimes.

webTitle: School report: Wordbank

fields.headline: School report
fields.standfirst: Wordbank
fields.trailText: Wordbank
fields.body:
Wordbank

(www.hope-education.co.uk tel: 08702 433400)

Price: £59.95 + vat

Age/ability range: 4-7yrs

The manufacturer says: "Wordbank will help children with alphabet sequencing, word construction and spelling. Comes complete with 26 A5-sized word cards printed with the first 100 most frequently used words, including all the essential key words highlighted in the National Literacy Strategy."

Christine Beswick, Reception Teacher, Our Ladies Catholic School, Stockport, says: "I was impressed by its quality; it's made of stitched plastic and is very long-lasting, bright and colourful. I used it with a reception class, but it could be used through KS1 and foundation.

"I liked the fact that the letters on the pockets were in lower case. The pictures matched their phonic sound well - this was a real plus. It was quite big (150cm x 100cm) which made it difficult to find somewhere both accessible and low enough for the children's hands to reach, but once it was up and running it was fine.

"The children enjoyed it and learnt about the order of the alphabet. They could touch and trace over the letters, and the more able could select words. It is a very well thought-out resource. Nine out of 10 for usefulness!"

Curriculum links
Literacy, reception: phonics, spelling and vocabulary

webTitle: Furthermore: Learning in a vacuum

fields.headline: Learning in a vacuum
fields.standfirst: One management course and Donald Hiscock thinks he's found a way out
fields.trailText: One management course and Donald Hiscock thinks he's found a way out
fields.body:
Thinking that a day spent out of college in the conference suite of a hotel would make a refreshing change I agreed to attend a management course on learning styles. I fell for the flattery and calculated charms of my Head of Programme Area when she suggested that I should have first refusal.

So that is how I found myself driving up and down the same short stretch of motorway intersection trying to figure out where to exit for the hotel. You know the scenario. First you see the place immediately on your left and then it appears in your rear view mirror on your right.

Twice I ended up outside a branch of Homebase before finding a service road that put me in a queue for the Drive Thru window of a fast food restaurant. Upon arriving at the order section I turned down the special salsa chicken dip combo meal with free travel mug and, instead, asked for directions to my hotel.

"Do you want fries with that?" came the voice from the speaker.

The only way out was to order a coffee and go. I went, found the hotel within seconds and then stared at a list of meetings and their rooms.

"Can I help you?" asked a receptionist.

"Learning styles," I said. "I think it's in the Blunkett Suite."

"There's been a change sir. It's in the annex, back of the car park."

There were two Portakabins next to the hotel laundry. I chose the left-hand one when I saw a colleague from a nearby college going up its steps. I sat at the back and sipped my coffee.

I was prepared for surprises. My mate Colin from maths had been on the same course last year. He took great delight in telling me about the role-play exercises and peer evaluation sessions. He recalled constructing bridges out of drinking straws and something about an exercise involving a banana and a tin opener.

"A load of bloody crap really," was Colin's evaluation of the day, "but I cleaned them out of mints and lime cordial."

So when the woman leading the session finished talking about motivation targets, outcomes and exchangeable pollen filters I wasn't at all surprised. I could barely hear her introductory speech for the noise of the tumble driers in the laundry next door. It was that all too depressing word "target" that confirmed I was well and truly taking part in a further education training day.

And I wasn't even surprised when most of the morning was taken up with a role-play on assembling and demonstrating a vacuum cleaner. Lunch was disappointing, but I did talk to several people in further education over a ham sandwich.

In the afternoon the trainer emptied out a bucket of flour and coal dust on the carpet. I was chosen to assemble the vacuum cleaner, suck up the mess and then describe the experience to my peers. I received a round of applause. I felt good about myself. I felt valued. This was the best training session I had ever attended.

And that brings me to a very special offer I would like to make to readers of Furthermore. I will gladly demonstrate the all new Suck-O-Matic in the comfort of your own home. Absolutely no obligation to purchase, but easy payment terms can be arranged.

webTitle: Raising the profile of vocational courses

fields.headline: Parity falters at deadline
fields.standfirst: Vocational courses need time, says  Simon Midgley
fields.trailText: Vocational courses need time, says Simon Midgley
fields.body:
It may raise the profile of their qualifications, but will red-eyed students struggling to complete coursework really care? This year's deadline for the submission of portfolio work in the new vocational A-level and Advanced Vocational Certificate in Education (formerly advanced GNVQ) has been brought forward from mid-June to May 15 and the change is causing consternation.

The government is keen that the results of A/S-levels, A-levels and the new vocational A-levels should be announced together on the same date in August. Its aim is to raise the profile and public acceptance of vocational A-levels in order to achieve parity of esteem with traditional A-levels.

As a result examining bodies such as Edexcel and AQA have brought forward the course work submission date to give them more time for mod eration and assessment. But the Association of Colleges is trying to persuade them to think again. Maggie Scott, quality adviser, said the association is concerned that teaching is having to be brought forward so that the students cover more work to meet the earlier deadline. In addition, the portfolio tends to be the culmination of students' work during the year. If the deadline is brought forward colleges may experience difficulty sustaining student interest until the full completion of the qualification at the beginning of July.

"These particular students, who do not respond so well in examination conditions, really need to be encouraged to develop portfolios and demonstrate their skills in this way. Anything which shortens the time they have or lessens their ability to demonstrate their skills is likely to have an adverse effect."

webTitle: Trades unions to be given new rights to fight for better training

fields.headline: All out for learning
fields.standfirst: Trades unions are to be given new rights to fight for better training. By  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Trades unions are to be given new rights to fight for better training. By Peter Kingston
fields.body:
Trade union officials who specialise in workplace training issues are to be given a legal status in order to persuade employers to take them more seriously, according to government plans to be announced today.

Ministers intend to grant formal recognition to union "learning representatives". This will entitle them to paid time off to carry out their duties and protect them from victimisation.

The government hopes it will enable them to negotiate more robustly with employers who may have previously sidestepped proper dialogue with unions about training, deeming it to fall outside their traditional role on pay and conditions, and their statutory functions on health and safety.

Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister, who is due today to publish a white paper, Enterprise, Skills and Innovation, including plans to beef up union learning representatives, is convinced they will perform major part of future trades union functions.

"I want the union of the future to be a learning union," he said. "This is a vital, positive new role for trade unions and we should all do everything we can to encourage it. Formal recognition will go a long way towards raising the profile of these representatives and improving their effectiveness."

Wicks thinks that employers will welcome this growing interest amongst trades unions in training and skills, although the Confederation of British Industry expressed unhappiness about legislation.

Bert Clough, senior education and training adviser to the Trades Union Congress, said: "We're effusive about this. We think it can do an awful lot about changing workforce development culture."

In recent years unions have trained some 2,000 learning representatives, mainly through the government's Union Learning Fund initiative.

They have been reckoned to be very effective at encouraging training and development in the workplace, particularly among workers with the lowest levels of skills.

Their role involves advising workers about training they need, raising their awareness of learning opportunities, and in some cases brokering courses from colleges, universities or other providers without recourse to employers.

Government set up a £12.5m Union Learning Fund in 1998 to fund projects to increase union capacity to encourage and support learning in the workplace. Learning representatives might be able to claim some of this cash for courses.

But where learning representatives believe employers should support learning, by making time or funds available, they will negotiate for this. It is envisaged that in the event of no agreement on training, disputes might be settled by a tribunal.

Nevertheless government is steering well clear of introducing legislation to require employers to spend a designated proportion of their turnovers on staff training, as happens in some countries.

Where it was common for employers to pay money into their sectors to support training, levy systems survive in only two sectors - construction and engineering.

Malcolm Wicks wants national training organisations to play a greater role in assessing skills shortages and training needs. He also believes the new Learning and Skills Councils will enable workforce training needs to be more efficiently met.

The minister is convinced that employers of all sizes will recognise the sense of learning representatives' advice to boost training, particularly if it means the difference between survival and collapse.

He cites existing good practice such as the deal between the shopworkers' union Usdaw and Littlewoods catalogue. Workers there, who could see that internet shopping was their future, were given ICT training.

webTitle: So you want to learn...field archaeology

fields.headline: So you want to learn...
fields.standfirst: ...field archaeology
fields.trailText: ...field archaeology
fields.body:
You there! Who me?

Yes, you. I trust you're going to clear up that appalling mess. Well, eventually.

Typical! You cable television people are all the same. We're not cab. . .

Just dig up the place and never leave it the same. We're not cable television.

Oh yeah. Who are you then? We're field archaeologists.

Well, how fascinating. What's that mean? Our main work is recording, recovering, possibly excavating, as we are doing here, and interpreting evidence from the past.

Looks frightfully muddy work. Not all of it. A lot of the time I'm assessing sites for their archaeological potential. That usually starts as a desktop exercise. If the decision is made to pursue the project, then further evaluation is undertaken which can involve a bit of trial trenching and geophysical surveys.

What do you do with the treasure? We clean, analyse, conserve and catalogue all the "finds". A lot of that takes place away from the excavation site and can continue long after the "dig" has finished. The information recorded goes to form an archive for the site.

So, if you think something's there, you just dig. No, excavation is not undertaken lightly. We prefer to preserve rather than excavate a site. However this cannot always happen if, for example, the site is to be built on.

Why does it take so long? The finer more precise work has to be done by hand rather than machine. It is crucial that all objects and accompanying features are accurately recorded. Attention to detail - discoloration of soil or waterlogged timbers - is vital, as this can lead to further discovery of past activities.

What skills do you need? Vital qualities include management skills certainly, the ability to organise staff and budgets and the capacity to work fast to a deadline in all weathers. Other requirements are physical fitness, good manual dexterity for using instruments and tools, an eye for detail, and patience.

Any necessary qualifications? Entry into professional archaeology is mainly through the university undergraduate route, followed by postgraduate qualifications. Relevant degree courses include archaeology itself or a combined degree with a related subject eg ancient history. There are lots of postgraduate courses specialising in particular areas such as conservation, archaeological surveying and aerial photography. The Institute of Field Archaeologists runs continuing professional development programmes.

Sounds very grand. You can do various practical archaeology courses throughout the country at schools, further education colleges and university continuing education departments, ranging from general interest through A-level up to HND level. For practical experience, you'll find archaeological organisations throughout the country offering opportunities for volunteers, either on- or off-site.

Institute of Field Archaeologists, University of Reading, 2 Earley Gate, PO Box 239, Reading, RG6 6AU

Telephone: 0118 931 6446

www.archaeologists.net

Council for British Archaeology , Bowes Morrell House, 111 Walmgate, York, YO1 9WA

Telephone 01904 671417

If the decision is made to pursue the project, then further evaluation is undertaken which can involve a bit of trial trenching and geophysical surveys. What do you do with the treasure? We clean, analyse, conserve and catalogue all the "finds". A lot of that takes place away from the excavation site and can continue long after the "dig" has finished. The information recorded goes to form an archive for the site. So, if you think something's there, you just dig. No, excavation is not undertaken lightly. We prefer to preserve rather than excavate a site. However this cannot always happen if, for example, the site is to be built on. Why does it take so long? The finer more precise work has to be done by hand rather than machine. It is crucial that all objects and accompanying features are accurately recorded. Attention to detail - discoloration of soil or waterlogged timbers - is vital, as this can lead to further discovery of past activities. What skills do you need? Vital qualities include management skills certainly, the ability to organise staff and budgets and the capacity to work fast to a deadline in all weathers. Other requirements are physical fitness, good manual dexterity for using instruments and tools, an eye for detail, and patience. Any necessary qualifications? Entry into professional archaeology is mainly through the university undergraduate route, followed by postgraduate qualifications. Relevant degree courses include archaeology itself or a combined degree with a related subject eg ancient history. There are lots of postgraduate courses specialising in particular areas such as conservation, archaeological surveying and aerial photography. The Institute of Field Archaeologists runs continuing professional development programmes. Sounds very grand. You can do various practical archaeology courses throughout the country at schools, further education colleges and university continuing education departments, ranging from general interest through A-level up to HND level. For practical experience, you'll find archaeological organisations throughout the country offering opportunities for volunteers, either on- or off-site. fields.body:
Born: March 23, 1971

Occupation: Television presenter, formerly in kiddies' corner, but now, post posing in the buff for assorted men's magazines and seeing her nude 100ft image projected onto Big Ben, she's moved to the adult schedules.

College: West Hertfordshire college

webTitle: Where you're coming from

fields.headline: Where you're coming from
fields.standfirst: Selection by postcode doesn't work for colleges, and it won't for universities, says  Neil Hopkins
fields.trailText: Selection by postcode doesn't work for colleges, and it won't for universities, says Neil Hopkins
fields.body:
Amidst the political infighting that has dominated the media coverage of the Select Committee's report on access to higher education, there has been very little said about the actual content of the report. Laura Spence and the Chancellor's reaction to her Oxford application may not have featured in the report, but a lot did - some good and some misguided.

An archetypal piece of well-intentioned impracticality is the committee's recommendation that universities receive a financial incentive to recruit "students from low-participation neighbourhoods". Sounds good, but . . .

In further education we have a similar scheme and the flaw is, how does one define a low-participation neighbourhood? It seems likely that postcodes and the government's index of deprivation will be used in the same way as they are in further education. This is just far too crude a device. What matters to the individual student is how deprived she or he is, not how deprived their neighbours are. There has to be a way of looking at individual circumstances.

Take the case of say the vicar's daughter in an inner city "deprived" parish. She may come from a family of two graduate parents, supportive of her education, and with an expectation from birth that she will go to university. Compare this to say the son living with his mother in her staff accommodation as a live-in cook/cleaner in the best part of town in a leafy home county. He may come from a family where no one has ever even taken A-levels let alone gone on to university. Yet postcode-based, widening participation-premium funding would give the university that recruited the vicar's daughter 20% more money than the university that managed to recruit the cleaner's son. Of course I have nothing against vicars or their daughters, but however deserving she may be, it would be the university that benefited from recruiting her, not the student herself.

And what has the committee to say about the recruitment process itself? It adds its voice to the chorus of those in schools and colleges that want the university application process to take place after students have taken their A-levels, not before. However, the report ties this recommendation in with the proposals to reconsider the calendar of the school year. What about the university year?

Already, colleges and schools are concerned about how to squeeze the work required for four or five AS-levels, three Key Skills and at least three A2-exams into the academic year. To bring A-level exams earlier in the year would be disastrous. Somehow the possibility of moving the university year seems to have been overlooked. Universities only teach for 30 weeks a year (Oxbridge for an incredibly short 24 weeks!), which leaves plenty of scope for starting the autumn term of the first year a month or so later, to allow time for exam results to be processed. Perhaps a five-week Easter break between university terms isn't actually absolutely essential?

This is not to say that the report doesn't have its good points. What a good idea to have the Higher Education Funding Council publish annually performance indicators for universities. Perhaps students might then be able to find out easily whether a reasonable proportion of those starting a course actually succeed in finishing it, or even find out how good the teaching on a course is? How have universities got away with the current secret garden arrangements for so long?

What a good idea that Oxford and Cambridge should publish admissions data on a college-by-college basis. What a good idea that the closing dates for Oxbridge, medical and veterinary schools etc should be the same as for all other universities. And what a good idea that "universities should respond with sufficient urgency to the development of the new AS qualifications". (What about Key Skills?)

And what a damning indictment of our universities that it should take a Select Committee report to state the obvious.

Neil Hopkins is the principal of Peter Symonds College, Winchester, but writes here in a personal capacity.

webTitle: Opportunities for training in the territorial army

fields.headline: Basic training
fields.standfirst: Need some soft skills? Join the territorial army, suggests  John  Crace
fields.trailText: Need some soft skills? Join the territorial army, suggests John Crace
fields.body:
A recent management survey by the Roffey Park Institute suggested that 80% of the workforce didn't trust their employers to look after their training interests. To which the jaundiced among us might add, "So few?". Anyway, the message is clear; if you want to add to your skills and qualifications there's no point in waiting for helpful suggestions from your employer.

And even when you know what you want to do, although some large firms may be prepared to fork out a couple of grand for a training course, most medium to small firms don't have the budget. They would far rather just recruit someone who had already been on that training course.

So what can you do about it? Well, you could think about becoming an officer in the Territorial Army (TA). Now, before you fall about laughing, consider this.

Name one other place where you can be paid over and above your normal salary to study for top level qualifications and training - from NVQs to MBAs and membership of professional organisations, such as the Chartered Institute of Personnel.

The TA doesn't have the best of images in civvy street. The combat fatigues went out of fashion with Swampy and running around playing soldiers on Salisbury Plain at the weekend isn't most people's idea of fun. Which is one of the reasons that the TA is currently on an officer recruitment drive.

Each year it needs to fill 400 places on its officer training course at Sandhurst and is currently only reaching about half that target figure. Put the words "officer" and "army" together and you tend to think posh, upper-class male. But that's far from the norm.

David Scott from Kilmarnock in Scotland joined the TA seven years ago when he was 28.

"I joined because I was looking for something a bit different," he says. "I wanted to drive trucks and it sounded like an interesting hobby." Scott was picked out as officer material and was fast-tracked. He is now a major in the Scottish Transport Regiment.

Men still dominate the officer ranks, but women are encouraged to apply. You might recognise Anita Newcourt as the woman who features regularly in the docusoap Airport as Heathrow's manager of the VIP suites; you almost certainly wouldn't recognise her in fatigues at weekends when she metamorphoses into a major at UK Land Command.

Both Scott and Newcourt speak eloquently of what skills the TA has given them in their civilian jobs.

"I got my current job as sales development coordinator with Arnold Clark Automobiles purely because I was in the TA," says Scott. "My boss recognised the qualities the TA provides and said, 'I want to employ you; all I need to do is to work out what job I want you to do.'"

Newcourt is equally emphatic. "British Airports Authority had such confidence in my TA training that I was given a team of 16 without having had any BAA management training," she says. "There are no courses run by BAA that could prepare me for the situations I face in my daily job."

The benefits of the TA do not end with formal training, though, as Dr John Knell, director of futures at the Industrial Society, points out.

"As people gain more qualifications, it becomes harder for employers to differentiate between candidates," he says. "Increasingly, recruiters are looking for people with the so-called soft skills of self-confidence, leadership, team building, dependability, communication and emotional intelligence. The hard part for most young people is to prove they have them. Serving in the TA is one way they can do this."

Even so the TA is having an uphill struggle to sell itself. Some employers see the benefits of having members of staff in the TA, but many are unconvinced. Similarly, many young people may balk at the commitment. TA recruits are expected to give up a minimum of 27 days per year and, as the TA is now deployed alongside the regular Army, they may also find themselves in the firing line in Kosovo.

The TA is aware of the problem, but as Lt Col Spencer Gammond says, "We're looking to appeal to everyone. What we want is to make sure that those who might be interested know what we have to offer."

webTitle: How colleges help communities hit by mass unemployment

fields.headline: To the rescue
fields.standfirst: When redundancy strikes, it's the college that steps into the breach. By  Nick Tester
fields.trailText: When redundancy strikes, it's the college that steps into the breach. By Nick Tester
fields.body:
It is an irony surely not lost on the 6,000 steelworkers now being thrown on the scrapheap as a result of the closure of Britain's biggest steel plant, run by the giant Anglo-Dutch firm, Corus. The further education colleges that helped make them the most efficient steel manufacturers in the world are now jumping to their rescue.

The Ebbw Vale tinplate plant, which has seen steel production for two centuries and is to close with the loss of 800 jobs, is already witness to 11% unemployment, the worst in Wales. Nearly 1,500 jobs are being lost at nearby Llanwern, Newport, with others being axed in Port Talbot.

Nor, in the cold commercial language, is "rationalisation" limited to south Wales: plants at Hartlepool, Teeside, Scunthorpe, Corby, Rotherham, Stockton and Stockbridge in England are also being hit.

When the major employer in the community goes down the ripples are substantial and it is the further education college that often tries to pick up the pieces.

Take Coleg Gwent - formerly Gwent Tertiary College. It seems that it is no exaggeration to point out that Corus owed its early strength to the college, the largest in Wales, comprising of six campuses and catering for more than two thirds of the entire Welsh further education sector.

A few years ago, explained vice-principal Jeffrey Robinson, it was primarily responsible for introducing to the production lines a series of "team training programmes" designed to make groups of up to 30 steel workers more adept at tackling technical problems as and when they occurred in the steel-making process.

"We've had a long association of working with the firm and the team training scheme we did helped to make it hugely productive." At one time Corus was producing 920 tonnes of steel per head of worker compared to the next best in the world, 700 tonnes.

"The idea was we'd train teams of steel workers to maintain production if a problem cropped up, rather than resorting to the traditional habit of waiting, and hence being inefficient, for a team equipped with separate skills to turn up and sort things out."

This example of how further education responds to the pressing needs of industry will have pleased Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, who sets great store by the ability of education and training institutions to pick up the pieces when things fall apart. Although his suggestion on radio that re-training was the answer provoked sneering disbelief from Today programme presenter John Humphries, Byers stuck to his guns, reminding the audience that a new learning and skills era was unfolding out there.

The minister didn't have much evidence to wave, so he may care to take note of the experience of Sutton Coldfield College, which found itself in the middle of an industrial crisis 10 months ago when the local Rover plant was shoved onto the hard-shoulder by owners BMW. A lot of steel, of course, had been shifted from Corus to make the Rover vehicles.

Graham Jones, principal of Sutton Coldfield College, says there are four main courses of action.

"We got in touch with the unions because they were the most effective way for us to get our message across.

"Then we put in dedicated support from the careers service to link advice and make sure new career chances were spelt out.

"The next thing was to check all our opportunities were coordinated, making sure as far as possible that our courses were relevant and accessible."

But the most important lesson, Jones believes, was not to delay their response.

"You have to move quickly, which is what we did. We didn't wait for official backing from the Further Education Funding Council to run extra courses. We decided to leap into the tide and worry later about funding."

Back in Wales it is understood that the Welsh Assembly wants some recent money earmarked for flood prevention to be re-directed to the Welsh funding council to allow colleges like Coleg Gwent to mop up with far more success. It is a pointed sign of how education and training -alongside rising floods - can be viewed as an emergency deserving contingency planning and rapid responses.

While Byers puts his faith in further education to ride to the rescue, Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister, says he is wary about current weaknesses in college provision, particularly in engineering and construction industries.

"Construction industry employers are finding it increasingly difficult to attract new workers, especially women, ethnic minorities and older workers," he laments, casting a steely eye on further education.

Fortunately, claims Robinson, Coleg Gwent has a proven track record of responding to local difficulties when they flare up, with a range of appropriate tactics to interest workers in the vast range of courses they put on.

"There is sufficient gloom in the area and we feel very close to it," says Robinson. "Our job now is to customise our courses and not add to the gloom. We are ready to go."

webTitle: In brief: Harrison Ford to play Indiana Jones for £30m

fields.headline: Harrison Ford to play Indiana Jones for £30m
fields.standfirst: Plus: Courteney Cox and David Arquette to work out marriage woes in public; Jamie Bell gets up to second world war mischief; Hannibal sparks film ratings row in Australia
fields.trailText: Plus: Courteney Cox and David Arquette to work out marriage woes in public; Jamie Bell gets up to second world war mischief; Hannibal sparks film ratings row in Australia
fields.body:
 Harrison Ford is a step closer to agreeing to appear in a final Indiana Jones film, according to ananova this afternoon.The 58-year-old star has apparently been offered more than £30m to reprise his role as the adventuring professor. This would include a £15m fee, plus shares in profits, merchandising and book deals which would bring him a further £15m. Steven Spielberg has been discussing Indiana's spectacular send-off with the What Lies Beneath star for some time. "Steven thinks Harrison is worth every cent," a source close to the project told ananova. "The guest star list Steven has planned is amazing with [Sean] Connery, his wife Kate Capshaw and Karen Allen who was in the first Jones movie."

 The stormy marriage between Courteney Cox and David Arquette is to be played out in a new film starring the couple, according to ananova. The Friends star and her husband will play a sparring married couple who are given a series of strange exercises to try by an unconventional marriage counsellor (to be played by James Woods). In real life the couple, who married two years ago, saw a therapist to help them through what Cox described as "teething problems." A source close to the project told ananova: "They think this would be a lot of fun to do in the hiatus from Friends. It might also put an end to rumours about them getting a divorce."

 Jamie Bell is set to star in a new film set during the second world war. The 14-year-old star will follow up the Oscar-nominated Billy Elliot with Who Goes There, the tale of three boys who get into mischief on a German U-boat. He told reporters: "It doesn't matter who's in it, because it's just interesting for me, wanting to go back to that time."

 The Australian attorney general has ordered a review of film classification after outrage from the public that children would be allowed to see horror film Hannibal (see earlier story). Daryl Williams is reportedly unhappy that the violent follow up to The Silence of the Lambs has only been rated MA (Mature Accompanied) which allows children under 15 to see the film with an adult. "In light of the national release of the film tomorrow," he told reporters, "I have asked the Classification Review Board to consider this application as a matter of urgency." The Australian Censorship Board, however, has defended its rating, claiming that the violence in Hannibal was not gratuitous. Hannibal is released in Britain on Friday, with an 18 certificate.

The Australian Censorship Board, however, has defended its rating, claiming that the violence in Hannibal was not gratuitous. Hannibal is released in Britain on Friday, with an 18 certificate.

webTitle: Harlow branded 'the next Hackney'

fields.headline: Harlow branded 'the next Hackney'
fields.trailText: An Essex council has been branded "the next Hackney" in the wake of a damning auditor's report on its work.
fields.body:
An Essex council has been branded "the next Hackney" in the wake of a damning auditor's report on its work.

Audit commission inspectors brought in to review Harlow district council say the authority provides, "high cost services, performing poorly across the board, and the situation is getting worse not better".

They add that Labour-run Harlow has no ambition to deliver significantly improved services, and call on the authority to urgently deliver a "serious step change" in costs and performance.

The statements are part of a preliminary presentation of the commission's findings. It hints that the inspectors will recommend government intervention - they conclude: "We cannot allow this situation to continue unresolved."

The final report has not yet been published, and ministers say they not received any recommendation for intervention yet.

Shadow local government minister Nigel Waterson today slammed Harlow's performance: "They're in a real state. I'd say they're on their way to becoming the next Hackney."

Troubled Hackney council has become a byword for local government catastrophe after discovering earlier this year that it could face a budget shortfall of up to £40m.

The three-strong inspection team went into Harlow to examine how well it was implementing the government's new best value service regime. The presentation says they intend to tell the public that: "Local people are poorly served by Harlow council. They are paying too much for poor services Harlow spends the most money per head than any other district council in the country. For this high spending, it has some of the poorest performance across a range of services."

The council has accepted nearly all the inspectors' findings, but argues that improvements to Harlow's services are already taking place.

A spokeswoman for the authority commented: "What the report says about what's gone before is correct. The council now has a new management team and a new political leadership, who've already put in place actions that will lead to significant improvements."

She added that a new financial and performance management strategy put in place over the last six months would help to turn the council around.

Independent councillor Matthew Shepherd said: "It's not the next Hackney. I think Harlow is unique in its level of incompetence."

webTitle: IPC to launch mag trade shows

fields.headline: Top IPC titles set to launch trade shows
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: IPC magazines such as Loaded and Marie Claire could soon have their own trade shows, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
IPC's high-profile magazine brands such as Loaded and Marie Claire could soon have their own trade shows.

The leading consumer title publisher has announced it is to launch a separate events division to house spin-offs from its magazine brands.

The new division, headed by former Gruner + Jahr exhibitions chief Stephanie Grice, will develep events from IPC's most successful magazines.

IPC already organises several shows, including the Decanter Fine Wine Encounter and the VolksWorld Show, but a spokeswoman said it wanted to tap into higher profile brands.

Ms Grice said she hoped to target one in four adults through the events in the next two years.

webTitle: Philip Morris denies F1 reports

fields.headline: Philip Morris denies F1 reports
fields.trailText:
5.45pm: Philip Morris has rejected reports of a pull-back from F1 sponsorship as 'inaccurate', reports Daniel Rogers.
Marlboro may quit formula one next year
fields.body:
Philip Morris has slammed press reports that it is on the verge of pulling out of its £45m-a-year Marlboro sponsorship deal with Ferrari formula one as "inaccurate".

However, the tobacco giant has fallen short of confirming its long-term commitment to the sport.

Speculation that Philip Morris was considering ending its backing for the Ferrari team in 2002 arose from a report in German magazine Focusi this week.

"The story in Focusi is inaccurate. There has certainly been no announcement about this," said a spokeswoman for Philip Morris.

Meanwhile, Ferrari formula one said it had not been informed of any change in the intentions of Philip Morris, which is free to advertise the Marlboro brand on cars until 2006 according to EC tobacco laws.

Focusi quoted Philip Morris chief executive Geoffrey C Bible as saying the company would only continue extremely low-level sponsorships to free up money to pay huge compensation claims in the US.

The news that Marlboro, synonymous with formula one for 30 years, was considering pulling out of the sport has shocked many in the UK marketing sector.

However Matthew Patten, chief executive of M&C Saatchi Sponsorship, sees some logic in the move.

"Governments around the world, and the sport itself, are reducing the ways in which tobacco companies can exploit their sponsorship. It is the law of diminishing returns."

He added: "The tobacco market in advanced countries is also mature, which means that brand building may be less effective than price cutting in boosting demand for Marlboro.

"It may be that Philip Morris is moving away from big bonanza sponsorship to more tactical marketing techniques."

webTitle: Byers confirms digital giveaway

fields.headline: Byers confirms digital giveaway
fields.trailText:
5.30pm: Stephen Byers has confirmed the government is to run pilots offering free digital television equipment. By Jessica Hodgson.
Feb 13: Digital TV pilots offer free switch
fields.body:
Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers has confirmed that the government is to run pilots offering free digital television equipment, as part of the new white paper on enterprise, skills and innovation.

The news comes as the chief executive of the Independent Television Commission, Patricia Hodgson, said she thought a UK-wide set-top box giveaway would be "inevitable" before analogue switch-off.

Mr Byers today launched the white paper, called Opportunity for All, which is designed to boost access to what the government calls the "knowledge economy".

The white paper makes provision for small-scale pilots for localised communities, where the government will assess the impact the technology has on people's lives.

Meanwhile, giving evidence today before the select committee for culture media and sport into the communications white paper, Ms Hodgson said a digital equipment giveaway "will have to happen".

Ms Hodgson, a former BBC strategy chief, told the committee that broadcasters had a responsibility to do "as much as we can" to speed up the uptake of digital.

She was responding to fears expressed by committee members that the target for 95% of consumers having digital TV before the analogue signal is switched off may not be reached by the 2006 target date for switch-off.

Ms Hodgson added that she was "struck by the way in which British broadcasters have managed to move into digital television".

Quizzed by the select committee on the ITC's decision to force ITV to reinstate News at Ten, Ms Hodgson defended the move.

She pointed out that the combined average audience for the BBC1 and ITV late evening news programmes had risen from 7.5m to 10m since the two bulletins had been head to head.

webTitle: Douglas nets top NHS finance job

fields.headline: Douglas nets top NHS finance job
fields.trailText: The top job in NHS finance has gone to Richard Douglas, a former senior Department of Health (DoH) finance manager, the government has revealed.
fields.body:
The top job in NHS finance has gone to Richard Douglas, a former senior Department of Health (DoH) finance manager, the government has revealed.

Richard Douglas, currently director of finance at National Savings, will replace his former boss, NHS director of finance Colin Reeves, who leaves the department this week.

Mr Douglas is believed to have impressed ministers with his work in kick-starting the faltering private finance initiative hospital building programme while NHS deputy director of finance between 1996 and 1999.

He will be pitched straight into managing acute NHS financial pressures as it struggles to balance next year's budgets with the demands of NHS plan initiatives, despite record funding increases.

The NHS finance community today welcomed the DoH's announcement, although there may be disappointment that the manager who will be in charge of the £40bn NHS budget is a career civil servant.

Mark Millar, chairman of the healthcare financial management association, said: "It is good to see Richard back. We know him in the service and he knows the system and the service. We look forward to an early meeting to discuss matters of mutual interest."

Independent management consultant and former NHS deputy director of finance Brian Marsden said: "The job will demand an all-round person with both technical accounting skills and a feel for wider economic issues. Richard fits the bill."

The post - which carries a salary of between £82,000 and £120,000 - will require Mr Douglas to provide advice to ministers on the affordability of their policies and to negotiate with the treasury for extra cash for the NHS.

It is Mr Douglas's third spell with the NHS. He was head of financial planning and monitoring at the NHS executive 1990-92, and deputy director of finance and performance from March 1996 to February 1999. In his early 40s, Hull University graduate Mr Douglas is a member of the Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accountancy.

webTitle: National charity to administer £70m anti-poverty fund

fields.headline: National charity to administer £70m anti-poverty fund
fields.trailText: The Community Foundation Network has been given the job of administering the £70m anti-poverty local children's fund network, the government announced today.
fields.body:
The Community Foundation Network has been given the job of administering the £70m anti-poverty local children's fund network, the government announced today.

The membership organisation, which co-ordinates community foundations nationwide, will administer the local funds from April. Community foundations are grant-making trusts which promote voluntary and community activity in specific geographical areas in the UK.

The foundations will now work in partnership with other voluntary organisations - including those specialising in children's issues - to administer the children's fund local network in selected areas in England. Partner organisations, such as other grant-making trusts and rural councils, will administer the funds in areas where there is no foundation coverage.

The children's fund local network will channel money directly to local community and voluntary groups working to tackle poverty and disadvantage among children and young people. The local funds are worth £70m over three years.

"We are delighted to have been given this opportunity," said the Community Foundation Network's director, Gaynor Humphreys. "It will allow us to support ideas and projects developed in local communities by people with first-hand experience of poverty who are looking for ways in which they can make a difference for their own children and those in their neighbourhoods and communities."

She added: "Community foundations have a strong belief in the value of their grants to community groups. At least 30% of their grants already support work with children, and much of that addresses poverty and disadvantage."

The local network will support local voluntary and community groups in England that help vulnerable children and youths aged under 20. Grants will be made according to four criteria:
 economic disadvantage, covering "imaginative schemes" to enable families to improve their living standards
 isolation and access, consisting of prevention and crisis work with hard-to-reach groups
 aspirations and experiences, aimed at bridging the gap between the experiences of children living in poverty and their contemporaries
 children's voices, giving children a chance to articulate their own needs.

Paul Boateng, minister for young people, said: "The involvement of local communities is vital in helping vulnerable children to break out of the cycle of poverty and disadvantage and move on to a brighter future. The local network, based in communities and administered by local voluntary organisations, will make a real difference to the lives of many children, young people and their families".

The children's fund, worth £450m over three years, was announced in the last spending review. The fund comprises a £380m programme of preventative work, aimed at children primarily aged between 5 and 13 and their families, and a £70m network of local funds.

By 2003-04, the local network should consist of about 50 local funds covering the whole country.

Areas to receive local network funding in 2001, along with detailed grant criteria and information on how to apply for funding, will be announced in March.

webTitle: New ITC regulation starts next month

fields.headline: ITC gets to work on new 'light touch' regulation
fields.trailText:
3.45pm: The ITC is to begin rolling out its new 'light touch' programming regulation next month, reports Wale Azeez.
Feb 13: Peaktime soap output soars by 150%
fields.body:
The Independent Television Commission has confirmed that this April will see the last of the annual reviews on the programming performance of ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5.

From next year, the annual review - in which the ITC holds the commercial broadcasters to detailed and sometimes painful account for the programming promises made in their licence submissions - will make way for a programme statement drawn up by the broadcasters themselves.

An ITC spokesman confirmed the regulator will next month be contacting the commercial broadcasters to begin the process of drawing up the statements of programming policy.

The ITC will review whether the broadcasters have kept to their programming commitments in 2002.

The spokesman added that the move reflected the recommendations made in last year's communications white paper for a less prescriptive assessment of programming output by the new single communications regulator Ofcom.

The BBC's programming services will remain outside the ITC's remit. But once Ofcom is set up, the BBC will also have to draw up a programming statement for the new regulator to review on an annual basis.

The ITC wil be sending a statement of principle to ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5 requesting a "diversity statement" on their programming outputs, to be submitted in March.

The statement of principle will provide a framework for the implementation of the white paper recommendations before new legislation is passed.

The broadcasters' "diversity statements" will then be measured against actual performance by the ITC after 12 months.

ITC chief executive Patricia Hodgson, speaking last night at the ITN European Media Forum Lecture, said the commission had decided to "step back from our own assessment of ITV, Channel 4, and Channel 5.

"Instead, we'll ask licensees to volunteer a rolling annual statement of how they plan to deliver their remits," she added.

The speech by Ms Hodgson, the former BBC policy and planning chief, was widely regarded as a pitch for the job of head of Ofcom.

"At the end of the year, we'll expect the channels to report on how they've done. But we won't leave it there - we'll report on what the licensees say in the context of audience judgements and an objective, fact-based assessment of what the industry as a whole has to offer," she added.

On the wider question of the future shape of public service broadcasting, Ms Hodgson said: "The BBC is the basis of the system and BBC1 the core."

"ITV must compete with it, and [BBC] 2 and [Channel] 4 complement it," she added.

"When BBC1 moves, so will the rest. So BBC1 must provide a sure foundation if public service is to survive.

"Guaranteed public funding makes that possible. When we decide to mould the market, that's where we should begin."

webTitle: Charities explore links between animal cruelty and child abuse

fields.headline: Charities explore links between animal cruelty and child abuse
fields.trailText: Two UK charities have taken the unusual step of teaming up to look at the links between child and animal abuse, and the implications for joint protection work.
fields.body:
Two UK charities have taken the unusual step of teaming up to look at the links between child and animal abuse, and the implications for joint protection work.

The NSPCC and the RSPCA yesterday held a joint conference, Making the Links, to examine what they say is mounting evidence, largely from the US, of the links between cruel treatment of children and of animals.

Professionals from social work, probation, domestic violence, health, police, veterinary, psychology and youth offending services were invited. Workshop topics included the impact of animal abuse on child development, indicators of abuse to animals and children, humane education and cruelty prevention, links between domestic violence and animal abuse, multi-agency working, pet fostering for abused families, and working with young abusers.

Mary Marsh, chief executive of the NSPCC, said: "Animals and children have one thing in common - they're both easy to hurt. Maltreatment of animals in a family can sound a warning bell that children are also at risk. We need to recognise the cruelty connection."

Research carried out in the US has shown that men who attack their female partners and children may try to exert more control by harming or killing family animals, or threatening to do so, says the NSPCC. US research has also found that children who are cruel to animals, or witness acts of cruelty, may become desensitised to violence in adulthood.

The RSPCA is about to launch a new educational resource for use with young offenders who have harmed animals. The charity's aim is to prevent repeat offending by encouraging the youths to "empathise" with animals.

One of the few studies in Britain looking at the likely co-existence of child and animal cruelty was the Hutton Report in 1981. The research reported that, of 23 families investigated by the RSPCA for animal abuse or neglect, 82% were also known to local social services departments because their children were at risk.

But because very little research exists in the UK, the NSPCC is planning a research project on the links between child abuse and animal cruelty in conjunction with the University of Durham.

webTitle: Making the cruelty connection

fields.headline: Making the cruelty connection
fields.standfirst: Mary Marsh explains why child protection workers and veterinary surgeons have something to learn from one another
fields.trailText: Comment: Child protection workers and veterinary surgeons have something to learn from one another, writes Mary Marsh
fields.body:
A wide range of professionals involved in child protection and animal welfare issues came to yesterday's conference at the NSPCC national training centre in Leicester to hear about the links between child and animal abuse, and the implications for their work.

What we heard led us to realise that there is a great deal of common ground among professionals working in both fields. However, there are also gaps where we are not making the best use of information available to us to ensure that children and animals are protected.

The conference clearly demonstrated the complexity of the subject. It's not just about victims and abusers but about the relationship between children and animals, and the way that relationship can be manipulated. Animals can be used as a way to put pressure on children or as scapegoats for parents' abuse of children. For instance, if a child appears at casualty with bruising, the parent or carer could claim the family dog caused the injuries.

It was also made apparent yesterday how distressing it is for both children and animals to observe abuse, and for children when they are forced to participate in abuse. US studies presented at the conference showed that violence against animals is prevalent as part of wider domestic violence. You might expect that families with histories of violence would be less likely to own pets but findings showed that such families had significantly more pets than the average household. The majority of these pets were less than two years old, with many being killed or discarded before they reached maturity.

Although research on the subject is extraordinarily limited, and quite seriously so in the UK, it is clear that witnessing or perpetrating cruelty against animals can be detrimental to the development of a child.

Social workers and other professionals - including vets - are not yet trained to notice the indicators of animal abuse. It would be useful to professionals working in child protection to understand these indicators, as pets are recognised as playing a significant part in family life, particularly for children. We need to develop awareness of this issue, but not to add another layer of bureaucracy to hinder over-burdened social workers.

One of our main tasks, following the conference, will be to tackle the paucity of research in the UK. The NSPCC is planning a research project in conjunction with the University of Durham. This subject needs to be recognised as a significant topic for debate, deserving priority among professionals. The group that planned the conference, itself a multi-agency group, will now come up with proposals for future work.

Animals and children have something in common - they are both easy to hurt - and we need to recognise this cruelty connection. The conference provided a unique opportunity for professionals to explore these links and consider how they can work together to create a future free from cruelty to children and animals.

webTitle: Lawrence friend's claim against Met thrown out

fields.headline: Lawrence friend's claim against Met thrown out
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The main witness to the murder of Stephen Lawrence had his negligence case against the former commissioner of the Metropolitan police thrown out yesterday.
fields.body:
The main witness to the murder of Stephen Lawrence had his negligence case against the former commissioner of the Metropolitan police thrown out yesterday.

Duwayne Brooks, who was with his friend Stephen on the night he was stabbed in 1993, wanted to sue the Met for negligence, misfeasance in public office and false imprisonment.

The Metropolitan police had applied to have Mr Brooks's case thrown out, and a judge at central London county court decided his claims were unsubstantiated in law or unarguable on the facts alleged.

Mr Brooks sued the commissioner and several officers after publication of the Macpherson report into the force's failure to properly investigate the murder.

His claims against the commissioner, who he alleged was liable for the actions of his officers, included negligence, because police did not identify him as a victim, and misfeasance, because police abused their powers in the way they treated him. He claimed false imprisonment because officers kept him alone and traumatised in a police car after the murder.

Mr Brooks's solicitor, Jane Deighton, will be appealing against the ruling.

webTitle: Four quit police advisory group on Met racism group

fields.headline: Four quit police advisory group on Met racism group
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard's tarnished reputation on race was dealt another blow yesterday when four black members of its independent advisory group resigned, saying group members had been reduced to being "nodding dogs".
fields.body:
Scotland Yard's tarnished reputation on race was dealt another blow yesterday when four black members of its independent advisory group resigned, saying group members had been reduced to being "nodding dogs".

The Met set up the independent advisory group as a key plank of its strategy to tackle its failings on race revealed by the Macpherson report into the Stephen Lawrence murder.

In their resignation letter the four said the IAG is "explicitly controlled by the police", losing its independence and credibility, and used by the Met to neutralise criticism.

The IAG, billed as being comprised of the Met's sternest critics, advised the embattled force on criminal cases and internal issues.

The four who resigned yesterday are law lecturer Ben Bowling, an expert on community and race relations, Andrea Cork, creative director with the management consultants Ionan, which trains parts of the Met in race relations, Jennifer Douglas, chair of the Lambeth community police consultative group and a home office advisor on gender issues, and Kirpal Sahota, a consultant forensic psychiatrist and a former vice chairman of the IAG.

Last night Ms Douglas said: "There is little evidence to suggest black Londoners should trust the Met. I don't think there's been any change impacting on the policing of London's communities since the Macpherson report."

In their resignation letter they wrote: "We feel that we can no longer remain members of the IAG because it is now explicitly controlled by the police. As a result it can no longer claim to offer independent advice and is, therefore, failing in its responsibility to improve policing for Londoners."

The four criticised the IAG chairwoman, Beverley Thompson, accusing her of becoming part of the police service: "We feel that in the past 18 months the IAG has gradually lost its critical distance from the police service. As a result, it has lost its capacity to challenge, its independence and its credibility in pursuing a critical agenda. All efforts to pull this back have been sabotaged from both the police and some members of the IAG.

"In particular, the chair of the group has, in our view, become too close to the police to be able to ask difficult questions, to challenge questionable practices, and to echo the hard to hear voices of local communities. We have reached the unhappy conclusion that the chair has become integrated into the police service."

The final straw for the four was Ms Thompson's involvement in the Ali Dizaei case, one of the Met's top ethnic minority officers who was suspended last month over misconduct allegations. The Met claimed that IAG members had reviewed the case, but the four say they were unaware of the group's involvement until they read about it in newspaper reports.

In their resignation letter the four former members said: "The IAG has ceased to function independently, or collectively. We cannot in good faith continue to be part of a group that is supposed to be comprised of the organisation's 'sternest critics', when this is clearly no longer the case. We cannot remain as nodding dogs who will not speak out for Londoners. We feel that the IAG process is no longer contributing to the restoration of confidence and trust in the MPS in any meaningful way."

After yesterday's resignations, the IAG is left with seven Asian or black members.

Lee Jasper, adviser on equality to London mayor Ken Livingstone who himself resigned from the IAG in 1999, said: "This is deeply damaging to the Met as they've lost individuals who have enormous amount of credibility with black communities right across London."
