webTitle: Gladiator and Crouching Tiger lead race for Oscars

fields.headline: Gladiator and Crouching Tiger lead race for Oscars
fields.trailText: The nominations for this year's Academy Awards put Gladiator, Traffic, Erin Brockovich and Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon at the front of the race for Oscar glory
fields.body:
The nominations for the 73rd annual Academy Awards were announced at 5.38am Pacific time (1.38pm GMT) by Academy president Robert Rehme and actress Kathy Bates (an Oscar winner herself for 1990's Misery). In keeping with the Oscar tradition the announcement took the form of a swift and sober Beverly Hills press call - a spartan contrast, one assumes, to the lavish ceremony that will follow on March 25.

There were few major surprises in the list of nominees. As expected, Gladiator leads the hunt with 12 nominations, closely followed by Ang Lee's dark-horse Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (10 nominations). The award for Best Film will be fought out between Chocolat, Erin Brockovich, Crouching Tiger, Gladiator and Traffic.

The one unexpected guest in the Best Actor category was Spanish star Javier Bardem (nominated for Before Night Falls). The other contenders are Russell Crowe (for Gladiator), Tom Hanks (for Cast Away), Ed Harris (Pollock) and Geoffrey Rush (Quills).

The nominees for Best Actress are Joan Allen (The Contender), Juliette Binoche (Chocolat), Ellen Burstyn (Requiem for a Dream), Laura Linney (You Can Count on Me) and heavy favourite Julia Roberts (Erin Brockovich).

The award for Best Director will go to either Ridley Scott (Gladiator), Ang Lee (for Crouching Tiger), Britain's Stephen Daldry (for Billy Elliot) or Steven Soderbergh who has been nominated for both Traffic and Erin Brockovich.

The great wild cards of this year's awards are thus confirmed as Soderbergh, who may yet wind up splitting the votes in both the Best Film and Best Director categories and so come away with nothing, and Crouching Tiger. Ang Lee's epic is nominated for both Best Film and Best Foreign Language Film. If Ang Lee's Mandarin film fails to snare the coveted Best Film Oscar, insiders predict it will take the other as a consolation prize.

5pm: Channel East, Channel 4 and the BBC Asian Network have been nominated for the broadcaster of the year award, writes Wale Azeez.

fields.body:
Satellite network Channel East is up against Channel 4 and the BBC Asian Network in the new broadcaster of the year category at the 2001 Race in the Media awards.

Actress Meera Syal and BBC newscaster Moira Stuart will present the awards at the RIMA ceremony, which will be held at the Savoy on April 6.

As well as broadcaster of the year, RIMA organiser the Commission for Racial Equality has introduced another new award - best soap.

Channel 4's Brookside will compete for the title against BBC Wales's Pobol Y Cwm and Westway, the BBC World Service radio drama.

A total of 375 submissions were received across the 18 RIMA categories.

This year's awards will be hosted by CRE chairman Gurbux Singh.

Clive Jones, chief executive of Carlton Channels and chairman of the Cultural Diversity Network, will be the keynote speaker.

Related story

webTitle: BBC brings forward MacArthur documentary

fields.headline: BBC brings forward MacArthur documentary
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: The BBC has brought forward a documentary on British yachtswoman Ellen MacArthur, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The BBC has brought forward a documentary on British yachtswoman Ellen MacArthur, after her record-breaking round-the-world voyage attracted massive media interest.

The BBC1 documentary about Ms MacArthur's extraordinary feat - becoming the youngest person ever to circumnavigate the world single-handed and in the fastest time for a woman - was originally scheduled for the autumn, but will now go out on March 1.

A BBC film crew met Ms MacArthur's yacht at Les Sables d'Olonne, a fishing village on the French Atlantic coast, when she completed her remarkable vovage on Sunday.

The rest of the programme will be made up of footage from four cameras installed on Ms MacArthur's yacht, video diary footage and an interview filmed before she began the race.

The BBC Wales documentary, which was originally commissioned as a 30-minute programme in the Extreme Lives series, will now be made into an hour-long special.

A BBC Wales spokeswoman said the decision to bring forward the documentary had only been taken today.

"It's great for us that she did so well, and we wanted to move fast with this one and show everyone how she did it," said the spokeswoman.

webTitle: Distribution is main obstacle facing aid agencies in Gujarat

fields.headline: Distribution is main obstacle facing aid agencies in Gujarat
fields.standfirst: Help the Aged's Nikki Hill reports on the work of aid agencies in Gujarat in the wake of the emergency rescue operation.
fields.trailText: Help the Aged's Nikki Hill reports on the work of aid agencies in Gujarat in the wake of the emergency rescue operation.
fields.body:
The rescue phase, and the stories of deaths and miracles amid the rubble, are well and truly over. Recovery activities are now in full swing for Indian and international agencies.

While massive amounts of relief are flowing in, distribution remains a pressing issue. For example, last Friday's Indian broadsheets carried stories about stockpiles of clothes and food supplies accumulating at Ahmedabad airport.

The mapping of needs on the ground remains a pressing task for all players, government and non-government organisations alike. For HelpAge International, together with network members Help the Aged and HelpAge India, rapid identification of the most vulnerable older people, such as those without family support or those caring for children whose parents died in the quake, is critical.

As for all aid agencies here, coordinating input to ensure maximum effect without duplication is essential.

HelpAge India's Ashok Rawat, who successfully managed HelpAge India's operations in the 1999 Orissa cyclone, has been appointed director of all emergency operations. Yesterday, his emergency team finalised details of a three-month plan, with immediate effect.

As the only agencies within the disasters emergency committee (DEC) to focus specifically on older people's needs in emergency and development settings, HelpAge International and partner HelpAge India have a critical role to play, both on the ground and in persuading other agencies to take account of older people in their planning of recovery activities and longer-term reconstruction work.

HelpAge India's mobile medicare units, which have reached into remote villages in Kutch since the earthquake hit on January 26, continue to dispense emergency medical aid and are, at the same time, establishing a clearer picture of the situation of older people and their families. A further programme of interview-based research, in areas such as the makeshift camps that have sprung up outside devastated towns, including Bhuj, has been agreed.

Two base camps, set up outside Bhachau and Bhuj and supported by sisters of the religious network Caritas Internationalis, a long-standing partner of HelpAge India, have been coordinating the distribution of food, blankets, shelters, cooking utensils and clothing.

During the next three months, activities will focus on the districts of Kutch, Rajkot and Surendranagar, reaching 7,500 older people and their families.

The mobile medicare units will serve a total of 52 villages, referring patients to other agencies such as Medecins Sans Frontieres, as required. They will provide preventive medicines (antibiotics, water purification tablets, and so on ) oral rehydration solutions, orthopedic treatment and psycho-social support, in collaboration with partner agencies.

A food and non-food distribution programme will operate in the same areas. It will focus on appropriate staple foods, including wheat mixed with bajra, oil and edible oil, pulses, and salt. Non-food items will include blankets, which will be distributed through HelpAge India and its local partner agencies; essential household items such as cooking utensils, buckets, water containers, plates and lanterns; and temporary plastic sheets and tents.

Coordination between DEC agencies continues. Mr Rawat and HelpAge International's emergencies officer Nadia Saim met with Oxfam last week to share information and coordinate activities.

Major institutional funders are showing active interest in the plight of older people in the wake of this disaster, and significant funding packages are being developed to support the relief programme.

Asian communities in the UK have contributed more than £120,000 to Help the Aged to support older people living in the earthquake zone.

 Nikki Hill is head of communications at Help the Aged.

webTitle: Sunday Express loses Craig to BBC

fields.headline: Sunday Express loses Craig to BBC
fields.trailText: 5.45pm: Sunday Express political editor Jon Craig has been made editor of the BBC's London political unit, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Sunday Express political editor Jon Craig is to join the BBC as the editor of its London political unit.

He is replacing Shaun Ley, who has been appointed the BBC's network political correspondent.

Mr Craig is a seasoned reporter, with experience as political correspondent on Today and home affairs correspondent on the Sunday Times.

Mr Craig also has regular slots on Sky News and Talk Radio and across the BBC.

He will present the weekly London programme MetroPol and will report on politics for Newsroom South East, BBC London Live and London Live online.

Mr Craig said it was a "dream job, involving TV, radio and writing.

"After being a newspaper correspondent for nearly 20 years, it's great to have a real crack at broadcasting and the new challenges it will bring," he added.

webTitle: 'We do not expect Sharon to be merciful to our children'

fields.headline: 'We do not expect Sharon to be merciful to our children'
fields.trailText: With prime minister-elect Ariel Sharon on the verge of stitching up a coalition deal, the papers are looking ahead with some nervousness to the installation of the new government.
fields.body:
With prime minister-elect Ariel Sharon on the verge of stitching up a coalition deal, the papers are looking ahead with some nervousness to the installation of the new government.

Herb Keinon, in the Jerusalem Post, has an interesting piece about Sharon's problem in persuading the world that the Oslo accords - the basis of the peace process - are dead and buried.

He predicts that the new government will place a much greater emphasis on a wider regional peace settlement, rather than a single agreement with the Palestinians: "According to this argument - one that will likely fall on receptive ears in a Bush administration that is very concerned about Iraq - the creation of a non-democratic Palestinian state will pose a threat not only to Israel but also to Jordan. In this scenario, even if a Palestinian state would not turn its sights on Israel, it could very well threaten Jordan in the hope of linking up with Iraq - a natural Palestinian ally - and create a huge, expansive, terror-sponsoring state on the border of Saudi Arabia." This is a prospect that would obviously concern the US and Europe and which will be raised by Sharon representatives in their forays abroad."

The Tel Aviv daily, Ha'aretz, helpfully provides an English translation of leading articles in the Palestinian papers. They cannot make comfortable reading for Israelis.

Al Hayat al-Jadida, for example, warns the incoming prime minister: "We are willing to stand up to anyone wishing to do us harm. Marcus asks, pertinently: "If we aren't witnessing the miracle of the leopard changing its spots, there's still the question of how exactly he will bring peace without removing a single settlement, without dividing Jerusalem and leaving 42% of the territories in Palestinian hands. webTitle: Email viruses

fields.headline: Email viruses
fields.standfirst: The Anna Kournikova virus is the latest to threaten our hard drives and our sanity. Here are the best sites to help avoid those pesky critters
fields.trailText: 13 February: As Anna Kournikova unwittingly threatens to damage a computer near you, we highlight the sites that will help you arm yourself against an attack.
fields.body:
1. A new virus that lures users with the promise of pictures of the tennis player Anna Kournikova is at large - and it could be coming to your email inbox soon. The Kournikova worm is the latest in a series of viruses transmitted as attachments to seemingly innocent emails, threatening unwitting users with untold damage to their computer at worst, or a lot of hassle at best.

2. The Love Bug was the last virus to hit the headlines, and you may also remember Melissa and the distastefully named Back Orifice 2000.

3. The list is endless. The problem is everywhere, and anyone can fall prey, from Microsoft to your mum.

4. Virus monitoring firm MessageLabs says it had detected and stopped 155,528 email viruses by the end of November last year.

5. It doesn't help that virus hoaxes abound, and there are always gullible but well-meaning saps ready to send them to everyone they know. The famous Good Times email virus, for instance, warned that a message containing the Good Times attachment would destroy your hard drive. It didn't exist.

6. The trouble is, we just won't learn our lesson about protecting our computers against virus attacks.

7. Being prepared is the key.

8. To avoid getting all worked up about a non-existent threat, check out sites such as Symantec's virus hoaxes page, which includes a handy hoax search facility to help you debunk spurious but scary virus warnings.

9. Or why not sign up for an email newsletter such as Tourbus or Virus Newsletter to keep abreast of all the latest hoaxes - and those genuine new viruses just waiting to make your life hell.

10. Finally, get yourself some effective anti-virus software - Norton Antivirus is one of the most popular - and make sure you get it updated regularly.

webTitle: Marlboro may end Formula One backing

fields.headline: Marlboro may end Formula One backing
fields.trailText: The government has received a massive symbolic boost to its anti-smoking campaign after one of the world's biggest tobacco brands suggested it may withdraw from Formula One sponsorship.
fields.body:
The government has received a massive symbolic boost to its anti-smoking campaign after one of the world's biggest tobacco brands suggested it may withdraw from Formula One sponsorship.

Tobacco giant Philip Morris is considering winding down its high profile Marlboro brand's £45m a year sponsorship of world champion driver Michael Schumacher's Ferrari car.

The government's tobacco bill, which will impose a staged ban of all tobacco advertising, sponsorship and promotion, today reaches its remaining stages in the Commons before passing to the Lords.

The bill controversially made Formula One a special case and allowed it a special three-year extension until 2006 to implement the ban. But Philip Morris said it would continue with only "low-key" sponsorships after 2002 in order to release funds to fight multi-million dollar compensation claims from former smokers.

The company's chief executive Geoffrey C Bible told German magazine Focusi: "After 2002 the engagement will only be at lower levels and on an economy flame. We have to find ways of saving money to meet these claims."

Anti-smoking lobby Action on Smoking and Health (Ash) welcomed the reports: "Marlboro has been a principle sponsor for so many years it would be a significant move from our point of view - it's very encouraging."

The tobacco advertising and promotion bill fulfils the government's 1997 election manifesto commitment to ban tobacco advertising as part of its bid to cut UK lung cancer death rates.

The bill, introduced last December, was opposed by the Tories who questioned whether tobacco advertising actually increased consumption. But it is expected to pass to the Lords unscathed - aside from government ammendments likely to strengthen the bill, such as the commitment to create a Tobacco Regulatory Authority.

The Department of Health is expected to implement the advertising ban within a few months of the bill receiving royal assent later this year, and the sponsorship ban by 30 July 2003.

 Four out of ten people who had promised to stop smoking as part of government-backed smoking cessation services had successfully done so four weeks after their target quit date, according to latest figures.

webTitle: The welfare state that oils Rolls-Royce

fields.headline: The welfare state that oils Rolls-Royce
fields.standfirst:
Despite the government's love of the free market, there are good reasons for helping world-class companies, says Larry Elliott

Government invests in Rolls-Royce engines
fields.trailText: Despite the government's love of the free market, there are good reasons for helping world-class companies, says Larry Elliott.
fields.body:
Everybody knows about the welfare state for people. It was the system of cradle-to-grave provision set up after the second world war following the publication of the Beveridge report.

Less well known is the welfare state for companies, the system whereby large dollops of public money are handed out by the department of trade and industry to big corporations.

Sometimes these hand-outs are to foreign companies that say that they will invest in Britain providing the government offers them the right fiscal package - tax breaks, a greenfield site for nothing, a straight cash payment.

Sometimes as in the case of today's £250 million subsidy to Rolls-Royce the money goes to domestic companies in order to safeguard jobs.

In political terms, it is not hard to see why the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, has dipped into the government's coffers. After the recent announcement by steel company Corus that it was planning major job losses, Labour needs to be seen supporting manufacturing industry.

In case anybody hadn't noticed, there's an election coming up.

There is also a good, solid economic case for the government backing Rolls-Royce, which is one of the world leaders in air engine production, in the development of the Trent 900 and the Trent 600.

Britain has precious few companies that could justly be classified as world class: Rolls-Royce is one of them. However, like much of the rest of British industry it has found the strength of the pound over the past few years uncomfortable, since a high exchange rate makes UK exports into a competitive world market more expensive.

While the government is unable or unwilling to do anything about the exchange rate, it is able to help Rolls-Royce in other ways.

But here's the oddity. This was a government that came into office converted to the delights of the free market. There was to be no government intervention, no bailing out of lame ducks, no picking of winners.

In one sense, it has been true to its word. Rolls-Royce was a lame duck when it was nationalised by the Conservatives in the early 1970s, but it is by no means a lame duck today.

Pre-tax profits, despite the level of the pound, more than doubled from £164 million to £365 million between 1995 to 1999, and the City is estimating a further rise to £435 million in 2000.

But this is definitely an interventionist policy. The real difference between now and the 1970s is twofold: the government has no desire to run businesses from Whitehall and companies are far more likely to get money when they are doing well than when they are doing badly.

Why? Because, in a world of mobile capital, they can always threaten to take production elsewhere. Whether this amounts to holding governments to ransom or simply good business, one thing is for sure. The payment to Rolls-Royce will not be the last.

webTitle: Coke hires US vice-president's PR chief

fields.headline: Coke hires US vice-president's PR chief
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Coca-Cola has hired US vice-president Dick Cheney's PR chief as its new spin doctor, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola has hired US vice-president Dick Cheney's PR chief as its new spin doctor.

Dirk Vande Beek, 42, has been appointed to the newly-created position of vice-president of public relations.

He was most recently director of communications and press secretary for Mr Cheney during the presidential campaign, where he developed Mr Cheney's national image and media strategy.

At Coca-Cola Mr Vande Beek will develop and implement the company's corporate public and media relations strategies and programmes.

He also will assist the company's separate divisions with their PR strategies.

Prior to joining the presidential campaign he was director of global public relations for the Halliburton Company.

Mr Vande Beek has also has served as director of development for Space Center Houston and has held positions within the National Policy Forum, the Federal Emergency Management Agency, the White House and the US Department of Labor.

"We will benefit greatly from Dirk's extensive communications experience in both the political and corporate arenas," said Coca-Cola senior vice-president and chief communications officer Charles Holleran.

"He is a very effective and strategic communicator and brings an expansive understanding of the importance and influence of communications to the Coca-Cola Company."

webTitle: Government invests in Rolls-Royce engines

fields.headline: Government invests in Rolls-Royce engines
fields.standfirst: Special report: Britain's car industry
fields.trailText: The government promised Rolls Royce £250m today, helping to sustain over 7,000 jobs.
fields.body:
The government promised Rolls Royce £250m today, helping to sustain over 7,000 jobs.

Rolls-Royce said today that it had secured orders worth more than £12bn for its Trent are engines, which will be designed and produced at the Rolls-Royce factory in Derby.

Ministers and union leaders welcomed the announcement because it safeguards more than 7,000 jobs at Derby and at suppliers across the UK.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said: "The government's backing for this project is a practical demonstration of our commitment to helping high-tech, high-skilled companies in the UK to compete on a global stage.

"Today's announcement confirms Rolls-Royce's position as a world leader in cutting edge high-tech design and manufacturing.

"The Trent range has already secured orders worth more than £12bn from 30 customers."

Mr Byers said that the government's investment followed "rigorous scrutiny", although it may be subject to approval from the European Commission.

"The investment will provide a substantial boost to manufacturing, not just in the East Midlands but throughout the country, with over 7,000 well paid, highly skilled jobs being safeguarded, as well as a direct return for taxpayers from the sale of the engines.

"This project will ensure that the Rolls-Royce Derby plant remains a centre of excellence for aero engine design, development and production for years to come."

Mr Byers, who has notified the EC of the government's investment plans, was visiting the Derby factory today.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union said: "This is a massive boost for the aerospace industry and shows government support for high-tech manufacturing. It is wonderful news."

John Rose, chief executive of Rolls-Royce, said: "The new Trent programme will reinforce the position of Rolls-Royce as a leader in the world civil aviation market, as well as strengthening the company's links with the world's two major airframe manufacturers.

"The programme will provide a further stimulus to technology acquisition and high-technology manufacturing in the UK. It will also sustain over 7,000 jobs within Rolls-Royce and its UK supply chain."

"That has got to be good news for manufacturing," said Mr Byers.

He was confident the deal would not infringe international rules on state aid for commercial enterprises.

"There are provisions under the World Trade Organisation and there was an agreement arrived at in 1992. And we have a power under the Civil Aviation Act to provide this sort of support.

"If people want to complain, well it's for them to do so."

He was confident that the government had complied with the rules on such investment, he added.

webTitle: Internet paedophiles jailed

fields.headline: Internet paedophiles jailed
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: 2.45pm update: Seven paedophiles were today sentenced to jail terms after a court heard how they helped compile a vast internet database of images of child sex abuse.
fields.body:
Seven paedophiles were jailed today after a court heard how they helped compile a vast internet database of images of child sex abuse.

All were members of the so-called Wonderland Club. Under present law, a three-year term was the maximum they could face, but all were given shorter sentences.

Judge Kenneth Macrae told the men at Kingston Crown Court that despite "pandering to the basest interests of man" they would have to be given credit for pleading guilty to conspiracy to distribute indecent images of children.

David Hines and Ian Baldock were sentenced to 30 months; Andrew Barlow, Ahmed Ali and Gavin Seagers to two years; Antoni Skinner to 18 months; and Frederick Stephens to 1 year.

The National Crime Squad's inquiry into the Wonderland paedophile ring was the world's largest police investigation, said officers from the case.

The group's 180 members saw themselves as the "elite" of the world's paedophiles.

Detectives who analysed the 750,000 pornographic images seized from Wonderland members know that 1,236 children were victims of the most horrific sexual abuse.

Meanwhile a teacher suspended from his job after pornographic images of children were found on a home computer has been was released on bail, police said today.

Special report: Child protection

webTitle: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. Why has it flopped in the east?

fields.headline: 'The film is so slow - it's like grandma telling stories'
fields.standfirst: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon has blazed a trail at western box offices. So why has it flopped in the east?  Steve Rose finds out
fields.trailText: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon has blazed a trail at western box offices. So why has it flopped in the east? Steve Rose finds out
fields.body:
Combining the cinemas of east and west is the cinematic equivalent of nuclear fusion: theoretically possible, potentially enormously rewarding, but in practice extremely difficult. And then came Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, with its combination of eastern philosophy and fighting, and western dramatic gravity. This, it was hoped, would be the film to crack the formula. The director said he wanted something that would be "like a summer blockbuster in Asia but an arthouse film in the rest of the world". But, if anything, the reverse has been true.

Having conquered film festivals across Europe and north America, Crouching Tiger has taken less than three weeks to become the UK's highest grossing foreign-language film of all time. In the US, it has also performed spectacularly (US$53m and rising). It recently received two Golden Globes, and is among this year's Oscar favourites.

Back on home territory, however, the reaction has been decidedly mixed. The film has scored well in Singapore and Taiwan but, in Korea and Japan, it has been outshone by domestic and Hollywood competition. In Hong Kong, despite critical acclaim, the film has taken HK$15.8m (£1.45m) since July, including a recent re-release. By way of comparison Jackie Chan's latest, Accidental Spy, has racked up almost twice as much in Hong Kong in its first three weeks.

"For Hong Kong Chinese there's simply not enough action," says Maria Wong, a post-production film executive in Hong Kong. "I grew up with this type of film. You can see them every day on TV. It's nothing new, even the female angle. But Crouching Tiger is so slow, it's a bit like listening to grandma telling stories."

For Hong Kong and Chinese audiences, the historical martial arts (or "wire-fu") genre is exemplified by 1980s films such as Ronnie Yu's The Bride With White Hair or Tsui Hark's Zu Warriors from the Magic Mountain and his Once Upon a Time in China series. The fight scenes are usually longer, more frequent and more technically skilled (Michelle Yeoh was the only real martial arts expert in Crouching Tiger).

Further, any intervals between fights are filled either with slapstick comedy or rapid-fire exposition, so as to cram in the extravagantly complex plotlines. Crouching Tiger's static drama was exacerbated for audiences in Hong Kong by seeing their Cantonese-speaking heroes, Chow Yun-Fat and Malaysian-born Michelle Yeoh, struggling with Mandarin prose.

In mainland China, where the film was shot, receipts have also been low, estimated at US$1.5m, though its performance may have been affected by Lee's Taiwanese nationality. Given China's strained relationship with the renegade republic, the mainland authorities are unlikely to have taken to the film. It was, in effect, off the market for three and a half months because of a dispute between producers, during which time millions of pirated DVDs of the film are said to have flooded the market, killing off subsequent demand.

James Schamus, Crouching Tiger's co-writer and executive producer, is quick to defend it: "It was the highest grossing Chinese-language film in virtually every Asian territory; even if it hadn't been released in the west, it would have been a huge success. It didn't do well in some places, but who's complaining? Not me!"

Schamus also dismisses as "western xenophobia" recent accusations that director Lee has tailored his "Chineseness" for western audiences, to deliver "cleverly packaged chop suey". Elements of the film were undoubtedly selected with western appeal in mind, however: cast members with international recognition; a score by cellist Yo-Yo Ma, well known in western classical circles; fight sequences by Yuen Wo-Ping, who now carries the suffix "of Matrix fame". Most importantly, the screenplay was in continual ping-pong between James Schamus and two Chinese scriptwriters, teasing out cross-cultural resonances from the source text: the fourth episode of Du Lang Wang's historical fable.

So Lee didn't quite crack the global formula, but he is not the first Chinese auteur to be feted in the west and ignored at home. Wong Kar-Wai, for example, has triumphed on western arthouse and film festival circuits with meditative urban tales such as last year's In the Mood for Love, but his films have only been minor hits in Hong Kong itself. Likewise with mainland stars such as Zhang Yimou (Raise the Red Lantern), Chen Kaige (Farewell My Concubine) and their successors. Frequently they have been forced to smuggle their films out of China for the benefit of appreciative western audiences.

For a film to conquer all corners of the world, it would have to be the cinematic equivalent of McDonald's: a big, bland, undemanding work of the type Lee will hopefully never produce. Films that succeed globally are usually out-and-out Hollywood epics such as Titanic or Mission: Impossible 2. From the Asian side, only Jackie Chan has that world-beating potential.

Even so, Crouching Tiger has, it is hoped, improved both sides of the equation. Western filmgoers might be tempted to delve further into the wire-fu genre - where works by Tsui Hark, King Hu, Chang Cheh among others await - and Chinese film-makers might be encouraged to return to it. The genre has all but dried up since Hollywood began tempting away its best exponents, most of whom had acquired cult status in the west with their home-made efforts, but whose US-made films have been dull. Hark, for instance, produced the indifferent Jean-Claude van Damme vehicle Knock Out in the US, but is now back in Hong Kong working on a sequel to 1983's Zu Warriors. He is reportedly trying to push the boundaries of the genre even further, in response to the success of Crouching Tiger. Given the west's new love affair with the genre, the film could even secure a theatrical release in the US or the UK, something Hong Kong action directors could never have dreamed of before.

webTitle: Reuters counts cost of net investment

fields.headline: Reuters counts cost of net investment
fields.trailText: 2pm: ,/B> Reuters's drive to embrace the internet has shaved £120m from its annual profits, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Reuters's drive to embrace the internet has shaved £120m from its annual profits between 1999 and 2000.

But the global financial news and information group has calmed investors' nerves by announcing results for 2000 broadly in line with analysts' expectations.

The company is juggling a massive internet investment programme and the planned flotation of its Instinet share-broking operation, but today's results showed both initiatives to be on track.

Reuters said its transformation into an internet-based group had reduced its "normalised" full-year profits from £577m in 1999 to £457m for 2000, after it spent £139m on the first stage of the programme.

Including goodwill and disposals, overall pre-tax profits rose 4% to £657m. This figure included a £271m gain from selling off some of the groups assets.

Reuters also said the flotation of its £2.5bn Instinet subsidiary would take place by the middle of the year.

The company brushed off concerns about falling revenues at Instinet by revealing that trading volumes on the US Nasdaq exchange hit record levels last month.

The group dominates the market for financial news and information and provides trading systems for professional investors.

But Reuters has become increasingly linked to new economy stocks as a result of a change in strategic direction and it has been hit hard by the negative sentiment that has enveloped dot.com and technology companies.

"The collapse of the valuation bubble around internet stocks has not affected our strategy, which goes forward as we stated last year," said Peter Job, outgoing chief executive of Reuters.

"We are confident this technology revolution will continue to open up many new opportunities for the group."

Tom Glocer, the chief executive-designate and first non-journalist to head Reuters, will find his management of the company's transformation coming under close scrutiny.

Reuters's shares rose 3% to 1048p on the results, although analysts said the climb was due largely to hedge fund managers getting back into a stock that is traditionally one of their favourites.

"Fundamentally, there is nothing in here which would make you want to rush in and buy the stock," said Nicola Stewart, media analyst at Commerzbank.

"It is very much a stock that is traded by the hedge funds, and they appear to have been closing up their positions."

Other analysts said the lack of clarity in the top-line figures was also a problem, although the results appeared to follow expectations.

webTitle: Enteraction gets cash boost

fields.headline: Enteraction TV to use cash windfall for expansion
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: Interactive broadcaster Enteraction TV has received a cash boost from a leading European bank, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Interactive broadcast specialist Enteraction TV has received a cash boost from a leading European bank.

WestLB Panmure will take a 14% stake in the company and Enteraction plans to invest the undisclosed windfall in expanding across Europe.

"We are delighted WestLB Panmure has recognised the significant value of our company," said Enteraction chief executive Mark Cullen.

"The scale of this investment will drive us rapidly to market leader position in the UK and will assist in international expansion of our business into key European markets."

Enteraction was founded in January last year and runs the TV Job Shop recruitment channel on Sky Digital. It also provides production expertise for the bid-up TV auction channel.

Stephen Davidson, managing director of media communications at WestLB Panmure, said Enteraction had "exceptional growth prospects".

Interactive television is seen as a big money-spinner for media companies, as it combines internet services and television programmes.

The spread of broadband networks, which offer high-speed internet access, is expected to create a boom in e-commerce through interactive television channels.

webTitle: Havas turnover up 48.6%

fields.headline: Havas turnover up 48.6%
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: Havas Advertising has announced an impressive 48.6% rise in turnover for 2000 to £7.65bn, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Havas Advertising, which owns three UK agencies, has announced an impressive 48.6% rise in turnover for 2000 to £7.65bn.

The company - the parent of WCRS, Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper and Partners BDDH - is now the fourth biggest global ad group. It said it had won £2.36bn of new business last year.

Havas's strongest growth region is believed to be Latin America, currently expanding by around 23% a year, with north America suffering a slowdown in growth. The UK market remains healthier.

The jump in turnover does not include Havas's £1.4bn acquisition of US advertising group Snyder Communications last February.

The group's share price remained stable at £10.16 following the turnover announcement.

Havas will publish full 2000 results on March 1. These will detail the billings added by the Snyder acquisition and give a further indication of the threat that Havas poses to the world's leading ad groups WPP, Omnicom and Interpublic.

French-based Euro RSCG is Havas's biggest network. It also owns Arnold Communications, which includes the WCRS and BDDH advertising brands.

Media, direct marketing and internet interests include the Diversified Agencies Group, Media Planning Group and Circle.com.

Havas agencies produce advertising for clients including Bass Brewers, BMW, Mercedes Benz and the Co-Op.

webTitle: TV ratings: February 12

fields.headline: C5 movie slaughters opposition
fields.trailText: 1.15pm TV overnights: Channel 5 cashed in on the publicity surrounding Hannibal by screening the Silence of the Lambs, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Channel 5 schedulers will be enjoying a nice Chianti after successfully cashing in on the publicity surrounding Sir Anthony Hopkins' new Hannibal film.

A screening of the film's 10-year-old predecessor, Silence of the Lambs, pulled in 2.8m viewers and a 22% share of the audience from 10pm last night, according to unofficial overnights.

Hannibal Lecter's audience share was double Channel 4's share for its 10pm film.

The 30-year-old Frankie Howerd feature, Up Pompeii, attracted 11% and 1.7m viewers.

But Channel 4's Roman-themed evening had already got off to a disappointing start.

At 9pm, the Real Spartacus, a documentary about the rebel gladiator, attracted 2m viewers and an 8% share.

On ITV, Who Wants to be a Millionaire? pulled in 9m and a 35% share from 9pm.

However, BBC1 provided the ITV ratings blockbuster with some stiff opposition.

Forensic pathologist Dr Sam Ryan returned in the first of a new two-part Silent Witness story from 9.10pm.

The Amanda Burton drama attracted 8.7m viewers and a 33% share.

On an evening dominated by cannibals and gladiators, Anne Robinson's own brand of scariness also proved popular.

The BBC1 quiz show the Weakest Link pulled in 8.2m and a 33% share from 8.30pm.

It just scraped past ITV opposition New You've Been Framed, which drew 8m.

In the early evening battle for the teen audience, Hollyoaks at 6.30pm on Channel 4 attracted 2m and a 9% share.

But a double helping of repeats of the series that helped launch Will Smith's career, the Fresh Prince of Bel Air, garnered 3.7m viewers and 2.9m on BBC2 from 6.20pm.

webTitle: Israel kills 'militant' as coalition talks continue

fields.headline: Israel kills 'militant' as coalition talks continue
fields.standfirst:
The latest killing does nothing to suggest that Ariel Sharon's election will change the state of affairs in Israel, writes Derek Brown

Special report: Israel & the Middle East
fields.trailText: The latest killing does nothing to suggest that Ariel Sharon's election will change the state of affairs in Israel, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
An alleged Islamist militant, Masoud Ayyad, has been assassinated by rockets fired from Israeli helicopter gunships. An officer in Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat's elite Force 17 bodyguard was also killed in the attack.

Two US-supplied Apache gunships fired four rockets in the well-planned attack on Ayyad, who was in a vehicle in the Jabaliya refugee camp in the Gaza Strip.

Ayyad, 49, and the unnamed Force 17 officer were killed outright. Four other men in the vehicle were wounded.

Israel makes no secret of its policy of "taking out" militants it suspects of carrying out or planning guerrilla attacks. Ayyad was the thirteenth Palestinian to have been eliminated by hit squads or airstrikes in recent months.

Immediately after the latest state assassination, Israeli military spokesmen made available their charge list against Ayyad, whom they say was an active member of the Hizbollah guerrilla group.

They accused him of planning two mortar attacks on Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip in the last two weeks.

He also planned a number of attacks and attempted kidnaps on Israeli forces and civilians, they said.

Ayyad's son, Nasser - allegedly a member of the militant cell run by his father - was arrested by Israeli forces two weeks ago.

Prime minister Ehud Barak congratulated the forces responsible for Ayyad's killing, calling it "another expression of the policy of punishing those carrying out attacks on Israeli civilians and IDF (Israeli Defence Forces) personnel".

Meanwhile, Mr Barak and prime minister-elect Ariel Sharon are inching toward a deal on a grand coalition in the Knesset (parliament).

Mr Sharon won a major victory in the February 6 direct election, but his Likud party has only 17 seats in the 120-member parliament. He urgently needs the support of Mr Barak's Labour party to secure the stability of his administration and defuse fears that his stridently rightwing policies could provoke a new regional war.

The coalition deal that has been sketched out commits the government to continue land-for-peace negotiations with the Palestinians.

But, crucially, the strategy speaks of building on interim agreements makes no mention of a final peace treaty. Nor does it offer any hope that the new government will soften Mr Sharon's fierce support for Jewish settlements in the Palestinian territories.

Both Labour and Likud sources told local reporters there was a good chance that Mr Sharon could present his national unity government to the Knesset at the start of next week.

But, as intensive negotiations continue over portfolio allocation and the final details of power sharing, there remains plenty of scope for a breakdown.

There are important dissidents in both the parties. Many political observers believe that former Likud prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu, who was heavily defeated byMr Barak in 1999, is manoevering to prevent the formation of a unity government.

He apparently believes such a government could run its full term of four years (an almost unprecedented feat in fractious Israeli politics) and thus retard his hopes of a comeback.

On the Labour side, leading pro-peace activist Yossi Beilin has fiercely attacked colleagues for even considering a deal with Likud.

He told a radio interviewer that a number of ministerial colleagues were "afraid of losing their seats and are prepared to sell their souls and kill off hopes for peace".

Mr Beilin warned that, if it entered the new administration, Labour could well be held responsible for "the bloody war that will be caused by the Sharon government."

webTitle: Brown sees off Brussels attack on spending

fields.headline: Brown sees off Brussels attack on spending
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, last night told the European commission that Labour's plans for higher public spending were non-negotiable after criticism by Brussels was seized upon by UK opponents of monetary union as fresh evidence of the dangers of joining the euro.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn in Brussels, Larry Elliott and Michael White
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, last night told the European commission that Labour's plans for higher public spending were non-negotiable after criticism by Brussels was seized upon by UK opponents of monetary union as fresh evidence of the dangers of joining the euro.

With the start of an election campaign weeks away, Mr Brown sought to defuse claims by Eurosceptics that joining monetary union would involve Brussels-inspired spending cuts by telling the commission that he would press on with his expenditure proposals.

The chancellor, determined that the euro should be sidelined as an issue on polling day, reacted with irritation to the criticism from Brussels, which said it was worried by the planned dip into the red in the government's finances caused by higher spending. "I made it absolutely clear that our plans for spending are prudent. The European commission has in my view taken too narrow a view of investment," Mr Brown said.

He singled out improvements to Britain's crumbling transport infrastructure as a particular priority and said billions of pounds were at stake since his plan was to more than double capital spending by 2004.

"This increase in frontline public spending is essential and it is in our national economic interest that it proceeds as planned. Our plans are de signed to reverse years of under investment. It is the right thing to do for the British economy and society."

William Hague's team immediately accused the European commission of trying to dictate to London in defiance of the "commonsense [instinct] that we should retain our ability to govern ourselves." The Conservatives were provided with extra ammunition when Ireland - the fastest growing country in the EU became the first country to be reprimanded by European finance ministers over the conduct of its fiscal policy.

The Business for Sterling group said: "The action taken against Ireland and the moves towards greater powers for the euro-11 group show how the euro is driving institutional change and how joining the euro necessarily involves losing control of budgetary policy."

Some MPs saw Mr Brown's approach as a deliberate as sertion of his own authority over British euro-policy. Downing St insisted last night that it was 100% behind the chancellor's tactics in challenging an over-rigid interpretation of the EU's so-called stability pact.

"The government would argue that the stability pact should not be interpreted too rigidly," the No 10 spokesman said last night. The Irish problem also illustrated that point. But the pact is "non-binding" he added.

Mr Brown's comments yesterday followed the the commission's latest assessment of the UK economy, an annual exercise to gauge Britain's readiness to join the euro. Although Brussels' analysis was broadly positive, it expressed alarm that Labour's ambitious investment plans for the coming years will mean that the UK will be saddled with a budget deficit of around 1% between 2003 and 2006.

"This would not be in line with the prescription of 'close to balance or surplus' contained in the stability and growth pact," the commission warned yesterday urging the government "to be alive" to any deterioration in public finances and suggesting "remedial action" may be necessary.

The fact that Britain is not yet a member of the single currency means that the chancellor is under no obligation to follow the commission's advice.

webTitle: Admission charges are one target for the new V&A director.

fields.headline: Access all areas
fields.standfirst: Admission charges are one target for the new V&A director, finds  Elisabeth Mahoney
fields.trailText: Admission charges are one target for the new V&A director, finds Elisabeth Mahoney.
fields.body:
"I hope you're going to defend him," the man at the Museum of Scotland's information desk says as I wait to meet Mark Jones, the new director of the Victoria & Albert Museum. Though his appointment is still to be ratified by Downing Street, nobody seriously doubts that Jones will make the move from Edinburgh to London later this year. "You're sorry he's going, then," I say to the man with all the leaflets. "Better the devil you know," he sighs, "and he's not even a devil."

This lack of a fiery image has meant some lukewarm responses to Jones's selection for the V&A job over more high-profile candidates such as the ebullient Timothy Clifford, director of the National Galleries of Scotland. Jones, by contrast, is seen as a subtle networker, a scholarly figure, adept at behind-the-scenes politicking but unlikely to stamp his personality on the V&A in a radical shake-up. Yet that is exactly what some critics claim is needed to save the 149-year-old museum from dwindling attendances and a nightmarishly bureaucratic way of working.

In Jones's office there is little to challenge this perception of him. It could be an academic's office, with shelves groaning under back issues of The Medal (Jones was keeper of coins and medals at the British Museum before moving to Scotland in 1992). But Jones isn't concerned about the way his selection has been reported, not even about the use of "bland" to describe his managerial style.

"It is true that I try not to offend too many of the people too much of the time," he says, "but only because that wouldn't be the best way to run a museum."

He makes a point of voicing his personal passion for Daniel Libeskind's controversial extension to the V&A (the so-called Spiral), despite calls from more conservative quarters for the project to be scrapped. And he singles out Give & Take, the current exhibition organised by Hans Haacke, which juxtaposes historical and contemporary objects from the V&A collection, for praise. Both comments suggest a new director committed to dragging the seven miles of galleries that make up the V&A into the vanguard of contemporary art and design.

Jones is egalitarian in his views, despite his educational background (Eton, Oxford and the Courtauld), and would like, he says, to return the V&A to free admission by the end of this year. He is also passionate about the democratising possibilities of new technology. "The educational potential of museums has not yet been realised, because until now you have had to get to museums to learn from them, and that's easier for some people than for others. With the internet, it becomes possible to use collections in the classroom, in the public library and at home."

When he talks like this, it's easy to imagine Jones during his "brief and inglorious" political career, contesting a safe Tory seat on Westminster council for Labour. He has long left politics behind, but remains liberal in his cultural outlook, quietly determined not to allow the V&A to abandon a concern with the cultural and social context within which it exists.

Last Monday, his staff in Edinburgh filled that austere office with balloons and cards for his 50th birthday. Embarrassed by all the attention, he told them he had just received the V&A offer. "There were a few tears," I'm told later. "Yes, it's great he's going from here, but he'll be missed."

webTitle: Spacecraft finds easy parking on Eros

fields.headline: Spacecraft finds easy parking on Eros
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: A little spacecraft the size of a saloon car last night parked itself forever at the solar system's most desolate destination - an asteroid 196m miles from the Earth.
fields.body:
A little spacecraft the size of a saloon car last night parked itself forever at the solar system's most desolate destination - an asteroid 196m miles from the Earth.

The touchdown - more a collision than a manoeuvre - will mark the end of the year-long courtship between a near-Earth asteroid rendezvous craft called Shoemaker and an asteroid the size of Manhattan known as Eros.

Shoemaker and Eros got it together on Valentine's Day 2000, and the spacecraft went into orbit around its peanut-shaped date, tumbling slowly through space beyond the orbit of Mars. Then, keeping a safe distance, Shoemaker began making a meticulous study of the asteroid, a lump of builder's rubble left over from the Big Bang.

Eros is 21 miles (33km) long and about eight miles wide. It is one of a class of near-Earth objects now seen by astronomers as cosmic traffic accidents waiting to happen. Were Eros to actually hit the Earth, the impact would certainly wipe out civilisation, and probably wipe out all life.

By the end of its manoeuvring, Shoemaker was swooping to within three miles of the surface of Eros.

Last night, the spacecraft had completed five years in flight and crossed 2bn miles of space. It was all but out of fuel, and at the end of its life. But astronomers still had one question left: was the surface of Eros dusty, or gravelly - or was it solid rock?

Since the spacecraft couldn't get home, they decided to land it on Eros, hoping for a featherlight touchdown. The astronomers chose their spot and let off four blasts of the onboard rockets to slow its descent down.

"We have completed our primary mission and its been very successful, and we are trying to get a little bonus science," said the mission director, Robert Farquhar. "And yes, it's a little risky."

Late last night, researchers heaved a sigh of relief when Shoemaker reported a safe landing. It may still have kicked up the dust of Eros, but it didn't destroy itself.

Shoemaker confirmed it landing with a little signal to Earth. It should have enough power to go on sending signals back to Earth for three months. The orbiter went on taking pictures as it drew closer to its final resting place.

webTitle: First Tuesday sale on the cards

fields.headline: First Tuesday sale on the cards
fields.trailText: 11.15am: First Tuesday owner Yazam is said to be close to agreeing a sale with the leaders of its regional branded franchises, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Yazam, the owner of networking forum First Tuesday, is said to be close to agreeing a sale of the business with the leaders of its regional branded franchises.

A deal could be finalised as early as next week, although Reade Fahs, chief executive officer, said there would be no announcement until the finer details of the contract had been signed off.

Mr Fahs denied Yazam had agreed a deal in principle with the leaders of First Tuesday's regional franchises, which are know as city chapters.

He said discussions were still ongoing with both the regional leaders and other interested parties, including publishers, conferences organisers and jobs and matchmaking firms.

The regional organisers of First Tuesday networking nights originally made an offer to take control of the network in January, although this was rejected. It is thought that their latest offer is up to £500,000, and an agreement "in principle" has been reached with Yazam.

Sources suggested the likely outcome to the new offer is a third party becoming involved to bankroll First Tuesday, which operates in 150 cities, which will then be run by the individual licence holders.

Such a deal would end Yazam's involvement in First Tuesday and solve the problem of a fragmented network with each franchise run individually.

Yazam bought First Tuesday last July for around £33m, the bulk of which was made up of shares in Yazam, plus an estimated cash investment of £2m.

A deal could be finalised as early as next week, although Reade Fahs, chief executive officer, said there would be no announcement until the finer details of the contract had been signed off. Mr Fahs denied Yazam had agreed a deal in principle with the leaders of First Tuesday's regional franchises, which are know as city chapters. He said discussions were still ongoing with both the regional leaders and other interested parties, including publishers, conferences organisers and jobs and matchmaking firms. The regional organisers of First Tuesday networking nights originally made an offer to take control of the network in January, although this was rejected. It is thought that their latest offer is up to £500,000, and an agreement "in principle" has been reached with Yazam. Sources suggested the likely outcome to the new offer is a third party becoming involved to bankroll First Tuesday, which operates in 150 cities, which will then be run by the individual licence holders. Such a deal would end Yazam's involvement in First Tuesday and solve the problem of a fragmented network with each franchise run individually. Yazam bought First Tuesday last July for around £33m, the bulk of which was made up of shares in Yazam, plus an estimated cash investment of £2m.

webTitle: Asylum policy could hit the sheltering scholars

fields.headline: Asylum policy could hit the sheltering scholars
fields.standfirst: Abdul Lalzad is an Afghan professor who, like many academic refugees, has found safety in Britain. Under Jack Straw's new strategy, says  Donald MacLeod, he might not have got this far
fields.trailText: Abdul Lalzad is an Afghan professor who, like many academic refugees, has found safety in Britain. Under Jack Straw's new strategy, says Donald MacLeod, he might not have got this far.
fields.body:
Like most academics, Abdul Lalzad talks eagerly about his research. He is working on a way of using solar power to desalinate water cheaply - potentially a vast boon to his native Afghanistan and a swathe of countries across Asia, the Middle East and Africa which suffer from water shortages but no lack of sunshine.

But as he talks at his bench at South Bank University in London his eyes betray deep anxiety and sadness. There is sadness for the wreck of his country under a regime which has driven him out and destroyed the university he was proud of. But uppermost in his mind is whether his wife and their five children will be allowed to join him after more than two years apart. They were being interviewed in Pakistan that day by the British High Commission about a visa. "My mind is not here," he apologises.

The professor of engineering from Kabul is one of 27 people now being helped by the Council for Assisting Refugee Academics (Cara), a body which started in 1933 to help Jews and other victims of the Nazi purge of universities. The formation of what was then called the Academic Assistance Council was kick-started by a tumultuous meeting at the Albert Hall addressed by Albert Einstein. Today the centres of persecution have shifted via South Africa and Latin America to Iraq, Sudan, Ethiopia, Rwanda and Somalia, but the job of helping university teachers and researchers to pick themselves up after persecution and establish themselves in this country remains the same.

The climate of hatred and distrust of asylum seekers is perhaps even worse than in the 1930s, although over the years Britain's reward for sheltering scholars has been out of all proportion to the tiny investment - 18 Nobel prizewinners, 71 fellows of the Royal Society, 50 fellows of the British Academy.

The council campaigns on refugee issues and criticises what it sees as the worst excesses of government policy, such as the demeaning vouchers system. Its president, Sir Raymond Hoffenberg, who himself was a political exile from South Africa, has attacked the "wholly unacceptable" Immigration and Asylum Act and the current wave of bigotry at a time of unprecedented prosperity: "It is difficult to imagine the implications for the UK and the world had Karl Popper or Max Perutz - two of the scholars we supported - been dealt with in the demeaning way envisaged by the current legislation: in isolation from other scholars, dumped far from cen tres of learning and forced to live on benefits provided by vouchers."

But most of the council's work is practical: advice about the labyrinthine asylum and social security regulations, making contact with university departments where they might be welcome, small grants for fees and travel. Cara limits its scope to helping genuine academics but even for this small section of the overall refugee population it could do a lot more if it had more funds.

Professor Lalzad's case is typical. A specialist in thermal engineering with a Russian masters degree, he taught in the department of mechanical engineering at Kabul University. He had five textbooks and more than 30 published articles to his credit and had held senior university positions. When the victorious Taliban closed the university, he worked for the Red Cross, in charge of distributing thousands of tonnes of food to 40,000 widows and disabled people.

He was arrested, beaten with Kalashnikovs and thrown in prison on suspicion of giving information to anti-Taliban forces. The influence of the Red Cross got him released, but his life was in danger and he fled to Pakistan, where his wife and children were eventually able to follow.

He arrived at Heathrow in December 1998, to be grilled for hours by immigration officials who believed he was Pakistani because his English was so good. (It was the medium of instruction in his department.) Lalzad concedes that Pakistanis do try to enter the UK by claiming to be Afghan refugees, and is sure he would have been deported had he not produced his Red Cross identity card.

Then came a frustrating wait while his application for asylum was considered (it took 18 months) and he tried to get work. "I felt ashamed sitting at home. It is a morally bad way of living for someone with education and knowledge not to work." Letters to universities produced no result, though he was encouraged by a short course at the University of North London, where he made contacts. He was at last given a break at South Bank by the director of engineering research, Professor Tassos Karayiannis.

A grant from Cara is paying bench fees and for the purchase of a computer as Lalzad pursues a part-time PhD on his desalination research. At the moment he is doing mathematical modelling with the aim of building an experimental model of a solar-powered desalination plant.

Desalination technology is well advanced in the oil-rich Middle East states, but across a wide zone of northern Asia, the Middle East and North Africa there is a pressing need for small, cheap plants. The goal is a gadget consisting of a small box and a condenser. "I hope it will be a very low cost and efficient technique for desalinating water that can be used in poor developing countries, especially where they have a lot of solar energy."

He hopes to be able to resume teaching at his new university. Meanwhile he waits for news of his family.

The potential benefits of Professor Lalzad's research are obvious. John Akker, secretary of Cara, says his case is repeated many times over among the academics on their books.

There is the Iraqi paediatrician, a consultant at Salahaddin University, forced to leave because of the help he gave to the Kurdish population. He has been given small grants for books and fees to enable him to pass the level of English that would allow him to practise in this country. Another Iraqi doctor is currently doing medical research at Manchester, while a bacteriologist identified only as Ms L is doing a PhD at Brighton University.

Also receiving grants from the council are academics from Ethiopia, Somalia, Sudan, Rwanda and Sierra Leon, and a Chinese economist who suffered long-running harassment and was dismissed from his university post after taking part in the Tiananmen Square demonstrations. He is now doing an English course to enable him to pursue a masters. Until the council paid for travel expenses (£697 last year) he was walking ten miles to college. Yet he has not left all harassment behind: now it's racial.

Akker is angered by current hysteria against asylum seekers, and worried by Home Secretary Jack Straw's proposals to process applications in neighbouring countries: "These people are seen as scroungers living off the state, but they want to contribute here actively, and want to go back to their countries to change the things that brought them here in the first place."

Cara: giving hope when hope has fled

Albie Sachs, an academic who became a judge in South Africa's constitutional court, was twice helped by Cara's predecessor body, the Society for the Protection of Science and Learning - once when he fled the apartheid regime in 1966 and then again when he was nearly killed by a bomb in Mozambique.

In a lecture he expressed his warm feelings for the body and its quiet unobtrusive work. "It is not one of those bodies which takes out adverts in the bottom right hand of the front page of the Guardian," he told his audience in London in 1997.

"It was people helping people in need simply because they were in trouble, because they got into trouble because they were trying to do research in an intolerant society where persecution became the name of the game."

This altruism did have enormous benefits to Britain in the contributions these outsiders made in teaching and research, and the effects did not stop there, he said. "When the causes of persecution have been removed and we go back to our countries, we take so much of Britain with us. The positive and negative lessons which we learnt here. The things to avoid, the mistakes that are made, the good things that are done, and we help to rebuild our own countries and to develop democracy, science and learning and culture."

Sachs listed a series of ministers in the first post-apartheid government in South Africa who had spent time in Britain, from Thabo Mbeki, Nelson Mandela's successor, who has an MA in economics from Sussex, to finance minister Gill Marcus, who set up a sandwich kiosk in Holborn, London, while in exile, and Frene Ginwala, speaker of the South African parliament.

There might be spin-offs for Britain, he added, "but what really matters is that some things are good in themselves, they do not need extra justification."

The council is launching an appeal this spring. Contributions to Cara, 38 King Street, London WC2E 8JS, tel 0207 836 8963. In the US, Scholars at Risk, based at the University of Chicago, was set up last year to do the same job

webTitle: South Africa's motorway murders

fields.headline: South Africa's motorway murders
fields.standfirst: Police are trying to cover up shocking crime statistics that could devastate tourism, writes Chris McGreal
fields.trailText: 13 February: Police are sitting on shocking crime statistics that could devastate tourism, writes Chris McGreal.
fields.body:
The first thing the growing bands of foreign tourists see after they leave Cape Town airport is never mentioned in the publicity extolling the magnificence of Table Mountain and the glistening sands of Camps Bay.

The N2 motorway in to the city cuts through the ever growing squatter camps that surround the townships to which black people were once banished from whites-only Cape Town.

It is an appropriate introduction to the realities of South Africa for tourists who might otherwise see only a city more rooted in Europe than Africa. But it is also a shock for many to catch even a brief glimpse of the squalid conditions to which so many black people are consigned, a dirty secret kept from them until the last minute.

There is another secret about the N2 kept not only from foreigners but Cape Town's own residents. A month ago, a motorist, Bertie Louw, was shot dead after his car broke down on the motorway. The local paper, the Cape Times, reported the killing and was surprised to receive a flood of letters from people who had been robbed by armed men on the road.

The paper wondered just how many people had been attacked on the N2. The police refused to tell, claiming that the government will not release any crime statistics on the grounds that they are "unreliable".

As a justification, the government cites the example of a sudden surge in reported "cash in transit" robberies in the eastern Cape. These are normally taken to mean raids on security vans delivering money to banks but it turned out that pickpocketing on buses was also included in the figures because it was robbery of money on the move.

Others suspect a different motive, particularly when it comes to the N2: the crime figures are just plain embarrassing.

South Africa's crime wave has already had an impact on tourism, and officials are concerned that if it becomes known that the road from the airport to Cape Town - the only means of travelling between the two - is a death trap, the city can wave goodbye to the tourists.

The Cape Times is now suing the government to force it to release crime statistics after scores of people wrote claiming to be victims of attacks on the N2.

Some said their cars broke down and that within minutes they found themselves being held up by armed robbers who quickly emerged from the squatter camps. At least two other people have been murdered, including a man shot in the head after he stopped at the roadside to take a mobile phone call.

A favoured tactic is to hurl rocks through windscreens from bridges over the motorway. When the motorists stop or crash, they find a man with a gun waiting for them. Police officials say that attacks on pedestrians walking along the N2 occur every two or three hours.

As if to prove the point, a press conference alongside the motorway last week by the region's security minister to announce new safety measures was interrupted by two people pleading for help after they were held up at gunpoint minutes earlier.

In an effort to curb the attacks, the provincial government has already boosted the number of police patrol vehicles on the road. But the long-term solution is said to lie with video cameras along the length of the N2. The Western Cape's security minister is promising that they will be installed within weeks, and that the police will be able to spot a breakdown or hijacking and respond instantly.

Cameras may also deter the killings that often accompany hijackings. Car thieves are said to murder drivers so there are no witnesses to testify in court. Cameras not only provide the evidence needed, even if the only human witnesses are dead, but also remove one of the reasons to commit a crime far worse than theft.

Three robbers who shot dead a man on a Johannesburg street last month were arrested after cameras followed them all the way to a nightclub. Crime in the city centre is reported to have dropped dramatically since then. But, of course, no one knows for sure because the statistics are a secret.

webTitle: Canadians remain calm over GM revelations

fields.headline: Canadians remain calm over GM revelations
fields.standfirst: A report severely critical of the Canadian government's attitude to GM foods has left the general public supremely unmoved, reports Anne McIlroy
fields.trailText: A report severely critical of the Canadian government's attitude to GM foods has left the general public supremely unmoved, reports Anne McIlroy
fields.body:
The news that Canadians are being used as guinea pigs to test genetically modified foods may have had politicians scrambling for a day or two but seems unlikely to change any local eating habits.

The report, from a panel of top scientists, was front-page news across the country last week, yet Canadians are likely to continue to complacently munch away on government-approved GM products - either because they don't know what they are eating or they simply don't care.

The waves of concern over GM foods that have swamped politicians in Europe are mere ripples in Canada, felt more by farmers who grow GM crops than the elected officials who pushed them to market.

More than 40 types of GM crops have been quietly approved over the past five years, including strains of corn, soy and potatoes. Most have had their genetic code changed so they will be resistant to herbicides or viruses.

Labels are not required under Canadian law, so consumers buying, say, cornflakes have no way of knowing if they are purchasing a GM product, unless they buy an organic brand.

So far, the experiment hasn't appeared to hurt anyone, the report says, but that could change as more complex varieties of GM food come on the market.

"There are significant risks associated with these new technologies. There are risks of new toxins and allergenic proteins introduced into genetically modified foods," said Conrad Brunk, co-chair of an expert panel that was set up to review Canada's GM food regulatory system.

He and other panel members were asked by the federal government to assess its regulatory approach to GM foods. The health ministry appointed the panel as a way to build public confidence.

Instead, the government got a stinging rebuke.

The panel said that regulators often used "unsubstantiated assumptions" when it approved GM foods and did not have a standard and clear procedure for determining the safety of foods that many British and European consumers refuse to buy.

They said researchers in Canada who wish to do work that may hurt the GM food industry cannot get funding.

The panel members also criticised the government for being secretive and far too close to the biotechnology industry, noting that the government agency responsible for protecting human health is also responsible for promoting the new food products - a conflict of interest that cannot be good for the health of Canadians.

Environmental groups are hoping these kinds of findings will be a wake-up call for shoppers. For now, however, there is little sign of public outrage. While the debacle over mad cow disease has left British consumers with little faith that the government will protect them from dangerous food products, Canadians are still trusting of their leaders

Environmental groups are calling for an immediate moratorium on GM products, but the government has rejected the idea. This is, in part, because it has invested heavily in GM foods. Government labs have done some of the pioneering working transferring genes from one species to another. Government programs have encouraged farmers to switch to GM crops.

Even though it was the health ministry that hired the scientists to sit on the panel, government officials began an immediate counter-offensive when the report was released, publicly criticising its findings.

They said the scientists didn't know what they were talking about when they concluded the system is flawed.

"Canada needs to remain on the leading edge of the new scientific developments," said Agriculture Minister Lyle Vanclief.

So for now, at least until there are signs the experiment is backfiring, sanguine Canadian guinea pigs will continue to munch on GM foods.

webTitle: Soap output soars

fields.headline: Peaktime soap output soars by 150%
fields.trailText: 12pm: The rise of the soaps on BBC1 and ITV has been at the expense of films and drama, writes Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
The time taken up by soaps on BBC1 and ITV in peaktime has increased by 150% over the past 25 years, according to Independent Television Commission research.

The amount of non-soap peaktime drama on BBC1 has halved over the same period.

The research, carried out by David Graham Associates, focuses on how programming diversity on public-service networks has changed since 1975.

BBC1 drama other than soaps accounted for just 11% of the peaktime schedule in November last year.

In contrast, non-soap drama takes up more than a quarter of ITV's peaktime schedule.

Almost all of this is home-grown, unlike 25 years ago when much was imported from the US.

ITC chief executive Patricia Hodgson revealed the statistics last night while delivering the ITN European Media Forum Lecture.

She contrasted the surge in soaps across BBC1 and ITV channels with the virtual disappearance of films from the broadcasters' peaktime schedules.

webTitle: In brief: Mel Gibson in line to play

fields.headline: Mel Gibson in line to play
fields.standfirst: Plus: Lewis Arquette dies; Martin Sheen slams George W Bush; John Hurt gets animated over Harry Potter
fields.trailText: Plus: Lewis Arquette dies; Martin Sheen slams George W Bush; John Hurt gets animated over Harry Potter
fields.body:
 Ananova is tipping Mel Gibson for the role of Hannibal and, no, he hasn't edged out Anthony Hopkins for the role of the fava-bean-fond psychopath in Lecter: the Early Years. Chomping cigars and donning alligator suits in the middle of crowds as befits his status as a "master of disguise" will be the order of the day if Gibson signs up for the role of A-Team supremo Hannibal in the forthcoming action-comedy based on the TV series. Brendan Fraser, Taye Diggs and Owen Wilson (as Face, BA and Murdoch?) are also being considered.

 Actor, comedian and father of the Arquette brood, Lewis Arquette, has died of heart failure aged 65, reports iWon. After starting his career on Broadway and a regular slot at top Chicago comedy club, Second City, he built up a reputation as a crack improvisational actor, which is probably why he hasn't appeared in many Hollywood films of late. He can be seen, however, in Scream 2 and Little Nicky. Friends and family, who presumably included children Rosanna, Richmond, Patricia, Alexis and David, attended a service on Monday.

 Democrat supporter Martin Sheen has aimed a broadside at new White House occupant George W Bush, according to BBC News online. The actor, who plays a fictional US president in TV series The West Wing, bad-mouthed Dubya's populist moves, saying that the fellow was: "Like a bad comic working the crowd, a moron, if you'll pardon the expression." Sheen was also bewildered by last year's extra-time-and-penalties election race and couldn't imagine why anyone would want to be president (except in a TV show). "Your life is over as soon as you say you want to occupy the Oval Office," Sheen opined. Evidently not in a patriotic frame of mind, he saved one last slap for the US nation, saying the only things it had contributed to the world were "jazz" and "Alcoholics Anonymous".

 Coming Attractions reports that John Hurt has snagged a small part in the Harry Potter adaptation as Morgana, apparently an animated character that appears on a Chocolate Frog card. "We are sworn to secrecy so it's very difficult to talk about it, but I have a small part, a cameo you could say," Hurt revealed.
