webTitle: Yacht sponsorship will make Kingfisher a household name

fields.headline: A message from her sponsors . . .
fields.standfirst: When Ellen MacArthur landed, Sir Geoff Mulcahy was there to say thanks for turning Kingfisher into a household name across Europe
fields.trailText: When Ellen MacArthur landed, Sir Geoff Mulcahy was there to say thanks for turning Kingfisher into a household name across Europe.
fields.body:
Two hundred thousand people lined the shore at Les Sables d'Olonnes on the French coast at 7.30 on Sunday night as Ellen MacArthur rewrote the sailing record books. One man in the crowd - and one of the first to greet the 24-year-old after 94 gruelling days at sea - was a businessman.

Sir Geoff Mulcahy is chairman of Kingfisher, which owns the Superdrug, B&Q, Comet and Woolworths retail chains and which sponsored Ms MacArthur's 18m boat. And Sunday night was the culmination of a two-year project designed to turn Kingfisher - a holding company with little public recognition even in Britain - into a household name across Europe.

Kingfisher has spent £4m on the project; £2m on the boat, its maintenance and the back-up team, and a further £2m on "exploitation" - using the boat for staging hospitality, media events, promotions and so on.

"It is one thing pay out to be in the race but, to make it really work for you, you have to spend the same again," said a spokesman for Kingfisher yesterday. "Without doubt, though, this has exceeded all our expectations."

The £2m Kingfisher shelled out to join the Vendée Globe race - which in the last two days alone has generated publicity on almost every TV news broadcast and close on a clean-sweep of newspaper front pages - is a bargain for the £7bn stores group. It is less than 5% of Vodafone's annual advertising bill and a fraction of the £20m a year that the FA is understood to be demanding from companies wanting their name on the Premiership.

World brand

Ms MacArthur's triumph - even though she was placed second in the race - will be a lesson to many companies on the returns that even relatively modest sports sponsorship can generate and is bound to refuel interest in an already booming business.

Dr Tony Meenaghan, of University College, Dublin, a specialist in sports sponsorship, claims that globally it has increased in value from £1.4bn in 1982 to more than £12bn today. "The emergence of Visa as a world brand can be directly traced to their sponsorship of the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles," he says.

According to Sportscan, a publication that tracks sponsor deals, the UK sector is worth in the region of £400m - up from some £4m in the last 30 years. Last year, says Sportscan, the UK sports sponsorship business grew by 6% - although the bulk of that increase was down to just one company and two deals, Vodafone's £30m deal with Manchester United and the renewal of its contract with the English cricket team.

How companies come to choose the sports they sponsor varies. There are sponsorship consultancies which specialise in matching sportsmen and women with willing givers, there are often links between the biggest in business and the best in sport and there is obviously always a tendency for companies to back the chairman's favourite pass-time.

Sir Geoff Mulcahy is a keen sailor - but Kingfisher insists that the decision to sponsor Ellen MacArthur was unconnected to the boss's hobby. "The original rationale was that a few years ago we moved from being a purely UK retailer to expand overseas, especially in Europe. We acquired Darty (a French electrical goods and furniture retailer), and linked up with D-I-Y group Castorama and wanted to raise our profile, especially in France," said a spokesman.

So when Ellen MacArthur and her team manager, Mark Turner, approached Kingfisher looking for finance to compete in the Vendée Globe, they were pushing at an open door. "Unlike in the UK, sailing in France is a massive, massive sport", said Kingfisher yesterday.

The company has also had extra mileage from Ms MacArthur. Before setting off around the world three months ago she was being hauled in by Kingfisher for store openings, management conferences and motivational sessions with younger staff.

As Kingfisher's investment was coming alongside in Les Sables, five thousand miles away in South Africa a corporate sports shindig of another kind was drawing to a close.

Instead of tales of adventure, individual heroism and triumphs in the face of adversity the Dimension Data Pro-Am golf challenge at the luxurious Sun City sports and gaming resort was sheer sun-drenched hedonism for almost 3,000 of the FTSE 100 company's clients, staff, management and their families.

Executives from blue-chip customers like Microsoft, Oracle, Cisco and Sun Microsystems were flown in for a week of R&R at a cost of more than £1m. For the lucky few there was also the chance to play around with golfing superstars like Nick Price, Lee Westwood and Darren Clarke.

"The clients absolutely love it, they wouldn't miss it for anything" said DiData's chief executive, Jeremy Ord, yesterday, still bubbling after playing four consecutive days in partnership with Mr Clarke. "A lot of the firms and people that we deal with identify with golf, and it's a great relationship builder. Very little of our business is physically done on the golf course, but the Pro Am and our sponsorship of players like Clarke more than covers our investment. In many ways the tournament is a big thank you to our customers and partners."

Sports sponsorship is far from new. The first modern sponsorship appeared in the form of advertisements in the programme to the 1896 Olympic games. Two years later the UK's first recorded sports sponsorship deal was signed when football league champions Nottingham Forest agreed to be endorsed by Bovril for a nominal sum.

These sponsorships can now take many forms. By becoming an official partner of the Uefa champions' league you are effectively buying media exposure through guaranteed advertising on programming credits, accreditation on the website, bill boards at grounds and slots in the match programmes. Others, like nPower's recent sponsorship of Test cricket, provide access to players for promotional purposes.

Some deals, like the Guinness sponsorship of the last rugby world cup, gave it the right to run official promotions in the car parks surrounding Twickenham, competitions on the side of beer cans and special rugby world cup branded offers in pubs.

TV exposure

NPower is delighted by the TV exposure that Test matches - which are scheduled to last five days - will provide. "Any brand can advertise on TV to gain visibility, but during the seven hours the cricket is on each day nPower will grab the viewer's attention like no other company," said Andrew Jameson, director of sports consultancy John Taylor International.

What is interesting is how quickly brands can identify with sports. The European Union decision to consign tobacco sponsorship of formula one motor racing to the ashtray of history by 2006 has presented dot.com and technology firms with several opportunities.

Last year Yahoo! agreed to spend an estimated $25m (£17m) over three years to have its logo etched on to the livery of the Prost formula one team's racing car. This followed the decision by Orange to stump up £70m to paint the Arrows car in its corporate colours. The fact that the team had not won a race in 22 seasons did not seem to bother the mobile phones operator.

Team Williams counts Compaq, Intel and Nortel Networks among its sponsors. "Internet is the new tobacco in formula one," said Ian Clifton, managing director of Premier Media Sports, which acts for the Jordan team. For technology firms there is the added attraction of being able to showcase their systems in the car.

"Sun Microsystems provides telemetry for the McLaren team and there's not much better than being able to take prospective clients down to the McLaren factory, show them the technology in action and tell them that if it's good enough for the sharp end of formula one it should be good enough for them," says Mr Jameson.

webTitle: Stigma of mental illness damages job prospects and earning power

fields.headline: Stigma of mental illness damages job prospects and earning power
fields.trailText: Mental health charities have called for a wider range of employment schemes to help service users into work, after a report warned that people with mental health problems are further isolated by poverty.
fields.body:
Mental health charities have called for a wider range of employment schemes to help service users into work, after a report warned that people with mental health problems are further isolated by poverty.

They say most mental health services fail to assess service users' career aspirations, only offering placements in "boring" manual labour, while employers' recruitment practices block service users from gaining fulfilling jobs.

The warnings come as a survey by the Focus on Mental Health forum found that only 15% of respondents were employed, with 57% of those on a low income. Nearly all (95%) said their diagnosis had affected their work prospects and for some made securing work "virtually impossible".

Respondents said the loss of their job had left them financially insecure and without purpose. Most wanted an accessible and flexible benefits system that helped them return to work, and more access to education and support.

One of the respondents, Philip Dixon-Phillips, describes the difficulties faced by service users trying to access the benefit system. "You have to write down your deepest secrets - that you've spent months uncovering with your psychiatrist - on some anonymised form, then talk about that to some bureaucrat. They don't realise the pain provoked by their questions."

The 53-year-old former teacher also attacked some of the day centre activities on offer to service users. "We don't want tea-time clubs," he said.

Edith Morgan, chair of Focus on Mental Health, said: "Having a mental health problem and a low income creates a vicious circle. Breaking it will require the concerted efforts of government, health and social services, the employment service and voluntary sector, working together in partnership."

Director of the Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health Matt Muijen said recovery programmes should address clients' employment aspirations and take note of their career histories.

Mr Muijen said: "Services are not geared to help people into competitive employment that allows them to operate at their highest level of function.

"What we have at the moment are day centres providing industrial repetitive labour in very supported environments. So someone who's been off work for six months goes into this boring environment full of people with low expectations. They get in a rut and become more institutionalised."

Susan Scott-Parker, chief executive of the Employers' Forum on Disability, said many support services offered employers no practical advice on hiring people with mental health problems.

The National Schizophrenia Fellowship (NSF) runs employment schemes with several leading firms, including Marks & Spencer and Kwik-Fit, and has helped many service users back into part-time and full-time employment.

Employment support workers broker jobs with companies, providing them with mental health awareness training and advice on how to make their working environment more friendly to people with mental health problems. These adjustments to their working practices are set out in a charter.

However, NSF operations manager Eileen McDonald said there were still many barriers in the way of employing people with mental health problems. "It's not just overt stigma that we need to overcome, it's administrative barriers. Every month we have someone turned down for a job because they couldn't be cleared for the medical until they were off medication," she said.

"In practice, the Disability Discrimination Act only protects people as far as employers are willing to make the effort."

Research indicates that between 61% and 73% of people with severe mental health problems are unemployed - but most of them want to work.

The Royal College of Psychiatrists has established a working party on employment issues for service users, which will publish guidance for psychiatrists and GPs in the coming months.

According to health minister John Hutton, the government is developing a new service to provide workplace support for people with mental health problems, due to be launched later this year.

webTitle: Sky One joins Mile High club

fields.headline: Sky One joins Mile High club
fields.trailText: 8.45am: Sky One has commissioned a drama about the lives and loves of airline cabin crews dubbed "Sex and the City in the sky", writes Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
Sky One has commissioned a drama about the lives and loves of airline cabin crews dubbed "Sex and the City in the sky".

Mile High will focus on a group of air hostesses and cabin attendants who share an apartment and "hotbunk", taking their flatmates' beds when they are away with work.

The 13 x 60-minute series is being made by Hewland International, the company behind long running Sky One football soap Dream Team.

Hewland managing director Jane Hewland described the drama, which will go out next year, as a "Sex in the City in the sky".

Ms Hewland is bringing in US writer Dianne Dixon to work on the series alongside UK writers. Ms Dixon has written for Ally McBeal producer David E Kelly on US dramas such as Sabrina The Teenage Witch and The Practice.

Ms Hewland and Cameron McAllister will co-executive produce the series, as part of a newly formed joint venture production company called Double Act.

webTitle: ITC issues interactive TV guidelines

fields.headline: ITC issues interactive TV guidelines
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The ITC has issued a series of guidelines for the regulation of interactive iTV services, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The Independent Television Commission has flexed its muscles in the interactive TV arena, issuing a series of guidelines for the regulation of iTV services.

The main thrust of the guidelines is to establish that, where there is a clear "doorway" between TV and an interactive service, it is the responsibility of the broadcasters to ensure the existing regulatory framework is upheld.

The ITC has opted to divide interactive TV service into two - dedicated interactive services such as Open, which will not be covered by the ITC's own codes, and enhanced programme services for which a number of rules and safeguards have been developed.

The ITC's main safeguards are that current programme standards are especially important; advertising linked to editorial content should remain separated; and children should be protected at all costs.

The guidelines do not cover web access via TV, which the ITC feels it is not in a position to try and regulate.

Regarding the separation of adverts from programmes, the ITC's new guidelines insist that there should be a "first click" screen to prevent viewers going straight from a programme to a commercial environment.

Interactive icons, which flash up on screen during programmes, should not carry branding or give any undue prominence to a certain product.

In addition, the ITC has laid down strident rules on enhanced TV for "sensitive categories of programme", namely news and current affairs, consumer advice programmes and children's programmes.

In these three strands of programming, no direct offers for sale will be allowed and certain types of advertising related to the programme content have been banned.

To keep a close eye on market developments, the ITC plans to establish a forum for ongoing discussion with the interactive TV industry.

The guidelines were drawn up following a series of in-depth consultations with interactive TV licencees over the past year.

webTitle: Cricket brand campaign

fields.headline: Cricket to adopt a more commercial image
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Cricket is to get its own brand identity in order to increase the commercial viability of the sport, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Cricket is to get its own brand identity for the first time in an effort to increase the commercial viability of the sport.

The sport's governing body, the International Cricket Council, has appointed corporate identity agency Minale Tattersfield Bryce to design an ICC brand.

The branding will be used across four of the properties owned and organised by the body - the ICC World Cup, ICC Knockout, ICC Trophy and ICC under-19s World Cup.

The decision to develop a brand was taken at a two-day ICC Executive Board meeting in Melbourne last weekend.

A series of initiatives for international cricket were approved by the board.

At the same meeting, the board announced the establishment of a rankings system called the ICC Test Championship.

This will be a rolling "league of nations" for five-day Test cricket.

A co-ordinated ten-year Test and One-Day International programme and a move towards a fully professional independent international umpiring system were also agreed.

An ICC spokesman said the new corporate identity would be the body's first concerted effort to create a commercial brand.

"Now we are involved with big commercial partners like the World Sport Group, which is responsible for marketing our tournaments over the next seven years, we need a more professional and considered image to present potential partners," said the spokesman.

He said it was undecided whether one ICC brand would run across all four tournaments or whether they would have separate identities.

But the deadline for Minale Tattersfield Bryce to create the imagery is June, when it will be presented to the ICC Annual General Meeting in London.

The Sydney and Brisbane offices of Minale Tattersfield Bryce are leading the initiative but will bring in staff from the UK and South Africa to help with the project.

webTitle: e-street buys out rival's mobile technology

fields.headline: e-street buys out rival's mobile technology
fields.trailText: 8.30am: London-based online city guide e-street has purchased the mobile technology assets of rival service Citykey, writes Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
London-based online city guide e-street has purchased the mobile technology assets of rival service Citykey.

Citykey is the WAP and PDA city guide which went into liquidation last November.

The acquisition, for an undisclosed sum, will enable e-street to expand its directory offering to users of personal digital assistants, at a fraction of what it would have cost to develop its own technology, according to chief executive Toby Robertson.

In a move indicative of a dotcom marketplace increasingly characterised by fire sales, where canny companies can pick and choose the parts they want at a massive discount, e-street has also acquired Citykey's domain name and source code, while rejecting its content.

According to e-street, it employs scouts who check the details of every shop, pub, cinema and hotel the company lists every six weeks, to ensure up-to-date information.

It recently expanded into Dublin and has plans to produce guides for Edinburgh, Glasgow, Bristol and Manchester.

webTitle: Digital TV pilots offer free switch

fields.headline: Digital TV pilots offer free switch
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Thousands of homes are to be converted free of charge to digital TV in an attempt to wear down consumer resistance to the change, the government will announce today.
fields.body:
Thousands of homes are to be converted free of charge to digital TV in an attempt to wear down consumer resistance to the change, the government will announce today.

Pilot schemes, each covering up to 1,000 households, will also be used to iron out technical difficulties.

Combined with a phone line, digital TV gives households access to internet shopping, banking and learning as well as email. Ministers hope to boost the e-economy by switching the whole of Britain from analogue to digital signals between 2006 and 2010.

The move will be unveiled by the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, when he releases a white paper on the knowledge economy. The paper will also contain plans to strengthen the powers of the regional development agencies in skills, planning and transport.

Households being offered free digital TV will have access to free-to-air digital and interactive services. The pilots are to be run in partnership with the digital industry and the independent television commission. The industry hopes to learn lessons about converting whole areas and how to overcome consumer resistance. The measures are likely to include the provision of digital access boxes, and the adjustment of aerials and video recorders.

webTitle: Artists oppose EU's 'legalised theft'

fields.headline: Artists oppose EU's 'legalised theft'
fields.standfirst:
More net news
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Writers and actors say they will be cheated of income under a European plan to allow broadcasters to pay minimal royalties for putting archive material on the internet or interactive TV services.
fields.body:
Writers and actors say they will be cheated of income under a European plan to allow broadcasters to pay minimal royalties for putting archive material on the internet or interactive TV services.

The actors' union, Equity, and four other trade organisations stated yesterday it amounts to "legalised theft".

Lobbying from the continental media has led to the proposal, which is being debated this week in the European parliament. It is part of a proposed directive on copyright law, which would also require film-makers to seek permission from architects and designers of public buildings or objects before picturing them. Another clause would give artists a mandatory share of profits in the sales and distribution of broadcast material. "There are quite a few barmy measures in this directive," one broadcaster said.

Under one proposal broadcasters would be able to use archive material on their websites or for the new "TV on demand" services (allowing viewers to watch programmes whenever they wish) without permission of the creators and on payment of a sum termed "equitable remuneration".

Artists urged Britain's MEPs to vote against the plan. Bernie Corbett, general secretary of the Writers' Guild, said: "This clause is very dangerous. Remuneration would appear to mean payment, but equitable is in the eye of the beholder."

In a joint statement yesterday Equity, the Musicians' Union, the Writers' Guild, and the Directors' Guild claimed the measure was introduced at the behest of media corporations. "This last-minute monster, which is aimed at allowing vast corporations to introduce internet and video on demand services at minimal cost, is the pay-off for millions of euros spent on lobbying by European and American media giants. They alone will profit."

The unions feared that if broadcasters could recycle cheap archive material there would be less demand for new work. The measure would not be binding on Britain, and the unions wanted the government to refuse to incorporate it into British law.

Broadcasters in Britain are not supporting the amendment, introduced by an MEP from Germany's Christian Democrat party. The BBC said it was "not an issue" for the corporation, and a source in the commercial sector said: "We think arrangements in place work perfectly well; these things would be better dealt with at a national rather than European level."

webTitle: £30m to kick-start broadband

fields.headline: £30m to kick-start broadband
fields.trailText: E-minister Patricia Hewitt and e-envoy Andrew Pinder joined forces today to launch a £30m fund to kick-start broadband uptake. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
E-minister Patricia Hewitt and e-envoy Andrew Pinder joined forces today to launch a £30m fund to kick-start broadband uptake in the UK.

The report, entitled UK online: the broadband future, sets out an action plan to solve the prevailing problem of limited broadband distribution in the UK.

"We do not want a nation of have-nets and have-nots," Ms Hewitt said. "The £30m fund is to help ensure that a digital divide in high speed internet access does not open up between urban and rural communities."

The report recommends increased broadband connections to all schools, libraries, colleges and universities and pledges the money will be spent on driving broadband into rural areas.

By introducing broadband connections to the public sector, such as schools, GP surgeries, police stations and town halls, the government is hoping it will encourage the private sector to speed up further roll-out.

Ms Hewitt has also promised to get more directly involved in broadband roll-out, with plans to set up a broadband stakeholder group, which will deal with industry problems and force BT into action.

Mr Pinder said: "This report is only the beginning of the road towards a broadband future but we believe it sets us out on the right route to providing access to the next generation of online services for everyone."

The report and action plan will be music to the ears of internet service providers that have fought long and hard battles with BT over fair access to its local exchanges.

Just this morning, representatives from AOL UK complained to the House of Commons select committee about BT dragging its heals over ADSL roll out.

Karen Thompson, managing director of AOL UK, was asked when she thought broadband would happen.

"I don't think it will be this year. I very much doubt it will be next year," she said.

"I believe the industry has been held back by slow access and information on pricing both for ISPs and for the consumer. It's very difficult to build demand for new services if you are not able to cost them."

webTitle: BP profits fuel price anger

fields.headline: BP profits fuel price anger
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol crisis
fields.trailText: Oil giant BP Amoco today announced adjusted profits of $14.2bn (£9.7 billion) for the last year - more than double the profit for the preceding 12-month period.
fields.body:
Oil giant BP Amoco today announced adjusted profits of $14.2bn (£9.7 billion) for the last year - more than double the profit for the preceding 12-month period.

The news from the British oil giant comes hot on the heels of other huge profits in the industry. Exxon Mobil recorded world record corporate annual profits of $17bn for the same time, while Royal Dutch/Shell picked up $13.1bn for the year 2000.

BP chief executive, Sir John Browne, said: "The strong trading environment, together with the benefits of recent integration and restructuring, and productivity improvements, has produced an outstanding worldwide result for BP.

"We have delivered on our 2000 cost saving target and are on track for the cost saving and improvement in return on capital targets by the end of 2001."

BP's figures are adjusted to take into account one-off charges and credits, including integration costs of US acquisition Arco, as well as rationalisation costs following the BP Amoco merger.

The announcement was made as energy companies face pressures from several quarters.

Environmentalists are stepping up campaigns for more alternative energy investment and less drilling in sensitive sites, while the fuel protesters who brought the country to a standstill last September will be angered by the news.

BP insisted that the scale of the profits was not related to forecourt petrol prices and sales.

webTitle: Commission provides preview of life under the euro

fields.headline: Commission provides a preview of life under the euro
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The timing could hardly have been worse. There was the government starting to make mildly more positive noises about holding a referendum on the single currency, and in wades Brussels with hobnailed boots.
fields.body:
The timing could hardly have been worse. There was the government starting to make mildly more positive noises about holding a referendum on the single currency, and in wades Brussels with hobnailed boots.

At one level, yesterday's decision by Europe's finance ministers to endorse the reprimand recommended by the commision to Ireland over its fiscal policy made perfect sense. You cannot have an effective monetary union if some of members operate fiscal policies that run counter to what the European Central Bank is trying to do. Monetary conditions in Ireland were relaxed when it joined the single currency, adding to the risks of inflation. Economic orthodoxy suggests that in such circumstances, governments should lean against the wind by tightening fiscal policy.

Far from toughening up fiscal policy, the Irish have relaxed it, announcing cuts in taxes and increases in public spending in an attempt to persuade workers in the country's ultra-tight labour market from pressing for inflationary wage increases. Ireland's finance minister, Charlie McCreevy, also argues that increasing investment spending will remove some of the bottlenecks in the supply side of the economy, thereby helping to control inflation.

At a time when it is running a hefty budget surplus and putting cash aside to deal with the effects of the demographic timebomb on pension liabilities, Ireland certainly has reason to feel hard done by. Even so, the row is unlikely to do much more than dent the country's broad support for Europe and its institutions.

On this side of the Irish Sea, however, it may be a different story. Those opposed to Britain joining the euro have always warned of the dangers of a one-size-fits-all policy, have said that Brussels would not be able to resist meddling in matters that should not concern it, and that the cost of monetary union threatens to be cuts in public spending. Here was the commission making the case in one fell swoop.

Presumably, that was why Gordon Brown was making such a fuss yesterday over the modest concern shown by the commission over Labour's plans to run a small deficit to fund higher capital expenditure in future years. The chancellor was yesterdayengaged in pre-emptive damage limitation, knowing full well how the news from yesterday's meeting would play in the British media.

Even so, the row is unlikely to do much more than dent the country's broad support for Europe and its institutions. On this side of the Irish Sea, however, it may be a different story. Those opposed to Britain joining the euro have always warned of the dangers of a one-size-fits-all policy, have said that Brussels would not be able to resist meddling in matters that should not concern it, and that the cost of monetary union threatens to be cuts in public spending. Here was the commission making the case in one fell swoop. Presumably, that was why Gordon Brown was making such a fuss yesterday over the modest concern shown by the commission over Labour's plans to run a small deficit to fund higher capital expenditure in future years. The chancellor was yesterdayengaged in pre-emptive damage limitation, knowing full well how the news from yesterday's meeting would play in the British media.

webTitle: DNA test unlocks prisoner's door after 18 years

fields.headline: DNA test unlocks prisoner's door after 18 years
fields.standfirst: Pardon for man with mental age of 10 who once came within days of being executed
fields.trailText: Pardon for man with mental age of 10 who once came within days of being executed.
fields.body:
Earl Washington, a 40-year-old man with a mental age of 10, was freed from a Virginia jail yesterday after more than 18 years in jail - nine of them on death row - for a crime he did not commit.

Mr Washington came within nine days of being executed in 1985 before being granted a stay.

As far back as 1993, genetic evidence had cast doubt on his conviction for the rape and murder of a woman in 1982. But the Virginia governor at the time, L Douglas Wilder, only commuted his death sentence. It took Mr Washington's lawyers another 18 years to win a pardon from later governor, Jim Gilmore.

Commenting on the pardon, Mr Washington said: "It made me happy ... He [Gilmore] did a good job by my book."

He said he was not angry about his 18 years of wrongful imprisonment, and would simply seek an apology.

No forensic evidence was presented at Mr Washington's trial, and he was convicted mainly on the strength of a confession made in police custody. But transcripts of his interrogation showed that the police officers led him through the confession, supplying him with the facts of the case.

New DNA analysis last year linked two other men to the crime.

Mr Washington was taken yesterday from the Greensville Correctional Centre to Virginia Beach, where he will live in a supervised block of flats for the mentally disabled.

Virginia has executed 8 people since the moratorium on the death penalty was lifted in 1976, far fewer than Texas in absolute terms, but the highest number of state executions per capita in the US.

Critics of capital punishment say that one of the reasons it is used so often in Virginia is a law that prevents new evidence being used in an appeal, if it is presented more than 21 days after the original conviction.

A bill to overturn this 21-day rule is now before the state legislature. A Virginia senate committee, however, rejected a proposal to suspend executions in the state pending an inquiry into how the death penalty is imposed.

Virginia authorities prevented Mr Washington from attending a press conference called by his supporters in Washington, saying he was still serving parole.

Mr Washington's case is the latest of more than 90 exonerations of death row convicts in recent years, which have provoked a rethink in several states.

Illinois, Nebraska, Arizona, North Carolina, Maryland and Indiana have begun inquiries into the fairness of their systems. Last year, the Illinois governor, George Ryan, declared a statewide moratorium on executions, after a string of blatant miscarriages of justice.

webTitle: Turkey jails spy and ex-police chief for running hit squad

fields.headline: Turkey jails spy and ex-police chief for running hit squad
fields.trailText: A court in Turkey yesterday jailed a former police chief and a leading intelligence agent for six years each for their part in a complex conspiracy which linked senior state officials to political murders carried out by criminal gangs.
fields.body:
A court in Turkey yesterday jailed a former police chief and a leading intelligence agent for six years each for their part in a complex conspiracy which linked senior state officials to political murders carried out by criminal gangs.

The former head of police special forces, Ibrahim Sahin, and a senior intelligence agent, Korkut Eken, were both found guilty of forming and running a criminal gang with the aim of "creating panic in society". Eleven others were also found guilty of lesser offences after a long trial and were jailed for four years each.

The Turkish public has long been convinced that there was a clear link between the state and the nationalist mafia, but these are the first convictions arising from the scandal in the wake of a car crash in the western town of Susurluk in November 1996.

The crash killed a senior police officer, a gangster and a former beauty queen. An MP who was also in the car - and who works closely with the security forces in mainly Kurdish south-eastern Turkey - survived.

Incriminating documents and weapons found in the wreckage soon forced the interior minister to resign.

What followed was an unprecedented campaign of public protest against corruption and abuse of power in high places. The official report into what became known as the Susurluk affair painted a murky picture of state security agencies using nationalist criminal gangs to kill their political opponents.

Among those killed were leftwing journalists and Kurdish activists. In return, the gangs were allowed to smuggle drugs and run extortion operations, laundering many of the profits through a chain of casinos.

Elements within the police and the intelligence agencies also used the extensive powers given to them in the fight against Kurdish rebels to commit crimes of their own.

The Susurluk report aired allegations that the Turkish secret service, Mit, took part in a failed coup attempt against President Heydar Aliyev of Azerbaijan in 1995, and in an abortive alliance with Israel's Mossad to try to kill the Kurdish rebel leader, Abdullah Ocalan, while he was in Syria.

Now, four years after the car crash, some of those involved are being made to take the blame. But critics believe that others - including politicians - are being allowed to go free.

"This verdict only says there was a gang," Sema Piskinsut, a deputy who served on a committee investigating links between the underworld and the state, said. "But what did it do, who did it work for? Parliament should find out who was politically responsible."

The Susurluk Affair was significant because it sparked genuine fears among ordinary Turks that gangs within the state had been given unfettered control, and could be a threat to democracy. Suspicion of what Turks call "deep state links" is still extremely strong.

The end of the trial comes amid fears of a renewed effort to destabilise the south-east, which is now enjoying its most peaceful period for years.

Two leading members of the pro-Kurdish political party, Hadep, disappeared late last month in Silopi after being asked to visit the local gendarmerie headquarters.

Even though the Kurdish rebel movement, the PKK, has largely withdrawn from the south-east, many believe that powerful forces in Turkey still have an interest in maintaining a tight security blanket across the region.

The south-east is the hub of a massive smuggling business involving drugs and human migrants. The hugely profitable trade is run by powerful criminal gangs, with the backing of renegade elements within the state - exactly the same combination which sparked the Susurluk scandal in the first place.

webTitle: Calais stabbings among migrants adds pressure for EU border deal

fields.headline: Calais stabbings among migrants adds pressure for EU border deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Two men were in a Calais hospital with knife wounds last night after fighting between some 300 Afghan and Kurdish refugees that will lend new urgency to efforts by France and Britain to resolve their growing problem with illegal immigration.
fields.body:
Two men were in a Calais hospital with knife wounds last night after fighting between some 300 Afghan and Kurdish refugees that will lend new urgency to efforts by France and Britain to resolve their growing problem with illegal immigration.

EU immigration officials are in London this week to discuss the coordination of migration and asylum policies, and more immediate practical moves to reduce the influx of refugees, 390,000 of whom applied for asylum in Europe last year.

The issue topped the agenda at last week's Franco-British summit in Cahors, where it was agreed that immigration officials from both countries would travel on Eurostar trains between Paris and London via Calais, inspecting papers before and during journeys. According to British officials, up to 400 immigrants a month have been entering Britain illegally by buying Eurostar tickets from the French capital to the Channel port, then staying on the train without proper papers and applying for asylum once upon reaching London.

The two wounded men, both stabbed in the chest, were among 15 injured on Sunday evening in a battle at the Red Cross refugee centre in Sangatte, outside Calais.

Police said the fight broke out when a Kurdish agent for one of the dozens of smuggling gangs operating around the port was discovered in the centre trying to extort a "fee" from a young Afghan refugee who refused to pay.

"It seems the area around the port and the mouth of the tunnel is effectively run by a gang of Kurds, who demand money from refugees simply for the right to try to get across the Channel," a police spokesman said. "The Afghans are the third largest group in the centre, after Iraqi Kurds and Iranians. They stuck together and said no."

Red Cross workers who man the centre said minor clashes between frustrated refugees had become increasingly common as crossing the Channel had become tougher.

"This place was originally opened in 1999 for 200 people. Right now we have 849," Michel Derr, the manager of the centre, said. "We have reached a critical level of overcrowding and it's generating enormous tension."

Some 25,000 illegal immigrants were caught trying to cross the Channel at Calais last year, with 1,700 cases reported last month.

The French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, last week rejected a radical proposal by London for a "bilateral repatriation" accord that would have seen illegal immigrants to Britain sent straight back to France.

He insisted that the problems caused by migrants arriving in Calais could be solved only by a broader agreement - either at EU level or by a three-way deal between Britain, France and Italy.

EU interior ministers meeting in Stockholm last week agreed to speed up the coordination of asylum policies to cut the number of "bogus" applicants, while trying not to ignore genuine refugees fleeing persecution.

The British home secretary, Jack Straw, has been pressing hard for more collaboration. Britain got the most asylum applications last year, 97,900. Germany at 78,800 was next.

webTitle: Mugabe tries to crush all opposition

fields.headline: Mugabe tries to crush all opposition
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe's president has scrapped the last veneer of legality in a terror drive against judges and the press

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's president has scrapped the last veneer of legality in a terror drive against judges and the press.
fields.byline: Andrew Meldrum in Harare and Chris McGreal
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe has more than a year before he is obliged to hold a presidential election he will almost certainly lose if it is anything like free and fair. But Zimbabwe's leader is apparently taking action to make sure no such thing happens, with a concerted assault aimed at breaking any challenge to Zanu-PF's grip on power.

In recent weeks, independent judges have been hounded from office fearing for their lives, the opposition press has been bombed, politicians who have denounced President Mugabe's abuses have been locked up on charges of promoting violence, and the mass of poor have faced tear gas and riot police for daring to protest at the rising price of bread.

Just a few months ago, Zimbabweans believed that Mr Mugabe's 20-year rule was grinding towards its end, as the economy collapsed and his government seemed to be foundering.

Support for the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) surged in last June's parliamentary election and the party took almost half the seats, despite ballot rigging. Mr Mugabe's enemies claimed that the president would be out of office by Christmas.

They could not have been more wrong. He has proved that he may be down, but he is far from out.

What has changed is that the last veneer of legality has now been stripped away. The government is waging a violent campaign against its opponents, and there is little doubt as to where the orders are coming from.

Two weeks ago, a mine destroyed the printing press of the country's biggest opposition newspaper, the Daily News, just days after the information minister, Jonathan Moyo, had labelled it a threat to national security that must be "stopped". The explosive used was almost certainly only available to the military.

Four MDC members of parliament were charged with inciting violence against the government last week, the first such arrests of Mr Mugabe's elected opponents. They are unlikely to be the last. One of the MPs, Job Sikhala, said that he and his pregnant wife were beaten by soldiers.

But it is in the courts, the last bastion of consistent defiance to Mr Mugabe from within the system, that the government is focusing its assault.

At first the government used its tested tactic of using the so-called war veterans - who led the invasion of white-owned farms - to carry out the intimidation of the judiciary: 300 of them stormed the supreme court last November in protest at its ruling that the land invasions were illegal, and its order to the police to remove those occupying the farms.

The judges were forced to seek refuge in their chambers but refused to quit.

Now the government has gone for a more direct approach. In what members of the Zimbabwe bar call "a coup against the judiciary", the justice minister, Patrick Chinamasa, told the supreme court's chief justice, Anthony Gubbay, that his safety could not be guaranteed if he did not resign. Mr Gubbay put up a brave public fight by criticising government intimidation of the courts, but finally opted for early retirement.

Similar threats were made last Friday to two other supreme court judges, Nick McNally and Ahmed Ibrahim. Mr Chinamasa told Mr McNally, who is white, that "the president does not wish to see you come to any harm".

Resignations

Mr McNally has refused to quit, saying that it is important for the judiciary to stand up to the executive. Mr Ibrahim, who is of Asian descent, is considering his position. Both now have good reason to fear for their lives.

The state-owned Herald newspaper admitted that Mr Chinamasa also intends to try to get the two other supreme court judges, who are black, to quit. And there are dozens of other judges, black and white, from the high court down that the government wants out for having a "Rhodesian mentality".

"We must begin to exorcise from all our institutions the racist ghost of Ian Smith and we do so by phasing out his disciples and sympathisers," Mr Chinamasa said.

In reality, Mr Mugabe wants a free hand to appoint an entire panel of judges unlikely to challenge his controversial and - according to the present court - illegal redistribution of white-owned farms.

More important, the president wants a supreme court that will not question his conduct of elections. The opposition fears this will open the way to widespread intimidation and ballot rigging to keep Mr Mugabe in power, because there will be no effective recourse to the courts.

Election challenges

The president is already concerned about the outcome of legal challenges to the election results in 37 parliamentary constituencies. The high court began hearing the first cases yesterday, but the final decision will almost certainly end up in the hands of the supreme court. If it overturns the results, Zanu-PF could lose control of parliament.

"It is hard to say what is most outrageous and despicable - the Mugabe government's efforts to neutralise the courts, or its intimidation of the press, or its violations of the rights of average citizens," the MDC's legal strategist, Tendai Biti, said. "What is particularly disturbing is that it is all being done through extra-legal means. It is destroying the legal fabric of the country. No one is safe from intimidation, from a peasant farmer to a supreme court justice."

The president of the Law Society of Zimbabwe, Sternford Moyo, has warned that if the government continues to condone lawlessness, ordinary people will disregard the law.

Mr Mugabe's opponents, at home and abroad, are at a loss as to how to stop him - not least because of the damage being inflicted on the country by corruption and the leadership's pursuit of spoils in the Congo war. Last week, in a further demonstration of the government's desperation in the face of a relentlessly declining economy, the president moved to seize the foreign exchange reserves of private companies, to pay for oil imports and the salaries of his diplomats overseas.

Late last year the MDC was promising mass protest, but it has backed away from taking the fight to the streets for fear of bloodshed that would give the government an excuse to impose a state of emergency and cancel the next election.

Britain's vocal criticism has done no more than aggravate the Zimbabwean president, who calls it neo-colonialist. And while President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa could do without such instability on his doorstep, his influence over Mr Mugabe is limited.

webTitle: Simon Hoggart: women in the ranks

fields.headline: 'Luscious lance-corporal' fails to stir the ranks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Defence questions yesterday, and a chance for MPs to tackle the vital issue being debated in the MoD, at Nato headquarters, and in army messes wherever the union flag still flies.
fields.body:
Defence questions yesterday, and a chance for MPs to tackle the vital issue being debated in the MoD, at Nato headquarters, and in army messes wherever the union flag still flies.

It is not the planned European reaction force, nor the missile defence system George Bush wants in Yorkshire. It's far more important: should women soldiers be allowed to pose topless in the Sun, our new paper of record?

Last Friday an NCO called Roberta Winterton (the "luscious lance-corporal" in Sun speak) appeared topless in the paper. Yesterday morning - well, I'll turn over to the Sun's reporter: "Corps blimey - a second army girl is stripping for action today. Our snaps of fighting fit Melanie Cotton, 27, are sure to send shell-shocked top brass diving for cover. She launched a second front yesterday..."

It turns out that "stunning Mel" works as a PT instructor at Supreme HQ, Allied Powers Europe, known of course as Shape. This is proof that there is a god who looks over Sun sub-editors.

The style is infectious, and so when the ranks of the Queen's Own Sketchwriters arrived in the press gallery yesterday, the order paper took on a series of entirely different meanings. MPs were demanding "vital statistics" about defence. What steps, they wanted to know, was the defence secretary taking "to enhance frontline equipment", and would he make a statement on "women serving in frontline combat roles"?

The phrases danced in front of our eyes like old-fashioned strippers, each hinting at greater revelations than we were actually likely to see.

Even the Tories, we thought, would find some way of dragging up this embarrassment for ministers. They are notoriously incapable of harrying the government on any topic, whether it's class sizes, the collapsing railway system, or the antics of Peter Mandelson, but surely even they could find some way of working in topless troopers.

Apparently not. There were questions about European defence co-operation, the strategic defence review, military kit, Sierra Leone and a dozen minor topics. The QOS, pens glinting in the balcony, were becoming desperate.

I almost wrote a note to fold into a paper dart, in the hope that it would glide into the chamber and bonk some rent-a-quote MP on the head to stir him into action. It would have been a grand gesture; I would be banned for life, but my comrades would always remember my gallantry and sacrifice.

Just when we feared all hope was lost and retreat inevitable, Gerald Howarth, a Tory who sits for the army base of Aldershot, rode to our rescue. There is something magnificently dated about Mr Howarth. Seeing him advance over the horizon was like watching a line of cavalry charging against tanks.

webTitle: Blood for blood on Route 60

fields.headline: Blood for blood on Route 60
fields.standfirst:
Israelis fire on Palestinian bus in reprisal for settler's murder

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli soldiers shot through the rear window of a Palestinian bus yesterday morning, killing a labourer in what appeared to be a random act of violence.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in al-Khader, West Bank
fields.body:
Israeli soldiers shot through the rear window of a Palestinian bus yesterday morning, killing a labourer in what appeared to be a random act of violence.

Ziad Abu Swayyeh, 20, was shot through the back when Israeli troops fired on the bus he was travelling in. They were apparently trying to avenge the killing of a Jewish settler by Palestinian snipers on the same road, barely 10 hours earlier.

The twin killings along Route 60, the road that cuts south from Jerusalem through the stony hills of the West Bank to the Jewish settlement blocks, looked certain to feed the renewed violence triggered by last week's election of the hardline Ariel Sharon as Israel's prime minister. With the toll in the four-month uprising approaching 400 dead, mainly Palestinians, both sides yesterday seemed determined to intensify the violence.

As night fell, Israeli troops fired tank shells and machine-guns at the Khan Yunis refugee camp in the southern Gaza Strip. At least 30 people suffered bullet injuries, or were hit by shrapnel in a 90-minute firefight between Palestinian gunmen and troops guarding the Jewish settlement of Gush Katif, Palestinian human rights workers said.

The day of blood and retribution began at 6.30am when the driver of Abu Swayyeh's bus, Ahmed Zaoul, was easing off the paved road and around a huge mound of earth and concrete blocks piled up by Israeli army bulldozers at the entrance to Route 60 from al-Khader. He was turned back by Israeli soldiers.

As the bus, carrying 16 passengers, returned to al-Khader, shots shattered its rear window, killing Abu Swayyeh, who was standing beside the driver, and hitting another man in the head. "He rode my bus every day," Mr Zaoul said of the dead man. "This must have been a message from Sharon to the Palestinians. One Israeli was killed and so this morning they have taken their revenge."

A few hours later, a column of Palestinian women with groceries and small children tried to cross the barricade on foot, but scattered when a soldier pointed his gun at them.

Thousands of mourners followed Abu Swayyeh's body in a traditional martyr's burial yesterday. But he was a simple labourer, not a member of a Fatah militia, and so when his family returned to their village of Artas, they sat alone, waiting to receive condolences from the Palestinian Authority that never arrived.

At about the same time, and a few miles to the south, mourners were gathering at Rosh Tsurim, part of the large Gush Etzion settlement, for the funeral for Tsahi Sasson.

An electrical engineer, 35, Sasson was shot dead as he passed the Jewish settlement of Gilo on his way home from his job in Jerusalem on Sunday night.

He was a relative newcomer to the settlement, renting a home with his wife and two sons two years ago. "He was looking for a place that would be good for the children, where they could feel more free," said Sharon Green, the settlement secretary.

She looked down in the valley to the Jewish settlement of Beitar, Abu Swayyeh's destination yesterday. He had been working there for six months as a builder, earning 100 shekels a day (about £16.50).

There will be more acts of retribution, with Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement yesterday claiming Sasson's killing and renewing threats to step up attacks on Jewish settlements.

"The Sharon era will not be as stable and secure as the criminal promised," a Fatah leaflet said. "Our goal is to bring down Sharon and all his settlements."

In the gunfights that raged overnight across the West Bank, Palestinian snipers fired on Gilo, south of Jerusalem, for the first time since December 6, when church leaders and Mr Arafat got them to stop.

Officially, there have been no orders to resume hostilities against Gilo, said Kamal Hmeid, Fatah commander of the Bethlehem district who helped to broker the ceasefire. "It is still forbidden, but after Sharon's election there is reaction from people and we cannot stop them," he said.

Israel was also in no mood to back down yesterday. The outgoing prime minister, Ehud Barak, told army commanders to "do what needs to be done" to protect Jewish civilians. Though Mr Sharon has yet to take charge, a senior member of his Likud party said the new government would use even greater force against Arab gunmen. "They should know that we have means that we still have not used," Moshe Arens told Israel radio.

Last night Israelis and Palestinians were bracing for more bloodshed along Route 60. An Israeli armoured personnel carrier trained its machine-gun on al-Khader, and troops fanned along the electrified gates of Jewish settlements.

Across the fields and barren vinyards, Palestinians filed home from work - on foot as the Israeli army bans their travel by private cars. Jewish settlers lined up outside their enclaves to stone passing Palestinian taxis and buses.

 Israel's attorney general has asked the supreme court to reject outright a petition that is seeking a ban on state-sanctioned assassinations of Palestinian leaders.

webTitle: Parties may face ban on gifts

fields.headline: Parties may face ban on multi-million gifts
fields.trailText: Labour and the Tories could be banned from receiving multi-million pound donations under plans being examined by a new electoral watchdog.
fields.body:
Labour and the Tories could be banned from receiving multi-million pound donations under plans being examined by a new electoral watchdog.

Amid increasing public concern over cash-for-influence donations, the electoral commission's new chairman announced yesterday that he would assess whether a cap should be imposed on individual donations.

The move comes after the recent controversy when Labour and the Tories accepted multi-million donations from a handful of benefactors. Labour accepted three last month, which were each worth £2m - from the publisher, Lord Hamlyn, the science minister, Lord Sainsbury, and the philanthropist Christopher Ondaatje.

The Tories set a new record a few weeks later when they were given £5m - the biggest single donation to a British political party - by Stuart Wheeler, the City betting entrepreneur. A poll in yester day's Daily Telegraph found that 70% of people thought that the wealthy could buy preferential treatment from Tony Blair's government.

Sam Younger, the chairman of the electoral commission, said yesterday that he would look at whether a limit should be imposed on such donations.

Mr Younger added that imposing a cap on individual donations would open up a debate on whether political parties should receive greater funding from the state. "You cannot disconnect this issue from state funding," he said. "The idea of an individual not giving millions of pounds looks attractive to people. But when they look at the alternative, which is the question of whether there should be state funding, a lot of those people will say no."

Mr Younger, whose commission makes recommendations to the government, declined to be drawn on what level a cap should be set. However, he pointed to remarks by the senior Labour backbencher, Tony Wright, who has called for a cap to be set at £100,000. Ministers, who have the power to reject Mr Younger's proposals, indicated that they might be persuaded on a funding cap.

The campaign for a cap on individual donations, which is supported by a growing number of Labour MPs, received a boost at the weekend when the outgoing standards watchdog threw his weight behind the calls.

Lord Neill of Bladen, who is retiring this month as chairman of the committee on standards in public life, told BBC's On the Record: "I think the problem is big donors means big influence."

Lord Neill added that he was disappointed that the government had not accepted his committee's call for a public register to record contacts between lobbyists and ministers. "I think there's got to be a great deal of awareness now that private side of business and the private field is mixing very much with government. What needs to be known is that this is taking place; what contribution the private side is making; what they're getting out of it."

The electoral commission was set up last year to police new rules on party funding. On Friday parties will have to declare all donations over £5,000.

webTitle: Eurocrats warn Kinnock to back off or face strike

fields.headline: Eurocrats warn Kinnock to back off or face strike
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: The largest and most powerful trade union representing civil servants of the European Union threatened yesterday to strike unless Neil Kinnock tones down plans to reform the European commission.
fields.body:
The largest and most powerful trade union representing civil servants of the European Union threatened yesterday to strike unless Neil Kinnock tones down plans to reform the European commission.

Mr Kinnock, the commission vice-president, is trying to make the body more efficient and improve its reputation after members of the previous commission headed by Jacques Santer were forced to resign en masse in 1999 because of fraud allegations against some of them.

He has unveiled plans for 600 people to be retired early, and his advisers have made no secret of the reform team's belief that the commission is packed with deadwood that needs to be cut back.

Mr Kinnock's methods have upset the EU's six main staff unions who regard the Welshman as a wrecker. They accuse him of an appalling lack of consultation and negotiation.

Alan Hick, president of Union Syndicale, told the Guardian yesterday that the situation was close to boiling point: his members were not keen on disrupting EU work, he said, but they might decide that industrial action was unavoidable.

"None of us wants to go on strike," he said. "We want to negotiate but the negotiations are simply not being conducted in a proper way.

"The situation has now come to boiling point and the unions will not accept this any more. If Kinnock does not change his methods then there will be industrial action."

Until the reform drive - the first of its kind at the commission - the union had been considered moderate.

But faced with the tough Kinnock proposals it passed a resolution last week complaining that the vice-president's efforts to overhaul the commission were "neither effective nor convincing". It said it would oppose by every means the "designs to dismantle careers within the community institutions".

The union's main complaint is that Mr Kinnock keeps presenting it with faits accomplis and it feels sidelined.

Eurocrats may enjoy scant sympathy in Britain but in Brussels many fonctionnaires feel unfairly maligned and fear that their pay and working conditions are about to be seriously eroded in what they see as a public relations exercise.

The former British Labour party leader wants to sweep away the French-style system of time-serving advancement and introduce a meritocratic system of promotions in hopes of erasing the image of Eurocrats as fat cats.

The unions have threatened strikes in the past but time is running out for them to make an impact: Mr Kinnock is scheduled to unveil new rules on salaries and pensions on February 28.

One reform-minded EU official yesterday accused the unions of scaremongering.

"Kinnock spends half his life negotiating with these people and more time than he does with his family," the official said. "But they have constantly run him down for not speaking French, for being British or a Tony Blair agent.

"They've tried everything to denigrate him. However, the fact is that the average member of staff will not lose out at all."

The last time the unions went on strike was for one day in 1998: there was a 97% turnout.

webTitle: Third world rush for human genome

fields.headline: Third world rush for human genome
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Scientists in the developing world have already made use of the human genome more than 300,000 times in the past two months, according to the researchers who deciphered the "book of humankind".
fields.body:
Scientists in the developing world have already made use of the human genome more than 300,000 times in the past two months, according to the researchers who deciphered the "book of humankind".

Teams in India, Brazil, Mexico and China have downloaded data for the complete sequence of the DNA of all the human chromosomes from an internet site, and begun combing it to help cure some of the world's ills. The human genome is so huge no single research organisation can handle more than a tiny fraction of the data at a time.

The tally of users from hospitals, laboratories and universities in the developing world came as two competing teams published their first papers. One team, a consortium of 16 organisations in Britain, the United States, France, Germany, Japan and China, has insisted on providing the information freely to all researchers everywhere.

Another team, Celera Genomics of Rockville, Maryland, is using a commercial outlet. Yesterday the consortium scientists said they calculated that the Celera database was being used by fewer than 50 paying customers.

Both groups worked frantically for two years to read the 3bn chemical bases of the DNA in the human chromosomes - a text so enormous it would fill 750,000 pages of closely typed paper. Because it will never be published on paper, the genome is stored in a publicly-accessible database, and researchers in distant countries are being provided with software to study it.

The database could help researchers combat diseases ranging from depression to diarrhoea. But there had been fears that the developing world would be excluded.

"At least 10,000 organisations throughout the world are accessing the publicly available data," said Graham Cameron, of the European Bioinformatics Institute near Cambridge. And Mike Dexter of the Wellcome Trust, which funded Britain's part, called the publication "a free gift to the world - and not simply to the developed world". Had the information been available commercially, many institutions would have been denied all access.

"I really don't think that to have a bizarre pay-and-view mechanism, almost like a digital TV buying up the World Cup, is right," he said.

The information could contain clues to explain diseases such as tuberculosis, sleeping sickness, river blindness, malaria and HIV.

The competing genomes are published and discussed in bumper issues of the magazine Nature, and its US counterpart Science, this week. Although the two groups published, there has been disagreement about access.

"Others want to charge the rest of the human race a fortune, but we are here to tell them that the human genome is not for sale," said Sir John Sulston, who led the British effort and was until recently director of the Sanger Centre near Cambridge. For a while there had been a possibility that the US government would stop funding the US public team. And without money from the world's largest charity, the Wellcome Trust, the British scientists could not have completed their 30% of the human chromosomes.

"Think what would have happened if the human genome had been privatised," Sir John said. "People tried very hard to do that in 1998. It was a near thing. The human genome has avoided that, and the crazy notion that the information could belong to one owner."

The competing genomes are published and discussed in bumper issues of the magazine Nature, and its US counterpart Science, this week. Although the two groups published, there has been disagreement about access. "Others want to charge the rest of the human race a fortune, but we are here to tell them that the human genome is not for sale," said Sir John Sulston, who led the British effort and was until recently director of the Sanger Centre near Cambridge. For a while there had been a possibility that the US government would stop funding the US public team. And without money from the world's largest charity, the Wellcome Trust, the British scientists could not have completed their 30% of the human chromosomes. "Think what would have happened if the human genome had been privatised," Sir John said. "People tried very hard to do that in 1998. It was a near thing. The human genome has avoided that, and the crazy notion that the information could belong to one owner." webTitle: Dioxins in city may be worst case in UK

fields.headline: Dioxins in city may be worst case in UK
fields.trailText: The spreading of poisoned incinerator ash over allotments in Newcastle upon Tyne's poorest area was one of the worst cases of dioxin contamination in Britain, an independent investigator said yesterday.
fields.body:
The spreading of poisoned incinerator ash over allotments in Newcastle upon Tyne's poorest area was one of the worst cases of dioxin contamination in Britain, an independent investigator said yesterday.

The consumption of eggs, poultry and vegetables produced on 22 allotments in the city was banned last year after 2,000 tonnes of incinerator ash was spread in Byker, in the constituency of the agriculture minister, Nick Brown.

The report, by Alan Watson, an independent scientist, was commissioned by residents. Separate reports by the environment agency and the food standards agency released last night confirmed high levels of metal contamination and the presence of high levels of dioxins - which can cause cancer - in the eggs of hens raised on the allotments. The environment agency has also revealed that the allotments were already highly polluted before the ash was spread. A fourth report, by Newcastle University, analysed the findings.

The disclosure of the findings, which had been held back for six months, provoked a big row between residents and the city council at a meeting in Byker last night. Newcastle council and the Newcastle and North Tyneside health authority have agreed to continue the ban on the consumption of eggs and poultry raised on the allotments as "a precautionary measure". But they claimed that, although the level of dioxins was high, it was not a serious danger to health.

Last year the council removed all the ash - which had been there for up to eight years - from the allotments, footpaths and bridleways in the city. Toddlers were prevented from playing on the allotments in case they ate the ash.

The council and Cambridge-based Combined Heat and Power face 19 charges between them of illegally disposing of toxic waste.

Dr Watson's report said: "The contamination of allotments in Newcastle by high levels of dioxins and heavy metals from the Byker incinerator could be one of the most serious dioxin contamination events in the UK ... this is because it is nearly unprecedented to have high levels of dioxin-contaminated material being introduced so directly on to land used for personal food supplies including eggs for a large number of people."

He accused the food standards agency and environment agency of not doing a thorough job. He said they had failed to assess the dioxin intakes of children under the age of 10 and had ignored the effect of dioxins on people who might have eaten the contaminated hens.

He said there could be other contaminated sites in Newcastle that had not been identified. "In at least some of the cases the allotments will need to be cleared completely, with new topsoil being supplied."

Last night Newcastle council condemned Dr Watson's findings. A spokesman said: "He is the only person who seems to have drawn such a conclusion - neither the food standards agency nor the environment agency are saying that the risk to health is so serious."

The reports from the two agencies and the analysis by Newcastle University all confirm heavy contamination. The university revealed that severe soil contamination with heavy metals and arsenic was found in more than half the allotments - and warned that other sources as well as the incinerator could be responsible. It also found that many of the eggs tested had dioxin levels "well in excess of levels found in supermarket barn eggs".

Both the environment agency and the food standards agency thought that people would have to have consumed huge quantities of produce to run a serious risk.

webTitle: Darling attacks pensioner aid

fields.headline: Darling attacks pensioner aid
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Conservative campaign to woo the pensioner "grey vote" ran into trouble last night after fresh concessions outlined by Michael Portillo drew charges from ministers that the Tory plans are ill-considered and innumerate.
fields.body:
The Conservative campaign to woo the pensioner "grey vote" ran into trouble last night after fresh concessions outlined by Michael Portillo drew charges from ministers that the Tory plans are ill-considered and innumerate.

The Tory leader, William Hague, teamed up with his shadow chancellor to provide pre-election details of another £1bn worth of concessions to the over 65s that would take 1m out of income tax altogether by lifting age-related allowances by £2,000 a year.

The move would ease bureaucracy and save pensioners from the "indignity, worry and confusion" of means testing, Mr Hague said. Mr Portillo called the modest taxes involved "pointless" to collect. Some pensioners would benefit by up to £8.50 a week.

In addition to implementing Gordon Brown's promised £3 uprating for single pensioners under 75 and £4.80 for couples Mr Portillo will give extra to the over-75s (usually the poorest) by raising their pensions by £4 and £6.80.

The move comes just a week after the Hague-Portillo team had also promised to abolish income tax on savings, which would mainly benefit older people.

But the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, called it deception - "like buying a round of drinks and then saying, 'I'm not going to pay for it'."

The Tory plans rest on £8bn worth of proposed spending cuts that - in theory - would allow prime minister Hague to both maintain key public services and cut taxes overall.

But Mr Darling said: "Pensioners, of all groups of the electorate, actually know that you can't spend the same money twice. If the Conservatives can't identify where these tax cuts are going to come from, they are not going to be taken in by it."

He argued that Tory claims that another £1bn could be saved from curbing social security fraud was "invented" and "absurd", not least because the Conservatives simultaneously plan to freeze benefit staff levels.

The Tory proposals, confirmed yesterday, would also allow OAPs to choose whether to have the chancellor's special payments, notably on free television licences and winter fuel payments, or have it added to their basic pensions.

The Tories are determined to court the 11m strong "grey vote" which is more likely than younger voters to go to the polling booths on election day. Labour says it has already taken 60% of pensioners out of tax altogether - though Mr Brown's determination to target his extra help on the poorest has led to growing means testing.
