webTitle: Justice in the spotlight. Can juries remain unbiased in high-profile cases?

fields.headline: Justice in the spotlight
fields.standfirst: Can juries remain unbiased in high-profile cases? With Michael Stone facing a new trial  Clare Dyer reports on encouraging evidence from a recent study
fields.trailText: Can juries remain unbiased in high-profile cases? With Michael Stone facing a new trial  Clare Dyer reports on encouraging evidence from a recent study.
fields.body:
Michael Stone will stand in the dock again later this year, accused for the second time of murdering Lin Russell and her daughter, Megan. But can he get a fair trial this time round? The brutal hammer killing of mother and daughter and the bludgeoning and near-murder of Megan's sister, Josie, as they strolled home from school through idyllic fields in rural Kent was one of the most shocking crimes of the past decade. Stone's conviction in 1998 unleashed a barrage of damning media coverage, pent up before and during the trial .

Since then the story has refused to die down, kept in the news by the continuing tale of Josie's recovery and the determined efforts of her father, Shaun, to rebuild a normal life for her. As Stone's QC, William Clegg, told the appeal court last week, the "fade factor", which usually dims the public's memory as time passes, has hardly operated in the Russell case. "If this case was to go to retrial", argued Clegg, "then the right of a citizen to have a fair trial not compromised by publicity will in reality be little more than empty words." He added: "It's difficult to imagine anybody having anything worse published about him than this man."

His plea failed to convince the three judges. They quashed the conviction after hearing that a key witness who claimed Stone had confessed to the killings had retracted his claims, but ordered a new trial. They will give their reasons tomorrow.

Judges may order a retrial after quashing a conviction if "it appears to the court that the interests of justice so require". The more serious the crime, the more likely the defendant is to face another trial. Yet, paradoxically, the more horrific the crime, the more lurid the coverage - and the more prejudicial the potential effect on the jurors who will eventually try the case.

Lord Taylor, the former Lord Chief Justice, acknowledged this in 1996 when he rejected Rosemary West's appeal against her conviction for murdering 10 young women and girls, including her own daughter and step-daughter, with her husband, Fred. West's appeal was based partly on sensationalist press reports before her trial.

"However lurid the reporting," said Lord Taylor, "there can scarcely ever have been a case more calculated to shock the public, who were entitled to know the facts." But it would be "absurd" to rule that the trial should not therefore have gone ahead. That would mean that if murders were horrendous enough to shock the nation, the accused could never be tried.

Judges have traditionally relied on the ability and willingness of jurors to put out of their minds anything read or heard before the trial. In 1969 Reggie and Ronnie Kray were convicted, with much sensational media coverage, of murdering two other gangland figures, Jack "The Hat" McVitie and George Cornell. Not long after, they faced another trial, this time for ordering the murder of Frank "The Mad Axeman" Mitchell, a man they had helped escape from Dartmoor.

Sir Frederick Lawton, who presided over the trial, allowed the defence to cross-examine potential jurors to find out whether they had read the offending stories, something which often happens in the United States but which was almost unknown in the English courts.

But he took a robust view of the dangers of prejudicing juries. "I have enough confidence in my fellow countrymen to think they have got the newspapers sized up, just as they have got other public institutions sized up, and they are capable, in normal circumstances, of looking at a matter fairly and without prejudice, even though they have to disregard what they may have read in a newspaper."

In 1990 three Irish defendants who were convicted of conspiring to murder the Northern Ireland secretary, Tom King, had their convictions quashed because of media statements during the trial by King and the former Master of the Rolls, Lord Denning. The charges against the three, who had exercised their right of silence and declined to give evidence, were about to go to the jury when King announced a government decision to abolish the right of silence. Lord Denning weighed in to say that exercising the right of silence in terrorist cases was tantamount to admitting guilt.

The outcome in that case inspired more defence counsel to argue, and judges to accept, that pre-trial publicity could endanger a fair trial. The Taylor sisters, Michelle and Lisa, had their convictions for murdering the wife of Michelle's former lover quashed in 1994 partly because they had been subjected to "trial by media," and partly because of irregularities during the trial.

In 1995, a judge threw out a prosecution against three alleged forgers exposed by the News of the World because the paper had printed details about the men's previous convictions, referred to them as "villains" and attributed a quote about drugs and children to one. Lawyers were astonished that the prosecution, which had been instigated by the paper's investigation, had been derailed by a single newspaper story published 10 months before.

Three months later a prosecution for assault against Geoffrey Knights, boyfriend of the EastEnders actress Gillian Taylforth, was thrown out after graphic accounts of the attack appeared in several tabloids.

But when the crime is as serious as murder, tabloid headlines weigh more lightly in the scales of justice. Judges have long maintained that the closed world of the courtroom, where everyone is focusing on the evidence put before them, together with the judge's warning to put everything else out of their minds, is enough to dispel any prejudice that might linger from months-old, barely remembered news stories.

The truth of this surmise was anybody's guess. The Contempt of Court Act 1981 bars English jurors from being questioned about the secrets of the jury room. Quizzing them about the factors that influenced their verdict is strictly forbidden.

But now research with real juries in New Zealand, where such questions can be asked, has provided the answer. The study, by Victoria University of Wellington in collaboration with the New Zealand Law Commission, the country's official law reform body, followed 48 criminal trials and interviewed 312 jurors. The research team chose all the high-profile cases, including murder, which came to trial during the study period - nine months in 1998 - because they wanted to find out whether pre-trial publicity affected jurors' ability to reach their verdict purely on the evidence in court.

"The research shows that the input of media publicity both before and during the trial is minimal," the report concluded. Only 19% of jurors remembered seeing or hearing any pre-trial publicity about the case - 58 out of 312. Of those who had, few could remember "anything beyond a hazy recollection of the bare essentials of the incident". Only 16 of the 312 jurors remembered any details which could have led to an element of bias, and only two of the 16 admitted that their knowledge had an initial impact on them. Jurors made a deliberate attempt to put aside any preconceptions. When confronted with evidence contradicting opinions they had formed as a result of pre-trial publicity, they cast their initial vote on the verdict, even before jury deliberations started, in line with the evidence rather than with their original opinion.

Jurors noted smugly that media reporting of the trials they were sitting on was less well-informed and accurate than their own knowledge. They put the coverage to one side because it was "partial and often inaccurate", and "regarded themselves as being much better informed than the media about what the real story was". It seems reasonable to assume that their scepticism would extend to what little they could remember reading about the case before the trial. And that the 12 new jurors who will have to decide Michael Stone's guilt or innocence will live up to their oath and "give a true verdict according to the evidence".

webTitle: Marcel Berlins on judges and their salaries

fields.headline: Marcel Berlins
fields.standfirst: You can't have our number one judge earning less than his number two. Or can you?
fields.trailText: In 1832, the salary of an English high court judge was reduced, from £5,500 to £5,000 - and it stayed at that figure for 122 years. Even when income tax was first introduced in 1842, which judges had to pay, no adjustment was made to compensate them for the loss in their real earnings. Not until 1954 did judges get their raise, since when they've not done too badly. From April 2001, following last week's senior salaries review body report, high court judges are to get £132,603 and law lords £157,699. The lord chief justice will trouser more than £171,000 and the lord chancellor exactly £2,500 more. It's always £2,500 more because there's a 1991 Act of Parliament which says so.
fields.body:
In 1832, the salary of an English high court judge was reduced, from £5,500 to £5,000 - and it stayed at that figure for 122 years. Even when income tax was first introduced in 1842, which judges had to pay, no adjustment was made to compensate them for the loss in their real earnings. Not until 1954 did judges get their raise, since when they've not done too badly. From April 2001, following last week's senior salaries review body report, high court judges are to get £132,603 and law lords £157,699. The lord chief justice will trouser more than £171,000 and the lord chancellor exactly £2,500 more. It's always £2,500 more because there's a 1991 Act of Parliament which says so.

The ostensible reason is simple. The lord chancellor is automatically the country's top judge, even though he spends very little of his time judging. Even so, the argument goes, you can't have the number one earning less than the number two. Moreover, of course, although the lord chancellor doesn't directly appoint the lord chief justice, he does have the biggest say and, it's said, you can't have him earning less than the chap he picks. Why not? Since when is that a point of principle? Was Lord Falconer's salary raised so that he could earn more than PY Gerbeau?

The judicial hierarchy point is equally unconvincing. The fact that the lord chancellor of the day automatically becomes numero uno judge (however little judicial experience he has) is a constitutional device based on history and tradition, not sense. As a result Lord Irvine is by far the best-paid member of the Cabinet and, unlike his colleagues, who aren't taking up their full entitlement, he is forced to grab the lot, so that he can keep his compulsory £ 2,500 lead over Lord Woolf.

Let me say right away that I don't for a moment think that anything untoward has occurred or was intended to occur. But I still feel uneasy about it. A number of senior barristers and solicitors known as Labour Party supporters have received letters from the party, asking for donations. Perfectly OK, except that these fundraising letters were signed by Derry Irvine, the lord chancellor. They were, I hasten to add, on party letterheads and not his own or his department's. But still, he's the one who appoints judges, and the people he's writing to are precisely at the level of seniority at which they might be applying for judicial posts. I repeat, I don't suspect anything, but what I can say is that two barristers who received such letters were embarrassed by them, and didn't think Lord Irvine ought to have been involved.

In the olden days, Kamlesh Bahl commenced a claim in the Watford employment tribunal, alleging unfair dismissal as well as sex and race discrimination. She, those with long memories will remember, was about to be the Law Society's first woman and first Asian president; until (according to her) she was hounded out of office. The case is finally limping to finality. I've been following it on the internet (www.aboutkamlesh.org) which has occasionally been tedious, but with a few highlights. One of the issues raised before the tribunal has been the difference in the treatment of Bahl compared to the kind way in which the Law Society dropped a previous vice-president - a white male who turned out to be an admitted multiple groper. The Bahl tribunal was told of his "putting his business card down the cleavage of a female journalist" even after he'd been warned about his behaviour. His excuse was that she'd said: "I have nowhere to put it but I can put it here." I particularly liked the Law Society's grand formula for dealing with his antics. He was politely asked to ensure "that his wife went with him on trips abroad".

You remember that famous photo of Christine Keeler sitting, apparently naked, her legs astride an Arne Jacobsen chair? It may soon become the focus of a seminal legal case. Publicity material for Joe Orton's Entertaining Mr Sloane has the actress Alison Steadman sitting cheekily in the same pose as Keeler, chair and all. This has not pleased the original photographer, Lewis Morley, who has threatened the theatre company with legal proceedings, alleging - here's the new, exciting bit - breach of copyright. Question - can there be copyright over a pose, a photographic arrangement? It raises wonderful litigation possibilities.

Thank you for noticing, and yes, this column - shorn of its Writ Large title - and the Law pages will in future appear on Tuesdays.

Moreover, of course, although the lord chancellor doesn't directly appoint the lord chief justice, he does have the biggest say and, it's said, you can't have him earning less than the chap he picks. Why not? Since when is that a point of principle? Was Lord Falconer's salary raised so that he could earn more than PY Gerbeau? The judicial hierarchy point is equally unconvincing. The fact that the lord chancellor of the day automatically becomes numero uno judge (however little judicial experience he has) is a constitutional device based on history and tradition, not sense. As a result Lord Irvine is by far the best-paid member of the Cabinet and, unlike his colleagues, who aren't taking up their full entitlement, he is forced to grab the lot, so that he can keep his compulsory £ 2,500 lead over Lord Woolf. Let me say right away that I don't for a moment think that anything untoward has occurred or was intended to occur. But I still feel uneasy about it. A number of senior barristers and solicitors known as Labour Party supporters have received letters from the party, asking for donations. Perfectly OK, except that these fundraising letters were signed by Derry Irvine, the lord chancellor. They were, I hasten to add, on party letterheads and not his own or his department's. But still, he's the one who appoints judges, and the people he's writing to are precisely at the level of seniority at which they might be applying for judicial posts. I repeat, I don't suspect anything, but what I can say is that two barristers who received such letters were embarrassed by them, and didn't think Lord Irvine ought to have been involved. In the olden days, Kamlesh Bahl commenced a claim in the Watford employment tribunal, alleging unfair dismissal as well as sex and race discrimination. She, those with long memories will remember, was about to be the Law Society's first woman and first Asian president; until (according to her) she was hounded out of office. The case is finally limping to finality. I've been following it on the internet (www.aboutkamlesh.org) which has occasionally been tedious, but with a few highlights. One of the issues raised before the tribunal has been the difference in the treatment of Bahl compared to the kind way in which the Law Society dropped a previous vice-president - a white male who turned out to be an admitted multiple groper. The Bahl tribunal was told of his "putting his business card down the cleavage of a female journalist" even after he'd been warned about his behaviour. His excuse was that she'd said: "I have nowhere to put it but I can put it here." I particularly liked the Law Society's grand formula for dealing with his antics. He was politely asked to ensure "that his wife went with him on trips abroad". You remember that famous photo of Christine Keeler sitting, apparently naked, her legs astride an Arne Jacobsen chair? It may soon become the focus of a seminal legal case. Publicity material for Joe Orton's Entertaining Mr Sloane has the actress Alison Steadman sitting cheekily in the same pose as Keeler, chair and all. This has not pleased the original photographer, Lewis Morley, who has threatened the theatre company with legal proceedings, alleging - here's the new, exciting bit - breach of copyright. Question - can there be copyright over a pose, a photographic arrangement? It raises wonderful litigation possibilities. Thank you for noticing, and yes, this column - shorn of its Writ Large title - and the Law pages will in future appear on Tuesdays.

webTitle: Sidelines

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Comedy misogyny | Women with short arms
fields.body:
It might be the weather, or the wine, or the hundreds of branches of Mango and Kookai. Or it might be the widespread access to decent, affordable childcare. Whatever it is, it works, because (as readers will doubtless have spotted) Sidelines is a committed Europhile. We can't help but long for that air of discreet sophistication and cultured je ne sais quoi slung so casually over one shoulder by our continental cousins. But, oh dear, they do let themselves down sometimes, don't they? To Italy for the latest example of comedy misogyny, where a judge has just ruled that a wife who didn't dust her house enough was in violation of her marital duties. Granting her husband a divorce, he concluded that Maria Cristina V's messy home "confirmed a total lack of interest in the rules of civil life". Which should be a lesson to anyone who failed to rinse out their cereal bowl this morning, entirely mindless of the threat this poses to the nation's moral fabric. And yet, curiously, Maria's husband Vincenzio's contribution to the household chores was not mentioned at all. Plus ça change (as we continentals like to say).

Happily, one group of women have found themselves with plenty of time on their hands to stay home and do the washing-up. The RAF, it transpired this week, has rejected every woman who applied to fly its new Eurofighter jets "because their arms were too short". Of course, this should not be seen as sexist, the RAF insists, because the seats also discriminate against small men. "It is a fact of life that men and women are different shapes," said a defensive spokesman. "Women have a slightly smaller frame." As observations go, it's not exactly rocket science. Which makes it all the more surprising that they didn't manage to think of it earlier. And rather tiresome that these things continue to be built only with strapping men in mind.

Esther Addley

webTitle: Tim Parks follows his team - Verona - to Catania

fields.headline: Feast of insults
fields.standfirst: 'It's madness, but I've promised myself I'll see every away game Verona play.' In the first of a regular column,  Tim Parks follows his team to Catania - and it's not just the match that kicks off
fields.trailText: 'It's madness, but I've promised myself I'll see every away game Verona play.' In the first of a regular column, Tim Parks follows his team to Catania - and it's not just the match that kicks off.
fields.body:
Is Italy a single nation, or a series of warring city states? Two weeks ago, on the train from Verona to Turin, a young man stares through the glass of my compartment, then comes in, and says: "Can I see your book?" It's called A History of Football in Verona. He takes it in his hands with reverent awe. Yes, he too is bound for Turin. He too is going to watch Juventus play Verona. He's one of countless thousands of Italians who travel the length and breadth of their country every weekend to see their teams play away. Always a soccer nut, this year I've chosen to join them. It's madness but I've promised myself I'll see every away game Verona play. "What do you enjoy most about it?" I ask this guy. He grins sheepishly. He seems the tamest person in the world. "The anger," he says.

"Gobbi di merda ," the Veronese shout at the Juventini. Shithead hunchbacks. "Verona Verona Vaffunculo! " Comes the response. Verona fuck off. It's a feast of insults.

And sometimes it gets out of hand. On that very same afternoon, in fact, way down in Reggio Calabria, some supporters had such a festival of anger when their team lost the seventh game in succession, that they invaded the pitch and tore up their own stadium. As a result they are condemned to playing their next home game in a neutral city: Catania, Sicily.

And that game is against Verona.

I've never been to Catania. It's about 900 miles south of Verona. Some of the Veronese supporters have hired a bus. I have a chance to take the last place available. Just £42. But I can't face a whole weekend on the road in the beat-up kind of vehicle people are willing to rent to soccer fans. The plane costs £285, £180 if you stay overnight (go figure European price fixing). This is completely crazy, I tell myself, as I climb aboard. It's stupid. £180 plus hotel, just for a soccer match, dammit.

I was right. Just for the match it was mad. But Catania was worth every last Lira.

Verona lies just beneath the Alps in the north. It has been raining for months here, and today is no exception. But as the plane crosses the Apennines, the weather clears. Strands of mist shine like fresh snow on the hills, then the sea is liquid copper under the morning sun. You fly right over the Eolie islands and then, dropping down, quite suddenly there is Etna, a picture-book volcano, its high crater topped with Christmas icing. Beyond, at the bottom of the mountain's long green slopes of vines and lemon trees, right on the dazzle of the coast, is Catania.

Italians will always insist on the differences between north and south. How could they insult each other if there were none? And up to a point they're right. When I ask for a granita in Catania, I don't get the crushed ice of the Veronese version, but a sort of liquid almond ice-cream, more an Arab sherbet. And the croissants here are always served hot. There's a difference. Then there's more noise in the street than in Verona and the traffic is constantly on the verge of total deadlock. Whereas Verona, through its foggy winters, has warm ochre walls and pink marble pavements, Catania under its blistering summer sun is lava gray, a monumental mix of volcanic rock and white limestone.

Yet overall what strikes you most is that these are all variations within the same Italian mindframe. There's the same glorious conglomeration of piazzas, statues and stunning facades (mainly baroque and 18th century in Catania, since everything earlier was destroyed in the earthquake of 1693). There's the same love of the passeggiata, the same Christmas markets full of candied fruit and cheap toys.

I take a bus east to check out the fishing village of Aci Trezza, where Giovanni Verga set his great novel I Malavoglia. Stone angels on the church facade blow their judgment-day trumpets right in the noses of the painted boats pulled up in the port. The place is so beautiful, it's hard to see how Verga could have been such a pessimist. But then the distant sight of the old Norman castle high on a rocky outcrop between the village and the town suddenly makes me nervous. The Normans in Sicily! There was an away game and no mistake. Time to get to the stadium.

The place is full. I'm amazed. Perhaps 40 busloads of fans have come from Reggio Calabria, across on the mainland, plus there are all the local Catania enthusiasists who never get a chance to watch top-level soccer. Surrounded by police in riot gear, about 100 of us have made it from Verona.

The insults begin. Non si capisce come cazzo parlate , the Veronese sing to the tune of Guantanamera: "Can't understand a fucking word you say!" Meaning, you're not Italian like us, we speak different dialects and ours is the real one. But in perfectly understandable Italian the Sicilians and Calabrians at once start to chant: Merda siete e merda resterete . "Shit you are and shit you'll stay."

Italy is a nation that defines itself by being constantly divided against itself, that is the game they play, the way some families are immediately recognisable as families precisely because they are always fighting with each other. As a foreigner, you can never quite be part of this. But you can get no end of pleasure from watching the fireworks go off in such magical surroundings.

As if to underline the similarity between these opposites, north and south, and to point up the mirror effect you get when two groups of fans start insulting each other, Verona scored just one minute from the beginning and Reggio Calabria equalized 88 minutes later just one minute from the end. So the fans set off home all equally happy and unhappy, equally disgruntled and relieved, equally Italian.

webTitle: Return of the riot grrrls. Sophie Foster on the Ladyfest movement.

fields.headline: Return of the riot grrrls
fields.standfirst: Thought their mouthy mix of music and feminism was silenced back in the 90s? Don't you believe it.  Sophie Foster reports
fields.trailText: Thought their mouthy mix of music and feminism was silenced back in the 90s? Don't you believe it.  Sophie Foster reports.
fields.body:
A phenomenon may be brewing. From Glasgow to Chicago, Boston to Bloomington, Indiana, women are getting together to organise arts events in the name Ladyfest. They are open to all but the ethos - "by women, for women" - is decidedly feminist. The programme ranges from fashion shows to debates on fat oppression to car mechanics workshops, but the main draw is music - and it couldn't be further from the manufactured, fame-seeking pop of the Britneys of this world.

Ladyfest takes its name and inspiration from a festival held in Olympia, Washington, in August last year, but its ideas were informed by a much earlier movement, riot grrrl. Remembered as a rough-and-tumble music scene populated by teenagers in secondhand dresses and Hello Kitty hairclips, riot grrrl was an exuberant underground movement of mouthy, anarchic women's bands, such as America's Bikini Kill and Brighton's Huggy Bear, which enjoyed a brief moment in the spotlight in the early 90s before melting away.

Like the original Ladyfest, riot grrrl took shape in Olympia, a sleepy-seeming hippy town with a history of political activism. It was the summer of 1991, and Naomi Wolf had just published The Beauty Myth, when a few women at the local university got together to talk about music and feminism. Their aim was to carve a space for women in a rock world that still saw them as groupies rather than musicians; their call was for "revolution girl-style now" and in tackling inequality, they planned to attack other issues: abuse, rape, eating disorders.

The further it travelled, the more riot grrrl took on a life of its own. In October 1992, music magazine Melody Maker published the first British story about the movement, but its network of meetings and fanzines was still largely undergroundand its musicians were reluctant to be seen as spokespeople spouting a manifesto that didn't exist. As a result, riot grrrl retreated back underground - only to see its ideas resurface a few years later, with "Girl power" slogans scrawled on stationery in Miss Selfridge and claimed by the Spice Girls as their own.

To many, riot grrrl's achievements appear to be few. The stereotypes it fought against remain intact: the music industry expects white women to sing anodyne pop and black women to be R&B divas. Women who play rock struggle to find an audience; women who play electronic music are practically ignored. But there is a wider picture. Riot grrrl helped to break down barriers in the industry, legitimising women's desire for their own space to perform - the development of the hugely popular Lilith Fair women's festival is no coincidence. Riot grrrl encouraged women to use music to address issues rather than expand egos and so heralded a new era of feminist pop. Most of all, it created a new language, informal and energetic, for feminist discourse, one that found a home in mainstream culture.

As an exuberant brand of feminism, riot grrrl continues to inspire. The programme for the first Ladyfest instructed: "Go home and plan one in your own town" and that's what one group of Glaswegian women has done. "We hated to think Ladyfest would become just a memory," says Lee Beattie, one of Ladyfest Scotland's organisers. "We wanted to see the event in the context of our own community, fitting the experiences of women here. The most important thing about Ladyfest is what people take away from it."

 Ladyfest Scotland details at www.ladyfest.co.uk.

webTitle: ANC minister in race row

fields.headline: ANC minister in race row
fields.trailText: South Africa's security minister has provoked a new race row by accusing Portuguese-speaking whites of trying to resurrect apartheid domination and of coming to the country "to join the master race".
fields.body:
South Africa's security minister has provoked a new race row by accusing Portuguese-speaking whites of trying to resurrect apartheid domination and of coming to the country "to join the master race".

Steve Tshwete made the charges in a letter to a leader of the Portuguese community after an anti-crime march organised by the community in Pretoria. About 12,000 people of all races joined the protest, at the end of which a strongly worded - some said racist - memorandum was handed to President Thabo Mbeki's office.

The memo protested at high crime levels and accused government officials of being "callous and arrogant, corrupt, ineffectual and unaccountable".

The Portuguese government was deciding how to respond yesterday as its citizens in South Africa demanded that their ambassador be recalled in protest at last week's letter by Mr Tshwete. The exact number of white Portuguese speakers and passport holders in the country is unclear, but thousands arrived after fleeing Angola and Mozambique after independence, 26 years ago.

"There is no doubt that the African dream, or renaissance, has become a lifetime nightmare for many of our people, as the criminals continue to impose their brand of injustice on all levels of society," the memorandum to Mr Mbeki said. "We call upon the government to switch allegiance from the self-destructive anarchies of Zimbabwe and the Democratic Republic of Congo to focus all efforts on saving the lives of South Africans!"

In a letter to Manny Ferreira, chairman of the "crime awareness campaign", Mr Tshwete said the memo showed the Portuguese community's contempt for the president, and that the protest was an "anti-government action" to undermine the African National Congress before local elections.

He accused resident Portuguese of racism, saying they protested at crime now, but never organised resistance to apartheid, which claimed "tens of thousands" of lives.

The Portuguese came to South Africa, he said, only because they could not accept the liberation of Angola and Mozambique.

"These came here because they knew the colour of their skin would entitle them to join the 'master race', to participate in the oppression and exploitation of the black majority and enjoy the benefits of white minority domination," Mr Tshwete said.

"It is perhaps because you have not outgrown these white supremacist ideas and practices that you wrote your memorandum." The minister then warned that the Portuguese views would be made known to "the masses".

Opposition parties yesterday accused Mr Tshwete of invoking the spectre of racism to distract attention from his failure to reduce the number of murders and robberies. The government claims to have cut crime, but no statistics are available because it refuses to release figures, saying they are "unreliable".

The leader of the protest march staged three months ago, Father Carlos Gabriel, described the minister's letter as "unacceptable". He said he would request an urgent meeting with Mr Tshwete.

"It is completely unfair to target the Portuguese. The minister is apparently unaware that members of other communities, including black people, joined the march," Fr Gabriel said.

Words that caused a storm:

"Some among the Portuguese community came to this country because they did not accept that the Mozambican and Angolan people should gain their freedom. These came because they knew the colour of their skin would entitle them to join the 'master race', to participate in the oppression and exploitation of the black majority. It is perhaps because you have not outgrown these white supremacist ideas and practices that you wrote your memorandum.

"You are aware that our government was elected by an overwhelming majority. These masses do not share the contempt you have for our government and president ... These masses need to know about your view of their government."

webTitle: William Hague is sexier than Tony Blair, finds a new survey of young women. Good news says his lookalike Toby Young.

fields.headline: Hey, good looking
fields.standfirst: William Hague  is sexier than Tony Blair, finds a new survey of young women. Good news says  his lookalike Toby Young
fields.trailText: William Hague  is sexier than Tony Blair, finds a new survey of young women. Good news says  his lookalike Toby Young.
fields.body:
People have always told me I look like William Hague, but I didn't realise quite how much I did until last month when I did an impression of him at a Spectator party to celebrate the launch of the magazine's website, which I'm in charge of. I leapt up on the editor's desk and, doing my best to sound like the bluff Yorkshireman, said I'd like to thank the magazine's staff for their unstinting support during these difficult times: "I know The Spectator is the home of lost causes, but this really is beyond the call of duty."

Looking around, I was astonished to discover that no one was laughing. On the contrary, the staff were receiving me with the customary half-smiles and diffident air they reserve for visiting dignitaries. Was my impersonation of the Conservative leader that feeble? Then the penny dropped. In fact, the impression was so good - and my physical resemblance to him so uncanny - they'd mistaken me for the man himself. Good God, I thought. Perhaps it's time for a visit to the plastic surgeon.

Fortunately, that may not be necessary. According to an internet survey carried out by the Virgin Group last week, students between the ages of 19 and 25 think Hague is hot stuff, at least compared to Tony Blair. Of the 1,650 students polled, 61% said they thought the leader of the opposition had more sex appeal than the Prime Minister. "I haven't really paid much attention to their policies but Hague is better looking," commented Sarah Scholes, a 19-year-old student at Bradford University. "He's quite cute in a babyfaced sort of way."

Until I saw this survey, I'd always thought of my resemblance to the leader of the opposition as a curse. For instance, whenever he appears on television, my fiancé starts fanning herself with her hand, pretending she's all hot and bothered, knowing full well he's never exactly been considered a sex symbol (not until now, anyway). The low point came when I met Gordon Brown at his brother-in-law's wedding last year and he did a kind of exaggerated double-take. "I could use a man like you in the next general election campaign," he chuckled. Would I be prepared to tour marginal constituencies spouting right-wing gobbledygook? He thought it would be very funny.

I have to confess, I'm occasionally tempted to spend a day impersonating the Conservative leader. I could swan past the policemen outside the House of Commons then point to the real William Hague and demand that the impostor be thrown out. I could then take up his position on the opposition front bench and announce that the Conservative party has decided to legalise cannabis and lower the homosexual age of consent to 12. I could turn up at Buckingham Palace and demand an audience with the Queen. I could tip off the News of the World, then go to Stringfellows and hire a coven of lapdancers to entertain me for the night. I can just see the headline now: "Willy Exposed In Vice Den!"

Now that I know that some people find the leader of the opposition attractive, perhaps I'll put my wedding on hold. During the election campaign, I imagine there will be quite a few blue-rinse, home-counties matrons eager to help their leader in any way they can. I'm told there is even a brothel in Las Vegas where people will pay good money to sleep with celebrity look-a-likes. If my career in journalism doesn't work out that strikes me as a pretty attractive alternative and, let's be honest, not all that different.

Less attractive, though by no means out of the question, is the work I could get as a strip-o-gram. Perhaps I could do a double-act with the official Margaret Thatcher look-a-like, though I don't suppose it would be very erotic. Nevertheless, it might become something of a cult act in young socialist circles, if they still exist. I believe the producers of porno movies are always looking for celebrity lookalikes to star in them, the more dignified and respectable the celebrity, the better. I'd like these people to know that, at the right price, I'm available for work.

In short, I could easily earn a living from impersonating William Hague, maybe earn good money. I might even be able to pick up some advertising work-endorsing Hague whisky, for instance. Still, I'm a little bit wary of making a career out of it because he may not be in the public eye much longer.

With any luck I'll bump into him before he retires to Brussels to become a Euro commissioner. I imagine the experience of meeting his doppelganger will be a lot more disturbing for Hague than for me. After all, I already know of his existence but I don't suppose he knows of mine. If I ever do see him at a party, my plan is to go up to him and say, "Don't make this hard on yourself Mr Hague. You're being replaced. On the planet I come from, death by vaporisation is considered a luxury."

webTitle: Country Diary from Cheshire

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Foul-weather friends
fields.trailText: Cheshire
fields.body:
Cheshire

A blackcap in the back garden has been enjoying our hospitality now for seven weeks. It arrived between Christmas and New Year in time to finish off the remains of the Christmas cake, since when it has settled down to a steady diet of crushed peanuts and hot cross buns, with the occasional visit to the pyracantha on the garden trellis to sample the abundant supply of red berries.

It is probably one of the small number of blackcaps from the continent that stop off in the UK during migration in October and stay to overwinter here rather than follow their colleagues to the warmer areas of the Mediterranean or even further south in Africa. In Cheshire some 40 to 50 are being noted in the winter months. Our bird is a male with a jaunty, glossy black cap cut off sharply just above the eye, who has taken total control of the feeding table, although he does tend to back away from the sharp-billed starlings. Blue tits, coal tits, robins and wrens are driven away quite ruthlessly, but fortunately he doesn't trouble them on the nearby hanging nut baskets.

Another beneficiary of the free meals on offer in the village is the fox, who can quickly pick up the scent of a discarded chicken dinner, and the contents of many a poorly secured plastic bin liner have ended up strewn over a garden path. At the moment the fox is looking its best, in a thick red-brown, winter coat, and last week I came eye to eye with a splendid male in the northern woods. Its big bushy tail had the largest white tip I have ever seen on a fox, and at regular intervals it would utter three soft barks - a contact call to the vixen, who could well be close to giving birth to this year's cubs.

webTitle: Satellite, cabel and digital pick of the day

fields.headline: Satellite, cabel and digital pick of the day
fields.trailText: The Freshman | The Spanish Prisoner | Champions' League Football
fields.body:
Films

The Freshman (Andrew Bergman, 1990) 8.35am, 4pm, Sky Cinema
Bergman's accomplished Godfather spoof has Matthew Broderick as a naive film student who is busy analysing Coppola's mafia movies when he is introduced to the genuine article: New York mobster Carmine Sabatini, the very image of Don Vito Corleone (as he should be, since he's played by Marlon Brando). Soon Carmine is treating the lad like family, and his life is just like in the movies. Witty, well acted, and Brando's self-mockery is hilarious.

The Spanish Prisoner (David Mamet, 1998) 12.40pm, 5.55pm, Sky Premier
Mamet is back in House Of Games mode, and he's built a veritable tower block of con-trickery this time. Campbell Scott's Joe Ross is the whiz behind The Process - a top secret wotsit with a hefty commercial value - and is drawn into an odd relationship with wealthy, enigmatic Jimmy Dell (Steve Martin) after an altercation over a camera in the Caribbean. Scott, as the dupe of a highly intricate scam, is too anodyne to be sympathetic, but it's a vastly entertaining intellectual exercise.

The Portrait Of A Lady (Jane Campion, 1996) 8pm, FilmFour
Intelligent and beautifully photographed version of Henry James's "unfilmable" novel about a rich and innocent young American woman adrift in corrupt old Europe. Nicole Kidman (pictured) is the spirited heroine, Isabel Archer, who is brought low by the cold calculations of Madame Merle (Barbara Hershey, forsaking her sweet and saintly image) and the mean-hearted Gilbert Osmond (John Malkovich), in a union straight out of Dangerous Liaisons.

Light Sleeper (Paul Schrader, 1991) 9pm, Studio
Schrader's druggy tale tiptoes between serious drama and thriller modes, finally opting for the latter - guns are easier. Willem Dafoe plays a New York drug dealer who is turning 40 and contemplating a new start with girlfriend Dana Delaney because his boss (Susan Sarandon) is turning to herbal remedies. There's a murder, and pistols are predictably drawn, but it's well handled, with fine performances.

The Mummy (Stephen Sommers, 1999) 10pm, Sky Premier
Indiana Jones meets the Evil Dead in this boisterous remake of the classic horror, with gruesome make-up and extra-special effects allowing a monstrous Arnold Vosloo to lumber about in the title role. Brendan Fraser is the gung-ho soldier of fortune providing the muscle for a 1920s expedition to Egypt. Rachel Weisz is the obligatory brainy beauty leading the show. Formulaic, but highly entertaining. Paul Howlett

Sports

Champions' League Football 7.30pm ONsport 1; 7pm ONsport 2;
If you see anyone strolling around town today with a noticeably smug grin, chances are they're OnDigital subscribers. It's not often that they boast anything that rival platforms don't, but this evening there are two top games that simply can't be seen anywhere else (except the pub). Leeds play Anderlecht on ONsport 2 while, from 7.30pm, ONsport1 carries coverage of Arsenal's visit to Lyon. Simon Burnton

webTitle: TV review

fields.headline: The icewoman cometh
fields.trailText: Silent Witness | Tribe
fields.body:
As plot devices go, avalanches are up there at the premium end of the scale, after floods and hailstorms but before earthquakes, volcanic eruptions and plagues of locusts. When an avalanche is called upon, it's a safe bet things will go downhill from there. Often, at high speed.

So Silent Witness (BBC1) started with an avalanche caused, the man in the snowflake jumper said, by a couple of snowboarders. Personally, I think it was triggered by the woman who wails her way through the aria-esque Silent Witness theme tune (which I imagine to be entitled Here Comes Laughing Sam Ryan).

Whatever, the Norwegian Search and Rescue turned up (helpfully wearing little fluorescent waistcoats with "Norwegian Search and Rescue" written on the back - in English) and dug out the snowboarders and the naked body of an English girl. Cue Laughing Sam, who half-shut her eyes and stared at the body. There was no doubt about it - the girl was dead.

It transpired that the snowflake jumper man was Jan (which is Norwegian for "Ugly Knitwear"). As preposterous as it might seem, he was a friend of Sam's, and between them they discovered the dead girl had been entombed in the snow for some 15 years, though not before telling the parents of another girl it was their missing daughter. Oops. Still, it wasn't oops for long since they then found the body of that girl too. (In their defence, it was an easy mistake to make, since both girls looked like Jo from S Club 7. Until they were defrosted. Then they looked like Baroness Young.)

Thus, Laughing Sam was dragged into the middle of the investigation being carried out by the jowly and truculent police officer and his oddly mute assistant. Now, you might not think "jowly and truculent" qualify as defining characteristics in a drama, but here they did. As did "floppy-haired holiday rep" and "potato-headed gamekeeper". In fact, the sketchy shorthand writing that passes for character description in Silent Witness was only surpassed by the clunky-as-a-bag-of-spanners dialogue.

Of course none of this is new, as it is years since any Silent Witness actually had a decent, involving and complex script. As long as they can wheel in a slew of guest stars (this time, the librarian from Buffy the Vampire Slayer), have a couple of post-mortem scenes in which Sam lifts an unidentified organ onto some scales, and have Amanda Burton looking pensive, the producers don't feel the need to bother with anything resembling good writing. All of that was fine before the novelty wore off, but now Silent Witness is as cold and mechanical as Laughing Sam's circular rib saw.

And in the first half of this story, Sam did even less than she normally does - which usually extends to being as expressive as a roll of lino - and instead consulted a profiler, who seemed to do most of the work for her. This Professor Michaels (graduated from Angels, no less) seemed more interesting than Sam did and much more deserving of her own series. Not only did she smile more, you couldn't see her bra through her jumper.

A banging theme tune and psychedelic graphics? Could Tribe (BBC2) be a yoof programme? It surely could - and a rather good one at that. Essentially the latest mutation in video diaries, Tribe followed Londoner Laura who was "in the garage industry", and a group of rough boys in Wales who had nothing to do all day but fight (and get their girlfriends pregnant).

While the tale of Dom, Darryl and Spuddy, who lived on an estate where washing got stolen from the line and three-legged dogs hobbled the street, was depressing and distressing, Laura's meander through her life was oddly uplifting. If only because the girl seemed completely bonkers.

Laura's part in the garage industry seemed to consist of flyering unsuspecting passers-by on chilly London nights, taking abuse from her boss who thought herself too cool by half, and going raving with her mate, Sunshine. Laura loved the Heartless Crew, who despite their names - Mighty Mo, Fonty and Bushkin - weren't actually cartoon characters. She adored their lyrics, which were "intelligent". Talking straight to camera as if she was born to do it, Laura marvelled at such lyrical wit as, "You can shine on my penis/I mean this/I'm not joking."

Eminem, eat your heart out.

webTitle: Little girl in a great big boat. Sally Weale on Ellen MacArthur's success and how it was reported.

fields.headline: Brave little girl in a great big boat
fields.standfirst: Sally Weale gives three cheers for Ellen MacArthur - and a boo and a hiss at the way her success has been reported
fields.trailText: Sally Weale gives three cheers for Ellen MacArthur - and a boo and a hiss at the way her success has been reported.
fields.body:
A couple of weeks ago, most of us had never heard of Ellen MacArthur. Yesterday you would have had to be stranded on a capsized boat in the middle of an ocean, without any ship-to-shore communication, to remain unaware of her. She was on the front page of every newspaper, topped every morning news bulletin and across the country her success spread an unexpected feeling of national pride and celebration, not experienced since Steve Redgrave won his fifth gold at Sydney.

So what had she done? After 94 days, four hours and 25 minutes at sea, 24-year-old MacArthur had crossed the finishing line of the Vendée Globe round-the-world yacht race. She became the fastest woman and youngest person to circumnavigate the globe in a singlehanded sailing race. The fact that she came second to Frenchman Michel Desjoyeaux did not matter.

And we now know - thanks to page upon page of analysis - that it was indeed a truly remarkable achievement. The Vendée is the toughest race in the sailing world; others have died trying to complete the 26,000-mile course around Antarctica and the physical demands placed upon competitors are almost unsurpassed.

MacArthur has been on her own for the past three months, skippering a yacht that would usually require an 11-strong crew. She has changed sails twice her weight a dozen times a day; she has scaled the 90ft mast to carry out repairs in 40-knot winds; she has lived off dehydrated food and 10-minute catnaps; she has dodged icebergs, defied the elements and stared death in the face more than once.

An extraordinary adventure story, but what has made it all the more interesting for the media is the fact that the hero is a woman. Sorry . . . let's get that right. It is all the more interesting because our "diminutive heroine" is but a "slip of a girl".

MacArthur is 5ft 2in, she weighs seven, eight or nine stone, depending on which paper you read, and to keep her spirits up along the way, the Daily Mail tells us, she has flapjacks baked by her mum, her gran's Christmas cake and some BBC tapes of Winnie the Pooh. And when she finally limps back to civilisation, her mum and dad are flown out in a helicopter 120 miles from the finishing line to greet their only daughter amid emotional family scenes. Isn't he proud, her father is asked. Yes, terribly proud.

Now, would that really happen if Ellen were Ed? Don't get me wrong. MacArthur has just completed the most extraordinary feat. I, like the rest of the world, am in awe. I have only admiration for her.

What is galling, however, is the media presentation of our brave little Ellen. Most of the press reports (including that in the FT) refer to her by her first name, rather than her surname, as if she were a child. Women sports stars are often subtly reduced in this way - think of tennis commentators chatting matily about "Martina" or "Steffi", in a way they never would about "Andre". In many papers, 24-year-old MacArthur is referred to as a "girl"; the coverage, centring on her proud parents, has almost without exception failed to mention that she has a long-term partner who also met her off the dock. Instead, much is made of her tears and, curiously, her "spirituality".

Yesterday's London Evening Standard reported that the "round-the-world yacht girl . . . broke into tears when she spoke of her work with gravely ill children" as if she were a contestant in a beauty pageant. And sure enough, MacArthur's appearance does not go unreported. Though the "elfin faced" yachtswoman, George Walden notes in the same paper, "is not pretty in any conventional sense . . . she joins that swelling proportion of womanhood who are outstanding for reasons that have nothing to do with their looks or their sex." He adds: "She is the very opposite of the caricature we hear so much about in jokes about women pilots and surgeons, whose judgment at vital moments is so easily thrown by external factors."

What makes this comment more insulting is the fact that the sailing community has recognised MacArthur as nothing less than the best ocean-going sailor Britain has ever produced. She was judged Young Sailor of the Year in 1995 and Yachtsman of the Year three years later. She may be Britain's pre-eminent sporting figure, male or female, in any discipline. Yet she is portrayed as a plucky little outsider.

If anything, it's worse in France, MacArthur's adopted home. There the press have nicknamed her "la Jeanne d'Arc anglaise". Le Figaro chose the headline "MacArthur, Little Fairy of the Oceans".

Meanwhile the Sunday Times reported that the French "were amazed that this 'petit bout de chou', this sweet little thing, had the guts and determination to endure the most gruelling of yacht races. webTitle: Radio pick of the day

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Hitler's Buddha | File On 4 | Jacques Loussier - Swinging The Classics
fields.body:
In 1937 John Rabe ran the Siemens branch in Nanking, then the capital of China. After 30 years' exile, however, his continuing ties with his homeland led him to join the Nazi Party. As Hitler's invading Japanese allies assaulted Nanking, Rabe accepted their assurances about the safety of its 1.3 million inhabitants. When, in fact, the Japanese ran amok, Rabe used his Nazi credentials to save hundreds of Chinese. RJ Gallagher has dramatised his diary as the Afternoon Play, Hitler's Buddha (2.15pm, Radio 4).

If Parliament accepts the latest Home Office proposals, we could be facing one of the most draconian changes in our property laws since the Middle Ages. Jenny Cuffe reports for File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4) on how the fight against organised crime is being extended to allow criminals' cash and property to be confiscated by the government. But the draft legislation also covers assets "intended for use in criminal conduct", even where there has been no conviction. It seems an extraordinarily catch-all proposal.

It's 40 years since a large chunk of the musical establishment was outraged by the sound of Bach being reworked by jazz musicians. A new six-part series, Jacques Loussier - Swinging The Classics (10.0pm, Radio 2), shows how much the habit has become part of the musical mainstream. Loussier's adaptations have gone on to cover Vivaldi, Ravel, Satie and Debussy.

webTitle: Loyalist leader admits bomb factory probably belongs to UVF

fields.headline: Loyalist leader admits bomb factory probably belongs to UVF
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: There was increased confusion yesterday over the activities of Protestant paramilitary groups supposedly on ceasefire after a loyalist politician admitted a substantial bomb factory uncovered by police in north Belfast probably belonged to the Ulster Volunteer Force.
fields.body:
There was increased confusion yesterday over the activities of Protestant paramilitary groups supposedly on ceasefire after a loyalist politician admitted a substantial bomb factory uncovered by police in north Belfast probably belonged to the Ulster Volunteer Force.

Detectives recovered a fire extinguisher packed with 45lb of explosives and primed for use, parts for 11 pipe bombs, an under-car booby trap and a coffee jar bomb, plus another 20lb of homemade explosives in a flat in Mount Vernon.

A Stormont assemblyman, David Ervine, whose Progressive Unionist Party is linked to the UVF, said he had "no doubt" the find was connected to that group, but denied that it was behind any of more than 50 pipe bomb attacks on Catholic families across Northern Ireland since the beginning of the year, which police are blaming on elements of the rival Ulster Defence Association.

He said an internal UVF investigation was underway but added: "What I can say, against the hype and backdrop that has been created by this spate of sectarian pipe bombings, I am assured there was no intention to use them for that purpose."

Instead, he said that the bomb factory might have been there for some time, indicating a possible connection with the recent UDA/UVF feud, which claimed the lives of seven Belfast men before a truce was declared before Christmas.

The RUC assistant chief constable, Alan McQuillan, said his officers had succeeded in cutting off a significant source of terrorist supply.

Two more Catholic families in Broughshane, near Ballymena, Co Antrim, had lucky escapes when pipe bombs were hurled at their homes on Sunday night. Two bundles of fireworks with nails wrapped round them were thrown over the peace line from nationalist north Belfast early yesterday, but failed to explode.

The RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, has blamed the growing sectarian violence on some members of the UDA, who are becoming increasingly disillusioned with the Good Friday agreement.

The UDA is divided into six semi-autonomous brigades province-wide and security sources said it would be difficult for operations to be carried out in areas without the leadership's knowledge. But as yet, it seems there is no evidence to prove the attacks against Catholics were sanctioned from the top.

Possible involvement by UVF members would be a complicating factor, suggesting a more coordinated campaign which could undermine the loyalist ceasefire, destabilising the peace process.

webTitle: Henri Cartier-Bresson is outraged by a collection of 'snapshots' of himself. Jonathan Jones reports

fields.headline: Camera shy
fields.standfirst: Henri Cartier-Bresson is outraged by a collection of 'snapshots' of himself. Jonathan Jones reports
fields.trailText: Henri Cartier-Bresson is outraged by a collection of 'snapshots' of himself. Jonathan Jones reports.
fields.body:
There is something poignant about the reluctance of the great 92-year-old photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson to have his picture circulated. Cartier-Bresson has objected to a book of photographs of him by the American David Douglas Duncan, entitled Faceless. They are mediocre, "snapshots" rather than true portraits, he protests. But it can't be just the quality of the pictures that has upset him. Duncan too is a famous photographer, whose images of the Korean war are classics. He was able to photograph Cartier-Bresson casually, over drinks at the Musée Picasso in Paris, because Cartier-Bres son was on assignment to photograph him. The fact is, the world's most revered photographer hates having his picture taken.

He's not alone. Who doesn't have a fear of the camera's power to tell us what we are? From posing for our first school photo, we learn the oppressiveness of the camera, its power to define us. Think of poor Marilyn Monroe, going through the contact sheets of her photo sessions, crossing out shots she didn't like. Artists, who understand the authority of visual experience, are not less but more mystical about the power of the image.

Cartier-Bresson at least allows some images of himself to circulate. Stanley Kubrick, who began as a photojournalist, be came such a stranger to snappers that an impersonator was able to pass himself off as the director despite looking nothing like him. And who can say what part was played in the disintegration of Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman's marriage by their decision to play a married couple to Kubrick's searching camera in Eyes Wide Shut? The camera seemed to capture a lack of physical passion in their scenes together, and a falseness in the marriage that has now collapsed.

Yet Kubrick did allow one person to portray him - his wife. Christiane Kubrick, an artist, painted Kubrick and showed his portrait in exhibitions in St Albans. Kubrick clearly only trusted images that were made with love. The same is true of Cartier-Bresson. He is happy with the photographs taken of him by his wife, Martine Franck. Similarly, it's hard to imagine the American painter Georgia O'Keeffe posing semi-nude in a series of portraits had the photographer, Alfred Stieglitz, not also been her lover.

Other artists have had a more troubled relationship with the one-eyed intruder. Jackson Pollock's fame was established by Arnold Newman and Hans Namuth's photos of him brooding in front of his canvases or throwing paint. But when Namuth persuaded him also to be filmed at work, Pollock felt exposed. He ended the session by falling spectacularly off the wagon (he'd been dry for a few highly productive years), turning over the dinner table and shouting: "I'm not the phony, you're the phony."

Artists seem to divide, just like the rest of us, into clumsy introverts, terrified of the camera, and people who love - and are loved by - the lens. I doubt whether Salvador Dali ever objected to having his picture taken. He even let Helmut Newton photograph him with a tube in his nose in his last days, a miserable figure of futile wealth and sterile fame. Picasso was a happy subject and adept media performer: Cartier-Bresson caught him in a fearful moment in wartime, Duncan shot the artist in the bath. But other kinds of portrayal caused Picasso pain; he was horrified when Françoise Gilot published an account of their relationship. Images didn't bother him; words did.

Duncan points out in his defence of Cartier-Bresson that he is celebrated for snatching "the decisive moment", photographing people unawares. But I don't think that's adequate. Cartier-Bresson is not a pitiless snapper. If he has a personal fear of the lens, he has tried to soften its assault on others. His pictures of artists in particular - Matisse, Bonnard, Picasso - are richly artful celebrations; "portraits", he would say, rather than "snapshots".

His portrait of Matisse, taken in 1944, catches the artist sketching in a room full of pet birds, one of which he holds; Matisse has been photographed spontaneously, yet the image Cartier-Bresson has selected from the many he took that day is an allegory of Matisse as creator, his imagination soaring. None of the birds is in a cage.

Cartier-Bresson complains that, rather than choose one significant portrait, Duncan has published an entire reel of film. He sees an opposition between the use of the camera to make a sensitive work of art and the routine photography that dominates our lives: arbitrary, crude in its definition of who we are and - in his eyes - violent.

 Faceless by David Duncan is published by Assouline.

webTitle: Pass Notes No 1818:  Screamin' Jay Hawkins

fields.headline: No 1818
fields.standfirst: Screamin' Jay Hawkins
fields.trailText: Screamin' Jay Hawkins
fields.body:
Age: Died a year yesterday, aged 71.

Appearance: Wesley Snipes in drag.

Legacy of: Interesting you should mention that. While Screamin's 30-odd years of recordings have, according to Rolling Stone, "virtually been ignored", the flamboyant entertainer left his mark in other ways.

How so? Well, it seems he spent an inordinate amount of time in bed.

Asleep? Quite the opposite.

Alone? Don't be absurd. Screamin' estimated he had sired 75 children, not all of them with his six wives.

Phew! All that and a hard-working career in showbiz, too? Yes, indeed. Not only did he find time to make his legendary recording of I Put A Spell On You - it frightened him so much when it was played back to him that he set fire to the record - but he also fathered his own lost tribe.

And did Hawkins put a spell on this tribe, and give it its own hair-raising rituals and customs? Not as far as we know. In fact, most members don't even know each other, though that may be about to change. Yesterday, at the House of Blues in Los Angeles, a dozen people gathered, all claiming Hawkins as their father.

What happened to the other 63? The search for Screamin's scattered clan continues as we speak, led by an investment banker called Maral Nigolian, who also cherishes an incomprehensible desire to be his biographer. But a total of 75 may prove to be a drastic underestimate.

You mean the man who invented "voodoo R&B" has infested the entire planet with his blood-sucking progeny? I wouldn't go that far. But when Ms Nigolian urged Hawkins' offspring to contact her website, jayskids.com, there were 2,500 applicants. Sorting the real ones from the fakes is time consuming, but she's verified 36 so far.

It should be made into a docusoap. Sorry, you'll have to make do with a Cutting Edge on Channel 4. Bloody TV crews get everywhere these days.

webTitle: Stuart Round regularly risked is life to smuggle arms to the ANC during the apartheid era.

fields.headline: I was a teenage gun runner
fields.standfirst: Stuart Round, a nice, ordinary 30-something bloke from Nuneaton. But for 15 years he kept a secret - as a youth, he regularly risked his life to smuggle arms to the ANC in South Africa during the apartheid era
fields.trailText: Stuart Round, a nice, ordinary 30-something bloke from Nuneaton. But for 15 years he kept a secret - as a youth, he regularly risked his life to smuggle arms to the ANC in South Africa during the apartheid era.
fields.body:
"Nice truck." The South African border guard considered it with almost lascivious interest. The model Bedford of the type once popular in the British army was entering the country on the last leg of a 7,000-mile safari from Nairobi to Cape Town. There were 18 tourists in the back, one tour guide in the front, and a ton of AK-47s hidden under the seats. It was 1986, at the height of the sanctions against apartheid.

The British driver, Stuart Round, 19-years-old and in a state of consolidated terror, weathered the guards' interest in the group's European passports. Then he was asked if there were guns on board. The answer he gave seemed to amuse them. After a brief lecture on the perils of driving unarmed through black Africa, the guards waved them on, brightened by another small instance of British stupidity. The driver allowed a smile too. Easing the truck into South Africa, his passengers bumped along in ignorance of the role they had just played in the African National Congress's plans to overthrow the white government.

Fifteen years later, the story of how 30 tons of weapons and ammunition were smuggled into the country by, among others, an A-level student from the Midlands, has been rescued from obscurity by South African television. David Brown made Secret Safari, broadcast in South Africa this week, after learning that his father, Mannie, had helped to set up a travel agency in London which for seven years was a front organisation for transporting guns and ammunition into the hands of Umkhonto weSizwe, the armed wing of the ANC, in the days when war in South Africa seemed inevitable.

While Brown and his partners worked on converting a truck and soliciting legitimate backpackers as decoys, Stuart Round was emerging from an "orthodox, middle-class upbringing" in Nuneaton, Warwickshire. His father was an RE teacher, his mother an office worker, and Stuart was taking what was then a common route to rebellion, from sociology lessons to membership of CND, to anti-apartheid demonstrations outside his local Barclays bank branch and the market stalls that persisted in selling Cape apples. His parents thought they were through the worst of it when, at 19, he dropped out of school, severed links with his activist friends, moved to London and got a job in a travel agency.

What they didn't know was that it had been set up by the ANC. The agency, Africa Hinterland, had premises in Greenwich High Road, south-east London. "We had a budget of £80,000," says Mannie Brown. "That was to buy the vehicle, convert it and get it to Mombasa. We bought a second-hand Bedford and converted it on farmland near Ipswich. My nephew did all the welding."

A glossy brochure offered a seven-week safari for £700. For those reluctant to break santions, there was a five-week option that terminated short of the border. "Underseat storage for foods supplies, camping equipment, tools, spares etc . . ." the brochure boasted. It omitted to mention the five-metre cavity in which arms would be hidden when the truck stopped for "servicing" in Lusaka.

Round is 33 now, an aerial photographer who lives in Nuneaton, still wearing the 11-hole boots of his demo days and smiling shyly beneath his freckles. "I was approached through friends of friends," he says.

"They said I was being recruited for 'something political, abroad'."

He got the train to London and was interviewed by Mannie Brown. "He was very young, but incredibly mature for his age," says Brown. Round had to keep his activities secret and accept the fact that he might never be able to share them. If he got caught en route , he was to tell his interrogators that he thought he was smuggling computer parts past sanctions and had no idea it was guns. He was prepared for imprisonment or worse. "The situation in South Africa was so stark. They needed guns and that was very clear cut to me."

Round took a six-week tour of Europe to get stamps in his passport and give him something to talk about with the passengers. He went to Ipswich and learned how to work the truck's secret compartments. He was trained in counter-surveillance - how to monitor people in shop windows and raise the alarm if he was being followed. Finally, he learned to drive.

webTitle: Obituary: The Rev Will Pugh

fields.headline: The Rev Will Pugh
fields.trailText: The Rev Will Pugh affected the lives of many young people in the Liverpool suburb of West Derby in the years immediately following the second world war, when he formed what became a large and successful youth club.
fields.body:
The Rev Will Pugh, who has died aged 84, affected the lives of many young people in the Liverpool suburb of West Derby, then a lower middle-class housing estate, in the years immediately following the second world war, when he formed what became a large and successful youth club. With his upright frame, much-worn sports coat, mop of unruly black hair and piercing eyes, he had the talents of an eccentric teacher of genius.

The son of a Merchant Navy steward, Pugh was born and raised in Liverpool. He was educated at the Liverpool Institute high school and studied theology at King's College London, before becoming a curate at St Mary's parish church, West Derby, where, in 1945, he founded a youth club.

He saw it as part of the Christian community, but was too wise to attempt preachiness at meetings, or to confine membership to Christians. The club flourished because Will had the ability to speak to several hundred young people at once, and leave each one feeling that his words had been directed at them alone. He shared with club members his enthusiasm for fencing, amateur dramatics, climbing in Switzerland, and listening to classical music amid the Edwardian decor of his drawing room.

The club's extensive programme, largely financed by subscriptions and Will's slender stipend, helped to inspire change in other Merseyside clubs, although few leaders possessed Will's rapport with young people.

Meanwhile, he was a turbulent priest, who found committee work uncongenial - it meant compromise - and never attended clerical meetings. For many years, there was a guerrilla war with his highly conventional rector. He rarely remembered that a curate was supposed to be a subordinate; unsurprisingly, he was never promoted. Typically, Will added to the annual Rose Queen parade a float bearing Queen Rosie, a whiskery youth in drag, pulled by a pantomime horse.

Revenge by the church establishment came in 1960. After studying the Oxford Movement for two years, for a research degree at Christ Church, Oxford, Will returned to West Derby expecting that his job would still be open. Within months, however, the church stopped paying his stipend. Until his retirement in 1981, he taught religious instruction - very successfully - to sixth formers at Ormskirk grammar school.

At the same time, however, his marriage was under strain. So enlightened elsewhere, Will was an authoritarian paterfamilias; he could not argue rationally about women priests - an idea he opposed - and the only television programme he did not denounce was one on the Chelsea Flower Show. He and his wife separated.

In his last 20 years he promoted frequent youth club reunions, which hundreds attended. He hated marking his 80th birthday, and gifts were banned. On his death-bed, he was visited by more faithful friends than his house could accommodate.

He is survived by his wife, Shirley, two sons and three daughters.

Ernest William Pugh, clergyman, youth leader and teacher, born February 17 1916; died January 28 2001

webTitle: Obituary: Roberto Sanesi

fields.headline: Roberto Sanesi
fields.standfirst: Critic, translator and master of Italian poetry
fields.trailText: Critic, translator and master of Italian poetry.
fields.body:
Roberto Sanesi, who has died aged 70, was one of the most remarkable Italian writers of his generation. A highly accomplished and prolific poet, he was capable of working in a great variety of metrical forms, and was a master of free verse. His poetry, always imbued with a certain intellectuality, ranged extensively from the confessional and anecdotal to the philosophical and metaphysical, and he could shift register with extraordinary skill, from the lyrical to the factual to the speculative, within the bound of a single poem.

In this respect he had learned much from TS Eliot and Ezra Pound, whose formal diversities and virtuoso uses of poetic impersonality he adapted with great originality to his own purposes in Italian.

Sanesi was also a major translator of English and American poetry, making available for the first time much of the historical and modernist canons of British, Irish and American verse. He directed Italian versions of plays by Shakespeare, Marlowe and Eliot, and wrote and translated libretti for operatic productions, including Benjamin Britten's The Turn Of The Screw.

A sensitive, respected and enthusiastic art critic, he was greatly loved by those whose work he championed. He created his own form of quick and fanciful pictorial calligraphy, and exhibited and published it with great success. He was also a gifted teacher and broadcaster.

Sanesi was born in Milan and spent his childhood mostly in Prato, near Florence, where he lived and worked for the rest of his life. His career as a critic began in the 1950s as a writer for Aut-Aut magazine and founder of Edizioni del Triangulo, a small company dedicated to publishing the poetry and drawings of contemporary artists and writers, including Kenneth Patchen, Enrico Baj, Gianni Dova, William Carlos Williams - and others.

In 1958, Sanesi made the first of many extended visits to south Wales; he travelled by train with a sailor's kitbag, directly from Milan to Oystermouth. He had come to work on a book about Dylan Thomas and to meet Thomas's friend, the poet Vernon Watkins, whose work he had also translated.

In that year, too, he met the painters Alfred Janes and Ceri Richards. Sanesi maintained an intense critical interest in these closely linked Welsh friends. He also met Henry Moore and Graham Sutherland, and was to write about both with a deep insight into their roots in English visionary romanticism.

Following the publication, in 1958 and 1960, of anthologies of translated modern American and English poetry - including works by Walt Whitman, Hart Crane, Wallace Stevens, WB Yeats, WH Auden, William Empson and David Gascoyne - Sanesi was authorised by Eliot to translate his works into Italian. In three superb volumes, published by Bompiani in Milan (1987, 1992 and 1993), he made the complete works of Eliot in poetry, drama and prose available to the Italian reading public. The 1980s saw also the publication of a masterly Italian version of Paradise Lost.

Sanesi was a crucial interpreter of British and American literary and visual culture to contemporary Italy and maintained an astonishing range of critical-creative activities. He wrote extensively and with great distinction on Italian art and literature, in books, magazines and newspapers, and was a regular contributor to Corriere della Sera. He taught at the universities of Parma and Verona, and was sometime professor of comparative literature at the Academy of Brera; he directed Italian versions of Shakespeare and Eliot at theatres in Bologna, Verona and Milan, and adapted Shakespeare and Marlowe for Swiss-Italian radio.

Throughout the 1960s, Sanesi edited the influential journal Poesia e Critica, and in 1972 founded the Munt Press, which published poetry and essays by international writers, including Octavia Paz and Simone de Beauvoir. From 1970 to 1975, he was artistic director of Palazzo Grassi in Venice.

He was, however, before anything else, a poet of outstanding gift, constantly writing and publishing from his mid-20s until his death. There are excellent English versions of his work by poets as distinguished as William Alexander, Richard Burns, Cid Corman and Vernon Watkins.

A man of great dignity and personal grace, Sanesi was elegant and courteous, charming and modest, although he had about him the slightest touch of the dandy. Respected as a writer by fellow artists, he was much loved by all who knew him. He leaves Anita, and a son, Federico.
