webTitle: Obituary: Judith Radstone

fields.headline: Judith Radstone
fields.standfirst: Radical bibliophile devoted to the worlds of poetry and protest
fields.trailText: Radical bibliophile devoted to the worlds of poetry and protest.
fields.body:
Detained at Bow Street police station for sitting down in Parliament Square during a CND demonstration in the 1980s, Judith Radstone found herself in the company of some of Britain's respected literary figures. Most of them were old friends with whom she passed a convivial night of chat and jokes in a haze of cigarette smoke. It was an occasion on which her two spheres of books and politics were happily conjoined.

Judith, who has died aged 75, was a bibliophile, bookseller and political activist, and a well-known figure in the poetry world: Carol Anne Duffy's Warming Her Pearls was dedicated to her, inspired by a conversation with Judith about the practice of ladies' maids increasing the lustre of their mistresses' pearls by secreting them beneath their clothes to be warmed by their skin. She was also a close friend of Quentin Crisp, Eduardo Paolozzi and the painter Frank Welby, with whom she lived for a time.

Judith was was born at Hadley Mill, near Ombersley, Worcester, and left school at 14 to work as a milliner's assistant. During the second world war she joined her father, a Chelsea policeman, in London. She was already developing her thirst for music, art and literature and, after the war, found her milieu in the bohemian atmosphere of the Bar-B-Q café restaurant in the King's Road, and the Patisserie Valerie in Soho. Her visits to Welby, after he moved to Paris, engendered her fondness for French art and literature.

In 1953, Judith married a struggling singer, Morris Radstone, now an art dealer, and devoted herself to her two daughters. Following her divorce in the late 1960s, she started working fulltime in the book trade, at Claude Gill and later as poetry buyer in Words And Music in the Charing Cross Road.

In 1979, she moved to Bernard Stone's Turret Bookshop in Covent Garden, where she organised events and readings. Thus began her long associations with poets and writers, among them Gavin Ewart, Kit Wright, Eddie Linden and the publisher John Calder, whom she met in the late 1960s.

In April 1981 Judith organised Poets Against The Bomb, a CND fund-raising event at Chelsea town hall. Ralph Steadman designed the poster, and Harold Pinter, Judith Kazantzis, Gavin Ewart, Adrian Henri, Brian Patten and Ivor Cutler were among those who took part.

Judith's life was also closely interwoven with the Poetry Society, for which she worked tirelessly as both a reader and part-organiser of its annual national poetry competition. Proud of her working-class origins, she was an inspiration to many, with a generosity of spirit and a gift for nurturing and guiding youthful artistic talent.

She was as passionate about politics and the venality of the powerful as she was about words on the page. A lifelong socialist, she supported the women of Greenham Common, and, through the 1980s and 90s, was still active on protest marches, most recently during the Nato bombing of Kosovo in 1999.

Although contemporary in her thinking, Judith was a defiant technophobe who deplored the arrival of the microchip. At home, she proudly wielded ancient flat irons and eschewed clocks. She detested computers and faxes, and recoiled at answerphones. Her extensive multi-lingual library was augmented by purchases from charity shops; books spilled out of the crammed shelves and flowed down the stairs to her front door.

In her last years, her life became more solitary, partly because of her less robust health. Although she still pursued the "nice things" with passion, her life was mostly concentrated on her family. She is survived by her daughters, Susannah, an academic and writer, and Sara, a ceramicist.

webTitle: Corrections and clarifications

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our leader, Mr Blunkett's three Rs, page 21, yesterday, we were wrong to say that only maths and science teachers are to have their student loans paid off. The new incentive applies to graduates in the five shortage subjects of maths, science, languages, technology and English.
fields.body:
In our leader, Mr Blunkett's three Rs, page 21, yesterday, we were wrong to say that only maths and science teachers are to have their student loans paid off. The new incentive applies to graduates in the five shortage subjects of maths, science, languages, technology and English.

 In our piece about the exhibition of Italian paintings of the 18th century, Settecento: Tiepolo's Century, at Lille, page 11, G2, yesterday, we mentioned Guardi's "Emmaus's Supper" and went on to speak of the painting as though Emmaus were the name of a man rather than a village "outside Jerusalem" (Luke, ch 24, verses 13-35). Paintings of the subject are usually called The Supper at Emmaus. The famous Venetian church Santa Maria della Salute is usually referred to by that name in French as it is, also, in English.

 In an article headed Biddlecombe chasing fame, on page 31 (Sport), February 8, the agricultural college mentioned is Hartpury not Hartbury. Churchdown public school, in the same piece, should have been Churchdown secondary state school

 In our report of Charlton v Newcastle, page 2, Sport, yesterday, we spelt the name of Charlton's South African striker wrongly: he is Shaun Bartlett, not Sean Bartlett.

 In the large picture across pages 8 and 9, Media, yesterday, Paul Krassner is on the left, not the right.

 The moray patterns, referred to in a caption on page 47, Weekend, February 10, are moiré patterns.

 A clue in our cryptic crossword on February 9, could only be solved, as those who referred to the solution on page 12, Saturday Review, February 10, would have been dismayed to discover, by misspelling the word Iridesce (by inserting an additional "r").

 Homophone corner, from page 29, Finance, February 10: "A peak at yesterday's results revealed that Shell is sitting on a cash pile of around £8bn."

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. Fax 020-7239 9897. Email: reader@theguardian.com

webTitle: Letter: good hygiene practice starts at home.

fields.headline: Good cooks
fields.trailText: The food standards agency report (Low public trust in food safety, February 5) focuses on the increasing incidence of infectious intestinal disease following a visit to a fast-food outlet or restaurant. But between 50 and 80% of food-related outbreaks arise in the home.
fields.body:
The food standards agency report (Low public trust in food safety, February 5) focuses on the increasing incidence of infectious intestinal disease following a visit to a fast-food outlet or restaurant.

But between 50 and 80% of food-related outbreaks arise in the home. Many of these are preventable - just by proper cooking and storage of food and simple hygiene during food handling and preparation.

These figures illustrate the need for an education programme about "good hygiene practice" within the home. Whether we prepare food at home or in a public place, most of our understanding of good hygiene practice is learned at home.
Silvia Pellegrini
International Scientific Forum on Home Hygiene

webTitle: Letter: I'll keep up the pressure in prisons

fields.headline: I'll keep up the pressure in prisons
fields.trailText: Your leader (February 7) based on my address to governors, was generous to acknowledge that I am committed to change. This is not a matter of needing more money. It is a matter of treating prisoners with dignity.
fields.body:
Your leader (February 7) based on my address to governors, was generous to acknowledge that I am committed to change. This is not a matter of needing more money, certainly not a matter of ministerial support. It is however a matter of treating prisoners with dignity, keeping prisons clean and putting more effort into preparing prisoners for release.

This is a task for governors - and their warm support at the end of the conference convinced me how much the overwhelming majority share my determination to change permanently some of the prisons which have been unacceptable for too long and to make the broadly acceptable institutions good ones.

But this is hard work and on my behalf, my deputy, Phil Wheatley, is managing governors so that prisoners get exercise, access to education, places on drug treatment courses and on offending behaviour programmes. He is ensuring prison officers work shift systems to allow constructive work with prisoners to take place rather, than has so often been the case, work shift systems which make that impossible.

A minority of governors caricature this properly firm line management as bullying. It is nothing of the sort, and your leader perpetuates that caricature by labelling Phil Wheatley as a "hardliner". What he and I are trying to do is simply no longer to compromise, no longer to accept prisons which do nothing to prepare prisoners for release and, in some circumstances, impose upon them an unacceptably harsh regime.

That can make life for governors hard and I announced details of how we plan to offer more support to them. But we will not take the pressure off and any one who wants to see prisons reformed must welcome that.
Martin Narey
Director general, Prison service

webTitle: Obituary: Abe Beame

fields.headline: Abe Beame
fields.standfirst: New York's first Jewish mayor, who was blamed for the city's worst fiscal crisis
fields.trailText: New York's first Jewish mayor, who was blamed for the city's worst fiscal crisis.
fields.body:
Abe Beame, who has died of complications due to open heart surgery aged 94, was one of the most ineffectual and derided mayors of New York city.

Mockingly described as the bean counter who couldn't count, he was unfortunate enough to inherit the mayoral mansion in 1973, just when New York was reeling from the financial problems left behind by his predecessor, the liberal Republican John Lindsay (Obituary, December 21 2000). So it fell to Beame to wrestle with the worst fiscal crisis in the city's history, when the bond markets refused it credit and the US president, Gerald Ford, was so unsympathetic that he inspired the headline in the New York Daily News: "Ford to city: Drop dead".

Beame had one undisputed claim to be remembered, however: he was the first Jew to serve as mayor of New York. He came up from Brooklyn through the ranks of Democratic clubs, which, in the 1950s and 60s, were challenging the Democratic "regulars" associated with the traditionally Irish-dominance of Tammany Hall. So there was an ethnic dimension to the conflict between regulars and reformers, with the regulars associated with Irish, and to a lesser extent Italian, Roman Catholics, and the reformers largely Jews and upper-class white Anglo-Saxons.

At the height of New York's tribulations in the mid-1970s, efforts to heal the fiscal crisis were not helped by the bitter feud between Beame and the governor of New York state, Hugh Carey, an Irish Catholic.

Politics, and the feud among Democrats, probably combined to load too much of the blame for the fiscal crisis onto Beame. The city's problems, due to profligacy and poor financial management, as well as to factors affecting central cities across America - such as the flight to the suburbs - had been growing for more than a decade. But there was certainly plenty of blame to go round; it was variously laid at the door of New York's exploding welfare bill, its wages bill, which multiplied by a factor of four in 15 years thanks to the power of the unions, and traditional political giveaways, such as artificially low subway fares.

The son of a restaurant owner, Beame was born in Whitechapel, London, and taken to Brooklyn a year later, where he grew up poor. He was only 5ft 2in tall, and worked eight hours a day in a factory while going through high school. He even earned extra money by getting up early to wake up factory workers without alarm clocks. He managed to qualify as a certified public accountant and went into politics, where his reputation for toughness earned him the nickname "Spunky".

He worked his way up through the Brooklyn Democratic party, and served as New York's budget director and comptroller, or chief financial officer, under Mayor Robert Wagner. In 1965, he ran for the top post himself, but was defeated by Lindsay.

It was Lindsay's attempt to help poorer New Yorkers and blacks, in cooperation with President Lyndon Johnson's "great society" policies, that brought on the city's fiscal crisis, long in the making. Beame was able to take advantage of Lindsay's difficulties, and was elected mayor in 1973. His slogan, ironically, was "He knows the buck".

He had brokered a coalition composed of all those Lindsay had alienated, especially working-class and middle-class whites. However, he was also able to strike a deal with Percy Sutton, the African-American leader in Manhattan, by promising to back Sutton for mayor in 1977. And he was supported by the Republican governor, Nelson Rockefeller, who planned to run for president and needed to dissociate himself from Lindsay's unpopular regime.

The crisis broke with full force in March 1975, when New York was refused credit by the bond market; later that year there was serious danger of a default on the city's debt. Beame threatened to refuse services - such as police and fire protection - in the districts of Republican state senators, and had to reassure voters in their districts that police and firemen would not be fired. In the end, the federal and state governments and the banks worked together to rescue the city. Beame maintained to the end that the crisis was over before he left office, but he continued to receive much of the blame.

In 1977, his career was shattered when he only came third out of seven candidates in the Democratic primary. For the last 25 years, he worked as a senior adviser to the Sterling National Bank, lunching twice a month on margherita pizzas with a group of old political friends at Scotto's restaurant on East 52nd Street. He worked for charities, and was admired for his dry sense of humour.

Felix Rohatyn, the banker who put together the New York rescue package, said he admired Beame for not putting the city into bankruptcy and blaming others, but for accepting the inevitable.

Beame's wife, Mary, died in 1995, and a son, Edmund, in 1999. He is survived by his other son, Bernard.

Abraham David Beame, politician, born March 20 1906; died February 10 2001

webTitle: Letters: Sorry, Tony, the maths doesn't add up

fields.headline: Sorry, Tony, the maths doesn't add up
fields.trailText: Is there any hope that those who propose to teach maths in universities will also have their student loans paid off (£10,000 deal for new teachers, February 12)?
fields.body:
Is there any hope that those who propose to teach maths in universities will also have their student loans paid off (£10,000 deal for new teachers, February 12)? Or do we, as usual, wait for the crisis before acting? It takes seven years to train a university maths teacher, and their skills are much appreciated elsewhere.
John Haigh
School of mathematical sciences, University of Sussex
J.Haigh@sussex.ac.uk

 Compared with other countries, our secondary education system is already too specialised at the upper end, with pupils studying only a few subjects at A-level. Now the government wants to shape our children's education on the basis of their interests and aptitudes (or lack of them) at the age of only ten or 11. Specialisation at an early age will restrict rather than increase opportunities.
Trista Selous
London

 The government recently criticised educational researchers for doing irrelevant research which does not provide the evidence needed by politicians. Yet, here are two well researched findings: in areas where all schools are comprehensive, children outperform those from areas which retain some selection; and failures in the UK economy are far more due to inadequate education below degree level than at and above it.

So the government invents a selective system which concentrates resources on the best. Blair and Blunkett, like so many before them, say: "do not disturb us with facts; our minds are made up".
Prof Lewis Elton
University College London
l.elton@ucl.ac.uk

 I am a governor at a small secondary school in an isolated rural area. We see it as our task to provide the best possible all-round education for all the pupils who come to us, and have rejected the idea of specialist status because we feel this would suggest that less importance is attached to other areas.

This approach has led to a successful school, and no "special aptitudes" have remained unnurtured. It seems we are again going to be faced with the choice of playing the government's game, or losing funding.
Averil Lewin
Penzance, Cornwall

webTitle: Letters: In defence of the drug giants

fields.headline: In defence of the drug giants
fields.trailText: Your front page story (At the mercy of drug giants, February 12) excoriating the pharmaceutical companies for not selling their drugs at a loss raises several interesting points.
fields.body:
Your front page story (At the mercy of drug giants, February 12) excoriating the pharmaceutical companies for not selling their drugs at a loss raises several interesting points. Firstly, if South Africa can afford to buy submarines it can afford drugs. That is their choice as a mature nation but you have to question the wisdom of politicians who put people's lives some way below macho military posturing.

And, in the case of HIV combination therapy, patient compliance is a huge problem in the developed world - maybe 16 pills at a time, some before meals, some after meals, all requiring a rigid daily regime if they are to be effective. It is not easy to see how such therapies could be applied where there is severe poverty.
Danny O'Hare
Brighton
D.OHare@bton.ac.uk

 Without expensive research, which unfortunately at the moment only the big companies appear willing to fund, AZT and other drugs would never have arrived on the market at all. At least under current rulings some can benefit, until patents eventually expire, and the drug becomes available at the "generic" pricings.

A scenario could be envisaged where a new epidemic (vCJD?) is ignored by Glaxo and friends because they know their billions invested would merely become charity. Are companies to be forced then to make gifts of all their research to the world? Why not also force the software, engineering and chemical sectors to surrender their patents; after all, they could all be said to be holding back poorer nations on the basis of this "knowledge economy".
Daniel O'Toole
Dublin
dotoole@tcd.ie

 The day before a march in Cape Town demanding affordable HIV treatments the issue was raised in an event outside the Tate Britain gallery in London. The same GlaxoSmithKline currently taking the South African government to court has been sponsoring the William Blake exhibition, an irony not lost on the assorted angels, chimney sweeps and others in fancy dress who gathered on the gallery steps to denounce them.

Public readings from Blake showed just how inappropriate was the association between the radical critic of child poverty and oppression and the actions of GlaxoSmithKline in Africa and elsewhere.
Neil Samuels
London

 Many of John le Carré's thrusts against "Big Pharma" are valid, but he's blaming them for far too much (A lot of very greedy people, February 12). Drug companies are just that; companies formed to invent and market medicines. Their boundaries are defined by commercial law; they exist to make profits for their shareholders, not to save the world.

When regarded as only companies doing their job, they appear quite remarkable. They deliver on the promises enshrined in their articles of incorporation. New and wonderful treatments appear almost daily. The secrets of genetics, of life itself, are being read. In a democratic society we are the ones who make the laws that define their conduct.

Does John le Carré's j'accuse include all the Americans who voted for Bush? Or only those who voted for Bush and have shares in "Big Pharma"? In the particular case of Aids in Africa, more could be achieved by disseminating information and condoms than by huge treatment campaigns with expensive and largely ineffective antiretroviral drugs.

Such drugs require administration in an environment of medical excellence, they're not likely to succeed where the infrastructure can't even support the distribution of illustrated leaflets and rubber johnnies. Beating up on the drug companies seems to be missing the point.
Dick Bentley
Southampton

 John le Carré's piece prompted an idle thought. Does he waive royalties on his books in developing countries, and support pirate editions? If not, why not?
Dick Bentley
London

 You imply treating TB is almost as easy as brushing off a cold. "She is going to the TB clinic. They will sort out her TB." Making sure each patient takes several antibiotics for six months is demanding on workers and drug budgets. So much so that TB is still the commonest cause of death in Aids sufferers and kills at least 50% more people worldwide than Aids. If we cannot spend the relatively small sums needed to control TB, how can we ever hope to manage Aids?
Tony Jackson
Secretary, TB Alert

 In at least 38 of the world's poorest countries, annual spending on health is less than $2 per head per year, according to the WHO. Even if combination antiretroviral drugs were available at $200 per head per year, the bills for developing countries would still be astronomical.
Peter Davies

 In at least 38 of the world's poorest countries, annual spending on health is less than $2 per head per year, according to the WHO. Even if combination antiretroviral drugs were available at $200 per head per year, the bills for developing countries would still be astronomical.

While I fully support the ability of poor countries to be able to produce and import generic drugs, especially those which lower mother-to-child HIV infection, surely equal attention must also be paid to education, promoting condom use and developing better primary health care systems?
Dr Jenny Tonge MP
Lib Dem international development spokesperson

webTitle: Indian right goes on heart-felt rampage

fields.headline: Indian right goes on heart-felt rampage
fields.trailText: Hindu extremists opposed to Valentine's Day celebrated an early victory last night after going on the rampage in one of north India's biggest cities, Kanpur, where they destroyed heart-shaped objects, cards and beat up shopkeepers.
fields.body:
Hindu extremists opposed to Valentine's Day celebrated an early victory last night after going on the rampage in one of north India's biggest cities, Kanpur, where they destroyed heart-shaped objects, cards and beat up shopkeepers.

Shoppers looking for Valentine's Day presents were roughed up as the activists ransacked shelves and burned fluffy pink gift items in the street.

The Hindu right, or sangh parivar, has waged an increasingly violent campaign in recent years against Valentine's Day, calling it "un-Indian", "sick" and "immoral".

Last night Bal Thackeray, the right's leading ideologue and head of the ultra-conservative Shiv Sena party, urged his followers to continue the disruption. The lovers' day of celebration had nothing to do with "Hindustani culture", he said, and merely encouraged college students to waste their parents' money.

He also called it a "conspiracy" to increase the profits of foreign multinationals.

"These foreign-inspired things are sullying our culture, which teaches us to love good work, good thoughts and good people all the time - unlike the Valentine's Day culture that espouses love for one day a year," he said.

The Hindu right has also called on newlyweds to take their relatives and parents with them on honeymoon, for to go alone in the western style was "anti-family".

The shopkeepers whose businesses were wrecked by Saturday's organised attacks responded by staging a sit-down protest, paralysing the city's traffic. They agreed to call off their protest only after officials told them the culprits would be punished.

The activists, from the Hindu Jagran Manch, an offshoot of the sangh parivar, had earlier issued a terse warning that they would not permit any kind of Valentine's Day celebrations.

Last year members of another extreme Hindu group struck out against Valentine's Day by swooping on restaurants, cinema halls and secluded picnic spots to catch young lovers. Restaurants offering Valentine's Day discounts for couples were also singled out.

Hit squads blackened the faces of the boys they caught and sent girls home with a stern warning to behave. Clothes are another issue.

"Young girls wear skimpy clothes in fashion shows to reveal their bodies," Mr Thackeray said last night. But these clothes are usually not worn anywhere, so why does all this go on?"

Hoping to avoid intimidation this year, shopkeepers in Kanpur had started selling cards written in Hindi rather than English - and without the word Valentine.

"Valentine's Day [cards] may be a western concept but the thoughts expressed in them are purely Indian," a bookshop owner in Lucknow complained, arguing that there was no reason to ban them.

Attempts to ban New Year festivities in Uttar Pradesh last year failed. But the state's chief minister has recently outlawed beauty pageants.

The lovers' day of celebration had nothing to do with "Hindustani culture", he said, and merely encouraged college students to waste their parents' money. He also called it a "conspiracy" to increase the profits of foreign multinationals. "These foreign-inspired things are sullying our culture, which teaches us to love good work, good thoughts and good people all the time - unlike the Valentine's Day culture that espouses love for one day a year," he said. The Hindu right has also called on newlyweds to take their relatives and parents with them on honeymoon, for to go alone in the western style was "anti-family". The shopkeepers whose businesses were wrecked by Saturday's organised attacks responded by staging a sit-down protest, paralysing the city's traffic. They agreed to call off their protest only after officials told them the culprits would be punished. The activists, from the Hindu Jagran Manch, an offshoot of the sangh parivar, had earlier issued a terse warning that they would not permit any kind of Valentine's Day celebrations. Last year members of another extreme Hindu group struck out against Valentine's Day by swooping on restaurants, cinema halls and secluded picnic spots to catch young lovers. Restaurants offering Valentine's Day discounts for couples were also singled out. Hit squads blackened the faces of the boys they caught and sent girls home with a stern warning to behave. Clothes are another issue. "Young girls wear skimpy clothes in fashion shows to reveal their bodies," Mr Thackeray said last night. But these clothes are usually not worn anywhere, so why does all this go on?" Hoping to avoid intimidation this year, shopkeepers in Kanpur had started selling cards written in Hindi rather than English - and without the word Valentine. "Valentine's Day [cards] may be a western concept but the thoughts expressed in them are purely Indian," a bookshop owner in Lucknow complained, arguing that there was no reason to ban them. Attempts to ban New Year festivities in Uttar Pradesh last year failed. But the state's chief minister has recently outlawed beauty pageants.

webTitle: War of blame after Thai-Burmese border clashes

fields.headline: War of blame after Thai-Burmese border clashes
fields.trailText: Thailand and Burma intensified their war of words yesterday about who was to blame for cross-border fighting at the weekend, some of the heaviest in the region in recent years.
fields.body:
Thailand and Burma intensified their war of words yesterday about who was to blame for cross-border fighting at the weekend, some of the heaviest in the region in recent years.

Burma's junta accused the Thai third army of helping the Shan State Army (SSA), which is fighting for an autonomous homeland in northern Burma. The Thais accused Burmese forces and a group allied to them, the United Wa State army, of infiltrating Thailand to attack the SSA.

While all this was going on, the junta was commemorating the 1947 agreement that led to Burmese independence from Britain. General Than Shwe said in a speech that Rangoon wanted "a flourishing and disciplined democracy" based not on western ideals but principles suited to the Burmese. He gave no time, but any election is likely to be at least two years away.

Opposition campaigners believe the military is unlikely to introduce any new system it does not control.

Colonel Kyaw Thein, a military spokesman, was reported as saying in the capital Rangoon that Thai troops had helped SSA forces shell Burmese positions near the town of Tachilek on Sunday. He said 14 soldiers and two civilians had been killed, and almost 70 soldiers and civilians hurt.

At least two Thai civilians were killed and more than a dozen injured in Mae Sai town when the Burmese retaliated. Residents started trickling back to their homes yesterday after Sunday's eight-hour bombardment but few shops opened.

"We haven't experienced fighting on this scale for years," said one shopkeeper.

Captain Songkarn Nilphan of the Thai army, commander of the unit that retook the Pang Noon border base yesterday morning, said almost 100 Burmese troops were killed.

The fighting began on Saturday when Burmese forces seized the Pang Noon base just inside Thailand and then started firing back into Burma, presumably at the Shan rebels.

Rangoon says that the SSA runs much of the drug trade in the region. Most observers say the Wa are behing the drugs flooding Thailand.

The Burmese ambassador to Thailand was summoned to the foreign ministry in Bangkok to explain his country's actions but Thailand's prime minister-elect, Thaksin Shinawatra, appeared keen to stop the confrontation from getting worse and said he would visit Burma as soon as his cabinet had been sworn in later this week.

His coalition partner, former prime minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, is thought to have close ties to Burma's military.

Gen Shwe did not mention the border tensions in his Union Day speech yesterday, but he appeared more optimistic than in previous years about pluralist politics.

"Success has been achieved to a significant extent in building national reconciliation," he said of secret talks with the opposition National League for Democracy. It easily won the 1990 election but has never been allowed to govern.

webTitle: Letters: Men, mice and Wallies

fields.headline: Men, mice and Wallies
fields.trailText: I have only twice the number of genes as a poxy fruitfly or a few hundred more than a mouse (Gene code opens new fields of medicine, February 12)? I'm no longer sure whether I'm a man or a mouse!.
fields.body:
Given common knowledge about the use of monoamine oxidase inhibitors as anti- depressants, I think it worth pointing out that monoamine oxidase is not directly responsible for alcohol metabolism (Analysis, February 12): that is the job of a separate enzyme, alcohol dehydrogenase, which converts ethanol to acetaldehyde.
Dr John Lagnado
School of Biological Sciences, University of London
j.lagnado@rhbnc.ac.uk

 I have only twice the number of genes as a poxy fruitfly or a few hundred more than a mouse (Gene code opens new fields of medicine, February 12)? I'm no longer sure whether I'm a man or a mouse!
Stan Labovitch
Windsor, Berks
SIL@heathland.hounslow.sch.uk

 The shouting of the name "Wally" (Letters, February 12) at festivals began at the Isle Of Wight festival, where a man lost his dog of that name, and spent the entire night roaming the site calling for him. Others joined in, and at subsequent festivals the call was made as an "I was there" - type shibboleth.
Stephen Potter
St Leonards-on-sea, E Sussex

 I suppose Keith Ord also believes that sex was invented at 70s rock festivals?
Robin Keable
Shoeburyness, Essex
robin.keable@ntlworld.com

 I believe I am the original Wally! I went to see Jimi Hendrix at the fabled Isle of Wight concert in the late 60s. I agreed to meet friends there and, not realising so many people would be there, we had arranged to just call out for one another. I remember hearing my name: "Wally! Wally!" Then everybody took up the chant: "WALLY, WALLY, WHERE'S WALLY?" I never did meet up with my mates.
Walter Caton
Newhaven, East Sussex
wal@catstones.fsnet.co.uk

webTitle: Loudcloud signs up News Corp

fields.headline: Loudcloud signs up News Corp
fields.standfirst:
Netscape's founder to take latest hi-tech venture to market

More net news
fields.trailText: Netscape's founder to take latest hi-tech venture to market.
fields.body:
Loudcloud, the company founded by Marc Andreessen which is preparing to list on the US stock market, is to provide the internet infrastructure used by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation.

The deal with one of the world's largest media companies represents the web hosting company's first global contract since it was founded less than two years ago.

News Corp's decision to outsource the technology for its online news operations around the world comes a month after the company shut its own online division.

The lossmaking Loudcloud, which is understood to be planning to launch an investor roadshow as early as next week, refused yesterday to discuss the terms of the deal. It is expected to announce the tie-up with News Corp at the start of the two-week roadshow. The California company yesterday declined to comment on its plans to go public, citing regulatory restrictions.

Investment bankers in Silicon Valley welcomed the plans for a roadshow as the first sign of life for the moribund IPO market. Loudcloud would be the first pure tech offering since the end of last year.

One banker not involved in the offering said that the company had the profile and pedigree to expect some investor interest. As a sign of the "star chasing" nature of the business, both Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs are lead underwriters on the IPO even though the company is relatively small.

At the age of 24, Mr Andreessen became one of Silicon Valley's best-known names when he earned $174m (£120m) from the initial public offering of Netscape, the web browsing business. The soaring stock market value of the fledgling company probably characterised the new mentality of the hi-tech arena more than other other. Netscape was bought by America Online in 1998.

Mr Andreessen set up Loudcloud, which aims to be a one-stop shop for internet infrastructure, after leaving AOL in early 1999.

Silicon Valley bankers said yesterday that they hoped Loudcloud would open the window on new hi-tech offerings, which have dried up since last year's collapse. One warned that even a business run by Mr Andreessen would have to be realistic about how much it could raise.

In its initial filing to the securities and exchange commission last September, Loudcloud said it was planning to raise $110m by selling 10m shares at $10 to $12 a share. This would value the company at more than $1bn despite losses of $50m in the first six months of 2000.

webTitle: Few tears as Waterstone's chief quits

fields.headline: Few tears as books chain chief quits
fields.standfirst: Waterstone's sacks managing director after disastrous year
fields.trailText: David Kneale abruptly lost his job yesterday as managing director of Waterstone's, Britain's biggest quality bookshop chain.
fields.body:
David Kneale abruptly lost his job yesterday as managing director of Waterstone's, Britain's biggest quality bookshop chain.

His departure - together with that of his operations director, Brian Worrall - was announced after a year in which he had publicly locked horns with hundreds of independent publishers and some of his own bookshop managers in an attempt to turn his company around financially.

At the peak of the unrest late last year, Mr Kneale, 47, was accused on BBC2's Newsnight of bullying small presses. Last night one independent publisher, asking not to be named, said, "There is no sorrow around that he has gone".

The departures are understood to have been agreed late on Friday after a meeting with Alan Giles, chief executive of HMV Media, Waterstone's parent group.

Yesterday's brief HMV statement said Mr Kneale and Mr Worrall had "agreed to leave the company with immediate effect", with another senior executive, Brian McLaughlin, temporarily stepping in as managing director.

Mr McLaughlin said both men understood "that a change in approach is necessary in order to accelerate the recovery of the business". The parting was "amicable".

It was, among other factors, Mr Kneale's efforts to increase centralisation of book ordering which brought conflict with sections of the book trade. He maintained the chain had 16m unsold books, partly because branch managers had become "a soft touch" for publishers' sales reps.

He sent a shiver through the trade by threatening to breach a hallowed publishing ritual by stopping his managers seeing reps. He dismissed his Manchester Piccadilly manager, Robert Topping, for allegedly failing to conform to the new policy.

He did, however, command some sympathetic respect among analysts for his dilemmas within a struggling chain with an indebted parent company and a static books market.

This was not immediately reflected in last night's reaction from the independent presses which succeeded in partly reversing his attempts to impose book discounts of up to 50% on them this winter.

Gary Pulsifer, head of Arcadia Press, said: "Waterstone's have had a solid year of bad publicity in different areas.

"That must have played a part in these departures."

Sheila Bounford, secretary of the 350-strong Independent Publishers Guild, said: "We hope the change of approach announced by Brian McLaughlin will include quickly taking steps to repair the damage to trading relationships with small and independent publishers done in recent months.

"Publishers will be looking for signals from Waterstone's that the new management will recognise their importance to the reading public's perception of Waterstone's as the UK's premier range-holding bookselling chain".

Last year was disastrous for Waterstone's. Comparable sales for the chain fell marginally to £404m while operating profits at the book chain slumped by 34% to £26.4m.

Part of the blame was put on disruption caused by the merger of Waterstone's and Dillons but the chain also suffered from intense price competition.

There was some better news in the run up to Christmas when sales improved by 5.6% but longer term sales have stabilised at best.

Although HMV Media is not actively seeking buyers for Waterstone's, insiders at the group suggest it would not baulk at a decent offer. The group, which is largely owned by EMI and the venture capital firm Advent, is saddled with debts of around £567m.

Last year it turned down at least two approaches, one from Bertelsmann, the German media group which owns the Random House publishing business, and one from the founder, Tim Waterstone.

Mr Waterstone, who has been a fierce critic of HMV Media's stewardship of the chain, is still keen to buy the business back. He has secured backing in principle from the venture capital arm of the Prudential but has so far been unable to raise sufficient funds for a bid.

webTitle: Ukraine leader accused of poll blackmail

fields.headline: Ukraine leader accused of poll blackmail
fields.trailText: President Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine came under increased pressure to step down yesterday after covertly taped conversations seemed to show him rigging the 1999 election that won him a second term.
fields.body:
President Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine came under increased pressure to step down yesterday after covertly taped conversations seemed to show him rigging the 1999 election that won him a second term.

With Ukraine facing its biggest political crisis since independence in 1991, the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, flew to meet Mr Kuchma.

But their signing of trade and energy agreements in the south-eastern Ukrainian town of Dnipropetrovsk kept them away from the capital Kiev, where thousands of protesters maintained a vigil, describing Mr Kuchma as "kaput" and demanding that Ukraine be made a "Kuchma-free zone'.

Yesterday's disclosures are from tapes by a former Kuchma bodyguard alleged also to show the Ukrainian leader's complicity in the murder last September of an opposition journalist, Georgiy Gongadze. It was his internet newspaper that released the new extracts yesterday.

Mr Putin described the accusations about the killing as "a sign of a normal democratic society". The crisis has already resulted in the sacking of a Ukrainian deputy prime minister, the head of the secret police, and the head of presidential security, and the suspension of the prosecutor-general. But there is no sign of Mr Kuchma resigning.

Yesterday's disclosures show the president apparently ordering the blackmail of officials. In language laced with expletives, Mr Kuchma, tells Nikolai Azarov, head of the tax authority: "You have to get all your ... subordinates together at district and regional level and warn them that if they lose the election they will be out of a job ... You have to tell them that they either get the votes or go to jail."

"It's okay, everything will be fine," Mr Azarov apparently responds.

The opposition socialist leader, Alexander Moroz, who was the first to disclose the tapes, yesterday repeated his calls for the president to stand down. Mr Kuchma "usurped power and created a dictatorship in the country", he said.

Mr Moroz is a leader of the anti-Kuchma "national salvation forum" mobilising people across the country to step up civil disobedience. "We can prove that he is not legally elected by 56% of Ukrainians, as previously stated," Mr Moroz is quoted as telling the Moscow newspaper Izvestiya.

"Thanks to the tapes we know how this victory was obtained - there was elementary intimidation and coercion of people using the police and the tax service."

Mr Moroz said the president could avoid prosecution by confirming the authenticity of the tapes and resigning voluntarily. Alternatively, "mass political actions" would be organised to topple him.

Foreign experts say that the tapes are authentic.

webTitle: Snub by duke triggers new dome controversy

fields.headline: Snub by duke triggers new dome controversy
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Legacy's hopes of buying the Millennium Dome were engulfed in fresh controversy last night when a property company with close links to its chairman, Labour donor Robert Bourne, was unveiled as a new partner after a damaging snub from the Duke of Westminster.
fields.body:
Legacy's hopes of buying the Millennium Dome were engulfed in fresh controversy last night when a property company with close links to its chairman, Labour donor Robert Bourne, was unveiled as a new partner after a damaging snub from the Duke of Westminster.

The group was forced to publicly name the Teesland Group as a "significant" shareholder after a stock market statement, saying that the duke through Grosvenor Estates had declined to take a stake, threatened to undermine the bid.

Legacy attempted to play down the blow ahead of crucial talks with government officials tomorrow and a meeting of ministers the day after, insisting that Teesland had a "wonderful track record" in property development.

Dome minister Lord Falconer was introduced to senior Teesland figures, including majority shareholder Kevin McCabe and chief executive Paul Oliver, at a cabinet office meeting as Legacy sought official approval for the move.

Legacy, fronted by Mr Bourne and dominated by an Irish company, Treasury Holdings, said it remained confident that a £125m bid would be accepted in principle by the government this week.

Teesland, said to be involved in projects worth more than £1bn, has worked closely with English Partnerships, the government agency handling the sale. A leaked letter this month revealed that the agency had reservations about Legacy's scheme to turn the dome into a hi-tech business park.

Mr Bourne is a boardroom colleague of Mr McCabe, a director of Sheffield United football club, whose wealth is estimated at £25m. The pair sit on the board of housebuilder Fairbriar, while the Bank of Scotland is the banker for Legacy, Teesland and Treasury Holdings.

Teesland is involved in a consortium which bought into Kent's Bluewater shopping centre and is developing business parks in north London and Rosyth, Scotland.

One property source said: "If what the government is looking for is very significant experience in development projects, it has found the right partner."

Legacy played down the Grosvenor Estates decision. Bruce Walker, Legacy's director of development, said: "The discussions were not compatible with Legacy's overall vision for the dome's future."

The Duke of Westminster, Britain's richest aristocrat, had teamed up with three other property firms - Quintain, Stanhope and Lend Lease - to consider joining Legacy.

A statement issued by Quintain on behalf of the quartet said: "Last week, the consortium was invited by Legacy to examine their proposals for the dome and associated land. On behalf of the consortium, Quintain Estates and Development plc carried out a detailed assessment. This has now been concluded and the consortium has decided not to enter into negotiations to become a partner with Legacy."

A Downing Street spokesman said: "Discussions between the government and Legacy are continuing and they continue to have preferred bidder status. These are complex issues and it's important in negotiations of this detail that we get it right, but clearly we want to see how we can move things forward."

A leaked letter this month revealed that the agency had reservations about Legacy's scheme to turn the dome into a hi-tech business park. Mr Bourne is a boardroom colleague of Mr McCabe, a director of Sheffield United football club, whose wealth is estimated at £25m. The pair sit on the board of housebuilder Fairbriar, while the Bank of Scotland is the banker for Legacy, Teesland and Treasury Holdings. Teesland is involved in a consortium which bought into Kent's Bluewater shopping centre and is developing business parks in north London and Rosyth, Scotland. One property source said: "If what the government is looking for is very significant experience in development projects, it has found the right partner." Legacy played down the Grosvenor Estates decision. Bruce Walker, Legacy's director of development, said: "The discussions were not compatible with Legacy's overall vision for the dome's future." The Duke of Westminster, Britain's richest aristocrat, had teamed up with three other property firms - Quintain, Stanhope and Lend Lease - to consider joining Legacy. A statement issued by Quintain on behalf of the quartet said: "Last week, the consortium was invited by Legacy to examine their proposals for the dome and associated land. On behalf of the consortium, Quintain Estates and Development plc carried out a detailed assessment. This has now been concluded and the consortium has decided not to enter into negotiations to become a partner with Legacy." A Downing Street spokesman said: "Discussions between the government and Legacy are continuing and they continue to have preferred bidder status. These are complex issues and it's important in negotiations of this detail that we get it right, but clearly we want to see how we can move things forward."

webTitle: Son urges public inquiry into murder of solicitor

fields.headline: Son urges public inquiry into murder of solicitor
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The son of the Belfast solicitor Patrick Finucane, assassinated by loyalist paramilitaries after alleged collusion with the army and the RUC, today urges the government to allow an independent public inquiry into the murder.
fields.body:
The son of the Belfast solicitor Patrick Finucane, assassinated by loyalist paramilitaries after alleged collusion with the army and the RUC, today urges the government to allow an independent public inquiry into the murder.

In an exclusive article for the Guardian to mark the 12th anniversary of the shooting, Michael Finucane, 29, said he believed "the British government was responsible" for the death of his father, who was gunned down in front of him as they ate dinner on Sunday, February 12 1989.

"It is an image seared into my mind," the article says.

"The thing I remember most vividly is the noise; the reports of each bullet reverberating in the kitchen, how my grip on my younger brother and sister tightened with every shot."

"(The murder) happened because he was a determined and innovative lawyer, and not, as the RUC and others claim, because he was involved in paramilitary activity.

"Both the RUC and the British government had a powerful motivation to kill him. He was among the first to successfully take the government to the European court of human rights over its practices in Northern Ireland.

"Our goal is a public, independent international inquiry into all the circumstances surrounding the murder."

Sensitivity over the murder of Patrick Finucane has intensified recently as an inquiry into collusion, launched by Scotland Yard, has attempted to unravel links between loyalists and a secret army intelligence cell, the force research unit, which handled all the army's undercover agents in Northern Ireland in the 1980s and early 1990s.

Nervousness within the Ministry of Defence has led to injunctions against newspapers which have reported the allegations of a former FRU member, known as Martin Ingram. Last weekend the MoD also banned newspapers from identifying an undercover British soldier who is at the centre of the Scotland Yard investigation.

The woman, one of the FRU's main handlers of its loyalist agents, was named on a widely-read US website called Cryptome.

After leaving Ireland, she was promoted to the rank of captain in the intelligence corps and now trains recruits at its headquarters in Chicksands, Bedfordshire.

The Scotland Yard team wants to interview her as well as Brigadier Gordon Kerr, former commander of the FRU and now British defence attache in Beijing.

The MoD and Treasury solicitor has warned it will take legal action against British newspapers who name the officer - known as Captain M.

The threat comes despite the publication of the name on the website and against the advice of Admiral Nick Wilkinson, secretary of the 'D Notice' advisory committee which runs a system of voluntary self-censorhip in cooperation with the media.

He said yesterday her name was now in the public domain - the test now applied by British courts on whether the media should be able to publish information about the activities of the security and intelligence agencies.

webTitle: Aventis chiefs in GM blunder sacked

fields.headline: Aventis chiefs in GM blunder sacked
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Three executives at Aventis CropScience in the US have been sacked after a scandal last year in which the French firm's banned genetically modified maize was found in food at Taco Bell restaurants.
fields.byline: Andrew Clark  and  Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
Three executives at Aventis CropScience in the US have been sacked after a scandal last year in which the French firm's banned genetically modified maize was found in food at Taco Bell restaurants.

Aventis's agribusiness head office in Lyon confirmed yesterday that Maurice Delage, president of its US crop sciences division, left the firm on Friday. General counsel Karen Weiner and Ed Makowski, vice president of market development, were also dismissed.

An Aventis spokesman said it was "fair" to link the departure of the three to controversy concerning StarLink - a form of maize developed by the company to resist insects.

US regulators approved StarLink for use in animal feed, but banned it from the human food chain amid concern that it could cause allergic rashes and diarrhoea.

Aventis promised to keep StarLink separate from crops intended for food supplies. But tests by pressure group Friends of the Earth revealed traces in taco shells served at branches of Taco Bell.

The incident has infuriated environmentalists and has cost Aventis a fortune - the group has set aside $100m (£65m) to cover compensation for farmers and customers.

webTitle: Comment: Hugo Young on the cabinet secretary

fields.headline: The decline and fall of the august cabinet secretary
fields.standfirst:
A once revered mandarin has been brought very low indeed

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: A once revered mandarin has been brought very low indeed.
fields.body:
The secretary of the cabinet was once the most revered figure in the British public service. Sir Burke Trend, who held the job in the 1960s, with an aloof manner and superior judgment, was a super-mandarin for the ages. When his successor, Sir John Hunt, appeared in court in 1975 to contest publication of the Crossman diaries, we witnessed an unprecedented descent from Olympus to the forum. Hitherto the cabinet secretary had barely been seen, let alone heard.

Next up, Sir Robert Armstrong, was forced into the open by Mrs Thatcher, to make a humiliating journey to Australia to stop Spycatcher: a bad day for the mystique of a very special post. But Armstrong's prestige was as respected as his cunning. It would not have occurred to him, in any circumstances, to take lunch with the Hinduja brothers of his time.

What these men had in common was high intellect, but also authoritative intimacy with their political masters. They were feared in Whitehall. Their judgment really mattered. They all had many fierce problems to settle every day. None of these involved ruling on the fate of ministers charged with some kind of scandal. That was political work. But it's a fair assumption that if they'd been called on to sort out that particular kind of mess, neither Trend nor Hunt nor Armstrong would have allowed panic to overcome due process. The cabinet secretary should be a bulwark, above all, against panic.

The last two cabinet secretaries have been judges at the centre of just such scandal, and they've both made a mess of it. Quality in high office seems to be declining. Sir Robin Butler refused to investigate a welter of evidence against Jonathan Aitken, preferring, in establishment style, to believe the word of a minister against that of the editor of the Guardian. Stubbornly and at leisure, Butler protested Aitken's innocence. Thanks to him, a corrupt minister for a while kept his job.

Now Sir Richard Wilson has made the opposite mistake in the case of Peter Mandelson, becoming an accomplice in panic which removed a decent minister from his job and maybe from politics. The sheet-anchor of propriety and process abetted the very folly which the man in his position is paid to resist.

Mandelson has not been sensible in the past few days. Visiting the enemy press to plead his case exposed him to forms of manipulation and publicity which the old Mandy would never have risked. He looks a bit of a bloody fool, and nameless slimebags in his party have rushed to defame him further. Oliver James, who deserves to be struck off the psychiatrists' register for unprofessional conduct, has pronounced him suicidal.

But the Hammond inquiry will find it hard to prove a case against him that measures up to the punishment he's already suffered. If it does not, Tony Blair will look a rotten boss, but Sir Richard Wilson's failure to behave like a proper cabinet secre tary will have been substantially to blame.

The decline in respect for the job is not all his fault. The tendency has Thatcherite origins, from a time when the personal familiars of the leader began to weaken the influence of the professional civil service. Mrs Thatcher never did think much of Whitehall. Under Blair, the eclipse of the mandarins at the centre of government is more pronounced. When Wilson got his job, three months after the 1997 election, he arrived to find Blairite chiefs of staff and press officers who mattered more to the leader, inexperienced as he was in government, than the descendant, however august, of Burke Trend.

Besides, Wilson wasn't picked for his authority. He's a fixer and agreeable smoothie, not a Trend. Nor was he expected, or allowed, to be particularly close. When the Mandelson panic began, Wilson therefore came at it with disadvantages. Nonetheless, he should have done more to insist on the observance of a system and process which are in his stewardship.

That he didn't take that seriously enough may have had something to do with where he came from. As the former boss of the Home Office, he seems to have believed what Home Office officials reported about what happened, via Mandelson, in 1998. In a very short time, without assembling all the evidence, he was hustled into lending the weight of his once-great office to the condign verdict against the minister.

Since then, the suspicion has grown that Home Office officials were allowing a miasma of rumour and half- remembered suspicion to congeal into "fact". Other versions were not tested. Perhaps not surprisingly, the latest word is that Wilson is seeking to distance himself from the events of the last week in January, hinting that Downing Street had more to do with them than he did.

That's not the only word emerging from the turmoil. After a week of slagging Mandelson off, No 10 now calls for calm and says he should be allowed to defend himself. It's obvious what's happening. Belatedly, the official machine feels the need to prepare itself for the possibility that Hammond will not find its conduct in all respects justifiable. The murmur of preparatory damage limitation shimmers round the system, both in particular, as regards the cabinet secretary, and in general on behalf of the Downing Street apparatus.

Hammond is inquiring only into the events of 1998, and the bearing these have on a single sequence of remarks allegedly made by Mandelson in recent weeks. Maybe the investigation will find conclusive proof, that a) he intervened to influence a Hinduja passport application and b) he told, in Jack Straw's word, an "untruth" about that recently.

Or maybe not. Though Hammond himself is a former Home Office man, he'll be aware that public scrutiny of his account and its supporting evidence will be intense. He won't get away with any kind of fiddle. More likely, he will be able to point to no more than a series of cock-ups unverifiable as evidence of personal guilt.

On the other hand, Hammond won't be looking at the whole of what happened early in 2001. This is a very big pity. As regards our system of government, Mandelson's (at worst) slender intervention in 1998, if it was made at all, is far less worrying than the hysteria that gripped the prime minister's office on January 29. That is the political moment that needs taking apart.

Not only did it destroy a minister who will probably turn out not to have done anything bad enough to deserve such a fate. It also exposed a system of politics that has broken the rules of orderly government, with the connivance of the official who was once the guarantor of those rules, the great umpire who protected the basic ethics of government. The cabinet secretary has been brought very low when he can't remind the prime minister of the prudence, let alone the morality, of not panicking. If they both pay a price for Mandelson's political corpse, they'll deserve it.

webTitle: Auction rivals jostle for position

fields.headline: Auction rivals jostle for position
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: US online auctioneer eBay appeared to cast a shadow over the prospects for its European competitor, QXL, as an independent company after reports yesterday that it would buy the leading internet auction site in France, iBazar.
fields.body:
US online auctioneer eBay appeared to cast a shadow over the prospects for its European competitor, QXL, as an independent company after reports yesterday that it would buy the leading internet auction site in France, iBazar.

Purchasing the French site would increase eBay's significant lead in Europe over QXL, whose third quarter earnings today are expected to highlight deepening losses.

The deal is believed to be an all-paper affair worth about €100m (£64m). One analyst said that an iBazar acquisition by eBay "was not necessarily bad news" for the British company.

He said the move could show that eBay was ready to purchase more companies in Europe.

Neither eBay nor iBazar would comment.

Before the drop in internet company valuations last year, QXL had hoped to be a formidable competitor to eBay, buying the leading German auction site Ricardo.de and expanding into ten other countries.

EBay, the leading US auction site, has also been on the acquisition trail, purchasing Alando.de in Germany and expanding into Italy, Australia, Canada, Austria, France, Italy, and Japan.

QXL's share price did not change after yesterday's news, but it has already fallen from a year high of 800p to 12p, and its cash reserves have been depleted by a series of expensive acquisitions.

Acquiring iBazar could seal eBay's lead over QXL, as the French company has proved successful in its home market and is also the favoured auction site in Italy, Spain, Sweden, Holland, Belgium and Brazil - countries where eBay does not have a significant presence.

While the Wall Street Journal says that a deal could be forthcoming as early as this week, iBazar and eBay have a somewhat acrimonious history.

Last October, the French company registered the domain name ebay.fr, inspiring its American competitor to sue for rights to the name. iBazar's chief executive, Marc Piquemal, had registered the name more than a year before eBay began its foray into France.

The suit was heard in a French court in December but, in a surprising turn, the judge found in favour of iBazar.

Local competition laws pre vent two companies in the same line of business holding the same name, but because Mr Piquemal had registered it under a second, non-competing company he also owned, he was exempt.

The case angered many French internet companies, who saw iBazar as abusing French law.

Since that stand against eBay, iBazar's fortunes waned as the internet sector has faded from favour.

Early last year the company was valued at around €520m, five times what eBay seems prepared to pay for it.

The company has been looking for a buyer for some time, and held talks with France Télécom's Wanadoo internet service provider in late 2000.

EBay has proved to be one of the few big winners in ecommerce. In its most recent quarter, to December 2000, eBay's gross margins topped 80%. Its revenues almost doubled last year.

QXL and eBay have held talks over a possible merger but the US company balked at its British rival's multiple technology platforms and what some insiders said was its limited competitiveness.

webTitle: Telecoms lead the fightback

fields.headline: Telecoms lead the fightback
fields.trailText: The cause was hardly inspirational, but for nervous investors and commission hungry brokers that did not matter - the FTSE 100 rose sharply yesterday.
fields.body:
The cause was hardly inspirational, but for nervous investors and commission hungry brokers that did not matter - the FTSE 100 rose sharply yesterday.

The fightback from three consecutive sessions of losses, which had seen 130 points wiped off the blue-chip index, was triggered by a fierce buying spree in the sector nobody wanted last week - telecoms.

Yet there was no obvious external event to get the sector going, just a feeling that the Orange float would be successful, albeit from a very low base, and that last week things had been, well, rather overdone.

Not that traders are suggesting the sector is cheap, but in the cases of BT, down 15% last week, and Vodafone, off 7%, there are some bargains to be had.

With its broker, Cazenove, said to be pushing the valua tion argument hard to clients BT rose 43.5p to 638.5p, while Vodafone recovered 8.25p of its recent losses to close at 224.5p. In the meantime, Cable & Wireless advanced 15.5p to 820p after Schroder Salomon Smith Barney labelled the company its favoured play in the alternative carriers universe.

With IT companies such as Logica (up 75p to £16.35) and Misys (37p higher at 632p) also rising sharply after the £3.6bn cash offer for Sema (77.5p stronger at 552.5), the FTSE 100 closed 77.1 points better at 6,241.4.

Nonetheless, the recovery lacked conviction. Senior traders said the advance was largely a technical correction to last week's drop and noted that market turnover - just over 1.6bn - was poor. This, they said, indicated that big institutions were not yet prepared to stick their necks out.

All of which is hardly surprising. Today, Alan Greenspan will provide a further insight on the Federal Reserve's latest thinking when he delivers his bi-annual monetary policy assessment to Congress. "We need soothing words from Greenspan to generate further interest in this market," said one trader.

Things were proving much more interesting lower down the market, however. Thistle provided some much needed entertainment for bored traders, as its shares rose to 172p on reports that Guy Hands, managing director of Nomura's Principal Finance Group, was set to launch a £1bn if he failed to win the Forte Hotel auction.

But then the inevitable happened - Thistle threw cold water over the speculation. "Thistle confirms that it is not in formal discussions with any party regarding a possible offer," it said. The shares closed at 158p, up just 0.5p.

On a more fundamental tack, Oxford Glycoscience, which specialises in the role of proteins in disease, rose 167.5p to £14.30, after it said it would apply for permission to market its new drug Vevesca - which treats Gaucher's Disease - in Europe later this year.

An upgrade from HSBC Securities helped Johnson Matthey end the day 6p better at £10.20. HSBC increased its stance on the speciality chemicals company to "buy" despite the prospect of a global economic slowdown.

Apparently, HSBC reckons the prospects for platinum (one of JM's biggest money-spinners) are set to remain strong and that the share price is not reflecting the potential value of its emerging fuel-cell business. The FTSE Mid 250 ended at 6,769.1, up 11.6 points.

Elsewhere, speculation that 19.7% shareholder Springwood , unchanged at 192.5p, is poised to return with a fresh offer sent Kingfisher Leisure up 4.5p to 55.5p.

Talks between the two broke down in March of last year and the gossips reckon that Kingfisher's good start to the year has rekindled interest in a possible deal.

On AIM, digital distribution specialist Tornado added 16.5p to 96p on news it had sealed a deal with BMG Entertainment to distribute digitally its music catalogue in Britain and Ireland.

BMG's roster of artists includes 5ive, Westlife and Christina Aguillera.

The fightback from three consecutive sessions of losses, which had seen 130 points wiped off the blue-chip index, was triggered by a fierce buying spree in the sector nobody wanted last week - telecoms. Yet there was no obvious external event to get the sector going, just a feeling that the Orange float would be successful, albeit from a very low base, and that last week things had been, well, rather overdone. Not that traders are suggesting the sector is cheap, but in the cases of BT, down 15% last week, and Vodafone, off 7%, there are some bargains to be had. With its broker, Cazenove, said to be pushing the valua tion argument hard to clients BT rose 43.5p to 638.5p, while Vodafone recovered 8.25p of its recent losses to close at 224.5p. In the meantime, Cable & Wireless advanced 15.5p to 820p after Schroder Salomon Smith Barney labelled the company its favoured play in the alternative carriers universe. With IT companies such as Logica (up 75p to £16.35) and Misys (37p higher at 632p) also rising sharply after the £3.6bn cash offer for Sema (77.5p stronger at 552.5), the FTSE 100 closed 77.1 points better at 6,241.4. Nonetheless, the recovery lacked conviction. Senior traders said the advance was largely a technical correction to last week's drop and noted that market turnover - just over 1.6bn - was poor. This, they said, indicated that big institutions were not yet prepared to stick their necks out. All of which is hardly surprising. Today, Alan Greenspan will provide a further insight on the Federal Reserve's latest thinking when he delivers his bi-annual monetary policy assessment to Congress. "We need soothing words from Greenspan to generate further interest in this market," said one trader. Things were proving much more interesting lower down the market, however. Thistle provided some much needed entertainment for bored traders, as its shares rose to 172p on reports that Guy Hands, managing director of Nomura's Principal Finance Group, was set to launch a £1bn if he failed to win the Forte Hotel auction. But then the inevitable happened - Thistle threw cold water over the speculation. "Thistle confirms that it is not in formal discussions with any party regarding a possible offer," it said. The shares closed at 158p, up just 0.5p. webTitle: Business: NMT Group's share analysis

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.standfirst: NMT Group
fields.trailText: NMT Group.
fields.body:
NMT Group, the producer of safety syringes, has not enjoyed the best of fortunes over the past 18 months but is starting to show signs of recovery.

A year ago the company was beset with manufacturing and supply problems after the hard-pushed production line spewed batches of "wobbly" needles. The news sparked a share plunge.

Only towards the end of 2000 did the quality start to improve, although analysts are still waiting for comprehensive figures with which to gauge the improvement.

"They have come a long way in a year and there has been a dramatic improvement," one industry observer said, "but we need the evidence."

A lot of the credit goes to Roy Smith who took over as chief executive of the Livingston-based company last April. Much of NMT's focus has been on the US market, which uses 66bn syringes every year. The company's fortunes were boosted by President Clinton's signature on a bill in November requiring hospitals to use safety devices if possible.

The US is a hugely competitive market prompting fears of a price war.

NMT is taking action to lessen its dependence on its products. Earlier this month it was revealed the company was branching out into intravenous catheters for which it was signing a joint venture agreement with India-based manufacturer, Eastern Medikit.

Yesterday it announced its first stocking order from Hospital Management & Supplies, a medical distributor, which hopes to sell them to the national health service. It has also received its first order from Pale and Hickey, of Ireland, which focuses on the general practitioner market.

As a result, shares went up 1.5p, or almost 5%, to 32p - well off the 62.5p year high but comfortably ahead of the 13.5p low.

The canny investor would do well to hold fire until tangible evidence that the manufacturing problems are solved. Hold.

webTitle: Napster loses court fight to supply free music on the net

fields.headline: Napster loses court fight to supply free music on the net
fields.standfirst:
More net news
Ninth district appeals court ruling
fields.trailText: The music-swapping internet service Napster has lost its court battle to provide free access to music.
fields.body:
The music-swapping internet service Napster has lost its court battle to provide free access to music.

In a historic ruling with implications for the music industry and the estimated 50m Napster users, a US federal appeals court in San Francisco decided yesterday that the company must stop distributing material it knows to be copyrighted - in effect almost all of the music it deals with.

"This is a clear victory," said Hilary Rosen, president and chief executive of the Recording Industry Association of America, which represented the music industry. "It ruled in our favour on every legal issue presented."

However, the court did not order the business to be closed down. It can remain in business but only in a very abbreviated form.

In a 58-page ruling distributed simultaneously at the US ninth district appeals court and on the internet, the court upheld key parts of an injunction won last year by the world's five largest music companies which sought to prevent Napster from effectively distributing music for free.

While the issue is far from dead - the court ruled that the original injunction issued by the US district court judge Marilyn Hall Patel was too broad and sent it back to her for rephrasing - the ruling is a serious blow to Napster. It states that the company will be held liable if it assists in the downloading of music it knows to be copyrighted.

In a statement yesterday, Napster said it was "disappointed" by the ruling and that it would appeal. "We look forward to getting more facts into the record. We will pursue every avenue in the courts and the Congress to keep Napster operating."

The five largest record labels - Warner, Sony, EMI, BMG and Universal - brought the action against Napster, which is based in Redwood City, claiming that the unauthorised use of the music was effectively theft and was costing the companies billions of dollars in lost profits. The five companies control about 90% of popular music worldwide.

In May 1999, Napster founder Shawn Fanning released software that made it easy for personal computer users to find and swap songs they had stored as computer files. The quality of reproduction was high and the idea of "peer-to-peer" song trading took off, spawning imitators such as Gnutella and Freenet.

The record companies have been exploring their own systems of supplying music via the internet, albeit ones that require a subscription payment.

Last year's injunction was almost immediately stayed pending the result of yesterday's appeal, but anticipating that the case might go against them, Napster reached an agreement with Bertelsmann, the parent company of the BMG music company that was one of the quintet suing them. The German media company has agreed to inject capital if Napster switches to a "subscription-based service" paying royalties.

Napster's legal team was led by David Boies, who fought unsuccessfully on behalf of Al Gore for recounts of the Florida presidential vote last year. He also acted - successfully - for the government in its anti-trust action against Microsoft.

Napster was deluged by users at the weekend ahead of the court decision. Nearly 2m song files were traded on Sunday.

webTitle: Lastminute.com's results court controversy

fields.headline: Dot.confusion
fields.standfirst: Lastminute results court controversy
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com's ability to court controversy returned to the fore yesterday when analysts complained that quarterly figures were presented in a way that made it impossible to judge how well the e-tailer has been performing, writes John Cassy.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com's ability to court controversy returned to the fore yesterday when analysts complained that quarterly figures were presented in a way that made it impossible to judge how well the e-tailer has been performing, writes John Cassy.

Chief executive Brent Hoberman, pictured above with co-founder Martha Lane Fox, was bullish as he reported revenues for the last quarter of 2000 showing 53% growth to £20.2m quarter on quarter, even though losses widened from £9.4m to £15.3m.

"These figures are ahead of where we said we'd be at last year's IPO and underline our ability to deliver," Mr Hoberman said.

Analysts said the figures were better because they included for the first time the contribution from Degriftour, the French com pany bought for £59m last August.

It was Lastminute's failure to break out how much the new firm had added to overall business that left some watchers nervous.

Geoff Ruddell, an analyst at Deutsche Bank who has previously pinpointed Last minute as one of the few likely dot.com survivors, said that based on his calculations of the contribution Degriftour was expected to make sales at the core business might have fallen.

"This is very worrying given the amount of growth being assumed to get the business to profitability," Mr Ruddell said, pointing out that the introduction of a new version of the website might have affected sales slightly.

The shares closed 1.5p higher at 71p.
