webTitle: Sema chief says £3.6bn bid is fair

fields.headline: Sema chief says £3.6bn bid is fair
fields.trailText: Schlumberger, the oilfield services group, yesterday revealed it had put forward an agreed $5.2bn (£3.6bn) cash offer for troubled Anglo-French IT company Sema.
fields.body:
Schlumberger, the oilfield services group, yesterday revealed it had put forward an agreed $5.2bn (£3.6bn) cash offer for troubled Anglo-French IT company Sema. The New York-based group said it wanted to develop a hi-tech arm to complement its existing old economy interests.

The takeover of Sema, the former technology sector darling of the stock exchange, by an oil-related company would have been unthinkable a year ago. But since Sema's troublesome takeover of American software firm LHS last year, the company's share price has plummeted from its high of more than £18 and management was forced to issue two profit warnings in November.

Yesterday, Sema's chief executive Pierre Bonelli said the Schlumberger bid - which has the support of management - was "fair", and provided a good deal for shareholders and staff. It also has the backing of France Telecom and Paribas which together hold 20% of Sema. They are locked into the deal unless a rival bid of more than 600p emerges - a prospect most analysts think unlikely.

Yesterday, Schlumberger chairman and chief executive Euan Baird described the mix of oilfields and IT as a world beater. We are arming ourselves for the internet age. We have been through the first bubble of the dot.com revolu tion and the second phase is about applying the internet to existing businesses."

But some analysts cast doubt over the compatibility of the two businesses and Michael Briest from UBS Warburg insisted Schlumberger was not an obvious partner for Sema.

"If I am a telecoms operator and I am buying my billing software from an oil company, I am going to think twice about that supplier," he said. "Where are they going? How much are they going to invest in research and development?" Schlumbergerreceives 95% of its profits from oil-related operations.

Schlumberger's offer of 560p a share - which values Sema at £3.4bn - is at a 7.5p premium on yesterday's closing price of 552.5p, up 77.5p on the day. The deal would mark a 124% increase on Sema's low of 251p five weeks ago.

Possible rival bids could come from EDS, the second largest IT provider in the US; Cap Gemini, the French IT company operating in similar markets to Sema; and the British software group Logica.

Under the deal, around 20,000 Sema staff around the world will work alongside 10,000 IT staff from Schlumberger. Sema will retain its name. Baird pledged not to sell off any part of Sema, though a number of contracts could change. There would also be opportunities for Sema to join forces with several of Schlumberger's non-oil related businesses.

webTitle: Regus a bear target

fields.headline: Regus a bear target
fields.trailText: Simon Cawkwell, the notorious City bear raider who styles himself as "Evil Knievil", has found himself a new target.
fields.body:
Simon Cawkwell, the notorious City bear raider who styles himself as "Evil Knievil", has found himself a new target.

Fresh from his triumph over Scotia, the troubled biotech company, he has now gone short on Regus, the serviced office specialist. "I think Regus is an absolute no-brainer sell," Mr Cawkwell said. His rationale for "shorting" Regus - selling stock he does not own in the hope of buying it back at a lower level - is that it is overvalued and set to face intense competition.

"It is being rated by the market as something which is going to march from here to eternity to good value. But it can't do. It is an ordinary company. It will face competition and the shares are bound to come down," he said.

A spokesman for Regus said: "We announce our figures on February 27 and we are happy to let them speak for themselves." Regus shares fell 5.5p to 355p.

webTitle: Sony in the game plan for Vodafone

fields.headline: Sony in the game plan for Vodafone
fields.trailText: Vodafone and Sony joined forces yesterday in a research partnership to "explore ways" that mobile phones and video game consoles will work together.
fields.body:
Vodafone and Sony joined forces yesterday in a research partnership to "explore ways" that mobile phones and video game consoles will work together.

The research group's first task will be to develop a text messaging service offering PlayStation hints and tips for Vodafone users, but both companies said this is only a "preliminary move".

Games are seen as an ideal use for the next generation mobile phones, which will have a high- speed link to the internet.

Operators such as Vodafone expect to recoup some of the £100bn spent on 3G licences through increased revenue from customers playing games while connected to their network.

The announcement comes after similar agreements signed last month between Sony, NTT DoCoMo, the leading Japanese mobile carrier, and its six overseas partners - AT&T Wireless in the US, KPN Mobile, Hutchison 3G and Telecom Italia iun Europe, Hutchison Telephone in Hong Kong and KG Telecom in Taiwan - to develop technology linking their mobile phones to Sony's PlayStation.

Chris Deering, president of Sony Computer Entertainment Europe, said "Mobile phone and PlayStation users have a lot in common."

webTitle: Profit alert takes Uniq stock lower

fields.headline: Profit alert takes Uniq stock lower
fields.trailText: Food group Uniq, formerly known as Unigate, yesterday blamed tough trading conditions as it slashed its dividend and issued a profit warning.
fields.body:
Food group Uniq, formerly known as Unigate, yesterday blamed tough trading conditions as it slashed its dividend and issued a profit warning.

Shares in the group, which have lagged behind the stock market by 60% in the last ten years, lost 12 %, closing down 30p at 220p.

Uniq sold off its Unigate milk business last year and is planning the demerger of its Wincanton distribution. It intends to concentrate on convenience foods - it is market leader in prepared salads, second in branded spreads, owns the St Ivel brand and makes sandwiches and sauces across Europe - but analysts believe it could face a break-up bid from private equity groups.

The company's problems are focused on its loss-making Malton pigmeat business, where trading "stays difficult".

A recovery plan has been implemented at Malton and Uniq said that reductions in UK pig prices relative to contintental prices indicated that the business would be back in profit in the coming year. Uniq said it would be making a provision against the business in its accounts, but that it was looking for "an industry solution".

Uniq said underlying pre-tax profits for the year to end-March would not be less than £60m, compared to £124m previously. But last year's results included the dairy and cheese business, which has since been sold, and analysts had been expecting profits of some £66m to £73m this year.

The dividend of Uniq and Wincanton will total 12.5p, compared to the previous 23.2p payout to Unigate shareholders.

webTitle: Factory price cuts biggest in 15 years

fields.headline: Factory price cuts biggest in 15 years
fields.trailText: Manufacturers slashed prices last month by the biggest amount for 15 years, despite a sharp increase in the cost of fuel and raw materials, implying a further squeeze on profit margins
fields.body:
Manufacturers slashed prices last month by the biggest amount for 15 years, despite a sharp increase in the cost of fuel and raw materials, implying a further squeeze on profit margins.

The Office for National Statistics said the prices of goods at the factory gate fell by 0.4% in January, trimming the annual rate of inflation to 1.9% from 2.4% in December. It said the main reason for the decline was a sharp drop in petrol prices, although this was partly offset by higher food prices.

The reduction came despite a higher than forecast increase in input prices, which rose by 0.5% in the month, lifting the annual growth rate to 6.3% from 5%.

The figures were at odds with recent business surveys, suggesting manufacturers are becoming more confident about their ability to pass on price rises.

However, Jonathan Loynes, chief UK economist at the consultancy Capital Economics, said the data showed weakening world demand was thwarting those ambitions.

"Overall, the numbers support the generally very benign outlook for goods prices at the retail level. The idea that services inflation needs to slow sharply to accommodate goods inflation is looking weaker by the month."

Figures out today are expected to show a further fall in the government's favoured measure of high-street inflation, excluding mortgage interest payments, which stand at 2%.

With the Bank of England's monetary policy committee mandated to keep underlying inflation at 2.5%, most economists expected last week's quarter point cut in interest rates to 5.75% to be followed by another reduction soon to avoid a bigger undershoot of the target.

But Michael Saunders, of Schroders SalomonSmith Barney, says no further economic stimulus will be needed.

fields.headline: New drug to slash costs
fields.trailText: The world's most expensive drug, a $150,000-a-year (£100,000) therapy for the digestive disorder Gaucher's Disease, could face a cheaper competitor next year thanks to work by the biotechnology firm Oxford Glycosciences.
fields.body:
The world's most expensive drug, a $150,000-a-year (£100,000) therapy for the digestive disorder Gaucher's Disease, could face a cheaper competitor next year thanks to work by the biotechnology firm Oxford Glycosciences.

Oxford Glycosciences' shares rose 167.5p to £14.30 yesterday on news that its treatment, Vevesca, had worked well in the final phase of clinical trials.

Sufferers are unable to store sugar in their bodies effectively, causing their livers and spleens to become grossly enlarged. A hereditary disorder, Gaucher's mainly affects Ashkenaze Jews with more than 25,000 patients worldwide.

Patients attend clinics every fortnight to receive infusions of enzymes into their blood to help break down sugar. This therapy, from the US biotech firm Genzyme, is taken up by only 3,000 patients because of its enormous expense.

Oxford Glycosciences's approach is to provide daily pills which reduce the body's production of certain digestive substances, so patients no longer need to store so much sugar. The company refuses to say how much it will cost, but says it will be "substantially" cheaper than Genzyme's offering. Analysts expect it to generate at least $100m of annual revenue.

webTitle: Call centres blamed for acoustic shock

fields.headline: Call centres blamed for acoustic shock
fields.trailText: Call centres, one of the fastest growing industries in Britain, are triggering a new industrial injury - acoustic shock.
fields.body:
Call centres, one of the fastest growing industries in Britain, are triggering a new industrial injury - acoustic shock.

The Communication Workers Union, yesterday described it as "the industrial injury of the 21st century".

The union is preparing claims for 83 workers whose hearing has been damaged while wearing headsets.

Adrian Fawden, the lawyer handling the case, said: "They are all headset workers, and they have all experienced, while working with headsets, a sudden, loud, noise. The results vary depending on the severity, from someone just going 'ouch!' and taking off the headset at one end to people having to take medical retirement, suffering hearing loss and dizziness, at the other."

He said anyone who used a headset at work was at risk.

Mr Fawden, of London law practice Simpson Millar, said the cause of acoustic shock was unclear. He said the shock of the noise rather than the sheer decibels might be the cause.

"Some of the noise has been caused by nuisance callers setting off rape alarms, by fire alarms and by large amounts of sound of a technical nature, like interference," he said.

Most of the current 83 claims were by people who had worked for BT, either at exchanges or in call centres.

British Telecom and the Call Centre Association claim that modern headsets made to EC standards, filtered out excessively loud noises.

A spokesman for the CCA, representing the employers of 45,000 call centre workers, said current claims related to the use of equipment when the call centre industry was in its infancy.

webTitle: Honda hints at boost for Swindon

fields.headline: Diesel power
fields.standfirst: Honda hints at boost for Swindon
fields.trailText: Honda hints at boost for Swindon.
fields.body:
Honda may make its first diesel engine at its Swindon plant, writes Nicholas Bannister.

Officials said yesterday the diesel engine, being developed in Japan, was needed to boost sales in Europe where almost half of all new cars had diesel engines.

The first diesel-powered Honda is likely to be the new Civic. This would make the Swindon plant - Honda's only engine facility in Europe - the lead candi date to make the new unit.

Company executives said that a decision on whether to put the engine into production would not be taken for several years. The choice of location would depend on the prevailing economic conditions at the time.

Honda is in the process of building a new car production line at Swindon that will increase its annual capacity from 150,000 to 250,000 and create 1,000 jobs.

webTitle: Billiton ready to splash the cash

fields.headline: Billiton ready to splash the cash
fields.trailText: Mining group Billiton yesterday revealed it has $1bn (£690m) available for acquisitions but said it was unlikely to make a move unless the deal on offer was exceptional.
fields.body:
Mining group Billiton yesterday revealed it has $1bn (£690m) available for acquisitions but said it was unlikely to make a move unless the deal on offer was exceptional.

Brian Gilbertson, chairman and chief executive, said Billiton had the financial clout to enhance its portfolio while industry observers insist it needs to expand or merge to be safe from hostile bids.

"We have a debt facility and are capable of doing something if the opportunity comes up," he said.

Billiton reported a 40% increase in attributable net profit to $338m for the six months to December 31. It said earnings per share stood at 15.4 cents, compared to 11.6 cents last time, while the interim dividend increased to 4 cents from 3.75.

The integration of Rio Algom, its £826m purchase that gives Billiton a considerable presence in copper production, should be completed by the end of this financial year.

In a statement to the stock market the company said there had been significant expansion of South American coal operations and feasibility studies have been carried out to expand the global aluminium, copper, coal and nickel operations.

The figures failed to inspire the City . Shares slipped 9.5p to 302.5p as the London markets closed last night, well above the 222p year low, but off the high of 395p.

The main shadow looming appears to be Anglo American, which already has a 7.1% stake, effectively increasing by 1.1% following its takeover of De Beers.

webTitle: Secrecy and arrogance cast a shadow: Goldman Sachs' reputational risk

fields.headline: Secrecy and arrogance cast a shadow
fields.standfirst: Goldman Sachs' reputational risk
fields.trailText: Goldman Sachs' reputational risk.
fields.body:
Round at the Fleet Street office's of Wall Street's finest, Goldman Sachs, there is more to trading and corporate finance than regular financial matters like "market" and "settlement" risk. There is an extra dimension, called "reputational risk".

The phrase is self-explanatory. But time, and also the awesome success of this investment bank in Europe over recent years, has clouded the origins of why Goldman - more than any other bulge bracket firm - is so concerned about its public profile.

A reminder arrived this weekend in the form of leaked details of the DTI inspectors' report on the flotation of Mirror Group Newspapers a few months before Robert Maxwell died in 1991.

Publication of the full investigation soon can be expected to shower all sorts of embarrassment on the likes of Michael Richardson, the now retired Smith New Court grandee, and Charlie McVeigh, the chairman of Salomon Brothers in London. Neither man did anything untoward, other than lend their pristine reputations to a financier who used their introductions to plunder other peoples' pockets.

And then there is Goldman Sachs.

Back in 1991 the bank's presence in London was limited and its power was almost non-existent - except in the market for shares in Maxwell's main vehicle, Maxwell Communications Corporation, and MGN.

It is easily forgotten, but Maxwell was brought down by journalistic digging, rather than whistle-blowing in the City. Key to this was the unearthing of something called a 212 notice, a document which gave a snap-shot of the individual holdings of London's market makers in MCC stock a few week's before Maxwell's death.

This showed that, while most City firms held just a few thousand MCC shares on their books, Goldman held tens of millions. Eric Sheinberg, one of its partners in New York who acted directly for Maxwell, controlled the market.

Subsequent investigations into an alleged share support operation cleared the American bank of any wrong-doing. And while the rules on the disclosure of directors' dealings were subsequently changed to take account of the sort of derivative-based trades used by Goldman and Maxwell, it is clear the bank always believed it was acting lawfully.

That was almost a decade ago. The mud has dried and fallen away from Goldman's corporate face. Yet there was a hint yesterday that even now, as a publicly-listed entity rather than a partnership, it still finds it difficult to shed the habits which have fuelled its business in the past.

Last week, Goldman organised share trades in its own stock where its two biggest outside shareholders, Sumitomo Bank and a charitable foundation based in Hawaii, sold bits of their holdings to a mystery third investor. The assumption is that this is a prelude to a big new share offering by Goldman, but the bank was not offering any guidance yesterday - even on the identity of its new major shareholder. Clearly, secrecy and arrogance remain very important business tools.

No connection

BT's rivals probably have the right to feel a little peeved.

Common sense dictates that BT would employ every trick in the book to delay the opening of its local monopoly to competition. It is a business, after all, and the more obstacles it can lay in the path of the process the longer the head start it gets to deploy its own broadband services using DSL technology - the handy piece of kit that upgrades the old copper wires without needing to dig up the road.

But the emergence yesterday of news that the company is cutting its workforce in BTopenworld, the division that houses BT's broadband services added insult to injury. Not only is BT allegedly holding up the process of breaking up its local monopoly, it is paring back its own mass market internet division at the same time. The vision of a "broadband Britain" championed by the government is looking increasingly unrealistic.

The so-called unbundling of the local loop has stalled. No serious business plan can be drawn around the release of 25 exchanges in disparate areas at a time - the first tranche released by BT. And the costs associated with rivals going into a BT exchange still appear prohibitively high.

BT, unlike operators abroad, is demanding that rivals' equipment be housed in separate rooms with separate entrances for instance.

"Broadband Britain" is in crisis and the government and regulator Oftel need to act fast if they want to help the internet sector through its current turbulent period. It might be cyberspace, but real jobs, and with them Britain's competitive edge, are at risk here.

webTitle: Vodafone deal kicks off

fields.headline: Vodafone deal kicks off
fields.trailText: Vodafone may be Europe's biggest company but, to get still bigger, it knew it had to link with Manchester United . It's not that the Berkshire-based telecoms firm is full of United fans, rather that its executives recognise the power of having the Vodafone brand on the shirts of United's star players.
fields.body:
Vodafone may be Europe's biggest company but, to get still bigger, it knew it had to link with Manchester United . It's not that the Berkshire-based telecoms firm is full of United fans, rather that its executives recognise the power of having the Vodafone brand on the shirts of United's star players.

The club's matches are broadcast in more than 100 countries every week and recognition of the brand in China alone reaches 95%.

"As a profile-raising exercise they don't come much better," said Vodafone corporate communications director Mike Caldwell of the £30m four-year deal.

Vodafone is on a corporate shopping trip unparalleled in history, constantly snapping up rival companies. Awareness of the Vodafone brand in international markets is likely to be higher than ever after the United deal. When it comes to persuading potential takeover targets of its credentials as a global company, that can be hugely helpful.

Extensive

In an illustration of how sports sponsorship deals are becoming increasingly sophisticated, Vodafone and United will share revenues on a new mobile internet service which will enable United fans with Vodafone handsets to subscribe to a variety of premium and exclusive content direct from the Old Trafford football ground.

United has an extensive roster of blue-chip sponsors ranging from software firms Lotus and Sun Microsystems and internet firms Sports.com and UUNet through to sportswear firms Nike and Allsports.

Nike recently shook British football by agreeing a $300m (£205m) 15-year deal to manufacture United's shirts. The football club will also be able to leverage Nike's global marketing machine which is particularly strong in the USA and South America.

webTitle: AorTech fundraiser raises City eyebrows

fields.headline: AorTech fundraiser raises City eyebrows
fields.trailText: AorTech International, a Scottish heart valves company, faced scepticism in the City yesterday after announcing a £64m fundraising to pay for more staff, factories and product development.
fields.body:
AorTech International, a Scottish heart valves company, faced scepticism in the City yesterday after announcing a £64m fundraising to pay for more staff, factories and product development.

The firm has come up with a brown plastic-like material called Elast-Eon, which is flexible enough for use in hip joints and heart valves, and carries a low risk of rejection by the body.

AorTech's cash call, through an offering of shares, is intended to generate enough money to see it through to a commercial launch.

However, the firm's shares fell 72.5p to 700p yesterday as analysts expressed surprise that it needed so much cash, and complained that the likely launch date of its heart valves had slipped back from 2006 to 2007.

AorTech's finance director, Ian Cameron, said: "Our objective in doing this is to fulfil our global aspirations. It will also give us flexibility in making acquisitions."

He expects the Lanarkshire firm's workforce to rise from 120 to 200 within a year. The company is extending its production facilities in Australia, and intends to build a new factory, probably in the US.

Mr Cameron said: "On the basis that nothing significantly new comes along, these funds will be sufficient to take us through to profitability."

As part of the share offering, chairman Gordon Wright and managing director Edward McDaid are selling £2m of shares each. They will retain a stake of about 25%, worth £50m.

AorTech has just launched its first significant product - a heart monitor called TruCCOMS, which measures blood flow more accurately than existing machines. However, commentators are concerned that this is taking off slowly.

Sally Bennett, an analyst at ING Barings, said: "Sales of TruCCOMS have been slower than expected. They're raising a significant amount of money today, and I'm not quite sure what they want to spend such a lot on."

AorTech's heart valves are considered the firm's most promising product, with potential sales of £144m annually. They last longer than the current alternatives, and will be tested in young sheep next year.

AorTech, which lost £1.8m last year, is to upgrade from the Alternative Investment Market to the main market.

 Concerns are growing about the future of up-for-sale vaccines developer Cantab Pharmaceuticals, following news that Powderject, a leading contender, has decided against making a takeover offer.

Powderject is thought to have backed out after suffering a recent slump in its own share price. Some 28 firms initially expressed interest in Cantab but only a handful are left - tipped to include Deeside-based Provalis.

Cantab's leading product, one for genital warts, failed in October.

webTitle: Dublin defies EU edict

fields.headline: Dublin defies EU edict
fields.standfirst: Ireland vows to stick to budget plans after Brussels censures 'inflationary' policy
fields.trailText: Ireland vows to stick to budget plans after Brussels censures 'inflationary' policy
fields.byline: Charlotte Denny and Andrew Osborn in Brussels
fields.body:
A defiant Dublin launched a blistering attack on the European commission yesterday, insisting it would stick to its budget plans after Brussels publicly censured it for pursuing "inflationary" policies.

As European Union finance ministers adopted a "get tough" approach to members whose economic policies are out of line with commission recommendations, the Irish finance minister Charlie McCreevy insisted he would stick by his budget plans. "There will be no policy changes vis-à-vis the budget, which was laid down in December," he said in an interview with Irish radio ahead of the finance ministers' meeting.

All fourteen of his fellow EU ministers endorsed the commission's view that Ireland's 2001 budget plans as out of line with EU guidelines and likely to lead to further rises in inflation. This is the first time the ministers have yellow carded a fellow EU member.

As well as criticising the Irish government, the finance ministers approved commis sion recommendations warning Italy to keep its deficit in check and urging France to cut its deficit faster.

Mr McCreevy rejected that the Irish budget was too loose, claiming that as it was running a healthy surplus of spending over revenue, Dublin's plans posed no threat to the health of other EU economies.

"We are running very, very large budget surpluses and setting aside substantial sums to fund future pensions, while at the same time our public expenditure levels per capita are significantly below that of other EU countries," he said to the meeting. "It is very difficult for me, in the light of the comparative performance of the Irish economy, to see that any recommendation is warranted."

Ireland is the fastest growing member of the EU, with output expanding at annual rate of 12%. Until recently it also had the highest inflation rate in the EU, but data released on Friday showed that it had fallen back to 3.9% on the EU-harmonised basis.

The commission fears that a loose budgetary stance will add to price pressures in the republic. "The Irish budget for 2001 is expansionary and pro-cyclical and therefore inconsistent with the [EU's] 2000 broad guidelines of the economic policies," the recommendation said.

One EU diplomat told the Guardian that by censuring Ireland in such a public fashion the single currency was now beginning to come of age. "This is the first time ever the euro group has publicly rebuked a member state for its economic policy and it shows that it has got teeth. If you are in the club you have to abide by the rules whether you like them or not. This was a test of the eurozone's credibility and it passed."

Yesterday's reprimand of Ireland is seen as a test of the commission's abilities to constrain euro members' budget policies. Brussels audits the economies of all EU members annually whether they are in the single currency or not.

Britain was told that its underlying budget position could deteriorate because of planned increases in public spending. But Gordon Brown said that Labour's spending increases were "prudent and cautious".

webTitle: Bankers seek keen price in Orange flotation

fields.headline: Bankers seek keen price in Orange flotation
fields.trailText: Bankers handling the Orange share sale were last night pushing for an offer price at the bottom of the indicated range, hoping a low price would stimulate demand in the weakened telecoms market.
fields.body:
Bankers handling the Orange share sale were last night pushing for an offer price at the bottom of the indicated range, hoping a low price would stimulate demand in the weakened telecoms market.

After months of planning, the company's advisers and management were locked in a meeting expected to last into the early hours to decide on a strike price that would ensure a successful flotation.

Bankers and advisers refused to give any indication of the price level being considered, but it is understood to be at the bottom of the already reduced range of €9.5 to €11.

Insiders believe the shares will reach the market this morning at €10.

Hopes of hitting the top end of the range were dashed late last week when rival Vodafone's shares hit a two-year low. France Télécom - Orange's parent company - yesterday dropped 1% to €82, its lowest level in 16 months.

webTitle: City diary: Richard Adams

fields.headline: City diary: Richard Adams
fields.trailText: • It's wonderful news that Paul O'Neill, George Bush's choice as US Treasury secretary, has sailed through his confirmation hearings. Let's hear no more nonsense about him being ignorant of Wall Street's workings or the rigours of modern finance. After all, running aluminium smelters (O'Neill's last job) is much like being in charge of the world's largest economy . . . isn't it? So ignore rumours suggesting O'Neill is merely a cipher given the job because he could twist the arm of his old pal Alan Greenspan to support Bush's tax-cutting bonanza - or that the real policy powerhouse will be Lawrence Lindsey, the former Federal Reserve governor who is certainly not waiting to get the 74-year-old Greenspan's job. One can tell O'Neill is a major player because of the quality of staff the administration is considering for him: on the list for press secretary is Tim Goeglein, a member of the swivel-eyed extreme right. Goeglein's credentials include being press adviser to Gary Bauer, the doomed right-wing loon who ran for the Republican nomination last year and who was so right wing that even Ron and Nancy Reagan used to tell him to calm down.

One can tell O'Neill is a major player because of the quality of staff the administration is considering for him: on the list for press secretary is Tim Goeglein, a member of the swivel-eyed extreme right. Goeglein's credentials include being press adviser to Gary Bauer, the doomed right-wing loon who ran for the Republican nomination last year and who was so right wing that even Ron and Nancy Reagan used to tell him to calm down.

 The world of hype is agog (one imagines) for the first release from the end product of the Popstars television series. The ITV proto-band's first single is not to be released until next month - and it would be a shame to spoil the build-up. Sadly, anyone with access to the Napster internet music sharing program can already download and hear the single: just search for Inner Spin (the band's new name) and the title, Pure and Simple. Better hurry, though, before a court in California declares the whole thing illegal.

 The phones were out of order at Brunswick - the PR company that is to the City what lint is to pockets (annoying and hard to get rid of) - for most of yesterday. Net productivity in the City soared as a result. (If anyone at Cable & Wireless fancies making £50 in return for cutting them off again, give me a call.)

 Clara Furse, the crazy, fun-lovin', wacky new head of the London stock exchange, says she's thinking about a new name for the poisoned chalice/venerable institution. What she's looking for is something that projects a forward-looking brand of dynamism. Something that is associated with global success and has strong European links. How about: Deutsche Börse?

 Animal cruelty is a terrible thing, of course, but one often has to be cruel to be kind. That's why City loft-style apartment dwellers will be keen to snap up the Bonzai Kitten, now available over the internet (www.bonzaikitten.com), where specially raised cats are kept in jars during their early growth phase to ensure they remain cute and cuddly right into adulthood. "The flexibility of the kitten's skeleton means that if the bones are gently warped at this early age," reads the website, "they can be molded into any desired shape." It is of course a spoof run by students at MIT in Boston, but (according to Wired magazine) the FBI has fallen for it and have presented the university with a grand jury subpoena demanding information about who runs the site.

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Rich expected to get richer
fields.body:
Rich expected to get richer

Britain's wealthy can look forward to getting considerably wealthier this year, according to research published yesterday.

Assets of Britain's private wealth management market are projected to grow 11% this year with continued low unemployment, the probability of lower interest rates and rising earnings looking set to maintain the growth trend, research by US investment bank Fox-Pitt, Kelton showed.

The double-digit growth forecast comes in spite of pressure on fee margins, fears of a fallout from US economic slowdown and uncertainty over the direction of financial markets.

ScottishPower hires CSFB

Electricity firm ScottishPower yesterday said it has appointed an investment bank to look at overhauling its Southern Water subsidiary.

But the company dismissed suggestions that the move could lead to the sale of the business.

The group said it had appointed Credit Suisse First Boston to advise on the refinancing and restructuring of Southern Water. But ScottishPower rejected reports that CSFB was also advising on a possible sale of the business in a deal that could be worth more than £1bn.

Daewoo sheds Worthing jobs

Daewoo is to shed a further 187 jobs at its UK technical centre in Worthing, west Sussex. The site employed 750 workers before the South Korean parent company went bankrupt. The cuts will take effect immediately and will reduce the workforce by 40%, leaving 250 employees. Daewoo is thought to be close to selling the Worthing centre but has refused to confirm speculation that it is negotiating with engineering and motor racing group TWR.

Agip wins deal in Kazakhstan

Agip, a division of Italian energy group ENI, has won operation of Kazakhstan's Kashagan oilfield, one of the world's largest untapped oil finds, an industry source said yesterday. The source was speaking after a meeting of the Offshore Kazakhstan International Operating Company to decide which of the consortium should become operator. The Kazakh government has yet to announce the winner officially.

Outlook bright for AG Barr

Scottish soft drinks manufacturer AG Barr said yesterday it expected pre-tax profit for the year to January 27 to exceed £13.5m thanks to strong trading.

Barra Global Estimates forecast Barr's pre-tax profit at between £12m-£12.9m. The stock rose after the announcement and closed up 21.5p at 422.5p.

IT boost lifts Thales sales

Thales, the defence electronics group, yesterday reported that sales soared 24.5% to €8.58bn last year, mainly as a result of a last quarter recovery by its IT and services operation. Thomson-CSF, the French defence company, renamed itself Thales after its £1.4bn takeover of Racal last year. It has since formed an air defence radar joint venture with the US defence group Raytheon.

webTitle: Diary: Matthew Norman

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: In the whole saga so far, nothing captivates like the untold story of Mandy Mandelson's departure that Wednesday after he had sat stoically at Mr Tony Blair's side during PM's Questions.
fields.body:
 In the whole saga so far, nothing captivates like the untold story of Mandy Mandelson's departure that Wednesday after he had sat stoically at Mr Tony Blair's side during PM's Questions. As Mandy left the chamber, Gordon Brown rushed up to express his deep regrets about this "tragedy", adding an apparently heartfelt "if there's anything - anything at all - I can do ..."

I know you're already thinking this is cobblers, and normally I'd be the first to agree. But these New Labour relationships are infinitely more complex than we tend to appreciate: when Mandy was last sacked (and whether altruistically or not) Gordon was on the phone ceaselessly for a couple of days offering succour; and recently Mandy was overheard at lunch gently chiding a friend for not fully appreciating Gordon's intellect and trying to get close to him.

This time, Gordon looked close to tears (honestly) as Mandy headed for his car, and even ran after it to deliver further consolation. The problem with bulletproof cars is that the windows do not go down, and off Mandy went. No snub was intended, however. Far from it, it would be very foolish for anyone to rule out a once unthinkable rapprochement, however secretively conducted. We shall see, we shall see.

 And the warmest of welcomes to William Rees-Mogg, who announces himself in the Times as the latest recruit to the planet's smallest and most futile guerrilla movement - the Hartlepool One Liberation Army (Hola!). In strict sooth, William's arrival is not what the soothsayers of ancient Rome would have viewed as a violently promising omen, his reputation for backing losers rivalling even my sane and rational friend Paul Johnson's. Still, the fact that he has almost always been wrong doesn't mean that he's inevitably wrong this time. Not inevitably. That's how we're looking at it, anyway. Hola, Moggie!

 Further suggestions from those Moggie calls "slimy" anonymous creatures at No 10 that Mandy is doolally force a decision concerning my friend Alastair Campbell. Finally, regrettably, the gloves must come off. An Ali Mental Health Special is being put together now and will appear here tomorrow.

 Confusion creeps into the Times's report on the hilarious party to celebrate the Press Complaints Commission's 10th birthday. There was no such thing as an A and B list for editors, it claims, with only those editors who sit on the PCC getting introduced to Prince William.

In fact Piers Morgan and David Yelland were presented (two minutes later, poor David was complaining about being snubbed; bless him, he'd already forgotten the whole thing!), and neither is on the PCC. Coincidentally, Times guv'nor Peter Stothard was not introduced. Nor, more curiously, was Telegraph boss Charles Moore.

 I am overjoyed to learn that my sniffly friend Michael Howard, whose frequent and severe colds remain such a constant worry to his mother Hilda and me, will be standing again at the next election for Folkestone. Michael is continuing with his political career, we hear, in the strong belief that there may yet be an important role for "a big hitter" like him (he always loved his baseball) at the top of the Tory party. He actually believes that. No really, he does. The sweetness.

 We hope Uri Geller enjoyed himself at the bar mitzvah party at Claridges he went to recently, even if he did have to perform. The bar mitzvah boy's father has just received an email from the hotel's deputy banqueting manager. "Just to warn you that included in the bill for the Jaraj event here will be a charge for cutlery that was ruined by Mr Geller," writes Joe Flattery. "There were approx 30 pieces that we cannot use again, and I will include them on the bill."

webTitle: Gynaecologist on indecent assault charges

fields.headline: Gynaecologist on indecent assault charges
fields.trailText: A long-serving gynaecologist with a large private practice was charged yesterday with 33 indecent assaults on 23 women over the past two decades.
fields.body:
A long-serving gynaecologist with a large private practice was charged yesterday with 33 indecent assaults on 23 women over the past two decades.

Paul Vinall, 53, who was suspended last July following a complaint from a former patient, was bailed to appear before magistrates in Leeds next month.

He was arrested and questioned by West Yorkshire police shortly after his sus pension, which applied to both his NHS contract in Leeds and private work. The Medical Protection Society issued a statement at the time saying that Mr Vinall was shocked and added: "He has done nothing wrong and looks forward to assisting with this investigation."

The charges followed more than 100 calls to an NHS helpline set up in August, although a considerable number of these were from patients offering the consultant their support. Others, how ever, led within a month to further investigations, said Det Chief Supt Grahame Bullock, the head of the inquiry.

Police also seized documents from files on more than 1,500 patients of Mr Vinall, who was a sought-after consultant in the Leeds area. He also paid regular visits to the Falkland Islands on medical work and had just returned from his 13th spell there in six years, on top of several emergency visits, when he was arrested.

A spokesman for West Yorkshire police said yesterday: "We can confirm that Mr Vinall has been charged with 33 offences of indecent assault against 23 complainants. The NHS and private health care providers have cooperated fully with the investigation. Anyone with any concerns should get in touch with the NHS helpline - 0113 206 8888."

The doctor, who is married with two children, was charged at Chapeltown police station in Leeds on a regular visit to answer the bail imposed after his arrest.

webTitle: Occult obsessed loner stabbed boy, 12

fields.headline: How loner's obsession with occult led to fatal stabbing
fields.trailText: A row of dilapidated swings is the only sign that Phoenix gardens in central London was intended as a children's playground. The grounds, in the courtyard of St Giles's church, Covent Garden, are a haven for drug addicts who hide in the bushes to shoot up.
fields.body:
A row of dilapidated swings is the only sign that Phoenix gardens in central London was intended as a children's playground. The grounds, in the courtyard of St Giles's church, Covent Garden, are a haven for drug addicts who hide in the bushes to shoot up.

It was here that 12-year-old Diego Piniero-Villar befriended Edward Alexander Crowley, a drifter four times his age, nearly two years ago.

According to Diego's mother, her son took pity on Crowley, 52, when other children started throwing stones at him. It was a kindness which cost him his life.

Diego could not have known the scruffy man carrying a plastic bag had a long history of mental illness and that he had developed an obsession with the occult.

Crowley's and Diego's relationship started with conversations by the swings and trips to play games at a local arcade, and were followed with visits to the swimming baths. Crowley bought Diego gifts and treats such as hamburgers, and for a while the schoolboy seemed flattered by the attention.

Police have never found any evidence that Crowley abused Diego, but the relationship was uncomfortably physical; it involved play-fights in which Crowley licked his ear and tickled his navel.

Diego appears to have kept their friendship a secret until the summer of 1999, when his mother became suspicious and contacted police. Officers were already on the case. Crowley had come to their attention in June that year, when residents reported seeing him approach children at Phoenix gardens.

In September 1999, Crowley went to Holborn police station to confess he was having a relationship with a 12-year-old boy, which he described as "loving but not primarily sexual". He then retracted the claim.

The subsequent investigation disturbed officers; a psychiatric nurse concluded Crowley was "a definite risk to young boys", and Diego's mother told them she had received calls from an anonymous man asking for her son. The boy, who by this time was unhappy with Crowley's attentions, was interviewed but gave no evidence of sexual abuse.

When detectives went to Phoenix gardens, they found messages painted with correction fluid on the swing seats. "I will always love you, Diego," stated one. "Please forgive me for everything. I couldn't stand the pain. One day you'll know how much you hurt me. How much I need you."

Another, dated November 2 1999, read: "Always cheat others before they cheat you - if they are clever enough. I wasn't and I wouldn't want to be."

It was addressed to "Bravo, mi chico Latino".

Crowley was arrested on November 3 on suspicion of indecently assaulting Diego, but released almost immediately for lack of evidence.

Crowley was not put off. On December 6, he went to Canada Blanch, the independent school Diego attended in west London, and painted in Spanish and English, this message across three doors. "Why did you cheat me Diego? Why all the lies? I should hate you but I don't. Alex."

He was arrested outside the school, and appeared before Marylebone magistrates the following day to plead guilty to causing criminal damage. He was given a two-year conditional discharge and released back on the streets.

Diego was clearly at risk. He was given a police mobile phone, enabling him to dial 999. Patrols around the school were stepped up and his step-father Juan Fernandez began escorting him to west London.

A few days later, Crowley was charged with harassment and remanded in custody by Highbury magistrates for mental health assessment. According to Camden council, a forensic psychiatrist who saw Crowley in prison concluded he was "dangerous and should be detained".

On March 20, three and a half months after his arrest, the CPS went back to magistrates and admitted the case was not ready to go to crown court for trial. Despite the objections of the police, district judge Dorothy Quick granted Crowley bail on strict conditions.

A charge of gross indecency was dropped a week later.

Crowley was ordered not to contact Diego, attend the boy's home or school, or go to Phoenix gardens. He was also to report daily at a police station, though this was relaxed after two weeks. Neither the police nor social services knew where he was. Crowley was not on medication and he was not under supervision from social services.

Mentally unstable and bearing a grudge which had festered in prison over 14 weeks, Crowley sought revenge.

On the evening of May 7, Diego's stepfather asked Diego and his stepbrother Roberto, 15, to run an errand.

As they passed Phoenix gardens at 8pm, they were confronted by Crowley, who was armed with a kitchen knife. He slashed the older boy, then turned on Diego, who managed to dial 999 on his mobile phone. The operator only heard his screams as he was stabbed more than 20 times. Diego was pronounced dead on arrival at St Thomas's hospital.

After the murder, police began to unravel Crowley's past and his fascination with the occult. They discovered his name was not Crowley. He was born Henry Allen Bibby in Middlesbrough in 1948, and had spent most of his adult life jobless and drifting. His medical records showed he had tried to commit suicide by drugs overdose on at least seven occasions.

His fascination with the occult can be traced from 1998, when he changed his name by deed poll to Edward Alexander Crowley, apparently in honour of the black arts magician Aleister Crowley, who styled himself "the wickedest man alive" and "the Beast". Aleister Crowley was born Edward Alexander Crowley and he died in 1947.

On one of the websites dedicated to the magician, police found the quote: "A male child of perfect innocence and high intelligence is the most satisfactory and suitable victim."

When Crowley was arrested after the murder, police officers found in his bag a piece of folded paper covered in references to child sacrifice in religion, black magic and classical myth. The Latin words "Delendus est D.Piniero - "Piniero must be destroyed" - were at the top of the page.

The boy, who by this time was unhappy with Crowley's attentions, was interviewed but gave no evidence of sexual abuse. When detectives went to Phoenix gardens, they found messages painted with correction fluid on the swing seats. "I will always love you, Diego," stated one. "Please forgive me for everything. I couldn't stand the pain. One day you'll know how much you hurt me. How much I need you." Another, dated November 2 1999, read: "Always cheat others before they cheat you - if they are clever enough. I wasn't and I wouldn't want to be." It was addressed to "Bravo, mi chico Latino". Crowley was arrested on November 3 on suspicion of indecently assaulting Diego, but released almost immediately for lack of evidence. Crowley was not put off. On December 6, he went to Canada Blanch, the independent school Diego attended in west London, and painted in Spanish and English, this message across three doors. "Why did you cheat me Diego? Why all the lies? I should hate you but I don't. Alex." He was arrested outside the school, and appeared before Marylebone magistrates the following day to plead guilty to causing criminal damage. He was given a two-year conditional discharge and released back on the streets. Diego was clearly at risk. He was given a police mobile phone, enabling him to dial 999. Patrols around the school were stepped up and his step-father Juan Fernandez began escorting him to west London. A few days later, Crowley was charged with harassment and remanded in custody by Highbury magistrates for mental health assessment. According to Camden council, a forensic psychiatrist who saw Crowley in prison concluded he was "dangerous and should be detained". On March 20, three and a half months after his arrest, the CPS went back to magistrates and admitted the case was not ready to go to crown court for trial. Despite the objections of the police, district judge Dorothy Quick granted Crowley bail on strict conditions. A charge of gross indecency was dropped a week later. Crowley was ordered not to contact Diego, attend the boy's home or school, or go to Phoenix gardens. He was also to report daily at a police station, though this was relaxed after two weeks. Neither the police nor social services knew where he was. Crowley was not on medication and he was not under supervision from social services. Mentally unstable and bearing a grudge which had festered in prison over 14 weeks, Crowley sought revenge. On the evening of May 7, Diego's stepfather asked Diego and his stepbrother Roberto, 15, to run an errand. As they passed Phoenix gardens at 8pm, they were confronted by Crowley, who was armed with a kitchen knife. He slashed the older boy, then turned on Diego, who managed to dial 999 on his mobile phone. The operator only heard his screams as he was stabbed more than 20 times. Diego was pronounced dead on arrival at St Thomas's hospital. After the murder, police began to unravel Crowley's past and his fascination with the occult. They discovered his name was not Crowley. He was born Henry Allen Bibby in Middlesbrough in 1948, and had spent most of his adult life jobless and drifting. His medical records showed he had tried to commit suicide by drugs overdose on at least seven occasions. His fascination with the occult can be traced from 1998, when he changed his name by deed poll to Edward Alexander Crowley, apparently in honour of the black arts magician Aleister Crowley, who styled himself "the wickedest man alive" and "the Beast". Aleister Crowley was born Edward Alexander Crowley and he died in 1947. On one of the websites dedicated to the magician, police found the quote: "A male child of perfect innocence and high intelligence is the most satisfactory and suitable victim." When Crowley was arrested after the murder, police officers found in his bag a piece of folded paper covered in references to child sacrifice in religion, black magic and classical myth. The Latin words "Delendus est D.Piniero - "Piniero must be destroyed" - were at the top of the page.

webTitle: Mentally ill stalker jailed for killing boy

fields.headline: Mentally ill stalker gets life for killing boy
fields.standfirst: Inquiry launched into why drifter remanded on charges of harassing 12-year-old had been released without supervision
fields.trailText: Inquiry launched into why drifter remanded on charges of harassing 12-year-old had been released without supervision.
fields.body:
A mentally ill man obsessed with child sacrifice was sentenced to life in prison yesterday for the murder of a boy of 12 in Covent Garden in London.

Alex Crowley, 52, who had a severe personality disorder, had stalked Diego Piniero-Villar, then hunted him down and stabbed him more than 20 times last May.

Moments before sentence was passed, Diego's mother, Angela, and two female relatives screamed death threats at Crowley and hurled cups of water at the dock before being hustled from the Old Bailey courtroom.

The court heard that Crowley, a homeless man, had formed an obsessive friendship with the boy in the year before his death, but this had gone sour after Diego had tried to break off their relationship.

He was held in Pentonville prison for more than three months on remand over harassment charges but not brought to trial, and was eventually released on to the streets without supervision.

Crowley, who had changed his name to that of the magician of the black arts, Aleister Crowley, was fascinated by the occult and appears to have planned to perform a "child sacrifice".

An independent review was under way last night into why Crowley was permitted to go near Diego again. It will look at the roles played by police, the crown prosecution service and the social services.

Crowley is not thought to have sexually abused Diego, but this will be looked at in the inquiry by a forensic psychologist and a former civil servant.

Neither the CPS nor the police has explained why it took so long to conclude the investigation of the harassment of the boy. "Crowley had been charged with harassment, but the custody time limit ran out," said a CPS source.

"The police needed more time to gather evidence. It's not right to say the case had been dropped.

"Once he was out on bail there was no way of forcing him to have further psychiatric assessments.

Crowley seems to have benefited from a loophole in the Mental Health Act which distinguishes between the care of people diagnosed with personality disorders and the care of people who are deemed psychotic.

While on remand, he was assessed by a forensic psychiatrist who concluded that he "has a personality disorder and is dangerous ... he should be detained".

However, the law states that a personality disorder is untreatable, and that sufferers cannot be compelled to have treatment.

"We offered him help before his arrest, during his time in custody, and after his arrest," said a spokesman for Camden social services. "He refused us every time. We could not legally force him to have treatment and he was adamant that he didn't want it.

"This is a problem area, and one that needs to be addressed with changes to the law."

Camden said it first learned of concerns about Crowley at a case conference on Diego held with the police in autumn 1999.

The drifter was not on the sex offenders register - he had no paedophile convictions - and he had not been referred to the council for treatment.

"The police told us about the stalking, but it was decided they should take responsibility for protecting the boy. They were quite happy to do so. There didn't seem to be real concern that he was in genuine danger at that point."

The report from the forensic psychiatrist who concluded Crowley was "dangerous and should be detained" was presented to court at a bail hearing last March when he was released from custody.

"Our advice was, unfortunately, not taken by the magis trate," said the council spokesman.

After his arrest for murder, Crowley's mental health history was reviewed by a psychiatrist who decided that he had been suffering from paranoid schizophrenia since the 1970s.

Crowley continues to deny that he is mentally ill - claiming he "fabricated symptoms" when assessed - and has asked to be sent to prison rather than to a secure psychiatric hospital.

The government is proposing to close the loophole in mental health legislation to make it possible to treat people with severe mental health disorder "either in their own best interests or to protect the wider public". But the proposals, published as a white paper in December, are unlikely to become law in this parliament.

Michael Howlett, director of the Zito Trust, said yesterday: "I think it is absolutely inexcusable that this tragedy was allowed to happen. It's pretty clear to me that this should have been picked up.

"We're talking about a young boy losing his life to somebody who has got this kind of history and is already going through the system.

"The government has told us that there are 400-500 people in the community with dangerous, severe personality disorders."

webTitle: Boy, 13, killed baby

fields.headline: Boy, 13, killed baby after row with mother
fields.trailText: A 13-year-old boy yesterday admitted killing his six-month-old brother by repeatedly stabbing him and cutting off his left hand as he lay in his cot.
fields.body:
A 13-year-old boy yesterday admitted killing his six-month-old brother by repeatedly stabbing him and cutting off his left hand as he lay in his cot.

The boy, who had a "wretched" upbringing and cannot be named for legal reasons, attacked the baby after an argument with his mother in January last year. He stabbed his half-brother 17 times in his face, neck and back. He then changed his blood-stained clothes and walked into a police station in Bristol and told officers he had stabbed his brother. He said he thought the baby may be dead and then produced a kitchen knife.

Bristol crown court was told that the boy, who was aged 12 when he killed his brother, had been brought up in circumstances of serious deprivation. He suffers from Asperger's syndrome, a mild form of autism.

When police went to his home, in the Withywood district of the city, they found his mother unaware of what had happened. They subsequently discovered the baby in his cot with stab wounds to his face, neck and back. One of the wounds had severed the baby's spinal cord.

Efforts to revive him failed and he was taken to a local hospital, where he was pronounced dead.

In a police interview, the boy said he got the knife out of a kitchen drawer to hurt the baby - but he didn't know why. Asked why he had done it, he replied: "I want to be with my mum."

Yesterday Roderick Denyer QC, prosecuting, accepted the boy's plea of guilty to manslaughter by reason of diminished responsibility. He had denied murder. The boy was detained in secure custody pending sentence.

Mr Denyer said the baby had been put back into his cot at 1pm with his bottle. The boy and his mother had argued and she had told him that he could not go out.

When the baby woke up his mother told the boy to give him a bottle and he went upstairs to his cot. After stabbing him he sneaked out of the house while his mother dozed on a settee with one of her other young children.

"Having stabbed the baby in the neck and face, he clearly turned him over," said Mr Denyer. "The wound through the spine would have required a significant degree of force even with a sharp-tipped knife and he couldn't have severed the hand without looking."

Lady Helena Kennedy QC, defending, said it was clear that it was not a cold act of malevolence. "It was the act of a boy who is still a child and was brought up in circumstances of serious deprivation and, at the time of the killing, was mentally ill," she said.

She said the boy's mother had been neglected by her own parents - including her father who was mentally ill and had abused his daughter and other children. She had been sexually abused while in care and her partners went on to abuse her and her children.

Lady Kennedy said Asperger's syndrome combined with the boy's social conditions led to a psychotic episode during which he stabbed the baby. Three psychiatrists who examined the boy decided that he had Asperger's syndrome.

"The family was permanently on the move," she added. "By any standards his existence was wretched."

Mr Justice Toulson adjourned sentence while suitable secure accommodation was found for the boy.

He told him: "You killed your baby brother in a terrible fit of violence. What caused you to behave this way lies inside you - you are very disturbed."

At an earlier hearing the judge described the boy as having an unfortunate and genuine history of adverse psycho-socio factors.

David Archer, chief crown prosecutor for Avon and Somerset, said they decided to accept the boy's plea of guilty to manslaughter rather than proceed with a murder trial.

He said it was unlikely that the boy would have been well enough to face such a trial for many months or years and such a course would have breached his human rights.

Detective Chief Inspector Paul Moody, of Avon and Somerset police, described it as a tragic case for everyone concerned. "Officers have been offered counselling and have worked closely with the family. Our thoughts go out to them," he said.

Social services in Bristol said an investigation was under way to see if any agency involved could have averted the tragedy. They were working with the family at the time, but the child had given no earlier cause for concern.

Asperger's sufferers obsessive about sticking to routines

Asperger's syndrome is a mild form of autism which affects up to 200,000 people in the UK. It is very unusual for sufferers to become violent, according to Richard Mills of the National Autistic Society.

Young children with the syndrome may become upset by sudden changes to routine and adults could become extremely anxious by an unexpected delay, such as a traffic jam.

Sufferers are exceptionally sensitive to the difference between right and wrong and are usually extremely law abiding.

Asperger's syndrome is a neuro-biological condition named after Hans Asperger, the Austrian paediatrician who first recognised it in the 1940s. Twenty years ago it was virtually unheard of, but now experts believe it is widespread and may affect between one in 100 and one in 2,000 people.

There is evidence of a genetic component in a complex neurological condition with multiple causes. People with the condition display impairments, also present in autism, which affect behaviour, communication and imagination.

People with the syndrome are often high achievers. They find socialising and small talk difficult, though they are good at absorbing facts. They find it hard to glean what others are thinking, can focus for long periods and have unusually strong, narrow interests.

webTitle: Comment: They killed my father

fields.headline: They killed my father
fields.standfirst:
Michael Finucane on the anniversary of a murder which is still the source of explosive scandal

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Michael Finucane on the anniversary of a murder which is still the source of explosive scandal.
fields.body:
How would you feel if you knew the government was responsible for murdering a member of your family? Would you do anything about it? Would you just get on with things as best you could and try not to think about it, or would you spend years struggling to get enough worldwide support to make the government at least admit what it did?

My father, Patrick, was a practising solicitor in Northern Ireland for 11 years before he was murdered, and I believe the British government was responsible. On Sunday February 12 1989, armed gunmen broke into my family home, ran to the kitchen where we were eating dinner, and shot my dad 14 times in front of my mother, my sister and brother.

I can still remember it clearly. It is an image seared into my mind. The thing I remember most vividly is the noise; the reports of each bullet reverberating in the kitchen, how my grip on my younger brother and sister tightened with every shot. It's not a memory I care to visit very often, but it's there. I expect it always will be.

Throughout his career, my father was the subject of intimidation and harassment from RUC officers. Detectives made threats, communicated to him by clients he represented. They began as snide comments about his legal ability or general personal insults, but escalated before long into death threats.

A typical example was: "He is a thug in a suit, a person trying to let on he is doing his job, and ... he, like every other fenian [Catholic] bastard, would meet his end." The detective continued, "He is a dead man. He'll be dead within three months."

The officer proved right. Not long after, Douglas Hogg, then a junior Home Office minister, said during a Commons debate on January 17 1989: "I have to state as a fact, but with great regret, that there are in Northern Ireland a number of solicitors who are unduly sympathetic to the cause of the IRA."

Seamus Mallon MP (now deputy first minister of the Northern Ireland assembly) realised immediately the potential consequences. When challenged by him, Hogg replied, "I state it on the basis of advice that I have received, guidance that I have been given by people who are dealing with these matters, and I shall not expand on it further."

The "people dealing with these matters" were the RUC. They had given this information to Hogg at a private briefing. Given his position at the time, what he said can only be viewed as a British government statement. In the intense atmosphere of Northern Ireland his comments were perceived as highly inflammatory, and perhaps that is exactly what they intended.

The RUC were well placed to know. One of their informants was a member of the Ulster Defence Association (UDA), the loyalist gang that carried out my father's murder. William Stobie was eventually arrested for the murder in 1999, but he said: "Not guilty of the charge that you have put to me tonight. At the time I was a police informer for Special Branch. On the night of the death of Patrick Finucane I informed special branch on two occasions by telephone of a person who was to be shot." Despite the warning, the RUC had done nothing.

Stobie had already been questioned about the murder back in 1990 and gave a detailed account of his involvement to the RUC at that time. It was decided not to prosecute him. During the current case against Stobie, a lawyer for the crown said in court that that decision by the DPP had been taken "at the highest level".

But the RUC may even have played a lesser role compared to the involvement of the army. A secret branch of army intelligence services, the force research unit (FRU) was infiltrating agents into loyalist paramilitary groups in order to control and direct their killings. FRU was established in 1982. Its purpose, according to its former commander, Col Gordon Kerr, was "in order that we can save life, that we can prevent attacks taking place, that we can prevent assassinations, that we can make arrests, that we can get recoveries of weapons and explosives ..."

FRU's agent in the group that murdered my father was named Brian Nelson. One of the first thing his handlers did after his infiltration in 1987 was to take away all his files and return them fully updated. This was easy: they were able to make use of all of the state's intelligence when doing so. Nelson, assisted by updated intelligence information, provided the UDA with method and means to carry out murders, selected specific targets, and guided the trigger men accordingly. Nelson himself has said information he was given included British army documents and photographs.

Former FRU soldiers and officials (including the former Northern Ireland secretary, Tom King) have maintained the falsehood about the purpose of the FRU. However, confidential FRU files that have made their way into the public domain paint a different picture. One document dated May 3 1988, states: "6137 [Nelson] wants the UDA only to attack legitimate targets and not innocent Catholics. Since 6137 took up his position as intelligence officer, the targeting has developed and is now more professional."

Another, dated February 6 1989, states: "6137 initiates most of the targeting. Of late, 6137 has been more organised and he is currently running an operation against selected republican targets." Six days later, my father was murdered.

What FRU were doing was carrying out a government policy that authorised the use of the army to direct assassinations. They had a job to do, and they did it. One former officer, known by the pseudonym "Martin Ingram" says the work of FRU was highly organised and controlled. In a Belfast newspaper, he wrote: "I was told on more than one occasion 'the ends justified the means' and the 'right' people were allowed to live and the 'wrong' people were not. The practice of presiding as a judge, jury and executioner is wrong and regrettably I cannot say the mindset of some individuals has changed to this day."

Brian Nelson was eventually arrested by a team of detectives investigating RUC collusion with loyalists, led by Sir John Stevens, (now commissioner of the Metropolitan police). Nelson received a 10-year sentence on 23 charges ranging from conspiracy to murder (my father's murder was not one of them) to collecting information for terrorist purposes. He served four and a half. Colonel Gordon Kerr was awarded a military OBE in 1991. He is currently the British military attache to Beijing.

To dwell on the role of people like Brian Nelson and Martin Ingram is to miss the point as to why Patrick Finucane was murdered. It happened because he was a determined and innovative lawyer, and not, as the RUC and others claim, because he was involved in paramilitary activity. Both the RUC and the British government had a powerful motivation. He was among the first to bring the RUC and the army to court when they broke the law. He was among the first to successfully take the government to the European court of human rights over its practices in Northern Ireland.

He was among the first to use the law to show that even in a situation of conflict, the law still applies. It is because he was prepared to do all of this that he became the first solicitor to be murdered.When the British government had to decide between preserving the status quo and putting up with some uppity Catholic lawyer, the choice was simple: the lawyer had to go.

My family does not regard the prosecution of the killers as the main concern in all of this. They were simply pawns in a bigger game. Our goal is a public, independent international inquiry into all the circumstances. We have gained the support of the UN, the US Congress, the Irish government, the European parliament, and others.

We are supported by every major human rights organisation in the world, from Amnesty International to the International Federation of Human Rights. The notable absentee is the British government, and it is there that ultimate responsibility lies.

The state machinery that murdered Patrick Finucane was not established to kill one man. Others died too, and the question that has to be answered is, how many? It was this point that my family urged upon the prime minister at a private meeting last September. A third police investigation by Sir John Stevens - the prime minister's preferred option - will simply not do.

Many people who still live in Northern Ireland were unaware of how precarious their existence was, and did not realise that for many years each of them was considered expendable. But they are aware of it now and they want to know the truth. How will the peace process ever succeed if it is kept hidden? Tony Blair's administration may not have been responsible for what took place but, by frustrating a proper inquiry, it has become part of the problem.

It has taken 12 years to uncover what you have just read. Instead of devoting resources toward the search for a peaceful solution, the government was obsessed with securing the defeat of republican paramilitaries, whatever the cost. They armed and assisted loyalists in order to do so. One line after another was crossed and, eventually, the line between right and wrong disappeared completely. Neither the law of the land nor human life itself was respected. This was your government's policy. If it had happened in Britain, there would be an outcry. But it happened in Northern Ireland, so no one cared.
