A typical example was: "He is a thug in a suit, a person trying to let on he is doing his job, and ... he, like every other fenian [Catholic] bastard, would meet his end." The detective continued, "He is a dead man. He'll be dead within three months." The officer proved right. Not long after, Douglas Hogg, then a junior Home Office minister, said during a Commons debate on January 17 1989: "I have to state as a fact, but with great regret, that there are in Northern Ireland a number of solicitors who are unduly sympathetic to the cause of the IRA." Seamus Mallon MP (now deputy first minister of the Northern Ireland assembly) realised immediately the potential consequences. When challenged by him, Hogg replied, "I state it on the basis of advice that I have received, guidance that I have been given by people who are dealing with these matters, and I shall not expand on it further." The "people dealing with these matters" were the RUC. They had given this information to Hogg at a private briefing. Given his position at the time, what he said can only be viewed as a British government statement. In the intense atmosphere of Northern Ireland his comments were perceived as highly inflammatory, and perhaps that is exactly what they intended. The RUC were well placed to know. One of their informants was a member of the Ulster Defence Association (UDA), the loyalist gang that carried out my father's murder. William Stobie was eventually arrested for the murder in 1999, but he said: "Not guilty of the charge that you have put to me tonight. At the time I was a police informer for Special Branch. On the night of the death of Patrick Finucane I informed special branch on two occasions by telephone of a person who was to be shot." Despite the warning, the RUC had done nothing. Stobie had already been questioned about the murder back in 1990 and gave a detailed account of his involvement to the RUC at that time. It was decided not to prosecute him. During the current case against Stobie, a lawyer for the crown said in court that that decision by the DPP had been taken "at the highest level". But the RUC may even have played a lesser role compared to the involvement of the army. A secret branch of army intelligence services, the force research unit (FRU) was infiltrating agents into loyalist paramilitary groups in order to control and direct their killings. FRU was established in 1982. Its purpose, according to its former commander, Col Gordon Kerr, was "in order that we can save life, that we can prevent attacks taking place, that we can prevent assassinations, that we can make arrests, that we can get recoveries of weapons and explosives ..." FRU's agent in the group that murdered my father was named Brian Nelson. One of the first thing his handlers did after his infiltration in 1987 was to take away all his files and return them fully updated. This was easy: they were able to make use of all of the state's intelligence when doing so. Nelson, assisted by updated intelligence information, provided the UDA with method and means to carry out murders, selected specific targets, and guided the trigger men accordingly. Nelson himself has said information he was given included British army documents and photographs. Former FRU soldiers and officials (including the former Northern Ireland secretary, Tom King) have maintained the falsehood about the purpose of the FRU. However, confidential FRU files that have made their way into the public domain paint a different picture. One document dated May 3 1988, states: "6137 [Nelson] wants the UDA only to attack legitimate targets and not innocent Catholics. Since 6137 took up his position as intelligence officer, the targeting has developed and is now more professional." Another, dated February 6 1989, states: "6137 initiates most of the targeting. Of late, 6137 has been more organised and he is currently running an operation against selected republican targets." Six days later, my father was murdered. What FRU were doing was carrying out a government policy that authorised the use of the army to direct assassinations. They had a job to do, and they did it. One former officer, known by the pseudonym "Martin Ingram" says the work of FRU was highly organised and controlled. In a Belfast newspaper, he wrote: "I was told on more than one occasion 'the ends justified the means' and the 'right' people were allowed to live and the 'wrong' people were not. The practice of presiding as a judge, jury and executioner is wrong and regrettably I cannot say the mindset of some individuals has changed to this day." Brian Nelson was eventually arrested by a team of detectives investigating RUC collusion with loyalists, led by Sir John Stevens, (now commissioner of the Metropolitan police). Nelson received a 10-year sentence on 23 charges ranging from conspiracy to murder (my father's murder was not one of them) to collecting information for terrorist purposes. He served four and a half. Colonel Gordon Kerr was awarded a military OBE in 1991. He is currently the British military attache to Beijing. To dwell on the role of people like Brian Nelson and Martin Ingram is to miss the point as to why Patrick Finucane was murdered. It happened because he was a determined and innovative lawyer, and not, as the RUC and others claim, because he was involved in paramilitary activity. Both the RUC and the British government had a powerful motivation. He was among the first to bring the RUC and the army to court when they broke the law. He was among the first to successfully take the government to the European court of human rights over its practices in Northern Ireland. He was among the first to use the law to show that even in a situation of conflict, the law still applies. It is because he was prepared to do all of this that he became the first solicitor to be murdered.When the British government had to decide between preserving the status quo and putting up with some uppity Catholic lawyer, the choice was simple: the lawyer had to go. My family does not regard the prosecution of the killers as the main concern in all of this. They were simply pawns in a bigger game. Our goal is a public, independent international inquiry into all the circumstances. We have gained the support of the UN, the US Congress, the Irish government, the European parliament, and others. We are supported by every major human rights organisation in the world, from Amnesty International to the International Federation of Human Rights. The notable absentee is the British government, and it is there that ultimate responsibility lies. The state machinery that murdered Patrick Finucane was not established to kill one man. Others died too, and the question that has to be answered is, how many? It was this point that my family urged upon the prime minister at a private meeting last September. A third police investigation by Sir John Stevens - the prime minister's preferred option - will simply not do. Many people who still live in Northern Ireland were unaware of how precarious their existence was, and did not realise that for many years each of them was considered expendable. But they are aware of it now and they want to know the truth. How will the peace process ever succeed if it is kept hidden? Tony Blair's administration may not have been responsible for what took place but, by frustrating a proper inquiry, it has become part of the problem. It has taken 12 years to uncover what you have just read. Instead of devoting resources toward the search for a peaceful solution, the government was obsessed with securing the defeat of republican paramilitaries, whatever the cost. They armed and assisted loyalists in order to do so. One line after another was crossed and, eventually, the line between right and wrong disappeared completely. Neither the law of the land nor human life itself was respected. This was your government's policy. If it had happened in Britain, there would be an outcry. But it happened in Northern Ireland, so no one cared. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Police gave 'drugs for confessions'

fields.headline: Police gave 'drugs for confessions'
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: West Yorkshire police is bringing disciplinary charges against nine officers in Leeds who are alleged to have supplied drugs to prisoners in exchange for confessions.
fields.body:
West Yorkshire police is bringing disciplinary charges against nine officers in Leeds who are alleged to have supplied drugs to prisoners in exchange for confessions.

The police complaints authority has agreed with an internal inquiry by the force that nine officers, based in a team at Killingbeck police station in Seacroft, Leeds, should appear before the chief constable on a total of 42 disciplinary charges.

Five have been suspended.

The authority supervised an investigation by the force's discipline and complaints department into allegations that officers supplied controlled drugs to prisoners to induce an admission of offences.

A file was sent to the crown prosecution service, which decided not to prosecute.

West Yorkshire recommended 42 disciplinary charges be brought, and a review by the independent authority yesterday agreed with this decision.

The allegations relate to 1997 and 1998 and involve members of the cross border team which was established to detect offenders involved in serious offences in Leeds.

Alison McDougall, a member of the authority, said that the alleged offences were falsehood and prevarication, discreditable conduct, neglect of duty, and being an accessory to a discipline offence.

Roger Benn, chairman of West Yorkshire Police Federation, said that the officers would be supported by the union when their case was heard.

webTitle: MacArthur swaps high seas for high profile

fields.headline: MacArthur swaps high seas for high profile
fields.standfirst: Rested and raring to compete again, Britain's sailing heroine talks of 'masochistic pleasure' in pushing herself beyond limit
fields.trailText: Rested and raring to compete again, Britain's sailing heroine talks of 'masochistic pleasure' in pushing herself beyond limit.
fields.byline: Paul Kelso  and Paul Weaver  in Les Sables D'Olonne
fields.body:
After the calm of her longest night's sleep for three months, Ellen MacArthur emerged yesterday into a storm of publicity that is likely to follow her for a while longer than it took to circumnavigate the globe.

Wearing civvies for the first time in 96 days and looking rested after the luxury of three hours' unbroken sleep, MacArthur faced the ravenous press corps and spoke of her achievement in becoming the youngest person to complete the trip single handed.

Demonstrating the passion for competition that sustained her extraordinary voyage, she insisted she would make the trip again.

"If there was another start tomorrow then there is a high chance I would be there," she said. As it is she will wait only a matter of months before returning to ocean racing.

"I'm going to stay with Kingfisher and do the Atlantic Challenge with her, fully crewed. After spending three months alone on her it will be strange getting used to sailing with other people."

MacArthur began sailing at the age of eight and at 24 is already regarded as the finest sailor the UK has produced. She said the gruelling Vendee Globe, in which she finished second, was the culmination of a decade of effort.

"When I see the fame and the glory, the flares of last night, it's very easy to forget the past and everything I have come through," she said.

"The biggest thing to learn is that if you have a dream you can achieve it. Ten years ago it was a dream to do this race. Believe you can do it and have the determination. I have just followed a dream and not thought about the fact that I am a girl and younger than a lot of the other people.

"I don't feel like a heroine and I don't feel famous, I just feel like people want to hear the story and I feel grateful that people have shared the race and that people have been interested in it."

She added: "I get this masochistic pleasure out of these things, out of finding my limit and then pushing myself beyond it. Somebody sent me an email. It said 'courage is not having the energy to go on. It's going on when you do not have the energy.' That's true."

Reflecting on her rapturous landfall on Sunday evening when 200,000 people lined the harbourside at Les Sables D'Olonne on the Bay of Biscay, she said: "Last night was a mix of emotions: almost a dread of finishing the race because I was so happy out there, but also the elation of finishing and coming back to the welcome of literally hundreds of thousands of people. It's hard to describe just how that felt.

"It seems very strange not to be thinking what the wind is doing or thinking about logging on and looking at the weather. All that is just a little world that has been turning for the past three months and all of a sudden it stops and I'm just standing here.

"I've got no money, no credit cards, no mobile phone, no nothing. It's just Ellen and it's going to take me a while to get back to normal."

Normality may be some way off but money should not be a problem. MacArthur's business partner and former rival Mark Turner had been besieged by requests for her time and publishers are circling, offering £100,000 for the rights to a book.

"It's been a very hectic few days. Awesome," he said. "The interest outside France is unbelievable and I don't just mean in Britain. Today I've had interview requests from Germany, Italy, Spain, Poland and Sweden," he said, looking more tired than his partner.

"I've to get back to CBS in America very soon. And the interest in Australia and New Zealand is incredible."

MacArthur said: "There is no doubt about it. I would not be sitting here now without him."

The BBC has already commissioned a programme on MacArthur's journey using footage from four cameras installed on the boat and she has been approached to endorse products from clothing to cars.

MacArthur will return to Derbyshire with her parents, Ken and Avril, in the next few days, but said she wanted to stay in France to see some of the Vendee competitors finish the race. Another 14 boats are still at sea.

webTitle: News in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Teenager on murder charge |  Skier 'jumped to his death' | Contaminated peanuts fear
fields.body:
Teenager on murder charge

A 19-year-old man has been charged with the murder of a pensioner killed in a fire at his home. Gary Lawson, from Grimsby, will appear before magistrates today accused of killing Alfred Wilkins, 67, a former merchant seaman, whose body was discovered at his flat in Grimsby on Friday.

Skier 'jumped to his death'

A British teenager is believed to have committed suicide by jumping from a mountain during a skiing holiday in the French Alps, the Foreign Office said yesterday. Ben Pettit, 18, plunged 1,000 metres from a mountainside on Sunday afternoon in Chamonix.

Contaminated peanuts fear

Nearly a third of peanuts imported into Britain from China are contaminated by high levels of aflatoxin, which is linked to liver cancer, checks at Felixtowe docks in Suffolk have suggested. EU scientists will consider banning the imports in April unless there are substantial improvements.

Five Live retains formula one

BBC Radio Five Live has won radio rights for formula one for a further four years, it was announced yesterday. The station has extended its contract until 2005, allowing it to broadcast exclusive radio commentary for every grand prix race around the world.

Guardsman found dead

Five guardsmen were yesterday being questioned by police after a Scots Guard was found dead near Buckingham Palace. Martin Rimmer, 22, was found slumped in a corridor at Wellington Barracks in Birdcage Walk on Sunday. It is believed he had been drinking with fellow guardsmen before his death.

Push to outlaw angling

Animal rights activists yesterday announced they are launching a hard-hitting nationwide advertising campaign as part of a push for angling to be outlawed.

Cook Report producers sue

Six producers and a lawyer working on the controversial ITV series the Cook Report are suing the News of the World over allegations that the show faked some of its investigations.

Brink's-Mat search ends

Detectives searching for gold stolen in the 1983 Brink's-Mat robbery have completed a search of a builder's yard in Hastings, East Sussex, without finding anything significant. More than 30 Metropolitan police officers spent five days on the search, using sophisticated scanning equipment. It is thought about £10m is still missing from the £26m robbery.

Graduate killed by elephant

A Cambridge University graduate was trampled to death by an elephant while on safari in Kenya, an inquest heard yesterday. An accidental death verdict was recorded on Edward Harrison, 28, a second lieutenant in the university's Officer Training Corps, who died instantly of multiple injuries when attacked by the beast in the Masai Mara game reserve last August.

Mercedes cars recalled

More than 4,000 British-owned A-class Mercedes cars built between September 2000 and January 20001 are being recalled because of a brake problem.

Stolen vehicle kills pedestrian

A man in his 40s died yesterday when he was struck by a stolen car as he walked to work in Leamington Spa. Warwickshire police said the blue Mercedes was later found abandoned on an industrial estate.

Crime posters withdrawn

Shock police posters showing a man lying in a pool of blood under the words "Young, gifted and dead" have been taken down after half were whitewashed. Police said around 30 of the 60 anti-gun crime posters were covered in super-adhesive white paint. They were launched two weeks ago in Brent, north-west London, which has one of the highest rates of shootings in Britain.

webTitle: Fragile habitats 'sacrificed' for development

fields.headline: Fragile habitats 'sacrificed' for development
fields.standfirst: Britain faces EU action for failing to protect environment
fields.trailText: Britain's environmental credentials were yesterday ripped to shreds by the European commission, which accused the government of sacrificing endangered species to the demands of developers.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn  in Brussels and Paul Brown
fields.body:
Britain's environmental credentials were yesterday ripped to shreds by the European commission, which accused the government of sacrificing endangered species to the demands of developers.

In a damning statement the commission said it was taking legal action against the UK in the European court of justice because the government paid scant attention to environmentally important areas when granting planning permission, and did far too little to save the often fragile habitats of endangered species.

The commission cited damage to breeding and resting sites used by otters, great crested newts and all species of bat.

Under the European Union's habitats directive, the most important piece of wildlife legislation agreed by EU member states, the government is allowed to grant exceptions to protection if it believes "there are imperative reasons and an overriding case to do so".

However, the commission stated that the government was hardly bothering to enforce the directive, and granting exceptions to almost anyone who asked.

It said: "Licences seem to be issued as a formality after development consent for a construction or infrastructure project has already been given, and do not appear to involve a careful weighting of the arguments for and against allowing damage to occur."

Such strong criticism from Brussels and the prospect of a high profile court case in Europe that could lead to a huge fine is potentially highly damaging to Tony Blair, who is keen to be seen as environmentally aware.

The EU's environment commissioner, Margot Wallstrom, warned the government last night: "We must take our legal safeguards seriously, or we face the wiping out of endangered species through the creeping loss of habitats."

Her office in Brussels said it believed the only valid reason for granting an exception to the directive was where there was no satisfactory alternative to a specific construction project, and it stressed that exceptions should not be the rule.

The government has two months to convince the commission that it is no longer in breach of the directive, otherwise the case goes to the court in Luxembourg.

Last night the Department of Environment confessed that it was "disappointed" by the commission's action, and was urgently reviewing its procedures to avoid prosecution. A spokeswoman said the department thought it had done enough last March, after being warned it was breaching EU law, and tightened the rules to prevent destruction of sites where rare species "bred or rested". Revised regulations said sites should not be destroyed unless there were reasons of overriding public interest, which included social or economic justifications.

Tony Juniper, of Friends of the Earth, said "The government has only got itself to blame because it has taken a minimalist approach to conservation. It has ignored the spirit and the legal intent of the directive. They have not taken species protection seriously or given over sufficient areas for protection. We and other green organisations have repeatedly complained to the commission, which has at last acted. We are very pleased."

The UK is not the only allegedly delinquent EU member state. Greece was also yesterday threatened with action for not doing enough to protect the breeding grounds of the Mediterranean sea turtle.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In Brief
fields.trailText: Latest Eta blast misfires
fields.body:
Latest Eta blast misfires

A car bomb linked to the Basque separatist group, Eta, narrowly missed causing injury yesterday. A detonator in the explosives-packed car, parked on a busy Madrid street, failed to trigger, officials said.

At least 30kg of dynamite was discovered in the vehicle, which caught fire when the detonator failed.

UN vets refugee crisis in Guinea

The United Nations refugee agency chief, Ruud Lubbers, said yesterday that international help, including military support, may be needed to help Guinea cope with the world's worst refugee crisis.

Mr Lubbers said in the capital, Conakry, that he would press the Guinean authorities to guarantee safe passage for the thousands of Sierra Leonean and Liberian refugees fleeing the fighting on the country's southern border.

Havel falls ill on Middle East tour

The Czech president, Vaclav Havel, broke off his Middle East tour yesterday and was flown home to Prague after suffering from a recurrence of acute bron chitis on Sunday. His personal physician, who accompanied him on the flight home, said a viral infection and the strain of travelling probably triggered the illness.

New Fischer claims denied

The German foreign ministry yesterday dismissed as "politically ridiculous" a report that the foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, had attended a PLO conference in Algeria in 1969 during which delegates agreed with the Palestinian vow to fight against Israel until they were victorious.

According to the report, Mr Fischer was part of a five-strong German team at the conference.

Estrada's wife eyes senate

The wife of the ousted leader of the Philippines, Joseph Estrada, declared her candidacy for the senate yesterday to vindicate the family name through the ballot box.

Luisa Ejercito's decision to join the race adds to Mr Estrada's personal stake in the general elections on May 14, which are widely regarded as a referendum on the revolt that toppled him last month.

Workers will start felling 1.3m trees this month to clear land for a huge reservoir in Portugal which is billed as Europe's largest man-made lake, and is opposed by environmentalists.

The lake will extend 50 miles into the rural Alentejo region of south-eastern Portugal.

webTitle: Leader: Labour fails the 11-plus

fields.headline: Labour fails the 11-plus
fields.standfirst:
Two tiers will create more inequity

Education site
fields.trailText: Until yesterday, Labour was approaching the election with education as a clear trump card. Ministers have every reason to be proud of their achievement in pre-school and primary education.
fields.body:
Until yesterday, Labour was approaching the election with education as a clear trump card. Ministers have every reason to be proud of their achievement in pre-school and primary education.

A new generation of children has been given a head start, compared to their elder siblings. Six years ago, more than half of 11-year-olds were failing to reach the expected standard for their age in English and maths. Now three quarters are there already in English and 70% in maths.

Incredibly bold targets are not just being met but exceeded, thanks to the introduction of intelligently tailored daily literacy and numeracy lessons. As the prime minister noted yesterday, "the lowest performing areas are now achieving better than the average did just four years ago". It is not just pupils who have been given a lift by these results, but primary teachers too.

Yesterday Labour opened its second front. The main focus rightly switches to secondary schools, building on primary progress. Some of it is laudable: a new drive to pick up children, who have been falling back in their first two secondary years; catch-up lessons for 12-year-olds; pilot projects to gauge whether 13-year-olds should take the current national tests at 14; and the extension of the "Excellence in Cities" programme to one third of secondary schools, providing learning mentors to tackle truancy and the disruptive, as well as special schemes for the gifted and talented.

But three fundamental flaws in this new plan are set to widen inequalities in secondary education, reduce opportunities, and create a two-tier school system. The first fault is the expansion of specialist schools. By 2006, they will double to 1,500, equivalent to almost 50% of all secondaries. They will receive £100,000 capital grant plus £123 per pupil per year - £225,000 for a school of 1,000 pupils. The other 50% of schools will not get anything. How can this do anything other than create two tiers? Theoretically, 30% of the extra provision will be available to pupils in nearby non specialist schools. In reality, this is unlikely to happen. It runs completely counter to a principle enunciated by the prime minister yesterday, where he rejected the idea of "a free for all that simply places one good school in an area alongside many more that are only average".

The second fault is the idea of children selecting specialist schools at 11. Music and sport could make sense, but choosing the new specialisms - science, engineering, business and enterprise - is a nonsense at that age. The third fault is the incoherence of the new philosophy, prompted by Labour's ambivalence over selection. Stand by for semantic smoke: selection by aptitude is OK - but not by ability.

If you have a specialist music school, for goodness sake, ability should be a key criterion. Ditto sport. The entire package is further confused by a move to increase faith schools by a further 100. This is the reverse of what should be happening in a secular multi-cultural society. Look at the US, where it was state schools which helped bind together hyphenated Americans with their different languages, religions and culture.

Labour should scrap this consultative plan and start again. All comprehensives should be offering specialisms, not just 50%, but at 14, not 11. Only in that way can the prime minister's goal of all children being educated "to the fullest extent of their ability" be met. It would tie in well with new vocational schemes for non academic pupils that also start at 14. The current plan smacks of a wish to please everyone - in reality it is in danger of pleasing no one.

webTitle: West Ham 1 - 1 Coventry

fields.headline: Hartson raises Sky Blue hopes
fields.trailText: John Hartson had a goal disallowed but Coventry grabbed a point after Joe Cole had broken the deadlock in an uninspired game.
fields.body:
John Hartson so nearly proved a point last night as his new team-mates came back to gain one and boost their fight against relegation.

Both teams left it late to find the net in an uninspiring game but Coventry's new signing twice came close to netting the winner and making a fairytale start to his role as City's potential saviour.

On 13 minutes the Wales striker had a perfectly good goal ruled out; his team-mate Craig Bellamy was offside but was clearly not interfering with play.

Then, after Joe Cole had given West Ham a deserved lead with seven minutes remaining and City had equalised with seconds left through a Christian Dailly own-goal, Hartson turned two defenders and was upended on the 18-yard line.

It looked a penalty in real time but the replay showed the offence occurred just outside the area. City, though, did not even get a free-kick and had to be content with a point.

In their position, second bot tom of the Premiership, they will take anything they can get, especially as they came into the game on the back of some awful figures: only two victories in their previous 15 league games and four league defeats in their four previous games.

As for West Ham, they too are looking shaky. One win in their last 10 league games is hardly the sort of form to go with the team's stylish image and this was a case of three points let slip.

However, the watching England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson will have been further impressed by the form of Cole as he ponders the make-up of his first squad, to be announced on Friday week, for the friendly against Spain.

The 19-year-old celebrated becoming the youngest player to make 50 appearances for West Ham with a typically impish display of midfield trickery, what looked briefly like the winning goal and a man-of-the-match magnum of champagne.

However, it did not stop the Upton Park crowd booing the team off at the end of each half. A shame, as they had begun the evening in good heart, treating Hartson to generous applause as he was introduced before kick-off.

His goals had played a crucial part in West Ham's avoidance of relegation from the Premiership in the 1996-97 season after his purchase from Arsenal, and Coventry's hope was that he could repeat the feat.

Despite the doubts that still surround his fitness he looks as though he can still make a difference at the highest level. So confident are Coventry of this that they have decided to sell another striker, Cédric Roussel, to Wolves.

After the disallowed early score Hartson was involved again on the half-hour, setting up John Eustace for a close- range header which the midfielder wasted. And Moustapha Hadji had already forced Craig Forrest, replacing the injured Shaka Hislop, into a diving save as Coventry showed a belief and commitment belying their lowly position.

West Ham's frustrations were compounded by the fact that Frédéric Kanouté should have given them the lead in the opening minute. Then on 43 minutes Frank Lampard contrived to spear a great chance wide from 12 yards.

West Ham got more of a grip on the game in the second half. Paulo di Canio hit the bar from an acute angle, then Hannu Tihinen saw his header cleared off the line by Lee Carsley.

Cole eventually found the net, converting Nigel Winterburn's low cross after Lampard had cleverly set the wing-back free. But with seconds remaining Dailly managed to head David Thompson's floated free-kick into his own net.

Despite their disappointment over the penalty, City would no doubt have happily taken this result before the game began.

webTitle: Two-week deadline to end passport crisis

fields.headline: Two-week deadline to end passport crisis
fields.trailText: The Football Association has given clubs a two-week deadline to clear up any possible problems regarding the passports of non-EU players.
fields.body:
The Football Association has given clubs a two-week deadline to clear up any possible problems regarding the passports of non-EU players.

All English clubs have been urged to seek the help of the Home Office "should they be worried about the documentation of players born outside the European Union or European Economic Area who may have dual nationality allowing them to play in this country on an EU passport".

The FA chief executive Adam Crozier will meet the Fifa general secretary Michel Zen-Ruffinen tomorrow and intends to push for standard punishments across Europe for passport violations. His haste to clear up the situation is based on his belief that "unsubstantiated rumours and allegations [are] damaging to clubs, players and the game as a whole".

webTitle: Mentally ill stalker jailed for killing boy

fields.headline: Mentally ill stalker gets life for killing boy
fields.standfirst: Inquiry launched into why drifter remanded on charges of harassing 12-year-old had been released without supervision
fields.trailText: Inquiry launched into why drifter remanded on charges of harassing 12-year-old had been released without supervision.
fields.body:
A mentally ill man obsessed with child sacrifice was sentenced to life in prison yesterday for the murder of a boy of 12 in Covent Garden in London.

Alex Crowley, 52, who had a severe personality disorder, had stalked Diego Piniero-Villar, then hunted him down and stabbed him more than 20 times last May.

Moments before sentence was passed, Diego's mother, Angela, and two female relatives screamed death threats at Crowley and hurled cups of water at the dock before being hustled from the Old Bailey courtroom.

The court heard that Crowley, a homeless man, had formed an obsessive friendship with the boy in the year before his death, but this had gone sour after Diego had tried to break off their relationship.

He was held in Pentonville prison for more than three months on remand over harassment charges but not brought to trial, and was eventually released on to the streets without supervision.

Crowley, who had changed his name to that of the magician of the black arts, Aleister Crowley, was fascinated by the occult and appears to have planned to perform a "child sacrifice".

An independent review was under way last night into why Crowley was permitted to go near Diego again. It will look at the roles played by police, the crown prosecution service and the social services.

Crowley is not thought to have sexually abused Diego, but this will be looked at in the inquiry by a forensic psychologist and a former civil servant.

Neither the CPS nor the police has explained why it took so long to conclude the investigation of the harassment of the boy. "Crowley had been charged with harassment, but the custody time limit ran out," said a CPS source.

"The police needed more time to gather evidence. It's not right to say the case had been dropped.

"Once he was out on bail there was no way of forcing him to have further psychiatric assessments.

Crowley seems to have benefited from a loophole in the Mental Health Act that distinguishes between the care of people diagnosed with personality disorders and the care of people who are deemed psychotic.

While on remand, he was assessed by a forensic psychiatrist who concluded that he "has a personality disorder and is dangerous ... he should be detained".

However, the law states that a personality disorder is untreatable, and that sufferers cannot be compelled to have treatment.

"We offered him help before his arrest, during his time in custody, and after his arrest," said a spokesman for Camden social services. "He refused us every time. We could not legally force him to have treatment and he was adamant that he didn't want it.

"This is a problem area, and one that needs to be addressed with changes to the law."

Camden said it first learned of concerns about Crowley at a case conference on Diego held with the police in autumn 1999.

The drifter was not on the sex offenders register - he had no paedophile convictions - and he had not been referred to the council for treatment.

"The police told us about the stalking, but it was decided they should take responsibility for protecting the boy. They were quite happy to do so. There didn't seem to be real concern that he was in genuine danger at that point."

The report from the forensic psychiatrist who concluded Crowley was "dangerous and should be detained" was presented to court at a bail hearing last March when he was released from custody.

"Our advice was, unfortunately, not taken by the magistrate," said the council spokesman.

After his arrest for murder, Crowley's mental health history was reviewed by a psychiatrist who decided that he had been suffering from paranoid schizophrenia since the 1970s.

Crowley continues to deny that he is mentally ill - claiming he "fabricated symptoms" when assessed - and has asked to be sent to prison rather than to a secure psychiatric hospital.

The government is proposing to close the loophole in mental health legislation to make it possible to treat people with severe mental health disorder "either in their own best interests or to protect the wider public". But the proposals, published as a white paper in December, are unlikely to become law in this parliament.

Michael Howlett, director of the Zito Trust, said yesterday: "I think it is absolutely inexcusable that this tragedy was allowed to happen. It's pretty clear to me that this should have been picked up.

"We're talking about a young boy losing his life to somebody who has got this kind of history and is already going through the system.

"The government has told us that there are 400-500 people in the community with dangerous, severe personality disorders."

webTitle: Leader: lavishing praise on Ellen MacArthur

fields.headline: Round the world
fields.standfirst: And into the hearts of two nations
fields.trailText: In an age when fame seems to come either to those who do nothing (Big Brother) or those who want it very badly (Popstars), it is a pleasure to lavish praise on a young woman with genuine talent, granite determination and true courage.
fields.body:
In an age when fame seems to come either to those who do nothing (Big Brother) or those who want it very badly (Popstars), it is a pleasure to lavish praise on a young woman with genuine talent, granite determination and true courage.

Only 24, Ellen MacArthur has managed not only to sail around the world on her own, but also to win the hearts of two nations more used to rivalry than shared affection. Her feat has united Britain and France in admiration and sheer joy - at the sight of a physical bravery and skill closer to the eras of Scott or Hillary than our own, more jaded age.

The grumblers have tried to find something to be miserable about. Some mutter about the French sponsoring her before the British woke up to her potential. Others wonder whether the prime minister should have spent a whole 15 minutes congratulating her on the telephone. But these are piffling matters. For there is good news in this story for almost everybody.

Patriots can take delight in an athlete who has shown an old maritime nation that it still has the right stuff. Europhiles can celebrate a young woman from Derbyshire who learned French, got to know their country - and was rewarded with a national infatuation. The yachting fraternity can welcome a fresh wave of attention to their sport - and hope she will shake it at last of its gin-and-tonic, blue-blazered image. Feminists can delight in what Clare Francis, another round-the-world veteran, called "the indomitable spirit of women".

But parents have cause for particular celebration. For in Ellen MacArthur they have a heroine for modern times. They can point to her determination - the way she saved her pocket money for three years to buy her first dinghy - and cite her as proof that there is nothing that can't be done. As Ellen puts it herself: "If you have a dream, you can make it happen." For a world too used to cynicism, here at last is a genuine role model.

webTitle: Leaders: EU shows yellow cards

fields.headline: EU shows yellow cards
fields.standfirst:
Serious arguments would be better
Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: To some people it is merely doing its job. To others it has acquired a talent bordering on genius to stir raw eurosceptic nerves this side of the channel. Whatever the truth of it, no one can accuse the EU of good timing.
fields.body:
To some people it is merely doing its job. To others it has acquired a talent bordering on genius to stir raw eurosceptic nerves this side of the channel. Whatever the truth of it, no one can accuse the EU of good timing. Yesterday, three months before a probable general election, it told Gordon Brown that he should cut public spending.

And it has held a yellow card up to the Emerald Isle, also facing an election, because Ireland's monetary policy is deemed too expansionary and should be reined in by tax rises or spending cuts. Even if these criticisms had some justification they would be inviting national governments to commit political suicide in the run-up to an election.

But do they have substance? Britain is being asked to cut public spending because the current budget surplus - unprecedented for a Labour government - could become a deficit of 1% of national income by 2005 (if anyone believes forecasts that far ahead).

Yet the projected increases in public spending are merely making up an earlier shortfall in response to a public outcry about deteriorating infrastructure. In years ahead, they could become a vital engine of growth as domestic demand falls. And even if there is a slight deficit, it will be well under the Maastricht 3% ceiling, and would be a result of borrowing for investment, not increased consumption.

Under Mr Brown's "golden rule", current spending must be matched by tax increases but borrowing is permitted for investment. True, the EU yesterday also issued pale yellow cards to other countries like France and Italy - but it would be very well advised to avoid any public actions that confirm the fears of sceptics that the EU is itching to be more deeply involved in running fiscal policies among member states as well as monetary policy.

The Irish government makes a credible case for allowing its own - highly successful - economic policy to be tested to destruction. It argues that nearly all of the inflation it has experienced is beyond its immediate control and wouldn't be curbed by fiscal restraint: oil increases were caused by Opec, house price rises by the EU's low interest rates and high import costs by the weak euro.

Inflation has started falling again and the current rate - 3.9% in January - though higher than the EU's average, is piffling compared with its near 10% annual growth rate. If recent form is taken into account it is Ireland, not the EU, that should be seen as the role model.

webTitle: The decline and fall of the august cabinet secretary

fields.headline: The decline and fall of the august cabinet secretary
fields.standfirst: A once revered mandarin has been brought very low indeed
fields.trailText: February 13, comment: The secretary of the cabinet was once the most revered figure in the British public service. Quality in high office seems to be declining, writes Hugo Young.
fields.body:
The secretary of the cabinet was once the most revered figure in the British public service. Sir Burke Trend, who held the job in the 1960s, with an aloof manner and superior judgment, was a super-mandarin for the ages. When his successor, Sir John Hunt, appeared in court in 1975 to contest publication of the Crossman diaries, we witnessed an unprecedented descent from Olympus to the forum. Hitherto the cabinet secretary had barely been seen, let alone heard.

Next up, Sir Robert Armstrong, was forced into the open by Mrs Thatcher, to make a humiliating journey to Australia to stop Spycatcher: a bad day for the mystique of a very special post. But Armstrong's prestige was as respected as his cunning. It would not have occurred to him, in any circumstances, to take lunch with the Hinduja brothers of his time.

What these men had in common was high intellect, but also authoritative intimacy with their political masters. They were feared in Whitehall. Their judgment really mattered. They all had many fierce problems to settle every day. None of these involved ruling on the fate of ministers charged with some kind of scandal. That was political work. But it's a fair assumption that if they'd been called on to sort out that particular kind of mess, neither Trend nor Hunt nor Armstrong would have allowed panic to overcome due process. The cabinet secretary should be a bulwark, above all, against panic.

The last two cabinet secretaries have been judges at the centre of just such scandal, and they've both made a mess of it. Quality in high office seems to be declining. Sir Robin Butler refused to investigate a welter of evidence against Jonathan Aitken, preferring, in establishment style, to believe the word of a minister against that of the editor of the Guardian. Stubbornly and at leisure, Butler protested Aitken's innocence. Thanks to him, a corrupt minister for a while kept his job.

Now Sir Richard Wilson has made the opposite mistake in the case of Peter Mandelson, becoming an accomplice in panic which removed a decent minister from his job and maybe from politics. The sheet-anchor of propriety and process abetted the very folly which the man in his position is paid to resist.

Mandelson has not been sensible in the past few days. Visiting the enemy press to plead his case exposed him to forms of manipulation and publicity which the old Mandy would never have risked. He looks a bit of a bloody fool, and nameless slimebags in his party have rushed to defame him further. Oliver James, who deserves to be struck off the psychiatrists' register for unprofessional conduct, has pronounced him suicidal.

But the Hammond inquiry will find it hard to prove a case against him that measures up to the punishment he's already suffered. If it does not, Tony Blair will look a rotten boss, but Sir Richard Wilson's failure to behave like a proper cabinet secre tary will have been substantially to blame.

The decline in respect for the job is not all his fault. The tendency has Thatcherite origins, from a time when the personal familiars of the leader began to weaken the influence of the professional civil service. Mrs Thatcher never did think much of Whitehall . Under Blair, the eclipse of the mandarins at the centre of government is more pronounced. When Wilson got his job, three months after the 1997 election, he arrived to find Blairite chiefs of staff and press officers who mattered more to the leader, inexperienced as he was in government, than the descendant, however august, of Burke Trend.

Besides, Wilson wasn't picked for his authority. He's a fixer and agreeable smoothie, not a Trend. Nor was he expected, or allowed, to be particularly close. When the Mandelson panic began, Wilson therefore came at it with disadvantages. Nonetheless, he should have done more to insist on the observance of a system and process which are in his stewardship.

That he didn't take that seriously enough may have had something to do with where he came from. As the former boss of the Home Office, he seems to have believed what Home Office officials reported about what happened, via Mandelson, in 1998. In a very short time, without assembling all the evidence, he was hustled into lending the weight of his once-great office to the condign verdict against the minister.

Since then, the suspicion has grown that Home Office officials were allowing a miasma of rumour and half- remembered suspicion to congeal into "fact". Other versions were not tested. Perhaps not surprisingly, the latest word is that Wilson is seeking to distance himself from the events of the last week in January, hinting that Downing Street had more to do with them than he did.

That's not the only word emerging from the turmoil. After a week of slagging Mandelson off, No 10 now calls for calm and says he should be allowed to defend himself. It's obvious what's happening. Belatedly, the official machine feels the need to prepare itself for the possibility that Hammond will not find its conduct in all respects justifiable. The murmur of preparatory damage limitation shimmers round the system, both in particular, as regards the cabinet secretary, and in general on behalf of the Downing Street apparatus.

Hammond is inquiring only into the events of 1998, and the bearing these have on a single sequence of remarks allegedly made by Mandelson in recent weeks. Maybe the investigation will find conclusive proof, that a) he intervened to influence a Hinduja passport application and b) he told, in Jack Straw's word, an "untruth" about that recently.

Or maybe not. Though Hammond himself is a former Home Office man, he'll be aware that public scrutiny of his account and its supporting evidence will be intense. He won't get away with any kind of fiddle. More likely, he will be able to point to no more than a series of cock-ups unverifiable as evidence of personal guilt.

On the other hand, Hammond won't be looking at the whole of what happened early in 2001. This is a very big pity. As regards our system of government, Mandelson's (at worst) slender intervention in 1998, if it was made at all, is far less worrying than the hysteria that gripped the prime minister's office on January 29. That is the political moment that needs taking apart.

Not only did it destroy a minister who will probably turn out not to have done anything bad enough to deserve such a fate. It also exposed a system of politics that has broken the rules of orderly government, with the connivance of the official who was once the guarantor of those rules, the great umpire who protected the basic ethics of government. The cabinet secretary has been brought very low when he can't remind the prime minister of the prudence, let alone the morality, of not panicking. If they both pay a price for Mandelson's political corpse, they'll deserve it.

 Oliver James is a clinical psychologist and not, as we suggested in a piece headed The decline and fall of the august cabinet secretary, Comment, page 20, February 13, a psychiatrist.

webTitle: Classical review: Camerata/Douglas Boyd

fields.headline: Camerata/Douglas Boyd
fields.standfirst:
Royal Northern College of Music
Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Royal Northern College of Music
Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Bringing Bach, Schoenberg and Webern together in a single programme is not as radical as it might appear. Schoenberg regarded Bach's music as the source from which his own contrapuntal style was a natural development.

But for the Camerata and their audience, it made quite a change: this is an ensemble with a core diet of baroque and classical music. Douglas Boyd, who will take over as principal conductor next season, clearly felt that some reassurance was necessary and chatted to the audience before playing.

The Camerata are one of the few British chamber orchestras to regularly perform baroque music on modern instruments. Although Boyd's attention to detail made for some finely crafted phrasing, there was no avoiding the fact that the Camerata's vibrato-less but metallic sound was an uneasy compromise; Purcell's Chacony and C minor Fantasia lacked the mellifluous elegance and warmth a period ensemble would have brought.

There were related problems in the Bach oboe concerto. Although Boyd managed his role of director and soloist well, the problems of balance caused by over-bright strings marred the outer movements. The inner Siciliano, however, was miraculous: here the Camerata came into their own.

The sheer intelligence of Boyd's conducting was enough to invest Webern's Five Movements for String Quartet with expressive coherence and the Camerata were quick to respond. Schoenberg's Verklärte Nacht fared less well.

Crucially, the audience's response could not have been warmer. The Camerata can surely afford to programme more concerts like this one.

webTitle: Musical review: Sweeney Todd

fields.headline: Sweeney Todd
fields.standfirst:
New Wolsey
Ipswich
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
New Wolsey
Ipswich
Rating: ***
fields.body:
More Brecht than Broadway, Stephen Sondheim's musical thriller about the barber unjustly transported to Australia who returns 15 years later to find his wife driven to her death and his daughter the ward of the evil, lecherous judge who sentenced him, is not what you'd call a jolly night out. Not one to think of having a late supper after, either.

This is a cut-throat evening of bloody brilliance that is a cross between a Greek tragedy and a Penny Dreadful. Sondheim has never written more bleakly or mordantly than about this Victorian world, a swirling social cesspit sick with the smells from the bakehouse of Mrs Lovett, whose pies have mysteriously gone from the inedible to the succulent overnight, and the rotting carcass of class and privilege. Its message is succinct: "The history of the world, my sweet, is who gets eaten and who gets to eat."

Sweeney himself is, of course, that fascinating figure: the victim turned predator. What begins as a revenge drama, a quest to right a terrible injustice, turns into a splatterfest. Sweeney likes killing. He makes Hannibal Lecter seem quite kind.

The strength of the evening comes from the curious conjunction of horror and comedy and music and lyrics that are constantly on a razor's edge as they try to undercut each other. Sweeney serenades his razors as if he has just been reunited with a long lost lover and his murders are conducted to the sweetest, most heart-aching, melody.

As the National discovered almost a decade ago, this is a chamber musical, and the resurrected New Wolsey theatre is an intimate enough space to make this the close-up experience it needs to be.

Ellen Cairns' design, clever though it is with its cage motif, is a little too specific and fussy and adds to the odd moment when Peter Rowe's production looks as though everyone might suddenly break into a chorus from Oliver!

The production is at its best when at its most simple and spare, particularly at the start and finish when the cast faces the audience and sing in an accusatory manner that implicates us all.

It also has a trump card in the shape of Paul Leonard who not only sings fantastically, but who also subtly marks the shift in Sweeney from vengeful tragic hero to psychotic serial killer who really loves his work.

This is a big, bold, brave choice for the re-opening of a theatre and it bodes well for the future. Now it is up to the local community to decide if they want a theatre.

The choice is quite clear: use it or lose it. Sweeney Todd should help concentrate their minds.

 Until February 24. Box office: 01473 295900. Then touring to Theatre Royal, York, February 28 to March 10, and Mercury Colchester, March 20 to 24.

webTitle: Work: Work and play will soon be one and the same according to a new exhibition in New York.

fields.headline: Labour of life
fields.standfirst:
Work and play will soon be one and the same according to a new exhibition in New York. Michael Ellison pays a visit

Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Work and play will soon be one and the same according to a new exhibition in New York. Michael Ellison pays a visit.
fields.body:
Tom Wolfe left out something rather important in his glib assessment of the state of the American working man at the turn of the century. "The average electrician, air-conditioning mechanic, or burglar-alarm repairman lived a life that would have made the Sun King blink," the reporter-literateur noted in Hooking Up, his latest collection, by way of illustrating that capitalism had delivered all that utopian socialism once promised. "He spent his vacations in Puerto Rico, Barbados, or St Kitts. Before dinner he would be out on the terrace of some resort hotel with his third wife, wearing his Ricky Martin cane-cutter shirt open down to his sternum, the better to allow his gold chains to twinkle in his chest hairs."

What the man in the white suit failed to mention is that this unappealing creature works all the hours God sends in order to acquire his baubles. Not that this is so terrible. Not, at least, if you swallow whole the ethic of Workspheres, a new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in New York.

Right away, from the sight of the first piece of evidence - a 12ft high nomadic home/office that used to be a Mercedes truck and is now a giant toy - the message is clear: work is fun and there's no getting away from it. The show is a completely uncritical illustration of the working environments of the day after tomorrow, doubling as the high street electronics store of the future.

"Workspheres presumes that while our work determines our lives, in the future our lives will be able to shape the way that we work," says the accompanying brochure. Now that it is becoming unnecessary for many people to travel to an office in order to earn a crust, the designers chosen by MoMA have devised a myriad of options for doing it elsewhere.

So the former Mercedes truck, designed by Bran Ferran, can climb a 45-degree gradient, conquer a 3ft boulder and ford a 5ft-deep stream in the jungle while keeping in touch via two-way video conferencing and a 50ft communications mast. And Helen Jongerius makes an excellent case for My Soft Office (pictured), a business bed extended and tilted forward at the end so that you can work away at two monitors without lifting your head from the pillow.

Not all the gizmos, prototypes and products are on such a grand scale. Nor are the needs of those unfortunates who must visit an office once in a while ignored. Among the "environments" created by six international design teams there is a folding mattress for an afternoon nap, sadly incomplete without a manual detailing how to convince your employers that the product is a necessity.

Denial of such a privilege, however, might oblige a worker to have recourse to the silicone rubber Sugar Ray ceiling lamp "that can turn into a frustration and tension reliever. It will withstand a Tyson punch". Or the machine that purports to offer drugs to enhance concentration, relaxation and isolation, the modern equivalent of a cigarette, and possibly of interest to the police.

Then - as though to confirm that this worker of the future really does have something up his sleeve - there is the Echarpe Communicante, an attention-seeking coat and scarf in tacky, shimmering silver containing a built-in computer screen, keyboard and telephone.

If nothing else, all this demonstrates how rapidly innovation is assimilated into the mainstream: a display of Nokia and Motorola mobile phones that would have been considered unbelievably small only a few years ago receive little or no attention today. Except, of course, when they ring and interrupt the Workspheres experience and an aggrieved member of museum staff instructs you to turn them off.

www.moma.org/workspheres

webTitle: End to upper age limit on work

fields.headline: End to upper age limit on work
fields.trailText: Employees are to be allowed to work as long as they like under new laws which will ban firms stipulating an age at which they should retire.
fields.body:
Employees are to be allowed to work as long as they like under new laws which will ban firms stipulating an age at which they should retire.

Clauses in contracts stipulating a retirement age will be deemed illegal and any employer showing ageism could be taken in front of an industrial tribunal and sued for discrimination.

The dramatic break with employment law - which will be seen as a tacit acknowledgment of the importance of senior workers in an increasingly ageing population - will be signalled by the employment minister Margaret Hodge when she speaks to the employment select committee tomorrow. It is expected to be brought in by 2006 following the setting up of a consultative working group.

The acknowledgment of elderly working rights has come about because Britain needs to comply with an EU directive which complements legislation set up in 1976 to tackle sexual discrimination in the workplace.

Under article 13 of the Treaty of Amsterdam, signed last autumn, discrimination in the workplace is to be outlawed whether on the grounds of age, race, disability or sexual orientation.

The move has already prompted concern from the Confederation of British Industry, which described the law as "fuzzy" when the directive was first proposed and predicted it would lead to more employment tribunal applications.

While the details have yet to be ironed out, it is clear that the pension age will be exempt and people will still be able to draw their pensions at 65. Should they wish to continue working, however, they will need to swap jobs.

"At the moment, you can draw your pension at 50 and then work elsewhere and it will be the same with this," said one senior government source. "But you won't be able to take the money and continue to work in the same place."

webTitle: Pop review: Lina

fields.headline: Lina's delicious smoky big band sound
fields.standfirst:
Lina
Manchester University
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Lina
Manchester University
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The current musical climate is not rife with innovation, which makes Denver-born Lina's efforts positively refreshing. Her music manages to blend the utterly incongruous grooves of contemporary R&B, hip-hop, a pinch of Billie Holiday and, most encouragingly, a delicious, smoky big band sound straight from the 1920s. You can imagine it booming out across the Harlem ghettos, or at a roaring flapper party.

For now, though, the ordinary confines of the university's Hop & Grape bar will have to do. But this doesn't stop Lina putting on the ritz. In classic Hollywood style, the band appear before the star. Encouragingly, all four of them wear preposterous baggy leather trousers and the bass player models an Afro.

After a teasing preamble, the girl herself appears and you can almost hear the sound of jaws dropping to the floor. In a tightly worn (Swanson-style) headscarf, lilac slashed top and jeans that appear to have been sprinkled with diamonds, Lina's look is part 1920s showgirl, part disco queen. Her cutesy control-freak persona is exactly what Nabokov had in mind when he wrote Lolita.

She doesn't have a stage routine, she has a courtship ritual. For an hour she seduces the audience and it will be a heart of stone that doesn't fall under her spell.

The Tallulah act wouldn't work if Lina didn't have a voice somewhere between Bassey and Minogue and oodles of natural charm. "You guys look good too," she simpers. Oh crikey. However, she's an object of desire to the men and an icon in the making for the girls, coming over as R&B and jazz's first smouldering agony aunt. Her "advice" is underpinned by a sassy, saucy take on feminism. Typically, she advises the "laydeez" on "how to bring your fella to his knees". The whole room blushes.

Although the 1920s jazz stuff currently comes from an electronic box rather than a big band, enormous grooves like Step Up (moral: treat your partner better. Yes, Auntie Lina) have the audience dancing in submission.

Later in her career, the girlie dominatrix persona might just grate, but so far, she's timing everything just right. Next week's single, Playa No Mo ("Y'all playas can't fuck with me" - ooh, the anti-Eminem) is delivered twice and she departs with a cheerful flounce.

Manchester is glad that it's raining. After an hour with Lina, a cold shower is very handy.

 At the Jazz Cafe, London, tonight (020-7916 6060).

webTitle: Ballet review: La Fille mal gardée

fields.headline: A perfect love match at the ROH
fields.standfirst:
La Fille mal gardée
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
La Fille mal gardée
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
American Ballet Theatre's Ethan Stiefel was among the international names who decorated the casting for the Royal Ballet's first season in the rebuilt opera house. Fans who took a liking to his street smart style, his gracefully deadpan confidence and deft dancing will be grateful to see his name on the ROH guest list this year. Especially since he is dancing the repertory's most sweetly laddish hero, Colas, in Frederick Ashton's La Fille mal gardée. And even more especially since his Lise is Sarah Wildor.

They make, as Lise's mum is forced to admit, a lovely pair. Stiefel is cast in neither a heroic nor dramatic mode, being slender, fast, decisive and with an askance sense of mischief (think Carter in ER). With his clipped, efficient power he dances like an American but he pays lots of willing attention to the English details of the choreography - the witty flourishes of the head and the largesse of the arms - and he is flirtatiously alert to everyone else on stage.

Wildor has always been lovely in Ashton roles, with a natural responsiveness to the choreographer's musical exuberance and an open, generous manner that chimes with his emotional transparency. Her Lise is as droll, pretty and vivacious as any faux 18th-century heroine ought to be but she has so much genuine fun with the role that it doesn't seem like a period piece. We laugh out loud at her jokes and believe absolutely in her physical and romantic adoration for Colas.

But, even as we're seduced by Wildor's charm, we also note the intelligence of the choices she's making as she dances, choices that, paradoxically, make it look as if she is performing the role for the first time. We note the brief challenging look she slips over her shoulder at Colas, then the second, longer, greedier gaze that tells us she cannot wait to fall into his arms. We note the tiny pause she holds before arching her back against his embrace, registering with decorous but unequivocal intent the erotic intensity of the moment.

The Saturday matinée show in which Wildor and Stiefel danced was packed with kids and while they were giggling enthusiastically at the lovers' jokes, the parents were melting in their seats.

William Tuckett, dancing Widow Simone, packs the role too full of effects to make Lise's mum as consistent a character as her daughter. Tuckett can't make up his mind whether to play a pantomime dame or a mother torn between the desire to marry her daughter off for cash or let her follow her heart. But all of his stagey business is carried off in high style and the cosy nonsense that Simone and Lise enjoy together alone is infused with a powerful bond between mother and daughter. It's clear that all of Lise's larky high spirits have been handed down through her genes.

 Until March 10. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

webTitle: Work: The networker

fields.headline: The networker
fields.trailText: Timesheet | Pay check | On the radar | Debunker
fields.body:
Timesheet

The museum security guard

George Milan is gallery warder supervisor at the British Museum

4:30am Gets up. Eats doughnut for breakfast.

5:45 Walks to Eastbourne station.

6:20 Catches train to London Victoria.

8:50 Arrives at work. Changes into "corporate wear".

9:16 Goes to admin block. Works out how many galleries to open today (there aren't enough staff to open them all). Decides to shut the architectural basement.

9:22 Cup of tea. White, no sugar.

9:40 Signs in staff and gives team briefing. "You're like a father, a disciplinarian, a mother, a confessor, a psychiatrist. You have to wear all these different hats throughout the day."

10:00 Doors open.

10:05 Starts making tour of museum.

11:22 "You can have really exciting days - pickpockets high on drugs running amok, 9,000 children arriving to see an exhibition that hasn't even been finished."

11:40 "If this were America there'd be armed guards. I went to St Petersburg, and in the Hermitage the guards have submachine guns. We're British, we're more understated."

12:00 Lunchtime. Brings packed lunch. "The queen of sandwiches, in my opinion, is cheese and tomato. I try not to have fishpaste." Reads book: The Monocled Mutineer.

1:30pm Elderly lady misses her footing on the stairs, falls and breaks her ankle. George applies cold dressing to reduce swelling, gets her into a wheelchair and waits for the ambulance to arrive.

1:50 Photocopies roster for next week. 3:15 "All these gentlemen's statues have their nether organs cut off. That was from when Queen Victoria visited, and they thought she'd be offended. We have drawers full of willies, but we don't know which one belongs to whom."

3:30 Meets Emily, another warder. She tells him there has been a squeaky door and she has contacted Design.

3:42 Rembrandt exhibition. George is approached by two American students. They ask for a drawing to be explained. "Well, it's Michelangelo, which is the most wonderful name to have, eh? Almost as good as Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart."

3:50 In the Japanese Room: "I love the Japanese people. The young people are so polite. The girls all bow and giggle."

3:57 "Girls, sorry to bother you, but would you mind not sitting on the steps. Old ladies seem to make a habit of falling over you and breaking their legs."

4:00 The Great Court is busy. "The whole world is here."

5:30 Packs up. Hangs up all of the keys.

5:45 Leaves museum.

Pay check

What you can do for £20,000

 Local-authority youth worker, Stoke-on-Trent

 Director's PA, Hammersmith hospital, London

 Red Cross emblem usage enforcer, London

 Girl Guide centre manager, Mexico

 Paint pigmentation technician, Northern Ireland

 Pro-vice-chancellor, University of Hertfordshire, Hatfield

On the radar

The new clubs

If the Pall Mall gentleman's club is a dying breed, its spirit is undergoing a rejuvenation. At Baby, a members' club for the net generation in a converted Amsterdam church, dance music and net-connected workstations have replaced the red leather, but the principle - for the 5,500 members paying £200 to join - is the same: the real business of business is done far from the office. Founder Rene Eller says: "There aren't very many modern clubs for people who care passionately about their work." So this is new-economy heaven: 5,000 computer enthusiasts listening to Dario G in a big room. Marvellous.

Debunker

Swimming with sharks

Succeeding at work, according to Harvey Mackay's book Swim With The Sharks Without Being Eaten Alive - now in a new edition - is all about adopting the same technique a diver uses to avoid predatory great whites: at all times, show your strength. "As long as you can prove to them you're tougher than they are," Mackay writes, you'll beat the sharks - "which is how the big fish got that way - and how you can be one too".

Ever alert to the perils of flagrant metaphor-abuse, Debunker called on the services of George Burgess, an expert on shark attacks at the University of Florida. And - how to put this? - something smells fishy.

"You must never harass a shark if you see one," says Burgess. No sane diver would deliberately invade a shark's territory, or indulge in displays of overt aggression: both are a surefire route to bloodstained seawater. Standing out from the crowd is a disastrous idea, too. "You should always stay in groups - sharks are much more likely to attack a solitary individual."

As for Mackay's conclusion that "You don't need to learn to swim with the sharks on your very first outing" - well, you do, actually. "Attacks," the university's shark attack guidelines note, "are usually quite severe, frequently resulting in death." Best to stick to being plankton, on balance.

webTitle: Classical review: Anderson premiere

fields.headline: Anderson premiere
fields.standfirst:
Imperial College
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Imperial College
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Though he has just become the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra's third composer-in-association, Julian Anderson has also been in residence with Sinfonia 21 since 1997. Their latest joint venture is part of a wider collaboration; the 14-minute The Bird Sings with its Fingers, which Anderson describes as four "choreographic sketches", is both an orchestral work and a ballet.

The Mark Baldwin Dance Company will introduce the stage version in High Wycombe tomorrow; Sinfonia 21 and the conductor Martyn Brabbins presented the concert premiere in Imperial College's Great Hall last Friday.

The inspiration was Jean Cocteau's film Orphée; a series of mysterious phrases announced on a car radio punctuate the narrative and Anderson has taken four of those seraphic messages as the titles of his four movements.

But each movement makes perfect sense without any knowledge of its provenance; Anderson's deftness and vivid aural imagination make sure of that. The first movement, The World Illuminated by a Single Glass of Water, for instance, uses just one melody, heard three times in ever lower registers and differently coloured and harmonised as it descends.

Everything is gorgeously coloured, every melody has elegance and purpose. Anderson has produced a beautifully proportioned, attractive piece that puts a chamber orchestra expertly through its paces; Sinfonia 21's performance was immensely accomplished and now the dance takes over.

 The Mark Baldwin Dance Company gives the stage premiere of The Bird Sings with its Fingers at the Wycombe Swan (01494 512000) tomorrow.

webTitle: Am I the next target?

fields.headline: Am I the next target?
fields.trailText: 13 February: My company are making it harder and harder for my sales team to make target. It's as if they want us to fail so they can push us out the back door.
fields.body:
The problem

I have worked for my company for nearly three years. It is expanding very fast and the structure is changing all the time. The problem is my team are target based and the company seem to be doing everything in its power to make it harder for us to make target.

They have now told us that if we don't make target then it is a disciplinary matter and they are advertising for direct sales teams to do the job we are doing already. It's as if they want us to fail so they can push us out the back door.

The solution

You might have a case for constructive dismissal (if you left voluntarily), but you would need to seek advice either from your union if you are a member, or from ACAS (number in your local phone book). It could be that the nature of the job has changed, and thus what management are doing is not unreasonable. For example, it sounds like they are reducing the effort involved in bringing leads into the company, probably to reduce costs. This means that the sales team are having to cold sell which is obviously the way this company sees its future developing. They could argue that they are trying to see which existing members of the sales team can adapt to cold selling and thus have a future in the company. As long as they are treating everyone the same - not giving some teams leads and not others - they may not be acting unfairly.

However, it does also depend on what your contract states regarding leads, so you will have to take further advice to see if your employer is in breach of your contract of employment.


 Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

webTitle: Pop review: PJ Harvey

fields.headline: The unspeakably provocative PJ Harvey
fields.standfirst:
Shepherds Bush Empire
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Shepherds Bush Empire
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
PJ Harvey stalks on stage, alone, guitar already slung over her shoulder, red sparkly dress glittering underneath. She plays the first severe chords of Rid of Me, smiling demurely from under her harsh black fringe at the packed Shepherds Bush Empire, then moves to the microphone and sings the first line: "Tie yourself to me..."

It's a song of degradation, of refusing to be dumped, and yet singing it, Harvey radiates only power. We could be on a rollercoaster, such is the adrenaline rush her performance induces. She ends the song yelling the chilling demand, "Lick my legs, I'm on fire" over the audience's cheers. It's one of those life-affirming moments to remind you why live music is unbeatably thrilling.

If the rest of the show doesn't quite live up to its incredible beginning, it's down to one thing only: Polly keeps putting down her guitar. It's not that her other two guitarists are inadequate - their sound is fearsome, cavernous, graceful - or that her jittery dancing isn't enjoyable to watch. It's just that she looks so sexy with a guitar, projects such confidence. When she stamps a twinkling foot in strappy four-inch heels on her effects pedal, it's unspeakably provocative. When she stands centre stage in the classic rock pose, shoulders back, pelvis thrust forward, lovingly wrenching those six strings, she challenges you to count her the equal of all those male axe heroes.

Of course, Harvey is playing up to stereotypes even as she demolishes them. She knows, for instance, that the men in the audience aren't quite as riveted by the pink cowboy hat, leopard-print platform shoes and furious playing of her band's second guitarist, Laika's Margaret Fiedler. But at least when Harvey plays, she becomes singularly inspiring. When she dances, she is more ordinary, more like other female singers, looking good for the boys.

These are thoughts to fill you with guilt, because Harvey looks so content, happy not to be shackled by her guitar, to be able to do little cha-cha-cha moves with her feet and twirl her arms. Particularly on the more visceral tracks from last year's album Songs from the City, Songs from the Sea, she prefers to be the calm centre of her music's maelstrom, nonchalant with a pair of maracas.

Big Exit and Kamikaze, enormous on record, here grow bigger still, detonating rhythms, churning out energy. When Fiedler's effects pedals momentarily stop working you realise how pristine the sound is. For these songs Harvey makes her voice sound metallic, rusty and scratchy; elsewhere, what you appreciate is the clarity of her voice, its beauty. She sings This Mess We're In and it's earthy, seductive, quite unlike Thom Yorke's eerie wails on record. There are hints of Patti Smith, but they don't detract from Harvey's own strength.

Despite the misgivings, it's a superb show, one to make you leave the venue feeling inches taller. Harvey is one of the most compelling songwriters around, and her set, spanning her career from 1992's Sheela-na-gig to the present, shows she's only getting better.

 At the Shepherds Bush Empire, London W12 (020-7771 2000), tonight.
